HEADLINE: A Setback For Albany: Agency Cuts Credit Rating

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 6

 BODY:
Three weeks after the Legislature adopted a budget that political leaders insisted was sound, a major credit agency, Moody's Investors Services, dealt the state a stinging setback today, lowering its long-term credit rating one notch.
The action comes two and half months after another major rating agency, Standard & Poor's, dropped the rating two notches. Both agencies now give New York roughly equivalent ratings. They are the lowest in the state's history and the third-lowest in the nation. Only Massachusetts and Louisiana have lower ratings. 
Moody's downgrading raises fresh questions about the solidity of the state's finances. The state has been in financial turmoil for so long that the new rating is not expected to have much effect on borrowing costs or marketing bonds. The state already has to pay more to borrow money than most other states because it is considered a poorer credit risk.
 
Holding Off Judgment
Moody's announced that it was lowering the rating late in the day, after the financial markets had closed. The agency dropped the rating, from A1, the fourth highest, to A, fifth highest.
Throughout the weeks of wrangling that resulted in the latest budget in state history last month, Moody's declined to act on the rating, saying that it wanted to review a completed financial plan before passing judgment.
Standard & Poor's, in contrast, early on lost faith in the ability of state leaders to produce a balanced budget and reduced the rating even before the April 1 budget deadline. Today, Standard & Poor's reaffirmed the rating it gave in March, an A, its sixth highest. The agency is not expected to re-evaluate the rating for at least several months.
In announcing its revision, Moody's noted that although the budget enacted last month appears balanced, it relied on many new taxes whose revenues ''have proven difficult to predict.'' The agency said an economic slowdown that was evident throughout the region was ''particularly apparent in New York, where employment growth has been static, and wage and personal-income growth has slipped,'' raising additional risks.
Although the state deficit last year ''was due to inaccurate estimates of the effects of tax reform,'' Moody's said, ''the revenue shortfall in fiscal 1990 was more fundamental, as it was due principally to economic weakness.''
The agency also pointed to an increasing reliance on one-shot revenues like reserve funds and debt refinancings as a weakness in the state's financial plan. ''Many of the one-time actions are questionable,'' the agency said in a statement, and only result in putting off debt-service payments.
The managing director of state ratings for Moody's, George Leung, said the downgrading was not ''that major,'' but rather represented ''an adjustment.'' He noted that Moody's has not rated New York as particularly creditworthy since 1975, when it reduced the rating from Aa to A1.
State Budget Director Dall W. Forsythe played down the significance of the lower rating, saying it was not unexpected. Repeating the Cuomo administration's refrain that New York's economic problems are part of a regional trend, Mr. Forsythe said, ''other state have been downgraded, and likely more will be.''
State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, who approved the budget last week, stressed that Moody's had not called the budget out of balance. ''There is no doubt, though,'' he said, ''that the existence of a serious structural deficit and gloomy outlook for next year have caused the low long-term ratings.''
 
Estimates of Falling Revenues
The bad news today about the budget is in keeping with the tenor of the financial news that has been emanating from here for two years. Every few months, the administration has announced that revenues are falling short of expectations and that the state will have to borrow additional money.
In budget talks this year, the administration's estimates of revenue fell almost $2 billion over four months. By the time the $50 billion budget was adopted last mnth, seven weeks late, it called for the largest tax increase in state history.
Moody's lowered the credit rating one day before the state's planned sale of $4.1 billion of short-term notes for its annual spring borrowing. The spring borrowing, which has enabled the state to carry a long-term deficit of almost $5 billion, is scheduled to be phased out over the next few years under an agreement reached by state leaders last month.
Besides lowering the rating on the long-term bonds, Moody's also reduced the rating on the short-term notes, from MIG-1, the highest available, to MIG-2, the second highest. The agency had provisionally reduced the short-term rating three months ago.

HEADLINE: THE 1990 ELECTIONS;
Bradley Wins New Jersey Primary

 BODY:
Senator Bill Bradley, who won an easy victory in the New Jersey Democratic primary in his bid for a third term, will face a little-known Republican candidate, Christine Todd Whitman, in the November general election.
Mr. Bradley defeated Daniel Seyler, 35, an unemployed marketing manager, to face Ms. Whitman, 43, a former president of the State Board of Public Utilities, who ran unopposed.
Ms. Whitman, a member of one of New Jersey's most prominent Republican families, is seen as having little chance against the popular Senator. But Republicans recruited her with hopes she could diminish his aura as a Presidential contender. 
Other major races were in the First Congressional District, which was served by Jim Florio for 16 years before he became governor, and the 12th Congressional District seat being vacated after 12 years by Representative James Courter, the Republican who opposed Mr. Florio last year.
In the 12th District, State Senator Richard A. Zimmer, 45, won the Republican nomination for Mr. Courter's congressional seat in an upset, defeating Phil McConkey, 33, a former receiver of the Giants football team, who finished a strong second in his campaign, and Assemblyman Rodney P. Frelinghuysen, 44, who had been the favorite. Joseph F. Shanahan, 76, was fourth. Mr. Zimmer will face the Democratic primary winner, Marguerite Chandler, 46, a businesswoman, who defeated James J. Cleary, a supporter of Lyndon H. LaRouche, the political extremist now jailed on fraud charges.
In the First District, the Camden County Freeholder Director, Robert E. Andrews, won the Democratic nomination over Linda Bowker, 41, the head of the New Jersey chapter of the National Organization for Women; John A. Dramesi, 51, a retired Air Force colonel, and Joel S. Farley, 35, a lawyer.
Mr. Andrews will face a Gloucester County Freeholder, Daniel Mangini, 56, who ran unopposed.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Donald J. Trump is relying on his three casinos to provide the cash he needs to keep his sprawling empire going. But making a success of his once-lucrative gaming houses in an increasingly difficult market will require management skills that Mr. Trump has yet to demonstrate. [Page A1.] 
 
Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores are expected to report narrower losses for the fiscal first quarter, a sign that the companies, which have filed for bankruptcy, are improving faster than anticipated. [D1.]
 
The creditors of Drexel Burnham Lambert voiced skepticism about the firm's reorganization plan, questioning whether Drexel management should supervise the liquidation. [D1.]
 
Businessland has formed a joint venture with several Japanese companies to sell personal computers and workstations in Japan. The venture will be called the Businessland Japan Company. [D4.]
 
Shearson Lehman Hutton overhauled its operations, reviving a respected investment banking name as part of its bid to rebound from record losses on Wall Street. [D4.]
 
NBC said it expects a $200 million shortfall in advertising revenue while acknowledging that it had lost ground competitively and economically over the last year. [D19.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
The Japanese Government has chosen American technology as a nationwide technical standard for the next generation of cellular telephones. The decision may make it a little easier for American cellular equipment companies to compete in Japan. [D1.]
 
American business leaders warn that a series of obstacles still prevents them from investing in a big way in the Soviet Union. [D1.]
 
THE ECONOMY
 
California voters approved higher gasoline taxes, a looser limit on state spending and more than $4 billion in bonds. [A1.]
 
Three top Federal regulators said there had been a slowdown in bank lending but no credit squeeze. [D8.]
 
The mortgage insurance program for single-family homes is losing about $350 million a year and could be insolvent by the end of the decade without immediate aid, the secretary of Housing and Urban Development said. [A21.]
 
MARKETS
 
Stock prices continued falling for the second straight day, with the Dow dropping 13.35 points, to close at 2,911.65. [D10.]
 
Treasury note and bond prices were narrowly mixed in very slow trading. [D16.]
 
Moody's lowered New York State's long-term credit rating by one notch, to A1, from A, the lowest in the state's history. [B1.]
 
Yields fell on taxable and tax-exempt money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report. [D9.]
 
Prices of energy futures finished higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange, rebounding from early losses. [D17.]
 
The dollar gained against most currencies except the Canadian dollar in sluggish domestic trading. [D17.]
 
TODAY'S COLUMNS
 
From the time the Japanese market for stock warrants broke to the surface about three years ago, it was embraced by the securities industry. But Japanese officials now say many individual investors are being overcharged. Market Place. [D1.]
 
Several California savings and loan associations are trying to sell their properties to comply with new Government regulations. Talking Deals. [D2.]
 
Paying ad agencies based on how well the products they advertise perform in the market is ''an idea whose time has come,'' a study said. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [D19.]

HEADLINE: Business Wary of Gorbachev Pitch

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, June 6

 BODY:
Although American business leaders were heartened by Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speeches in the last week on economic reform in the Soviet Union, they warn that a series of obstacles still prevents them from investing in a big way in that country.
They expect that it will be years before American involvement in the Soviet economy is substantial. ''It will probably take a decade unless you have a revolution there,'' said William Farley, chairman and chief executive of Fruit of the Loom Inc., the clothing manufacturer.
John Hinds, president of the international division of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said: ''There is an opportunity that did not even exist a few months ago. But there are many impediments to success in the Soviet market.'' 
In speeches on Sunday in Minneapolis and again on Monday in San Francisco, Mr. Gorbachev gave what might be called ''we're-open-for-business'' speeches to some of the most prominent American industrialists and farm leaders.
He said the Soviets were considering making the ruble convertible into Western currencies and were examining ways to allow increased foreign ownership of Soviet enterprises. Mr. Gorbachev also provided a checklist of business sectors in which he said the Soviets would seek American involvement, including telecommunications, computers, farm technology and transportation.
American executives were perhaps most impressed by what they considered to be Mr. Gorbachev's high economic I.Q. The Soviet leader, they said, talked knowledgeably about such topics as repatriation of corporate profits, joint ventures and the establishment of securities exchanges.
''Here was a guy who didn't refer to his notes much,'' said Robert L. Joss, a vice chairman of the Wells Fargo Bank. ''He was throwing off complex concepts in a logical, coherent way. I've seen Presidents need more economic briefing.''
Some American executives say they had already heard what the Soviet President had to say. It was ''mainly a reaffirmation of things we already knew,'' said Allen F. Jacobson, the chairman and chief executive of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, the adhesives maker.
But even Mr. Jacobson acknowledged that Mr. Gorbachev's speeches in this country were significant, if only because of the enthusiasm and apparent sincerity with which he talked of converting his country's military factories into plants for producing consumer goods and his willingness to discuss difficulties like food shortages that economic liberalization is causing.
But the consensus in the American business community is that large impediments remain to investing in the Soviet Union. Leading the list is the conversion of the ruble into ''hard'' currencies.
 
Getting the Profits Out
''Why would you want to do business there?'' Mr. Farley asked. ''One reason, certainly, is not only to make a dollar but also to get that profit out. Presently, that is not possible.'' Other executives expressed concern over the Soviets' lack of services for business.
''Basic services that business people need - telephones, hotels, and airline service - are still very poor,'' said John Sculley, chairman and chief executive of Apple Computer Inc. ''Without telephones and fax machines, we can't do business.''
Still others said it was critical that the Soviets loosen rules on market research and foreign management of business enterprises. ''We'd have to be assured of the acceptance of our product,'' said Richard L. Knowlton, chairman and chief executive of Geo. A. Hormel & Company, the meat processor. ''But we wouldn't mind being 50-50 partners if we could control the manufacturing.''
Clearly, one impediment to increased American investment in the Soviet Union is the export approvals that continue to be needed on many American products. The Control Data Corporation, for instance, has been waiting for months to receive permission to send the Soviets six of its Cyber large-scale computers that were ordered last summer.
Notwithstanding these hurdles, Mr. Gorbachev appears eager to elevate the American participation in the Soviet economy from its current modest level. Levi Strauss & Company, for instance, which sells its blue jeans around the world, has only one operation in the Soviet Union - a state-owned hard-currency shop that it considers very successful.

HEADLINE: Bank Lending Said to Slow; No Credit Squeeze Is Seen

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 6

 BODY:
Three top Federal regulators said today that there had been a slowdown in bank lending but no credit squeeze. And they said that any slowdown should not be attributed to excessively harsh treatment of banks by examiners.
At a hearing of the House Small Business Committee, the three regulators - John P. LaWare, a Federal Reserve governor; Paul G. Fritts, a director at the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, and Robert L. Clarke, the Comptroller of the Currency - said the pain felt by small businesses and real estate developers who have been turned down for loans was a price to be paid for maintaining the banking industry's financial health.
''The economy's credit needs are being met,'' said Mr. LaWare, who was previously head of a large New England bank. In the text of his comments, he said that ''tightening of credit standards that has occurred so far is appropriate'' to the Fed's economic policy goals. 
 
Pleased With Economy
Several Fed officials have said recently that they are generally pleased with the economy, which grew at a sluggish 1.3 percent rate in the first quarter, after inflation. Officials at the central bank have said they seek economic growth of 1.5 to 2 percent.
The Fed has held monetary policy and short-term rates stable for nearly six months. With the economy settling in to sluggish growth of less than 2 percent, which economists hope will keep a lid on inflation, many analysts do not expect a quick change in Fed policy.
Several times during the hearing the regulators described how they were trying to balance the need of a growing economy for bank loans with their responsibility to supervise banks tightly enough to prevent a situation like the savings and loan crisis. Despite a cascade of anecdotal reports from developers and small businesses that have been denied credit in recent months, the regulators concluded that there was no threat to the economy great enough to justify a return to the more relaxed lending standards of the 1980's.
 
Concern About 'Another Disaster'
Representative Jan Meyers, Republican of Kansas, noted that the rising cost to taxpayers of the savings bailout was a reminder of the need for a ''regulatory system that will prevent another disaster.''
The regulators repeated the advice they gave at a special meeting with bankers a month ago: Do not stop lending or taking risks. But the regulators also said that the weakening of real estate markets and the economy in regions like New England would require that they continue to pay special attention to bank lending in those areas.
In New England, where bank losses from bad real estate loans have been greatest and borrowers' complaints about lack of credit the loudest, Mr. Fritts said the drop in bank lending was a ''normal response'' to overbuilt markets and a slumping economy. He noted that a special hotline created by the Governor of Massachusetts, Michael S. Dukakis, attracted 200 calls, which he said was a small number considering the size of the state.
Mr. Clarke, the Comptroller, whose office is an arm of the Treasury that regulates nationally chartered banks, noted that the shift to more stringent lending standards did not suddenly appear in the last six months. He said that many bankers who became more cautious two or more years ago have survived examinations without making major losses or large increases in their reserves for loan losses. ''This is not Sherman's march,'' Mr. Clarke said.
Examiners of the Comptroller's office are not making special ''targeted'' examinations of small-business loans as they are for real estate loans, Mr. Clarke said. But he noted that when a regional economy turns weaker and real estate values fall, it may ''also make a bank less willing to lend to all customers, including small business.''
Mr. Clark added that his office had identified many regions and kinds of lending where some banks face greater than normal risks and perhaps should become more cautious. He urged that banks ''pay more attention to the environment where they operate'' but declined to say which regions or which types of lending face the greatest risks.
Representative John J. LaFalce, Democrat of upstate New York, said he did not want to ''infringe on appropriate examination and regulation'' but told the regulators that they should do more to encourage bankers to work with troubled borrowers rather than abruptly withdraw loans.

HEADLINE: Stocks Continue Down As Dow Retreats 13.35

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
Stock prices continued falling yesterday, for the second straight day, with the Dow Jones industrial average dropping 13.35 points to close at 2,911.65.
Selling by some investors after the big run-up that peaked on Monday with the Dow at a record 2,935.19 was again cited by traders as a reason for pressure on the blue chips. ''The market came so far and so fast that it was natural for people to want to take some profits,'' said Dennis E. Jarrett, market analyst at Kidder, Peabody. ''The fact that there was no heavy selling bodes well for the next few months.'' 
 
Volume Slips to 164 Million
Volume slipped to 164 million shares, from 199.7 million on Tuesday. Some 872 issues declined and 656 advanced.
The market was also down as measured by the broader S.&P. 500 index, which closed off 1.68, to 364.96.
Along with the selling, skepticism grew on the economy. An article in The Wall Street Journal yesterday said that the Federal Reserve was unlikely to allow short-term interest rates to fall anytime soon, despite a slowing economy.
A money manager, Robert G. Freedman, said that there were still ''a lot of skeptics and a lot of cash'' staying out of the market. Mr. Freedman, chief equity investment officer for John Hancock mutual funds, is not among the skeptics, however.
''I think the market is still going higher,'' he said, ''and it will easily get to 3,000.''
A cloud shaded the market before noon as traders reacted to news reports of a mysterious cloud over the Barents Sea in the Soviet Union. The Dow dropped almost 20 points before new reports said the cloud was not radioactive. ''Once that seemed not to have developed into some full-blown problem, the market stabilized,'' Mr. Jarrett said.
Among the most active stocks, Union Carbide gained 1, to 21; Philip Morris added 3/8, to 44 1/2, and Eastman Kodak rose 1 7/8, to 41 7/8.
Kodak, rumored to have attracted possible bidders for its Sterling Drug unit, declined comment on the jump in its stock.
Oil issues sagged on reports that Saudi Arabia is taking steps that would continue downward pressure on oil prices. Texaco dropped 1 1/2, to 57 7/8, and Atlantic Richfield, 2, to 116 1/4. But airlines, which had surged Tuesday on indications that fuel costs could decline, edged up yesterday. AMR the parent of American Airlines added 1/8 to 69; Delta Air Lines, 1/8, to 80 1/8, and Pan Am 1/8 to 2 1/2.
Some retail issues were lower on expectations of weaker May sales reports. The Limited lost 1, to 49 1/4. May Department Stores fell 1 3/8, to 56 1/8, and the Gap dropped 7/8, to 62 7/8.
 
Campbell Issue Downgraded
Campbell Soup lost 3 1/8, to 56 7/8. A Prudential-Bache analyst, John McMillin, downgraded the issue to a hold from a buy. He said an annnouncement by three of the company's holders that they would pool their 17.4 percent stake into a trust meant that a deal to buy the company was not likely for some time.
Upjohn, which has long been rumored as a potential merger partner with an overseas pharmaceutical company, declined comment on activity in its stock. The issue was up 2 3/8 on Tuesday but dropped back 1 1/4 yesterday.
NCH, a specialty chemicals maker, lost 4 1/2, to 58 3/4, on second-quarter earnings disappointing to analysts.
Tyco Toys, which gained last week on prospects of a sale of the company, fell 4 3/4, to 22 3/4, in over-the-counter trading, after it said the talks had been terminated and no new suitor was being actively sought.
The Amex market value index closed up 0.36, to 364.19, and the Nasdaq composite gained 0.35, to 464.96.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Notes and Bonds Narrowly Mixed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed in very slow trading yesterday, as dealers sifted through, and ultimately shrugged off, a series of potentially negative developments.
Among the events the market participants chose to ignore were a rise in oil prices and a newspaper report that the Federal Reserve Board is not about to ease monetary policy.
The report, which quoted some Fed governors by name and others anonymously, appeared in The Wall Street Journal.
Although he was not quoted in the article, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, seemed to add some credibility yesterday to the notion that the Fed will maintain its current policy stance. 
Without commenting directly on the Fed's intentions, after a speech in San Francisco Mr. Greenspan said that despite three straight months of weak employment data he saw no signs of an ''underlying deterioration'' in the economy.
''The fact that the market absorbed a lot of bad news is moderately constructive,'' said James R. Capra, a senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Government Securities. ''But until we get more data next week I would be surprised to see interest rates move up or down by more than five basis points.''
William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds, said that ''ordinarily, the market might have viewed Mr. Greenspan's remarks as a mild negative,'' adding, ''But after the decline in prices on Tuesday there is a bid for paper at these somewhat lower levels.''
 
Short-Term Notes Fall Slightly
Perhaps in deference to the notion that the Fed is not about to ease policy shortly, prices of shorter-term Treasury notes dipped modestly. But long-term note and bond issues posted small gains.
Because of their shorter maturity, notes and bills are more sensitive to shifts in the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market than longer-term securities.
In the secondary market for Treasury notes, the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at a price of 100 10/32 late yesterday, down 1/32, to yield 8.41 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent two-year notes were unchanged at 100 10/32, to yield 8.32 percent.
Among longer-term securities, the 8 3/4 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at 103 14/32, up 5/32, to yield 8.43 percent. Late Tuesday the benchmark issue was offered at a price to yield 8.44 percent.
Treasury bill rates were little changed on the day.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.68 percent, down one basis point, or hundredth of a point. Six-month bills were unchanged at an offered rate of 7.59 percent. And one-year bills were offered at 7.49 percent, also unchanged on the day.
Activity in the corporate bond market was highlighted by a two-part offering of $600 million worth of credit sensitive notes from the Georgia-Pacific Corporation.
The first $300 million of the issue are seven-year notes that mature June 15, 1997. The securities are noncallable for life.
The 10 percent notes were priced at $100, 1.50 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent seven-year notes at the time of pricing.
The rest of the issue consists of $300 million of 12-year notes due June 15, 2002.
These securities, which are also noncallable for life, carry a 10.10 percent coupon and were priced at $99.937, to yield 10.109 percent, 1.65 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes.
Bear, Stearns & Company acted as lead manager for the underwriting. Both sections are rated Baa-3 by Moody's Investors Service and BB-plus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
Secondary Market Activity
Activity in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds was light, traders said. Prices of most widely quoted issues were unchanged on the day.
Trading was also fairly quiet in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds. Participants said that prices of most actively traded issues dipped by about 1/8 point.
Today's activity will be highlighted by New York State's delayed sale of $4.1 billion worth of short-term tax and revenue and anticipation notes.
The offering had to be postponed because of protracted negotiations in Albany over ways to address the state's 1991 budget gap. As a result of those talks, the budget was not formulated until May 23, 53 days into New York State's fiscal year.
In advance of the sale, Moody's and Standard & Poor's assigned their highest short-term ratings to the notes. The securities, which will be sold through Shearson Lehman Brothers, mature March 28, 1991.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Light Trading As Gold Prices Are Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday against all primary currencies except the Canadian dollar in sluggish domestic trading marked by various international considerations.
Gold prices posted moderate declines in the United States after moving slightly higher abroad.
Foreign-exchange dealers said trading volume was light. Various concerns depressed the Swiss franc and West German mark, steering investors to the dollar, they said. 
Confirmation that Switzerland is seeking to join the International Monetary Fund and speculation about possible declines in interest rates there encouraged selling of the franc, said Richard Levine of Merrill Lynch Futures.
The mark came under renewed pressure amid reports of a potential strike by thousands of workers in East Germany. Unconfirmed rumors of a possible accident at a Soviet nuclear power plant - stemming from reports that Finnish authorities were checking a large cloud drifting toward their country - also weakened the currency.
But Mr. Levine said the nuclear accident rumor did not have an effect on currency trading over all.
The dollar began higher in Tokyo, rising by 0.17 Japanese yen to close at 152.60 yen. Later, in London trading, it was quoted at 152.45 yen. By the time trading finished in New York, the dollar was quoted at 152.68 yen, up from 152.35 yen late on Tuesday.
The pound was quoted at $1.6880, compared with $1.6820 late on Tuesday. Sterling weakened in later United States trading, dipping to $1.6875 late in New York, from $1.6880 late on Tuesday.
Selected late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late Tuesday, included: 1.6885 West German marks, up from 1.6840; 1.4365 Swiss francs, up from 1.4280; 5.6905 French francs, up from 5.6785; 1,242.00 Italian lire, up from 1,240.00, and 1.16975 Canadian dollars, down from 1.17605 Canadian.
The Canadian dollar's strength was tied to various political developments. Talk had arisen in the market that a rift between the Maritime Provinces and the rest of the country was not as serious as had been thought.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold prices finished lower. Gold bullion for June delivery settled at $357.40 an ounce, down by $2.40 from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted an ounce of gold at $356.75 late yesterday, $2.25 lower than Tuesday's late bid.
In London, gold bullion traded late yesterday at a bid of $359.50 an ounce, up 25 cents from late on Tuesday. In Zurich, the bid was $358.60 an ounce, unchanged from late Tuesday.

HEADLINE: White House Panel Says U.S. Can Fight Pollution and Grow

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 6

 BODY:
The White House's Council on Environmental Quality says the progress of the last two decades shows that the nation can have both economic growth and environmental quality.
Michael R. Deland, chairman of the council, said in his introduction to the council's annual report, issued Tuesday: ''Over the past two decades the presumed linkage between economic growth and environmental degradation has been broken. We know now that a growing economy and a clean environment go hand in hand.'' The council is the executive branch's environmental coordinating group. 
The acknowledgment that environmental protection and economic progress are compatible and even mutually reinforcing is a significant departure from the views of Ronald Reagan's Administration, which frequently opposed environmental regulation on the ground that it had a dampening effect on business expansion.
 
Criticism Comes Quickly
But the report of the council, which mainly praised the nation's anti-pollution efforts, was quickly criticized by environmental groups. They complained that it inadequately conveyed the urgency of the environmental problems facing the nation and the world.
''They have virtually ignored the most pressing environmental problems of the day: global warming and the depletion of the ozone layer,'' said Ruth Caplan, executive director of Environmental Action, a group formed 20 years ago to promote the first Earth Day.
''It seems to me,'' she said, ''that this is just another example of the council's failure to serve as the environmental conscience of the Administration. America needs to be challenged, not patted on the back.''
The council was created in 1970 by the National Environmental Policy Act to oversee the executive branch's environmental activities. In that same year, Congress passed the Clean Air Act and President Richard M. Nixon issued an executive order creating the Environmental Protection Agency.
Under Mr. Reagan the staff of the Council on Environmental Quality was reduced. But the council is being revived and expanded by President Bush and Mr. Deland.
''There can be little doubt that 1970 was the single most important year in this country's history,'' the council noted in its 494-page annual report.
Much of the report is devoted to describing the successes achieved by the nation in reducing pollution and protecting public health. While the report points to some ''mixed results'' in areas like protecting wetlands and coastal areas, it emphasizes improvements in the quality of the nation's air, water and soil during a period of substantial economic growth.
Noting that the population of the United States rose 22 percent over the 20-year period and that the economy grew by 75 percent, the report noted that the country had made substantial progress in reducing the pollutants singled out by the Clean Air Act.
Paul Allen, a spokesman for the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group, said the report ''has a bland quality about it that gives little indication of the seriousness of the problems we face.''
In response to a question, Mr. Deland said the report was not intended to be self-congratulatory. He said ''we have without question a long way to go'' in reducing waste, conserving energy and curbing pollution.

HEADLINE: Joseph Tomassi Jr., 67, A Specialist in Mergers

 BODY:
Joseph J. Tomassi Jr., an industrial executive and a specialist in mergers and acquisitions, died on Monday at his home in Milford, Conn., at the age of 67. His family attributed his death to heart failure. 
Mr. Tomassi was president of Corning Packaging, a subsidiary of Corning Glass, from 1958 to 1967. After serving with Canada Dry for seven years he became manager of the international division of the National Distillers Corporation from 1974 to 1977.
In 1978 he entered the mergers and acquisitions field, first in New York and then in Boston, and since 1986 he had headed his own company, North American Matrix Ltd. in Milford.
Mr. Tomassi, a graduate of Syracuse University, held a master's degree in economics from Columbia. In World War II he served with the Army Air Forces in the Mediterranean.
He is survived by four daughters, Kristen Ball of Soler, Mallorca, Spain; Merrill Delaney of London, Jacquelyn Richardson of Southport, Conn., and Lowell McHugh of Westport, Conn., and eight grandchildren.

HEADLINE: G.M. AND MOSCOW IN $1 BILLION PACT

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 7

 BODY:
In a move that could foreshadow closer ties between the Soviet Union and American companies, the General Motors Corporation signed a $1 billion agreement in the Soviet Union today to sell auto parts to the largest Soviet car maker.
Aside from the size of the five-year contract, the deal is significant because G.M. will receive payment from the Soviets in United States dollars. It may also prove a test of whether American-style capitalism can profitably contribute to an important Communist industry that plans to raise its exports to the West.
The currency issue has stymied many foreign corporations trying to do business in the Soviet Union, because of the difficulties of obtaining payments for products or services. The Soviet ruble cannot be easily converted into dollars on international markets, the country's foreign currency reserves are not large, and the Soviet Union has few products to trade to the West other than oil, vodka, furs and caviar. 
G.M., which has been talking to Soviet automotive officials for 18 months, said it would supply fuel injectors, wiring, electronic controls and catalytic converters to the Volga Automobile Works, known as VAZ, in Togliatti, 700 miles southeast of Moscow. Shipments will start in 1992, G.M. said. The parts, for systems that make fuel burn efficiently with lower amounts of pollution, will be installed in two models of the Lada passenger car, G.M. said, so the cars can meet pending clean-air standards in the European Community. The Soviets plan to export the Ladas to Western Europe after 1992.
''Pollution respects no international boundaries; neither should the proven technology to control it,'' said William Hoglund, a G.M. executive vice president in charge of component operations.
Mr. Hoglund acknowledged that the company, the world's largest auto maker, understands it is accepting some risk in the deal because of the Soviet Union's currency problems. Moreover, the volume of G.M. sales to VAZ will ultimately depend on how well the Lada is received by European consumers.
Current versions of the economy car have had limited success in foreign markets, including some Western European countries and Canada. The Lada is heavily based on the 20-year-old design of the Fiat 124, and its chief appeal to Western consumers is its low price. The Lada sells for about $10,000 in Britain, where cars tend to cost more than in the United States.
VAZ hopes, at a minimum, to double current sales in Western Europe of about 50,000 cars a year, and perhaps reach sales of 150,000, G.M. officials said.
''If everything hangs together, this could be a good business opportunity for the Soviet Union,'' said David Nash, vice president of Autofacts Inc., an automotive consulting firm in Paoli, Pa.
Since the Soviet Union does not have emission standards for cars or trucks, it has not developed pollution-control equipment for vehicles. And few, if any, Soviet-built vehicles today have fuel injection or other advanced engine technologies that are commonplace in the West.
Versions of the Lada exported to Canada, which has pollution standards similar to those of the United States, are able to meet those standards only after they are fitted with additional pollution-control devices.
In reaching the agreement, G.M. won out over two West German companies, the Robert Bosch Corporation and Siemens A.G., which were also negotiating with VAZ. G.M. will manufacture the parts at several factories, including those in Melbourne, Australia; Southampton, England; Coopersville, Mich.; Rochester, and Milwaukee.
To surmount the obstacles posed by the Soviet currency situation, some American companies doing business in the Soviet Union agree to accept barter goods, rather than currency, for their earnings.
 
Pinched for Hard Currency
In recent months the Soviet Union said that it was pinched for hard currencies - those that can be freely converted in the foreign-exchange markets - and had deposited gold in banks abroad to reassure foreign companies that they would be repaid.
''To sign an agreement of this size with G.M. for $1 billion in convertible currency rather than some other form of compensation, and not in the context of a joint venture, is remarkable,'' said Morris Bornstein, a professor at the University of Michigan who specializes in Soviet economics. ''It's safe to say this is a sizable deal given the current circumstances of their economy.''
Mr. Hoglund declined to answer questions about the details of G.M.'s contract, saying he did not know the exact terms of the contract because of poor communications with G.M. negotiators who had been meeting with VAZ officials in Togliatti, U.S.S.R. A G.M. spokesman noted that Togliatti has only two international telephone lines, service is slow, reception is spotty and there are no fax machines.
 
Hurdles for Foreigners
Poor communication has been frequently cited as a hurdle to foreign business in the Soviet Union. But G.M. is studying the possibility of setting up its own satellite dish and communications network in Togliatti, through its Electronic Data Systems and GM Hughes Electronics subsidiairies, that would bypass the Soviet telephone system, said Jan Tannehill, general manager of G.M.'s AC Rochester division.
Mr. Tannehill said G.M. had proposed the idea, which is unprecedented and extraordinary in terms of past cold war tensions, and ''the Soviets are thinking about it.''
Mr. Tannehill said G.M. and Volga were also discussing a joint venture that would allow the Soviet company to produce its own catalytic converters eventually. He said an agreement was possible within a year. In the meantime, G.M. must train Russian engineers and assembly workers in advanced technologies relating to so-called ''engine management systems,'' which are sophisticated electronic and mechanical controls that reduce emissions and improve fuel efficiency.
''The Russians tell us they want advanced technology,'' Mr. Tannehill said. ''They're not afraid of it. They know they're going to need it if they want to compete.''
 
Gorbachev's Encouragement
During his recent visit to this country, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev several times encouraged American businesses to come to his country, notwithstanding the fact that American executives have reported numerous impediments when trying to negotiate agreements.
G.M. officials said the Russian executives of VAZ proved to be tough negotiators. Since November they had been close to signing an agreement twice, only to see their efforts fizzle. Through it all, ''they kept emphasizing how much like us they are,'' Mr. Tannehill said. ''They would say how their cultures are mixed like ours, how they are world leaders as we are.''
Early last year, the Ford Motor Company withdrew from a United States trade consortium with the Soviet Union because it did not receive what it said were sufficient financial guarantees to justify a $1 billion investment in an auto plant in Gorky. Specifically, Ford officials had said they were worried because the Soviets would not guarantee to repay their investment in hard currency.

HEADLINE: COMPUTER PROJECT WOULD SPEED DATA

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
A group of private companies, universities, research laboratories and Government agencies is planning to develop an advanced computer network in which data would be transmitted at speeds 700 times faster than possible now. The plan is to be announced today by the National Science Foundation. It would be the first comprehensive effort in the United States to advance the technologically critical area of computer networks and is being called an important model for cooperation between business and government.
The widespread support for the computer-network project stands in sharp contrast to the reception received by other recent cooperative projects in high technology, such as the effort to finance research in high-definition television and the joint venture, known as U.S. Memories, that was intended to strengthen the United States in the semiconductor business. Those projects have foundered for lack of money or enthusiasm among Government and business. 
In Japan, the Government and large corporations have already begun work on high-speed computer networks, known as data highways, that enable the transmission of the equivalent of about 160 hefty novels every second, compared with only about one novel every four seconds in even the fastest networks today.
By conveying so much data so quickly, using the same optical-fiber cables now used by some long-distance telephone carriers, high-speed computer networks hold the promise of many new scientific and commercial uses that could be available by the middle of this decade. These include the ability to transmit to and receive data from a hybrid of television and computer. The new device would have a picture and sound of movie-like quality and the capacity to allow the viewer to manipulate the images and data displayed on the screen and instantaneously exchange the information with other users.
Other potential uses that could evolve from the new project include three-dimensional medical imaging that enables doctors thousands of miles apart to analyze lifelike, high-resolution images; far more accurate understanding and prediction of weather and climate because of the ability to link the power of supercomputers around the country, and multimedia teleconferencing that would combine video images and computer data, allowing business meetings without the need to travel. $100 Million From Companies The data network is being initiated with $15 million from the National Science Foundation and from a Pentagon agency that has financed research in basic technology. But more than $100 million will come from companies, including the International Business Machines Corporation and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, during the three-year project, executives at the foundation said.
The venture ''marks an important step forward,'' said Robert B. Reich, a Havard University economist. ''There are a host of technological areas in which the United States is falling behind to which this model might be directly applicable if it means developing skills and insights in new technological areas,'' he said.
The computer-network project will draw together dozens of corporations and universities, including I.B.M., A.T.&T., the MCI Communications Corporation, the regional Bell telecommunications companies and universities including the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the University of Pennsylvania, the California Institute of Technology and the University of California at Berkeley. Government laboratories including those in Los Alamos, N.M., and Livermore, Calif., and the nation's five supercomputer centers will also participate.
 
A Pioneer's Brainchild
The project is the brainchild of Robert E. Kahn, a pioneer of the nation's first computer network experiment, called Arpanet, and David J. Farber, a computer scientist at the University of Pennsylvania. Mr. Kahn is president of the Corporation for National Research Initiatives, a computer technology research group in Reston, Va., that will receive the Government grant expected to be announced today.
Mr. Kahn was director of computer science research at the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, the Pentagon agency participating in the project. Mr. Kahn said that he would not comment on the project until it had been formally announced by the National Science Foundation.
Computer scientists said significant technical challenges remain to allow the transmission and reception of computer data at speeds above a billion bits per second, a goal of the new network.
Transmitting computer data is done in a way similar to the way mail has been sorted in post offices, said William A. Wulf, a computer scientist at the University of Virginia. Postal employees read addresses and place envelopes in particular slots.
 
Stream of Digital Signals
Similarly, computer networks break data into packets, send them as strings of digital signals and then sort them when they arrive at their destination. The problem with very high speed networks, said Dr. Wulf, is that even the fastest machines that serve as gateways between the data highway and the computers they connect are not able to keep up with the stream of 1's and 0's possible with new networks. The challenge is therefore to develop a new class of machines to serve as gateways.
The development project consists of five experimental networks.
The effort represents the first phase of a multiyear endeavor that supporters hope will ultimately create the national data highway.
Project developers said they are still uncertain about the cost of deploying a nationwide high-speed network. It is possible, they contend, that the rapidly increasing technology of long-distance optical-fiber networks may generate a surplus in capacity, permitting low-cost delivery of data and digital video services.
 
Support of Gore
''This represents a great example of how industry and government can work together to develop a key technology needed for the effective use of a national network of data super-highways soon to put in place,'' said Senator Albert Gore Jr., Democrat of Tennessee. ''It's not a huge amount of money, but it will provide a great many useful applications for the network.''

HEADLINE: Texas Researchers Develop 4 Gene-Altered Calves

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, June 6

 BODY:
A team of scientists here has produced the nation's first genetically engineered calves, a new milestone in using advanced genetic technology to alter food-producing animals.
Four calves born in the last 15 months on a farm near Marquez, Tex., 120 miles north of Houston, have genes from other species, including humans. Researchers expect the genes, inserted into fertilized eggs removed from the womb, to speed growth and make cattle leaner. The four calves are a first step in understanding how direct genetic manipulation of the chromosomes of cattle will affect meat and milk. 
In producing the genetically engineered calves, which look no different from ordinary calves, scientists in the United States have completed their goal of inserting foreign genes into the chromosomes of every important food animal. The breakthrough holds the promise of eliminating many steps in the long and costly process of cattle breeding, and also of producing superior livestock with traits that until now have existed only in theory.
There have been no striking changes in three of the first four genetically engineered cattle, but scientists say the fact that the new genetic traits became a permanent part of the chromosomes shows that an important technical boundary has been crossed.
Federal regulators said they had several concerns about how genetic transformations might affect the quality of meat and milk, and these issues are being reviewed by the Department of Agriculture. Animal welfare groups and some family farm groups have been worried as well about the new technology's potential to harm animals, the environment and smaller producers who could be forced out of business.
Gene-altered cattle have been developed in Canada and Europe, but the achievements, reported in specialized technical journals, have received little attention outside the small fraternity of scientists conducting animal reproductive research.
The procedure has been done in pigs, sheep, goats and chickens, but scientists say the genetically engineered calves represent a significant step in using the technology because cattle are much more complicated to work with and far more important economically.
Farm specialists say the technology holds vast promise for altering production practices and changing the structure of the nation's $35 billion beef industry and $20 billion dairy industry.
For instance, cattle companies could offer McDonald's beef animals specially designed to produce more meat for hamburgers. Kraft may have the opportunity to operate dairies with its own trademark breed of cows that produce milk specifically intended for producing cheese. And farmers could gain animals far more resistant to diseases and stress, making it possible to halt or sharply curtail the use of toxic drugs and dangerous antibiotics.
 
'Tremendous Implications'
''This technology has tremendous implications,'' said Dr. Caird E. Rexroad, a research physiologist at the Department of Agriculture's Beltsville Agricultural Research Station in Beltsville, Md., who produced genetically altered sheep. ''For the time being, most people are looking at improving efficiency; the amount of feed it takes to produce a pound of meat. In the future, we're looking at manipulating growth and other characteristics.''
But Dr. Michael W. Fox, a veterinarian who is vice president of the Humane Society of the United States, had another point of view. ''We have 2 billion cattle, 1.6 billion sheep and goats, and 800 million pigs in the world today,'' he said. ''That population needs to be drastically reduced because of adverse environmental impacts. This focusing on enhanced productivity might look good to investors but is the last thing the world needs.''
The genetically engineered calves were developed by a group of Texas researchers led by Dr. Bert O'Malley, a cell biologist from the Baylor College of Medicine in Houston; Dr. Robert Hammer, a research physiologist at the Howard Hughes Medical Institute in Dallas, and Dr. Ken Bondioli, a senior scientist at Granada BioSciences Inc., an affiliate of the Granada Corporation, a cattle breeding and food company in Houston.
Darold F. McCalla, president of Granada BioSciences, which financed the research, said his company had not been eager to disclose the breakthrough until now because not enough animals had been produced and Granada was concerned about the reaction of those who oppose biotechnology development.
 
The Earlier Developments
Two other research groups have said they produced genetically engineered calves before the American group. One group led by Dr. Robert Church, a medical biochemist, at the University of Calgary in Alberta, Canada, said they developed a calf in June 1986 that had a human gene that produced the protein interferon as a way to improve disease resistance. Dr. Church said in an interview from his office in Calgary that the Canadian group has reported three generations of gene-altered animals, 23 males and females in all. An East German group from the Academy of Agricultural Sciences in Dummerstorf reported the birth of a genetically engineered calf on Jan. 19, 1988.
The American research team's first transformed calf, a male, was born on March 17, 1989. The animal, now a husky 15-month-old bull, contains a human gene in its chromosomes, the estrogen receptor gene, that researchers hoped would accelerate growth by making better use of the animal's own production of the hormone estrogen.
Although tests showed that the gene was successfully inserted into the animal's cells, the calf grew no faster than other animals, said Dr. Bondioli.
Two other calves, one born on Sept. 22, 1989, and the other, born on March 30 this year, both males, have an extra cattle gene that produces a protein known as insulin-like growth factor. That protein regulates development of cattle by promoting the growth of muscle tissue. The Texas scientists theorized that adding another gene to increase the levels of insulin-like growth factor would enhance meat production in cattle. The animals are too young to determine whether the gene worked, but one black male calf is bigger than calves of the same age.
Dr. Bondioli said more calves with the insulin-like growth factor need to be produced before making conclusions.
On Dec. 17, 1989, the group gained its first genetically engineered female. This fourth calf has an extra cattle gene, the bovine growth hormone gene, that controls development and milk production.
 
Drugs vs. Genetic Manipulation
The same gene has been spliced into bacteria by four large chemical and drug companies who hope to market a new veterinary drug to be injected into cows to boost milk production. The new drug has become a political issue in the Middle West, where farmers believe it could lead to new surpluses and consumers say they don't want a new artificial hormone in milk.
The Texas researchers are taking a different approach. They believe that increasing the levels of bovine growth hormone in a cow's blood through direct genetic manipulation is a better and safer way of gaining more milk.

HEADLINE: Loss of Tropical Forests Is Found Much Worse Than Was Thought

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
Tropical forests, which play a vital role in regulating the global climate, are disappearing much more rapidly than previously estimated, an international research group said today.
Each year recently, 40 million to 50 million acres of tropical forest, an area the size of Washington State, has been vanishing as trees are cut for timber and to clear land for agriculture and other development, the World Resources Institute said in a report. The group said 1.9 billion acres of tropical forest remained.
The report, ''World Resources 1990-91,'' prepared in collaboration with the United Nations, was described by its authors as the first comprehensive estimate in a decade of tropical-forest losses around the world. 
The rate of loss, measured in most countries in 1987, was nearly 50 percent greater than the last global estimate, prepared by the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization in 1980, according to the institute.
''We were startled to uncover this rate of global deforestation,'' said James Gustave Speth, president of the institute, a nonprofit Washington-based research and policy organization that specialized in environmental issues. ''We were saying we were losing the forests at an acre a second, but it is much closer to an acre and a half a second.''
The disappearance of tropical forests is regarded by environmental experts as one of the most serious global environmental problems. Through photosynthesis, the forests absorb huge quantities of carbon dioxide, the most important of the gases that are accumulating in the atmosphere. Many scientists believe that carbon dioxide, if not kept in check, will cause a significant warming of the earth in the next century, through a process known as the greenhouse effect.
 
From Satellite Data
The report on forests was based on remote sensing data from National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and Landsat satellites that was orginally analyzed by each of the affected tropical countries. Dr. Allen L. Hammond, editor in chief of the report, said at a news conference here that for most of the countries the satellite data covered 1987, but for Brazil it covered 1988, since newer data were available for that country.
He said the estimates of actual forest loss were ''very conservative,'' and that the actually losses probably were considerably higher.
The group's report said that in nine major tropical countries, the estimates of total annual losses of tropical-forest acreage were about four times as high as estimates from the years 1981 to 1985. The nine countries were Brazil, India, Indonesia, Vietnam, Thailand, the Philippines, Costa Rica, Cameroon and Myanmar (formerly Burma). Dr. Hammond said, however, that in Brazil, the rate of deforestation declined in 1988 from 1987, largely because the levels from the latter year were the highest on record.
As the tropical forests shrink, their capacity to absorb carbon dioxide declines, hastening the onset and increasing the magnitude of the warming phenomenon. And as the vegetation from the cut forests decays or is burned, it emits more carbon dioxide.
The tropical forests also contain the largest and most diverse populations of plant and animal species of any habitat. As the forests vanish, so do many of these species, many before they ever have been discovered, named and analyzed.
Tropical forests have infertile soil because most of the nutrients are in the vegetation, not the soil. Thus, when these forests are cleared they tend to regenerate slowly, if at all.
 
'An Unparalleled Tragedy'
''Tropical deforestation is an unparalleled tragedy,'' said Mr. Speth. ''If we don't reverse the trend soon, it will be too late.''
Senator Patrick Leahy, Democrat of Vermont and chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, said in a statement: ''This is the first reliable data we've had on tropical deforestation in 10 years. A situation we knew was bleak is now shown to be truly horrendous.''
The World Resources Institute report was prepared in collaboration with the United Nations Environment Program and the United Nations Development Program. Joan Martin Brown, special adviser to the executive director of the United Nations Environment Program, said at the news conference that her organization did not have its own capacity to do the kind of research contained in the report.
Since preagricultural times, the report said, the world has lost about one-fifth of all its forests, from more than 12 billion acres to under 10 billion acres. In the past, most of the losses were in the temperate forests of Europe, Asia and North America. In recent years, however, it is the tropical forests of the developing countries of Latin America, Asia and Africa that have been disappearing most rapidly.
 
Forests Without Trees
Brazil, with the largest remaining tropical forest area, is also experiencing the worst losses - between 12.5 million and 22.5 million acres a year, the report found. Myanamar is losing 1.7 million acres a year, more than 500 times the 1980 estimate by the Food and Agricultural Organization.
India, according to the data, is losing its forests at a rate of 3.7 million acres a year. Large areas legally designated as forest land ''are already virtually treeless,'' the report said. Indonesia is losing 2.2 million acres a year, and Costa Rica 300,000 acres, both substantially more than the 1980 estimate.
The problem of deforestation in developing countries ''has been exacerbated by government economic, land tenure and agricultureal policies as well as population pressures, poverty and debt,'' the report said.
The World Resources report also contains a new index of countries that are the greatest net contributors to the atmosphere of carbon dioxide, chlorofluorcarbons and methane, the major gases contributing to global warming.
 
Surprises on List
The United States and the Soviet Union are the first and second-largest net producers of these greenhouse gases, the report found. It added that if the European Community were considered a single country, it would rank second behind the United States.
But the next three countries on the index, surprisingly, were developing nations, Brazil, China and India.
It has been widely believed that the industrialized countries are the main producers of greenhouse gases. But the research group found that the developing countries already account for 45 percent of emissions of these gases, and that their contribution is likely to rise sharply as they consume more energy for industrial development.
While there is still uncertainty about global warming, Mr. Speth said, the scientific consensus is that ''the risks of global climate change are very real and it would be very shortsighted to conclude otherwise.''
''The conclusion of the great bulk of credible scientists is that enough is known to act now,'' said Mr. Speth, who was chairman of the Council on Environmental Quality in the Carter Administration. ''It is our view that it is already late.''

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
U.S. to Relax Standards On High-Tech Exports

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, June 7

 BODY:
Responding to political change in Eastern Europe and intense lobbying from Western companies, the United States and other major industrial powers agreed today to a sharp reduction of controls on high-technology exports to Warsaw Pact nations.
After a two-day meeting, the 17 members of the technology watchdog group known as Cocom also said that Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia could soon enjoy still greater access to advanced products on the ground that they now pose a minimal strategic threat to the West.
With German economic unification only weeks away, Cocom further took note of the special case of East Germany and agreed to lift most remaining restrictions on exports to that country pending political union between the two Germanys.
 
Fewer Sensitive Products
United States officials said the list of sensitive products had undergone its most drastic revision since 1949, when all NATO countries except Iceland, and Japan and Australia, set up the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Exports Controls to prevent Western technology from being used for military purposes by the Soviet bloc. 
''We have adopted measures that will enable Eastern European countries to move ahead with the modernization of their economies,'' said Allan Wendt, special representative for strategic technical policy at the State Department. ''These are crucial decisions for these countries.''
But Mr. Wendt added that, following the principle of ''higher fences around fewer products,'' Cocom had also agreed to tighten controls on exports of ''truly sensitive items.'' Mr. Wendt said, ''This will be possible because we have agreed on a common standard of enforcement.''
As an example of this, the United States and Britain vetoed proposals by the Denver-based US West Inc. and by British Telecom to build a fiber optic cable across the Soviet Union, arguing that it would involve technology with potential military application.
 
End to Bickering
Nonetheless, this week's Cocom meeting appears to be a significant breakthrough, not only because it will open major new business opportunities for Western companies, but also because it should put an end to months of bickering over trade restrictions among the Western allies.
At Cocom's last session here in February, the United States was accused of ''cold-war thinking'' when it blocked Western European moves to slash the list of controlled items. But the United States called for caution and insisted on distinguishing between Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
Early in May, however, President Bush gave the green light for lifting controls on 30 of 116 restricted categories. Now Cocom has agreed that, as of July 1 this year, these 30 categories, ranging from floating docks to transistors, can be freely traded. It said it hopes to eliminate eight more items by mid-August.
This liberalization also extends to relaxation of controls on exports of machine tools, computers and telecommunications, which account for the vast majority of Cocom licensing requests. All countries on Cocom's proscribed list - the Warsaw Pact nations and China, will benefit from this, with no conditions attached.
 
Export of Computers
The new ruling will permit exports of personal computers up to the speed of 275 megabits a second and standard mainframe computers for industrial and office use, as well as some high precision machine tools and more sophisticated telecommunications equipment.
Dennis Kloske, Under Secretary for Export Administration at the Commerce Department, said that, once all these measures have gone into effect, some $45 billion worth of United States exports will no longer be subject to licensing requirements. ''This means removing 50 percent of the licensing caseload,'' he added.
Mr. Wendt said that Cocom also accepted a British proposal that an entirely new list - a so-called ''core list'' - of sensitive products be drawn up before the end of this year. ''We will be rewriting Cocom controls from scratch,'' he explained, ''and this should further reduce the number of controlled items and make the list easier to enforce.''
One of Cocom's central decisions this week was to give preferential treatment to Eastern Europe, with United States officials noting that this will first apply only to Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia. Mr. Wendt said it was difficult to establish an exact criteria that would permit other Eastern European countries, such as Bulgaria or Romania, to obtain similar preferential treatment. ''A number of factors are involved in establishing the right strategic environment,'' he said. ''We're going to judge each situation as it arises.'' ---- White House Objects WASHINGTON, June 7 - The White House today made known its strong objections to legislation passed in the House Wednesday night that would relax controls on exports of computers and other advanced technology to the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, but set conditions curbing the President's foreign policy discretion.
Senior advisers have told the President that if the bill were to pass unchanged in the Senate, they would advise a veto, a White House official said today.
The bill, the Export Facilitation Act, which passed 312 to 86, would speed the transfer of technology by reducing red tape that causes delays in export licensing and clarifying department roles to limit bureaucratic infighting.
But the bill also links exports of high technology to the Soviet Union with Moscow's handling of the independence movement in Lithuania.

HEADLINE: New Civil Rights Bill Doesn't Mean Quotas

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In attacking your editorial support for the proposed Civil Rights Act of 1990, Frederick J. Krebs of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce asserts (letter, June 1) that the bill permits an aggrieved worker to attack an employer's ''employment process'' merely because of racial imbalance and therefore ''relieves the plaintiff of the obligation to show that an employer practice contributed to imbalance.''
But the text of the bill clearly states that a violation is established only where ''a complaining party demonstrates that an employment practice (or a group of employment practices) results in a disparate impact.'' Nowhere does the bill permit a challenge to an employment process or a claim based solely on racial imbalance; rather it requires that the complainant identify the challenged employment practice and link it to a disparate impact on minorities and women.
Mr. Krebs's claim that the bill will ''undoubtedly drive many employers to use quotas'' is built entirely on his erroneous premise. The bill faithfully restores the Supreme Court's unanimous 1971 decision in the Griggs case, which has removed obstacles to the economic advancement of minorities and women without calling for quotas.
The Civil Rights Act of 1990 is moving through Congress with broad bipartisan support because it is widely understood that the national interest is served by fair treatment in the workplace and employment practices that use the productive capacities of all Americans. A handful of influential opponents, including the Chamber of Commerce, has persistently mis-characterized the bill as involving quotas.
 
WILLIAM L. TAYLOR
 Washington, June 2, 1990
The writer is a lawyer.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Aide to Bush Assails Cuomo On Drug Plansi

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 7

 BODY:
William J. Bennett, the President's national drug policy director, issued a blistering attack on Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's drug policies today and asserted that the White House has no fear of a Cuomo Presidential candidacy.
''If Mr. Cuomo wants to wax Presidential, either cutely or otherwise, he needs to work gubernatorially first,'' Mr. Bennett said at a news conference at the State Capitol after a speech to the Legislature.
The public assault on Mr. Cuomo was the second by a member of President Bush's Administration in two days. On Wednesday, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Jack F. Kemp, told reporters at a Washington breakfast that Mr. Cuomo is politically vulnerable because of the huge tax increase in this year's state budget. 
Both Mr. Bennett and Mr. Kemp said their remarks came in response to Mr. Cuomo's speech at the state Democratic convention here on Tuesday, when the Governor blamed many of New York's problems on the policies of the Reagan and Bush Administrations. Both officials raised the subject of Mr. Cuomo without being prompted by reporters.
 
White House Comment
White House and Republican Party officials said there was no orchestrated effort by the Bush Administration to bruise Mr. Cuomo. But they also said the White House did not disagree with anything said by either Mr. Bennett or Mr. Kemp.
''They don't have to and didn't clear their remarks through here, but we don't disassociate ourselves in any way from what they said,'' said a senior White House official who works for John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff.
Mr. Cuomo, who was delivering a speech in Miami Beach today, told The Associated Press that Mr. Bennett ''may have been on a political mission.'' The Governor's spokesman, Gary G. Fryer, said he suspected that Mr. Sununu, who tried to recruit Republican candidates to run against Mr. Cuomo this year, had played a role in the attacks on Mr. Cuomo.
Facing severe budget problems this year, Mr. Cuomo has been regularly blaming Washington for the Republican Administration's handling of issues ranging from the economy to drug policy to the savings and loan bailout. His use of his nomination acceptance speech to continue those attacks and his refusal to promise to serve a full four-year term as Governor were widely interpreted this week as signs that he is keeping his political options open.
Mr. Bennett, who was invited here by Republican state senators, opened his news conference by expressing his annoyance that Mr. Cuomo had told the state convention that ''the problem of drugs is not a state failure - it's a national failure.''
John McArdle, a spokesman for the State Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, said the Senate Republicans had informed Mr. Bennett of Mr. Cuomo's remarks.
''The Governor really needs to cut it out,'' Mr. Bennett said. ''I'm doing my job. He needs to worry about doing his job rather than bashing Washington. You've got governors in this country, Republicans and Democrats, who are not spending most of their time complaining about Washington.''
 
'Nobody Is Afraid of This Guy'
Mr. Bennett made it clear he believes Mr. Cuomo is using his attacks on Washington because of Presidential aspirations, and he welcomed a Cuomo candidacy.
''There's this notion out there that if he steps in, the sun will be blocked by a cloud, the earth will stop, the animals will look around, the earth will fall silent,'' he said. ''Nobody is afraid of this guy. He's got a record to run on and the record on drugs, I have to tell you, is not what it should be.''
In his speech to a joint session of the Legislature, which was delivered in the Senate chamber, Mr. Bennett said New York had made progress in the war on drugs but needed to do better.
He focused on law-enforcement issues, encouraging the legislators to override Mr. Cuomo's veto of the death penalty and to pass a bill that would strengthen the state's ability to seize property used in drug transactions. That bill is backed by Mr. Cuomo. Criticism of Bennett Mr. Bennett said little about drug treatment initiatives, which have been the centerpiece of recent anti-drug efforts by the Cuomo administration. This year's budget includes money to increase the state's capacity for drug treatment by more than 7,000 over the next few years - which would more than double the state's treatment capacity.
The Cuomo administration has criticized Mr. Bennett for paying lip service to its plan to build drug treatment campuses across the state without providing either sites or financing for the centers. Mr. Bennett said today that he liked the concept, but he provided no commitments of Federal help.
In Washington on Wednesday, Mr. Kemp was talking with reporters about tax policy when he told them that Mr. Cuomo is vulnerable because ''he is going to push through the biggest tax increase on New Yorkers ever, ever, ever.''
 
Weary of Attacks
He said Mr. Cuomo is ''so shortsighted that he fails to make the connection between the high tax rates in his state and high capital gains taxes and the economic decline of the Northeast.''
Mr. Kemp, a former New York Congressman, also said he would have a hard time supporting Pierre A. Rinfret, the Republican gubernatorial candidate, because Mr. Rinfret supports abortion rights and opposed the 1981 Federal tax cut, which Mr. Kemp supported.
Although White House officials denied any coordinated effort to attack Mr. Cuomo, Republican strategists said it was clear that the White House had grown weary of Mr. Cuomo's attacks.
''Cuomo's up there using Bush as a punching bag,'' said Eddie Mahe Jr., a consultant to Mr. Rinfret's campaign. ''I would hope at some point they would begin to hit back.''
