HEADLINE: LAW;
Mandatory Sentences in Drug Cases: Is the Law Defeating Its Purpose?

BYLINE: By KATHERINE BISHOP, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, June 7

 BODY:
The case before Federal District Judge William W. Schwarzer last fall made him weep as he sat on the bench.
The case involved a 48-year-old longshoreman with no previous criminal convictions. The man's offense: he gave an acquaintance a ride to a fast-food restaurant, where the acquaintance made a drug deal with a Federal undercover officer.
The drug seller became a fugitive. The driver, who testified that he knew nothing about the illegal cargo, was convicted of conspiracy to traffic in narcotics. And Judge Schwarzer, bound by a Congressional decision made four years ago, had to sentence the man to a 10 years in prison. Earning the maximum number of good behavior days, he will serve eight years and eight months, a longer sentence than many people serve for manslaughter. 
''We are required to follow the rule of law,'' Judge Schwarzer said at the sentencing. ''But in this case the law does anything but serve justice.''
 
Congress Urged to Reconsider
Judge Schwarzer, who became director of the Federal Judicial Center in Washington three months ago, added, ''It may profit us very little to win the war on drugs if in the process we lose our soul.''
Increasingly, Federal judges are voicing that sentiment. Last July the chief judges of the 15 District Courts in the Ninth Circuit passed a resolution urging Congress to ''reconsider the wisdom'' of these mandatory sentences. Judges in several other circuits followed suit.
With the Anti-Drug Abuse Act of 1986, Congress intended to cripple illegal drug trafficking by requiring stringent Federal prison sentences for everyone from large-volume dealers to low-level couriers. The sentences were based solely on the amount of drugs possessed or sold: 10 years for 11 pounds of cocaine, 2.2 pounds of heroin or 1.7 ounces of crack. Then, the Anti-Drug Abuse Amendments Act of 1988 upped the ante, making life without parole the sentence for those with two or more prior convictions.
''What we frequently see in this district are the mules,'' said Federal District Judge Judith N. Keep, in San Diego, who serves the Southern District of California. ''A lot of them have severe economic problems. They often have no prior criminal record, just a financial crisis. They take a chance and they get caught.''
 
Mandatory 10-Year Sentence
In one such case cited by Judge Keep, an impoverished 36-year-old farm worker and divorced mother was convicted of drug trafficking last year after she drove a truck across the border from Mexicali. Hidden inside were 40 pounds of cocaine and more than 400 pounds of marijuana. Under the 1986 law, Judge Keep had to sentence her to 10 years in prison.
Asked whether he thought cases involving low-level couriers or lookouts produced sentences that were too severe, William T. McGivern Jr., who became the United States Attorney here in March, said, ''That may happen, but people shouldn't be involved in drugs at all.''
''We would like to get the higher-ups, the big people,'' he added. ''That's what we're here for. But Congress passed these laws and people look at me like it's my fault.''
Despite the concerns of some judges and lawyers, the public mood regarding even low-level participation in drug trafficking seems clear, at least in Judge Keep's district.
''The last four cases I've tried have been this kind of case,'' she said. ''And the juries have been out less than an hour.''
 
'Harsh Action' Required
Not all judges agree that the law's penalties are unduly strict. Last December, it fell to Federal District Judge David W. Williams of Los Angeles to impose only the second mandatory sentence of life without parole under the drug law. The 22-year-old dealer, who had three prior offenses related to cocaine, was arrested on charges of possession for sale of about five ounces of crack.
''We are in a war on drugs and it does require harsh action,'' Judge Williams said. ''It deals harshly with a lot of people, but it may get some people out of the business.''
Judge Williams, noting that the convicted dealer told the police that he had been cheated out of $500,000 in profits by gang members, said, ''This man is not a mule: he's an operator.''
Another concern often expressed by many judges is that the surge in drug cases is overwhelming the Federal courts, to the point that the anti-drug effort is being sabotaged. According to a report by the Federal Courts Study Committee, a 15-member panel appointed by William H. Rehnquist, the Chief Justice of the United States, to propose ways to improve the Federal judicial system, the sheer volume of drug cases has become the most pressing problem now facing the Federal courts.
 
Civil Lawsuits Crowded Out
The report says the growing backlog threatens access to the Federal courts by those pressing civil lawsuits, because the law requires that criminal cases be given priority.
''People such as those bringing Federal civil rights cases will have the legal right to file but will be unable to get into court,'' said Steven G. Gallagher, counsel to the study committee.
At some point, the drug case backlog will threaten the war on drugs itself when the flood of cases cannot be prosecuted in a timely manner as required under the Federal Speedy Trial Act, the report says.
''We're desperate in this district to try them,'' Judge Keep said of drug defendants, ''before they have to be dismissed because they were not given a speedy trial.''
Historically, about 95 percent of all Federal criminal cases involve plea bargaining; only a small number go to trial. But because mandatory sentences in drug cases leave the accused with nothing to gain by pleading guilty to a lesser offense, more and more cases are going to trial.
 
'Federal Day' Proposal
The proposed anti-crime legislation pending in the Senate, sponsored by Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., a Delaware Democrat, would create a ''Federal day,'' designating one day each month in which everyone arrested by the state authorities for felony drug violations would have their cases prosecuted in Federal court, where sentences tend to be tougher. The proposal is opposed by the Justice Department.
Barry Portman, the Federal public defender here, called the idea a ''publicity relations ploy to make it appear the Democrats are rougher on crime than the Republicans.''
He added, ''We'll have people plucked out of the state system getting 10 times greater sentences in the Federal system - just the kind of extremes uniform sentencing laws were meant to destroy.''

HEADLINE: LAW:At the Bar;
The fetish of footnotes, or the folly of trying to eradicate the profession's enduring weeds.

BYLINE: By David Margolick

 BODY:
It was supposedly Noel Coward who once complained that encountering a footnote was ''like going downstairs to answer the doorbell while making love.'' Or was it John Barrymore, and was his choice of verbs more pungent? For further information, see footnote 23 in ''Footnote#1 Skulduggery#2 and other Bad Habits#3,'' by Arthur D. Austin of Case Western Reserve Law School.
Professor Austin clearly has a fetish about footnotes, those agglomerations of type that protrude upward like stalagmites from the bottom of most pages of most law reviews. The typical legal scholar, a wit once wrote, ''may not assert so much as 'the sun rises in the east' without citing Copernicus'' (see Coleman, Student Lawyer, Feb. 1989), and Professor Austin tries to explain why. 
He has already found two publications, the law reviews at Vanderbilt and the University of Arizona, masochistic enough to print his iconoclastic views. Last year, he addressed the subject at the National Conference of Law Reviews. Now, in his ''Skulduggery'' article, coming soon to a law library near you in the University of Miami Law Review, he tackles it again.
Ridiculing footnotes is nothing new. Fifty-two years ago, Fred Rodell of Yale called them ''the flaunted Phi Beta Kappa keys of legal writing,'' and little has changed.
Footnotes still help allay the lingering fear that legal scholarship is to scholarship as military justice is to justice as military music is to music (see Clemenceau). But Professor Austin maintains the problem has become even worse.
The last decade, he notes, has yielded a record for footnotes in a single article - 4,824, in Arnold S. Jacobs's ''An Analysis of Section 16 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934,'' a piece that also set a record for consecutive see infras (16). The 1980's also brought perhaps the longest footnote (No. 317 in Sciarrino, ''Free Exercise in the Defamation Forest: Are 'New Religions' Lost?,'' which consumes five solid pages of agate type) and the highest percentage of ids since Freud (444 out of 574 footnotes in Buchanan, ''Comparative Analysis of Name and Likeness Rights in the United States and England'').
What accounts for this scourge? Professor Austin explains the many functions footnotes serve in addition to elucidating texts. For as maligned as footnotes are, he writes, they have many constituencies. Indeed, the footnote lobby is as entrenched in legal academia as the tobacco lobby is in Congress.
For authors, footnotes offer an easy way to look scholarly or curry collegial favor. For schools, they make faculties appear more productive. For editors, they help fill issues. For legal researchers, they provide a livelihood. And for readers, they afford the thrill of turning the pages of turgid texts with lightning speed.
Some citations are, like Piltdown man, outright hoaxes. In an article on the duty to wear seat belts, in the University of Washington Law Review, two professors said - apparently as a prank - that a certain Earl of Andrews once declared: ''Quoth, what fool darest upon the highways of this realm without properly strapping his ass to his cart?'' The man, and the quote, were bogus.
But Professor Austin contends that other footnotes, while less explicitly fraudulent, are no more legitimate. Some are soapboxes for ideologues. Others provide authors with a chance to razzle-dazzle readers or escape the editorial straitjacket of the text or simply to prove they're regular guys or Renaissance types.
Law-and-economics types throw in graphs or formulas, law-and-psychiatry types throw in Jung, law-and-literature types throw in Tolstoy, law-and-baseball types throw in Yogi Berra or, in Professor Austin's case, Reggie Jackson (in legal literature, he says, footnotes are ''the straw that stirs the drink''). ''With the Woodstock generation now retiring to the friendly bosom of academe, rock lyrics have become a popular titillator,'' he writes, noting how Martha Minow of Harvard recently cited the singer Holly Near.
Footnotes provide an easy way to butter up colleagues. For junior professors, they win friends and influence people - particularly people on tenure committees. Acknowledging Laurence Tribe or Richard Posner, even if their contributions were minimal, is a bit like stamping ''Reg. Penna. Dept. Agr.'' on a box of Lorna Doones: that is, it is a sign of wholesomeness and quality. It is also a poor substitute for the kind of peer review found in other disciplines.
In a mere 16 pages of text, Professor Austin's article had 161 footnotes. Reading it is a bit like playing a Bach toccata and having to look not only at the keys of the organ but also at the pedals below.
Of course, it's his way of making a point. But even in his more scholarly efforts, he says, he can't escape footnotes. ''I try to be economic as possible, but I have to play the game,'' he said. Why?
See supra.

HEADLINE: Johnson Leaving as No. 2 at Fed

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
Manuel H. Johnson, an important voice of conciliation on the Federal Reserve Board and a leading expert on international finance, announced today that he would resign from the board in August when his term as vice chairman expires.
Mr. Johnson, whose resignation was no surprise here or on Wall Street, will move to George Mason University in Fairfax, Va., where he will hold an endowed chair in international economics and direct the school's Center for Global Markets. He also plans to start a nonprofit organization to study and promote international economic coordination.
In recent years, votes of the Federal Open Market Committee, the arm of the Federal Reserve that sets monetary policy, have been lopsided, so Mr. Johnson's departure is not likely to lead to a change in policy.The committee consists of the seven Federal Reserve Board governors and the presidents of five Federal Reserve banks. 
The Fed has left credit policy unchanged for the last six months, and outside analysts say they see no sign of a change of course soon. Mr. Johnson said in an interview that he was generally pleased with the current state of the economy. That appears to be the view of Alan Greenspan, the chairman, and most other members of the board.
President Bush was traveling today, and there was no word from the White House or the Treasury about a replacement for Mr. Johnson. Administration officials said that Mr. Johnson had not been in line to succeed Mr. Greenspan as chairman of the board and that his resignation had nothing to do with whether Mr. Greenspan would be renominated when his term is up next year.
In a statement issued by his office today, Mr. Greenspan said he regretted but understood Mr. Johnson's decision to resign and added: ''The vice chairman and I have been an effective team. I'll miss him.''
Mr. Johnson's position on setting monetary policy has been somewhat different from Mr. Greenspan's. The chairman's view, which is the prevailing one, is that the Fed should maintain interest rates high enough to keep economic growth somewhat below its potential. The resulting slack in product and labor markets, Mr. Greenspan argues, slows the rate of inflation.
Mr. Johnson has argued that the economy's potential for growth cannot be measured accurately enough to be the standard for monetary policy. Instead, he has proposed that policy be guided by a set of financial indicators, including the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates.
Despite the difference, Mr. Johnson did not cast dissenting votes on monetary policy. He did, however, occasionally dissent on issues that reflected his general disapproval of intervention in international currency markets.
Mr. Johnson was an Assistant Treasury Secretary and an outspoken proponent of supply-side economics when Ronald Reagan nominated him four years ago.
But he proved to be most concerned about controlling inflation and cautious about roiling markets. In fact, his personality much more than his ideology marked Mr. Johnson's term as vice chairman.
 
A 'Fence-Building Influence'
 Just before Mr. Johnson joined the Federal Reserve Board, Preston Martin, his predecessor, led a palace revolt against the tight-money policies of Paul A. Volcker, who was then chairman. The board was deeply divided, and Mr. Johnson, a soft-spoken Alabamian, worked hard to bring the different factions together. He continued in that role after Mr. Greenspan became chairman in 1987.
''He has been a healing, moderating, fence-building influence,'' said James F. Smith, a former Federal Reserve staff member who is now professor of finance at the University of North Carolina Business School.
Mr. Johnson, 41 years old, said he had decided to leave because he was unwilling to commit himself to another four-year term as vice chairman. He has two small children, and friends said he had begun to worry about financing their education.
Mr. Bush can either elevate a current board member to the vice chairmanship or nominate Mr. Johnson's successor on the board to the No. 2 position. Some people outside the Government suggested that Mr. Bush might promote David W. Mullins Jr., who went on the board early this year, but officials said that was uninformed speculation. Mr. Mullins had been Assistant Treasury Secretary for Domestic Finance.
The vice chairman presides over meetings in the chairman's absence but normally has little more influence than other Fed governors.
Mr. Johnson is the only board member now who specializes in international finance, and some have suggested that the President might name someone expert in that field. One person in that category is David W. Mulford, Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs.

HEADLINE: Argentina Pays Debt Interest

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
Trying to improve relations with its foreign creditors, Argentina met today with leading banks in New York and made a $40 million interest payment.
The payment was only a small part of the $6.1 billion in past-due interest, but it was a tangible sign that Argentina's leaders want to regain access to world financial markets. Since Argentina defaulted on its debts two years ago, it has been unable to borrow for long-term projects and has had difficulty financing its foreign trade. Argentina owes foreign banks about $30 billion. 
The negotiations between 13 large banks and Javier Gonzalez Fraga, vice president of Argentina's central bank, are the first since Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady began in early 1989 to encourage banks to forgive some loans to debtor countries like Argentina. Large borrowers that have arranged debt forgivness under the Brady plan include Mexico and the Philippines.
 
Relations With the I.M.F.
 Before meeting with the banks, Argentina had patched up its relations with the International Monetary Fund so that the fund would resume disbursements from a $1.4 billion loan, which Argentina could use for a variety of purposes, including payments to creditors. The country recently received about $240 million from the I.M.F. and another $240 million is expected this summer.
When it agreed to resume lending to Argentina, the I.M.F. urged the Argentine Government to make a token interest payment to the banks to help get negotiations started. The I.M.F. and the bankers are encouraged that the economic policies of Argentina's new President, Carlos Saul Menem, appear to be making progress, although the country is in a recession. Inflation has fallen to a monthly rate of 11 percent in April from a high of 96 percent in March, and the Government is accumulating a budget surplus.
''The biggest challenge for Argentina is to keep its budget in surplus,'' said an economist who follows the country's program. The economist, who asked not to be identified, said Argentina might accumulate a trade surplus this year of $5 billion.
The Associated Press reported that Argentina was seeking an agreement to pay the banks $300 million in interest by the end of this year. Banking officials said they were seeking more, but were currently talking about monthly payments of $40 million.
Analysts expect that the package to be negotiated with Argentina will give the banks significantly less than the 65 cents on the dollar they received from Mexico or the 50 cents on the dollar from the Philippines.
In the market that has developed for trading the loans of troubled debtor countries, Argentina's loans were offered today at about 14.75 cents on the dollar, little changed on the day. Earlier this year, Argentine loans traded as low as 9.5 cents on the dollar.
 
Debts of $62 Billion
Argentina has total medium- and long-term foreign debts of $62 billion, and it is the third-largest debtor among the less-developed countries, following Brazil and Mexico.
Bankers, who hope that the debts of Argentina and Brazil may be reorganized this year, noted that both countries have taken steps in recent months to cut inflation and make economic changes. The Government of Brazil, which stopped paying its $77 billion of foreign bank loans in September 1989 and owes more than $5 billion in interest, has sharply reduced its inflation by freezing most bank accounts.
Brazil, like Argentina, is trying to reach an agreement with the I.M.F. before negotiating with its bank lenders. Brazilian officials have declined to schedule a formal meeting with a committee of bank lenders, but they have been meeting sporadically with individual banks.
American banking regulators are scheduled to meet on Monday to judge the quality of bank loans to less-developed countries and tell the banks which loans, if any, must be written off as a loss. The regulators are not expected to require that banks write off as a loss any loans to Brazil or additional amounts of their loans to Argentina.
''The fact that Brazil has taken measures to reform its economy would loom very large'' in the eyes of regulators, said John Hazeltine, director of banking at the Institute for International Finance, a Washington organization financed by large banks.

HEADLINE: Iacocca Says He Will Stay At Chrysler's Helm Past '91

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 7

 BODY:
Seeking to allay concerns among investors, dealers and employees that a leadership vacuum could develop at the Chrysler Corporation, Lee A. Iacocca said today that he would stay on as chairman beyond December 1991.
The 65-year-old executive had previously said he would make a decision on his retirement by the end of 1991, when his current contract expires.
Mr. Iacocca's decision to stay came at Chrysler's regular monthly board meeting today in New York. No retirement date was set, and a spokesman for the company said board members had not yet negotiated a new contract with Mr. Iacocca. 
Automotive analysts expressed dismay last week when Chrysler's vice chairman, Gerald Greenwald, resigned. Mr. Greenwald signed a five-year contract to become chairman and chief executive of UAL Inc., which owns United Airlines, if financing can be lined up for the proposed employee buyout of UAL.
Two other top Chrysler executives, the corporate treasurer and an executive vice president, announced plans in recent weeks to leave. While Chrysler appeared to handle those departures in stride, Mr. Greenwald's decision seemed to rattle Wall Street, and some analysts expressed concern that the company's management lacked depth and experience.
''Clearly there is a crisis of confidence among the white-collar rank and file, dealers and, to some extent, investors,'' said Joseph S. Phillippi, an automotive analyst at Shearson Lehman Hutton.
Robert M. Barboza, who owns a Chrysler-Plymouth dealership in Raynham, Mass., said: ''It's good that he isn't leaving with auto business tough as it is, because he is a seasoned auto pro. There are people who can do Mr. Greenwald's job, but Mr. Iacocca is very essential for us to keep selling cars.''
''With Iacocca at the helm, we feel kind of stable,'' said Aaron Taylor, president of Local 7 of the United Automobile Workers union, which represents 3,500 unemployed hourly workers whose hope for the future depends on an unfinished Chrysler plant in Detroit.
In a statement issued by the company, Mr. Iacocca, who earned $1.4 million in salary and bonus last year, said one of his primary responsibilities would be to arrive at an orderly succession plan. ''We're going to do that according to our own timetable, and it won't be driven by a big X on a calendar,'' he said.
Chrysler wasted little time dividing Mr. Greenwald's management duties among other ranking executives. But today's announcement is likely to go further in calming the jitters of nervous investment analysts, many of whom said last week that they had hoped for a signal from Mr. Iacocca that he would stay past 1991.
 
More Competition Expected
 ''I think this is an indication that Iacocca will be more of a hands-on manager than he has been in the last few years,'' said David Healy, an auto industry analyst for Barclays Bank in New York. ''He has said the 90's are going to be so highly competitive. I think he still wants to be there to run the show.''
In the current competition for American car and truck buyers, Chrysler has been bloodied more than its rivals. Chrysler's market share for the first five months of the year stands at 8.9 percent, nearly two full points below the 10.7 percent market share it posted through May of last year.
The company's decision to drop its subcompact Omni and Horizon models and reduce sales to rental fleets accounts for a portion of the decline in market share. But Chrysler has also been losing ground in the remainder of its car models. Even more worrisome to Chrysler is the new competition to its mini-vans and Jeeps, which have been vital sources of profits.
Chrysler stock has seesawed in the week since Mr. Greenwald made his departure official, trading between $15.375 and $16.625 before losing some of its price at the end of the week. The shares rose 12.5 cents each today, closing at $16.125 on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
How a Trade Pact Could Aid Soviets

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
The trade agreement signed by President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev at the Washington summit meeting still has high hurdles to clear before it takes effect.
Foremost among these is the Jackson-Vanik requirement that to achieve most-favored-nation tariff status from the United States, countries must grant liberal emigration rights to their citizens. Mr. Gorbachev has liberalized emigration policy for Soviet Jews. But Mr. Bush, although he signed the agreement granting most-favored-trade status to the Soviet Union last week, said he would not submit the agreement to the Senate for ratification until the Soviet legislature, the Supreme Soviet, enacted a satisfactory emigration law.
Although he has not required codification of emigration rights from China and other Eastern European countries to gain most-favored-nation status, Mr. Bush apparently wants a law from the Soviets to insure against on-again, off-again swings in exit rights for Soviet Jews, as occurred under previous Soviet leaders. 
Indeed, during the summit talks, Mr. Gorbachev raised anxieties that he might do the same, warning that he might withdraw exit permission from Soviet Jews if Israel settled many of them in the West Bank, which he regarded as Arab territory. Soviet officials later said that Mr. Gorbachev had not threatened to restrict Jewish emigration in response to Arab pressures.
The Soviets have, in fact, been working on a new emigration law, and a draft was given to Jonathan J. Halperin, president of FYI Information Resources, an American company specializing in analyses of Soviet affairs, by a Soviet official.
The law establishes ''the right to exit from and enter the U.S.S.R.'' but states various reasons why a Soviet citizen ''can temporarily be denied the possibility to go abroad.'' These include ''reasons affecting state security of the U.S.S.R. - until the circumstances constituting an impediment for his going abroad cease to exist.''
An even broader clause in the draft law provided that a Soviet citizen may not be allowed to leave when the refusal ''is dictated by the need to protect public order, health and morality of the population - until the circumstances constituting impediment to exit the country cease to exist.'' But that clause has apparently been deleted from the latest draft of the law. Heated debates over the draft law took place in Moscow during the weeks before the Washington summit meeting, but no action is expected until the fall.
How important is it for the Soviet Union to pass a law that will satisfy Mr. Bush and Congress and earn it most-favored-nation treatment from the United States? Soviet officials visiting this country this week said the trade status was extremely important ''psychologically'' and ''symbolically,'' but not urgent economically in the short run because of the relatively low level of Soviet-American trade and the limited export potential of the staggering Soviet economy. Mr. Bush signed the agreement on most-favored treatment to demonstrate good will and the prospect of future benefits.
And most-favored trade should, in the longer run, in fact mean big benefits for the Soviet Union in money terms. Its exports are currently hampered by the tariff rates set by the highly protectionist Smoot-Hawley Tariff of 1929. For instance, tariffs on various Soviet textile fabrics now range from 40 percent to 83.5 percent; these would fall to a range of 3.4 percent to 16 percent. Duties on chess sets, now 35 percent, would drop to 3.5 percent. On average, duties on Soviet goods would fall to 5 percent from 40 percent.
Most-favored-nation tariffs would make the Soviet Union a far more attractive place for many American companies to locate manufacturing plants, for export sales back to the United States or other Western countries.
But the Soviets' lack of most-favored trade is only one of many factors discouraging foreign investment there. The trade agreement would deal with problems in cutting red tape for American business activities, for example providing access to all advertising media and extending rights to hire directly local employees or citizens of other countries.
But the most serious deterrent to American and other foreign investment is the inconvertibility of the ruble. Changing that will necessitate deep reform of the Soviet price system and strengthening the balance of payments. The Russians have been covering their worsening trade balance with gold, but while producing nearly 11 million ounces a year, their gold reserves have been declining.
According to Central Intelligence Agency data, Soviet gold reserves peaked at 76.1 million ounces in 1985, and were down to 74.5 million in 1987, the last year for which C.I.A. data are available. But even with that hefty war chest, total Soviet gold reserves, at current prices, are worth less than $30 billion, just about equal to the nation's net hard-currency debt to the West.
Without an internal economic overhaul and a big export push, the ruble will stay very soft and will deter foreign investment in the Soviet Union.

HEADLINE: Trump Aide Denies Talk Of Sales

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY, June 7

 BODY:
The executive in charge of Donald J. Trump's three casinos denied today that Mr. Trump was seeking buyers for any properties and sought to dispel reports of poor casino performance, managerial dissension and widespread layoffs.
''There is no for sale sign on the Trump properties,'' said Edward M. Tracy, president and chief executive of the Trump Hotel Management Corporation, which runs the Trump gaming operation here. ''We are not shopping the properties. We are not interested in selling the properties.'' 
Mr. Tracy said the summer season at the three Trump casinos, the peak period for this resort market, would ''produce an avalanche of cash.'' He added: ''Donald Trump is thrilled. He should be thrilled.'' Mr. Tracy, at a news conference in one of the chandeliered meeting rooms of the Taj Mahal, the newest and costliest of the Trump casinos, would field no questions about the discussions Mr. Trump is conducting with his bankers in New York. Those talks are said to be aimed at renegotiating various repayment deadlines facing Mr. Trump, whose estimated $2.3 billion in debt includes $1.3 billion in mortgage bonds sold to finance his three gaming properties.
An executive from one of the banks who asked not to be identified said there had been a positive atmosphere at the negotiating table. The official said the negotiations were expected to continue on Friday.
Mr. Tracy declined to say whether Trump's Castle, the financial laggard of the three, was prepared to make a $22.6 million payment to bondholders due on June 15.
What he chiefly wished to discuss, he said, was the ''fabulous'' performance of the three casinos during May, and their prospects for the months ahead.
He said the Taj, which is twice the size of any other casino here, collected $36.4 million in casino revenue and $14 million in other revenue for the month - a daily average of $1.6 million. That is well above the lavish casino's break-even point, which he said was likely to fluctuate between $1.1 million and $1.3 million a day, according to the volume of business.
Mr. Tracy did not cite the revenues per square foot at the Taj - a significant calculation since the casino is twice the size of any of its rivals. Recent figures provided by A. C. Action, a newsletter for the gaming industry here, showed that the giant casino's revenues were about $304.40 a square foot in May, which placed it eighth in the citywide rankings and below the city average of $342.40 a square foot.
Mr. Tracy also boasted of the record-setting revenues at the Trump Plaza in May. The Plaza revenues were more than $31 million, on which the estimated operating profit was more than $9 million, he said. But he did not mention that almost $10 million of the Trump Plaza's May revenues represented the losses of Akio Kashawagi, a high-stakes Japanese gambler who stalked angrily out of the casino after his losses and vowed not to return to any Trump property because of a dispute with Mr. Tracy over his credit limit.
As for the Trump's Castle casino, Mr. Tracy said gross revenues declined by about 2 percent in May in the face of competition from the Taj. ''But we were thrilled it didn't decline more than it did,'' he said.
In response to questions, Mr. Tracy said that if there were any morale problems or dissension in the executive ranks at the Trump casino facilities, ''I have no knowledge of that.'' None of the three casino presidents on the dais with him - W. Bucky Howard of the Taj, Gary Selesner of the Plaza and Anthony Calandra of the Castle - made any comment throughout the news conference.
Mr. Tracy confirmed that some vendors were being paid less promptly now than in the past, but he said that was simply the result of better cash-management techniques.
''The Trump Organization has always had a reputation for always having paid everything absolutely on time,'' he said. ''But I have a little bit different view on life.'' In his view, he said, ''On time is a relative term.'' At present, payments to vendors are being made anywhere from 30 to 120 days, he said, depending on the vendors.
Mr. Tracy dismissed local news reports that some 2,500 of the approximately 6,500 people working at the Taj would soon be laid off in an economy move.
While about 350 people had been dismissed since the Taj opened in early April, Mr. Tracy attributed those layoffs to the ''streamlining'' typical of any start-up casino operation.
''Will we lay off people? Absolutely,'' he said. ''But nothing close to what has been projected.'' He forecast that the Taj, at its optimum staffing levels, would employ the equivalent of 6,000 to 6,200 full-time people.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Some Managers Shunning Stocks

BYLINE: By Anise C. Wallace

 BODY:
As the Dow Jones industrial average flirts with 3,000, many market watchers are wondering whether a group of professional investors will be forced by their clients to join the rally and spend their huge sums of cash, thus pushing stock prices even higher.
But so far the almost two dozen firms that use the computer-modeling technique known as ''tactical asset allocation,'' which weighs the probable risks and returns of various investments, have not acted in unison. While some firms have increased their holdings in stocks slightly in recent weeks, others, like the Quantilogic Asset Management Company in San Francisco, have sold stocks and moved their clients' assets into Treasury bills or bonds.
Quantilogic, which invests $800 million for pension funds and other institutions, has earned one of the best investment records among managers using this strategy. In the last few years its model successfully timed the firm's shifts in and out of stocks and bonds while some firms stumbled. Last year, for instance, its pension fund accounts appreciated 29.2 percent while other firms using the technique had returns of 5 to 15 percent. This year, as stock prices have climbed, the fund managers at Quantilogic have cut their clients' holdings in stocks to only 30 percent of the portfolio. 
The firm's computer models compare stocks, bonds and short-term investments and find that stocks are now riskier than bonds. ''There is some risk to corporate earnings this late in the economic cycle,'' said A. Darrell Braswell, managing director of the firm. ''Stocks are a little overvalued.'' The computer models used by several other firms that use this form of analysis suggest a different scenario. Their models suggest that stocks should provide the best returns over the next six to twelve months. Firms like Matrix Capital Management in Stamford, Conn., New Amsterdam Partners in New York and Avatar Associates Inc. in New York have bought stocks or stock index futures over the last month to increase the equity percentage of their clients' portfolios.
The model used by Matrix suggests that stock returns, including dividends, should increase by another 10 percent, said Michael A. Petrino, the company's president. ''We expect inflation to stabilize, interest rates to come down a little and real economic growth not to be negative,'' Mr. Petrino said. If these variables continue to improve, the firm would buy more stocks, he said.
The direction taken by firms that use this computer-aided trading technique are often important signals for traders who try to determine short-term moves in the financial markets. No one knows for certain how much these money managers control for their pension fund clients. But corporate executives and consultants who monitor investment management firms estimate that it could be as high as $40 billion.
The firms' computer models analyze and rank different factors, including interest rates, inflation, corporate earnings and dividends. Unlike so-called portfolio insurance, a form of program trading popular before the 1987 market crash, tactical asset allocation is used to anticipate expected investment returns rather than in reaction to moves in the various markets. And unlike firms that use stock-index arbitrage and trade daily, these managers shift their client portfolios monthly or even less frequently.
Most of these firms do not move all of their clients' assets in or out of stocks at one time. Generally they make small incremental moves in and out of the market by buying and selling stock index futures, they say. Nevertheless, because they control such large sums for institutional investors, these firms often buy or sell millions of dollars worth of securities or stock index futures at a clip.
Some traders keep an eye on Renaissance Investment Management Inc. in Cincinnati, which in the past has made dramatic moves in and out of the stock market. For instance, after the Dow fell more than 190 points on Oct. 13, Renaissance bought stocks, raising its clients' stock holdings from zero to half its portfolio. The move was its first into stocks since mid-1987.
While some of the firm's clients have questioned the wisdom of buying stocks after shunning them at lower prices, Renaissance officials say there are important differences in today's market. ''People look at the market now and think it is expensive,'' said Frank W. Terrizzi, managing director. But he argues that some stocks are cheaper than they were in 1987, when the model said they were overvalued.
Mr. Terrizzi said the firm had not bought more stocks since October. And he declined to say what changes in his model would direct him to increase his clients' holdings in stocks to 100 percent of the portfolio. ''Our model is saying we're in the right place,'' he said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Issues Rise in Light Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose slightly in light trading yesterday, as interest rates remained locked in a tight range.
''We are in a very narrow counter-trading market,'' one Government bond trader said. ''That means when prices go down by a few ticks you see some buyers, and when they go up by a few ticks you see sellers. I think it will stay that way through the end of next week at least.'' 
The announcement that Manuel H. Johnson, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, intends to resign in early August mildly surprised market participants, and bond prices dipped briefly after the news was made public.
The decline was short-lived however, and a report later in the day that showed that consumer credit growth during April was weaker than had been expected prompted some buying.
 
Fed Governor Resignation
 An analyst said that while he had been a staunch ally of Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve Board chairman, for the last three and a half years, for market participants the real significance of Mr. Johnson's resignation would be who is chosen to replace him.
''It has become a common practice for Fed governors to resign well before their terms are about to expire,'' said Darwin L. Beck, an economist at the First Boston Corporation.
''I personally never thought that Mr. Johnson would serve out his full 14-year term. And from the market's perspective, the announcement of who will replace him might well cause more of a flurry than his resignation created.''
Mr. Johnson, who was appointed to the Fed by President Reagan on Feb. 7, 1986, became vice chairman on Aug. 4 of that year. His resignation will come at the end of his term as vice chairman. His term on the central bank would have ended Aug. 21, 2000.
As noted, the rise in Treasury prices was modest.
By late in the day, the 8 3/4 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 103 17/32, up 1/8 point, to yield 8.42 percent. Late Wednesday the benchmark issue was offered at a price to yield 8.43 percent.
 
Treasury Note Issues
Among Treasury note issues, the 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 102 27/32, up 1/32, to yield 8.44 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 10/32, unchanged on the day, to yield 8.32 percent.
Treasury bill rates were little changed.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.69 percent late yesterday, up one basis point, or hundredth of a point. Rates on six-month bills dipped by one basis point, to a late offered rate of 7.58 percent. And one-year bill rates also fell by one basis point, to a late offered rate of 7.49 percent.
Activity in the tax-exempt securities market was highlighted by a successful sale of $4.1 billion worth of tax and revenue anticipation notes for the State of New York.
Despite recent ratings downgrades, which reflect the state's poor economic prospects, the notes were sold at lower interest rates than were issues at the state's spring borrowing in March 1989.
The 6.60 percent notes sold yesterday were priced at $100.378, to yield 6.10 percent.
By contrast, the $3 billion worth of notes sold by the state in March 1989 had a coupon of 7.50 percent and were priced to yield 7 percent.
''In the final analysis, the ratings downgrade didn't effect the state that much,'' said Stanley Ciemniecki, an executive vice president in charge of municipal underwriting at Shearson Lehman Hutton, the investment bank that acted as lead manager on yesterday's negotiated underwriting. ''There was strong institutional and retail demand for these securities.''
The notes are rated MIG-2 by Moody's Investors Service and SP-1 by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Elsewhere in the municipal market, the State of Illinois offered $90 million worth of general obligation bonds at competitive bid.
A bid from a syndicate led by Prudential-Bache Securities won the issue, which consists of serial bonds with maturities from 1991 to 2011. Coupons on the bonds range from 5.80 percent in 1991 to 6.95 percent in 2011.
The issue is rated Aaa by Moody's and AA-plus by Standard & Poor's.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, the Whirlpool Corporation offered $200 million of 10-year securities through an underwriting group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The 9.5 percent notes, which mature June 13, 2000, were priced at $99.875, to yield 9.519 percent, 1.05 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The issue, which is noncallable for life, is rated A-2 by Moody's and A-plus by Standard & Poor's.
Prices of most actively traded bonds in the secondary market for tax-exempt securities rose by about 1/8 point, traders said. Prices of widely quoted corporate bonds were unchanged on the day.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported that all three measures of the nation's money supply fell sharply in the week ended May 28.
The report had no impact on prices in the credit markets, but analysts said that the sharp slowing in money growth over the last two months could be a worry should it continue much longer.
''If this kind of pace continues through June, people at the Fed will probably start to get concerned,'' said Wayne Smith, an economist at Ried Thunberg & Company, an investment advisory firm in Westport, Conn.

HEADLINE: Don't Test Mandela on Israel

BYLINE: By Alisa Solomon; Alisa Solomon is a member of Jews for Racial and Economic Justice, a group of religious leaders, professionals and community organizers.

 BODY:
Nelson Mandela is on his way to Geneva to meet with leaders of half a dozen mainstream American Jewish organizations who are asking him to clarify his position on Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization.
Mr. Mandela's answers will determine not only how but whether several major Jewish organizations, such as the American Jewish Congress and the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, welcome Mr. Mandela to New York City on June 20. Will Mr. Mandela utter the magic words these men want to hear?
What troubles many Jewish leaders is what they call Mr. Mandela's ''embrace'' of Yasir Arafat. Mr. Mandela has met with Mr. Arafat twice and has expressed his sympathy with the P.L.O.'s cause of self-determination for the Palestinian people. 
Spokespersons for Jewish organizations have told me that if Mr. Mandela says in Geneva that there is no question that Israel exists, that won't be enough. If he says that Israel should live with guaranteed security beside a Palestinian state, that won't be enough either. Only the magic phrase ''Israel has a right to exist'' will do. Even then, he better not add a word more. If his response is inadequate, Mr. Mandela will be greeted by a variety of protests on his visit.
The Jewish community's decision to stand up for a cause of such clear moral rectitude as the fight to end apartheid should not be held hostage to this litmus test. With a sly trick of a trope, Mr. Mandela's physical greeting of Mr. Arafat - clasping shoulders - is employed for metaphorical duty. Saying that he has ''embraced'' Mr. Arafat is meant to imply that he adopts everything Mr. Arafat has ever said or done. Mr. Mandela has done no such thing.
He has - as has the African National Congress - supported the call for Palestinian rights. So have countless American Jews. So have countless Israelis. Indeed, members of the Knesset and Israeli military officers have long argued that Israel's security depends on Palestinian self-determination in the West Bank and Gaza. Obviously, there is no majority position on this matter in Israel, but it is openly debated. Only among America's mainstream Jewish leadership is discussion denied.
As a result, the mainstream Jewish leaders misrepresent the people for whom they claim to speak. Opinion polls show that the majority of American Jews support a land-for-peace compromise between Israel and Palestinians in the occupied territories. And a poll funded by the Israel-Diaspora Institute, an Israeli policy center, has revealed that the leaders don't even speak their own minds. A full 76 percent of leaders of American Jewish groups back trading land on the West Bank and Gaza for peace.
Clearly, then, American Jews and their purported leaders have no trouble recognizing that supporting Palestinian rights and supporting Israel's existence are not mutually exclusive. Then why assume that because Mr. Mandela speaks out for Palestinians he is attacking Israel's existence, especially since the A.N.C. has never questioned Israel's status?
Many mainstream Jewish leaders object to Mr. Mandela calling Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza ''a unique form of colonialism.'' Even if one disagrees, it's understandable that the leader of a third-world liberation movement would use such terms to describe a situation in which 1.5 million people live under military occupation without the right to vote.
What's more, Mr. Mandela has good reason to be wary of Israel, which continues to sell arms to South Africa. While it's true that Israel need not be singled out for special criticism - plenty of other countries trade with South Africa - Israel must not be excused, either.
There are Jews and Jewish organizations that will honor Mr. Mandela. Rabbis will participate in interfaith services, and Jews for Racial and Economic Justice will hold a Sabbath service. Yet Jewish right-wing fringe groups threaten to dog Mr. Mandela as he races from event to event, protesting his ''Communist'' platform.
But mainstream Jewish organizations claim to speak for the Jewish community at large; they are the ones to whom journalists go for quotes; they have the resources to take out ads proclaiming their views. As such, they should be counted among those welcoming Mr. Mandela, a moral voice for human rights all over the world.

HEADLINE: SHAMIR ANNOUNCES A NEW GOVERNMENT OF THE RIGHT WING

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, June 8

 BODY:
With his final deadline only hours away, Acting Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir announced tonight that he had succeeded in forming a new Government, the most conservative ever in Israel.
The announcement appears to have brought an end to almost three months of bargaining and bickering that kept Israel from dealing with a wave of Soviet Jewish immigrants, a continuing economic crisis and a hardening of attitudes among its Arab neighbors.
''This ceremony marks the end of much effort by many parties,'' Mr. Shamir said as his Likud party and its proposed partners - nine religious or far-right parties and individuals -signed an agreement on the new Government's terms and priorities.
 
Priority for Immigration
Chief among those priorities, the document says, is ''dealing with the massive immigration that's coming here and its absorption.'' 
Also on the list is a commitment to ''strengthen, expand and develop'' Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip - a position that may send Israel into a period of confrontation with its main ally and benefactor, the United States.
Though the document's language appears to avoid explicit promises to increase the number of settlers or settlements in the occupied territories, the Bush Administration opposes any expansion of the settlements. And not one member of the new Government advocates pursuing Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's plan for initiating Israeli-Palestinian peace talks.
 
Faces Parliament Monday
The new Government is not official until it is approved by Parliament on Monday, and in the meantime Mr. Shamir must satisfy a two-seat religious party, Torah Flag, which signed the accord today but has not signed the formal coalition agreement.
But even assuming that that problem is resolved and the new Government is approved on Monday, it will have only 62 supporters in the 120-seat Parliament, including one 2-seat far-right party, Moledet, that agreed to vote for approval of the Government but declined to join it.
''This Government, you can say for sure, will represent the majority of the population in Israel,'' Mr. Shamir told the Israeli television tonight.
But in a national opinion poll published in an Israeli newspaper this week, only 14 percent of the country's Jewish population said they favored the establishment of a government consisting solely of right-wing and religious parties. Such a government has never been in power in the 42 years since Israel's independence.
Three far-right Likud members who dogged Mr. Shamir for the last year, repeatedly accusing him of leaning too far left, have been given the most senior positions.
David Levy, whose best-known recent action as Housing Minister was to authorize the secret $1.8 million Government financing of the disputed Jewish settlement in the Christian Quarter of Jerusalem's Old City, has been promised the Foreign Ministry.
Ariel Sharon, the former Defense Minister whose resignation as Trade Minister last winter set off the Government crisis that seems only now to be ending, is to head the Housing Ministry, which subsidizes housing for Jewish settlers in the occupied territories. He will also be the immigration chief, in charge of coordinating Government policy toward the resettlement of immigrating Soviet Jews, who are now arriving at the rate of more than 10,000 a month.
 
Sharon Wants More Settlements
Mr. Sharon is an outspoken advocate of increased Jewish settlement in the occupied territories, and as Housing Minister he will have broad authority to promote his views and perhaps even to increase the small number of Soviet Jews who move to the West Bank and Gaza.
Yitzhak Modai, the dissident Likud Minister who before agreeing to join the Likud coalition in April demanded a $10 million personal bond to insure that Mr. Shamir's promises would be kept, is to be the Finance Minister.
Acting Foreign Minister Moshe Arens is to be Defense Minister.
Without necessarily referring to any of these appointments, Mr. Shamir, like others in his party, professed no great enthusiasm for the proposed new Government. Asked if he was satisfied, he said, ''We'll see after it is established and begins its work.''
The crisis began in March when the Labor Party, the junior partner in a coalition with Likud but unhappy that Mr. Shamir had refused to accept the American proposal for peace talks, brought the Government down with a parliamentary vote of no confidence.
 
Bad Gamble for Peres
The Labor Party leader, Shimon Peres, was jubilant at the time, but after five weeks of trying he was unable to form a new governing majority.
In retrospect, Mr. Peres's gamble 11 weeks ago could hardly have produced worse results for him. The Labor Party is now essentially powerless, in opposition, and former Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin is challenging Mr. Peres for the party leadership.
The proposed new Government will be so unstable that if even one of the smallest two-seat parties grows unhappy and pulls out, the Government will be just one vote short of collapse.
The three small parties - Tehiya, with three seats, Tsomet, with two, and Moledet, with two - all advocate holding onto the West Bank and Gaza Strip forever. And Moledet, which plans to support the Government without joining it, urges the expulsion of the Arab population from the territories.
So Mr. Shamir, now one of the most liberal members of his new Government, is less likely to push even his own modest plan for regional peace than he was when he was in coalition with Mr. Peres and Labor.
 
Three Individuals Join
The other new coalition partners are the National Religious Party, a right-wing and moderately Orthodox group that has five seats, and two rigorously Orthodox parties - the Sephardic Torah Guardians, or Shas, with five seats, and Torah Flag, with two. Two dissident former members of rigorously Orthodox parties also signed with Likud as independents.
And just as the Labor Party lured a Likud member away seven weeks ago, only to see him return to Likud after Labor failed, so Likud has lured away a senior member of Labor, Mordechai Gur, a former Army Chief of Staff. Likud itself has 40 seats. Mr. Peres was bitter over that today and said Mr. Shamir's new Government ''was born in sin.''
''I don't think this new Government will solve problems,'' he added. ''It will cause problems.''
Mr. Shamir, meanwhile, acknowledged that keeping the new Government from collapse ''will not be easy.''
 
INTERNAL MATTER, BUSH SAYS
OMAHA, June 8 (Reuters) - President Bush said today that Israel's forming of a new right-wing Government was an internal matter for the Israelis, and that United States policy toward Arab-Israeli peace talks would stay the same.
''Israel can do what it wants with its government, and I'll work with whomever that country puts forward as their government,'' he said. ''But they know the policy of the United States on peace talks. U.S. policy is firm. We want the peace talks to begin.''

HEADLINE: New York Agencies Push Huge Queens Development

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
In a plan that is being pressed with unusual urgency at City Hall, three public development agencies in New York City and several prominent business executives are trying to build a small new city along the East River in Queens.
The project, planned along 1.25 miles of waterfront in the Hunters Point section of Long Island City, would include 6,300 apartments, a hotel and offices in 15 buildings across the river from the United Nations building in Manhattan. The site is blighted by rundown warehouses and industrial buildings.
The plan is under review by the city's Planning Commission, and is expected to be put to a vote by the Board of Estimate in August as one of its last acts before it is disbanded under the revised City Charter. Some critics, however, charge that the public agencies are moving too quickly through the approval process. 
If approved, the Hunters Point project could be a model for redevelopment of old industrial space along New York City's waterfront, which many regard as a vast, underutilized asset. It would also give Queens its biggest economic boost in decades, attracting thousands of affluent new residents and supporting other new development of retail space and offices.
''We deserve this project,'' said Claire Shulman, the Borough President of Queens and a leading advocate of the plan. Like other Borough Presidents, who are on the Board of Estimate, her influence over the Hunters Point project will be reduced in August when the board's land use review powers pass to the City Council and the Planning Commission.
 
Difficult Questions for Dinkins
The Queens plan could pose difficult questions for Mayor David N. Dinkins, who said during his campaign last year that he favored a balanced approach to development that would provide low- and moderate-income housing, open space, recreation and other neighborhood improvements.
Most of the apartments at Hunters Point are being designed as market-rate housing, with two-bedroom apartments priced at $250,000 or more. Nonetheless, Sally Pinero-Hernandez, the deputy mayor for finance and economic development, said the project was being supported vigorously at City Hall.
It is hard to find anyone who objects to redeveloping the gritty, 70-acre Long Island City waterfront site, which commands New York's most expansive view of midtown Manhattan and has no housing. But critics say that because the current Hunters Point proposal has attracted so large a network of investors and is approaching approval without a developer or detailed plan for improvements to roads and subways, it has become questionable.
The plan has gone through several revisions. An earlier version envisioned a 50-50 mix of office space and apartments, but the mix has been changed to 80 percent residential and 20 percent commercial space.
The Public Development Corporation, one of the project's sponsors, said this week that it had told representatives of the neighborhood around the Hunters Point site that open space and playground would be increased to 19.2 acres from 16.7, and that a preschool and kindergarten would be built by whoever is chosen as the developer.
The agency also said some of the new housing at the riverfront site would be set aside for elderly or low-income tenants, but that it was too early to determine how much.
The negotiations did not satisfy all complaints.
 
'Behind the Scenes'
''We still don't have confidence in what is going on behind the scenes,'' said Walter L. McCaffrey, a City Councilman whose district includes the Hunters Point site. He added that the plan was being rushed through city approvals in a way that gave residents far too little information.
The plan is different from most other developments that have been sponsored by New York government agencies or involved publicly owned land. A third of the 70-acre Hunters Point site is owned by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which has budgeted $125 million for the project. Another $30 million has been budgeted by the city.
For the first time, all three of New York's major public development agencies - the Port Authority, the city's Public Development Corporation and the New York State Urban Development Corporation - are sponsoring the plan together. The state agency, with powers to condemn property and speed environmental review, stepped in as the lead public agency in August, partly at Mrs. Shulman's request.
In most past projects, the public agencies have decided on broad guidelines, selected developers through competitive bids, and assigned them responsibility for architecture and environmental and regulatory reviews. But at Hunters Point, the agencies do not intend to select developers until those reviews are complete.
 
Investors Aggressively Buying
With the three agencies pressing forward, investors have been aggressively buying land in the development site that is not already owned by the Port Authority.
Barbara J. Fife, the deputy mayor for planning, said last month that she had stepped aside from any involvement in the project to avoid the appearance of a conflict of interest. Her decision followed a report in New York Newsday linking her husband, Martin Fife, to a Wall Street concern that has taken a financial stake in Hunters Point land.
Mr. Fife is an outside director of the Dreyfus Corporation, an investment firm that operates several mutual funds and deals mainly in stocks and bonds, but that recently created a new fund to invest in real estate, including land at Hunters Point. A spokesman for Dreyfus, Jack Bernstein, said Mr. Fife's responsibilities were confined to overseeing a small number of funds that deal exclusively in stocks and bonds.
Others involved rank among New York's business elite. A group headed by William Zeckendorf Jr., the developer, and Martin J. Raynes, president of a large brokerage and real estate management company, has been buying land and courting landowners in the Hunters Point site.
Mr. Zeckendorf said the group included James D. Wolfensohn, an investment banker; and a partner in Mr. Wolfensohn's firm, Paul A. Volcker, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve. Victor Elmaleh, chairman of the Worldwide Group, a real estate investment firm and Arthur Cohen, another large real estate investor, are also members of the group, Mr. Zeckendorf said. Dreyfus's interests are represented by the Trotwood Corporation, an investment fund it established last year that is headed by Herbert J. Sturz, a former chairman of the New York City Planning Commission.
 
Two Japanese Concerns
Mr. Zeckendorf said the group had bought or entered into contracts to buy separate parcels that amount to 25 percent of the 70-acre site. Mr. Raynes said the group had a ''business agreement'' to purchase another major part of the site, now owned by Pepsico Inc., which operates a bottling plant on the site.
Pepsico's land would give the group nearly 50 percent of the site. The largest remaining parcel is owned by the Port Authority.
Other private interests taking part in the venture, Mr. Zeckendorf said, are two Japanese concerns, the Tekken Construction Company, which has bought a 50 percent stake in a large parcel in the Hunters Point development site, and the Tobishima Corporation, an investment concern. He added that Mr. Wolfensohn had received preliminary commitments from the Fuji Bank, a major Japanese lender, to provide financing.
Another unresolved question is how much, if any, of the housing will be set aside for subsidized low-income or elderly tenants. Mr. McCaffrey and some neighborhood groups have proposed that 20 percent of the apartments be set aside for elderly people.
But Ms. Pinero-Hernandez said Mayor Dinkins would support the project even with less than 20 percent set aside.

HEADLINE: Cuomo's Real Race

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 8

 BODY:
Four years ago, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was swept into a second term by the biggest landslide in New York State history. He defeated his opponent, Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Westchester County Executive, by a margin of more than 2 to 1, and carried 57 of the state's 62 counties.
 
This year, aides to the
Governor are desperately hoping to avoid a repeat of 1986.
It is not because they are uninterested in winning, and winning big. It is because in racking up the largest victory in state history, Mr. Cuomo gained a reputation for arrogance and irascibility that lent his landslide a pyrrhic quality. 
''It didn't cost him many votes,'' Lee Miringoff, director of the Marist Institute for Public Opinion in Poughkeepsie, said of the Governor's behavior in the last campaign. ''But it clearly cost him in terms of perceptions.''
 
More Refined Standards
In its broad outlines, the 1990 campaign looks so much like the 1986 campaign that the risk of repetition seems enormous. Once again Mr. Cuomo, a popular incumbent with a full campaign treasury, faces a politically unknown opponent with an empty war chest this time Pierre A. Rinfret, an economist.
Because the Governor enjoys such an overwhelming advantage, he is likely to be judged, as he was in 1986, by more refined standards than politicians are normally subjected to. The consultants and commentators who handicap the contest will be looking to see not only how strong the Governor is at the polls, but also how gracefully he handles his strength.
While it is still far too early to tell whether Mr. Cuomo will be able to avoid the kind of public relations damage that he sustained during the last campaign, it is already clear that a desire to avoid it is shaping the Governor's strategy as his campaign team, led by his son Andrew, prepares for the next election.
Perhaps the most damaging perception that arose during the 1986 campaign was that Mr. Cuomo was too aloof and arrogant to engage his opponent, Mr. O'Rourke, in a genuine race. The perception arose from the Governor's reluctance to do the kind of state-fair stumping that is a staple of most gubernatorial campaigns and from his refusal to debate his opponent more than once.
 
Campaign Trail
This year, Mr. Cuomo has pointedly pledged to act like a more down-home kind of candidate, the sort that might win points for humility. Accepting the Democratic nomination on Tuesday, Mr. Cuomo promised to drag his running mate, Stan Lundine, the Lieutenant Governor, from one end of New York to the other.
''We'll talk to them in Buffalo, and we'll travel all throughout central New York,'' he said, adding, ''I especially like the rural areas in the summer.''
Mr. Cuomo also seems anxious to avoid the accusations of selfishness that were leveled against him in 1986. Members of the State Senate's Democratic minority, who saw the campaign as their best shot at seizing the majority, complained that the tremendously popular Governor did little to put his prominence to work for his fellow Democrats.
The Governor has pledged to do better this year. ''He will not be accused of being out there for Mario Cuomo and not for the ticket,'' said an adviser who is working on the campaign. ''He's much more sensitive to that.'' Already the Governor has called at least four potential Democratic candidates and exhorted them to run for the State Senate, aides to the Governor said.
 
'Press War'
One of the greatest challenges that Mr. Cuomo faces this summer is avoiding the bruising battle with news organizations that became the story-behind-the-story of the last campaign. During that campaign, the Governor several times accused reporters of intentionally distorting their coverage to damage him.
''I didn't make me look bad; you made me look bad,'' he said at one point to a group of editors and reporters.
Known affectionately in Albany as the ''press war,'' the Governor's running contretemps with reporters in 1986 fostered the already popular image of him as testy and thin skinned, and it raised questions about whether he was temperamentally suited to a Presidential race.
''People thought, 'If this is a guy who focuses on issues, why the sideshow,?' '' said Mr. Miringoff, of the Marist Institute. ''It raised eyebrows.''
Advisers to the Governor attribute the clash to restless reporters who felt deprived of a bona fide campaign. ''In many ways the adversary was not the Republican candidate,'' said one of the Governor's closest advisers, who asked not to be identified. ''Reporters cast themselves in the role of opponent. They figured if O'Rourke wasn't going to make the case, they were. That's a game that you don't win. The Governor has to be cognizant of that and not let it happen again.''
 
Bad Times and Mickey Mouse
In an effort to prevent this campaign from turning into a five-month contest between Mr. Cuomo and the state's news organizations, advisers to the Governor are zealously trying to convince reporters that the race will not be so easy as it looks.
''You're running against incumbency, you're running against bad times and running against bad stories,'' one adviser said. ''You have to remember that Republicans would start out with 35 percent of the vote if they ran Mickey Mouse.''
In case reporters are still not taking the race seriously, the Governor's campaign staff is planning to treat them to a whistle-stop tour of upstate New York in August.
''This will be a much more active campaign than last time,'' one adviser said, ''first for the Republicans and second for the press corps.''

HEADLINE: Shepard Clough, 88; Professor and Writer Of European History

 BODY:
Dr. Shepard B. Clough, who retired after 42 years as a history professor at Columbia University, died on Thursday at Northeast Vermont Hospital in St. Johnsbury. He was 88 years old and lived in East Peacham, Vt. His son Peter said Dr. Clough (pronounced cluff) had died after a stroke.
Dr. Clough, a specialist in European economic history, wrote ''The Rise and Fall of Civilization,'' (1951), ''Basic Values in Western Civilization'' (1960), ''The Economic History of Modern Italy'' (1964) and ''The Economic Basis of American Civilization'' (1968).
He was born in Bloomington, Ind. After earning a bachelor's at Colgate University, he did postgraduate work at the Sorbonne and Heidelberg. He received a doctorate from Columbia, where he began teaching in 1928. He retired in 1970.
In World War II he was in the economic studies division of the State Department, lectured at the School of Military Government in Charlottesville, Va., and worked in the Office of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation. After the war he became a knight of the Order of Merit of the Italian Republic and a chevalier of the French Legion of Honor.
Surviving are his wife, the former Marion McGill; two sons, Peter, of Pound Ridge, N.Y., and Shepard, of Lexington, Mass; two sisters, Dorothy Howard of Lebanon, N.H., and Barbara of Wellesley, Mass.; a brother, Reginald, of Old Saybrook, Conn.; eight grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren.

GRAPHIC: Dr. Shepard B. Clough (1967)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JUNE 9, 1990

 BODY:

 
 
The Economy
 The Public Service Commission's authority to price electricity based on power saved, rather than power used, has been upheld by a New York State court. The approach, which is an attempt by regulators to reduce air pollution and cut power costs, is opposed by some large companies. They contend that if the money spent for conservation does not justify the investments, it will lead to one group of customers subsidizing another. [Page 31.] The drive to re-regulate the cable television industry gained momentum as the Senate Commerce Committee approved a bill that would let the Federal Communications Commission set guidelines on the fees cable subscribers pay to receive broadcast and public-access channels. The industry opposed it. The House is preparing its draft for the end of the month. But passage of re-regulation this year is far from certain. [35.] 
 
 
 
Markets
 Stock prices tumbled, as the Dow Jones industrial average lost 34.95 points to close at 2,862.38. The slide, the fourth in a row, left the blue-chip barometer 72.81 points below the record it set on Monday. Computerized sell programs magnified the downward trend. [31.] Prices of long-term Government securities eased, but the market in shorter Treasury maturities was essentially unchanged in unusually lackluster trading. [34.] Gold recovered a bit from its recent selling bout, with bullion for current delivery up $1.10, to $355.70 a troy ounce, on the New York Commodity Exchange. The dollar was also stronger. [39.] Cocoa futures prices were sharply lower, and grain and soybeans also declined. Crude oil and gasoline were higher. [39.]
 
International
 The American electronics industry is losing its edge in the world marketplace, the Commerce Department warned. The $200 billion-a-year giant long considered a bellwether of the country's competitiveness may well be eclipsed in this decade by Japan and newly emerging producers like South Korea, the agency said in a 221-page study. The study, ordered by Congress, could cause the White House some discomfort. [31.] Negotiations to conclude a major trade agreement between Japan and the United States before an economic summit meeting in Houston next month may be derailed, people on both sides said. There is a struggle within the Japanese Government and resistance to American demands for more specific commitments. [32.]
 
 
 
Companies
 Ames Department Stores took its biggest cost-cutting step since its April 25 filing for voluntary bankruptcy by announcing the closing of 188 stores in addition to the 33 it had previously said would be closed. Some 18,000 employees are involved in the closings, which affect about a third of the chain's stores. [31.] Gerald Greenwald will get at least $9 million to give up his post as vice chairman of the Chrysler Corporation and become head of a union effort to buy the UAL Corporation, people familiar with the plan said. If the buyout is completed, he will also be paid $1.2 million a year, plus an additional $1.2 million in the first year. [33.] Layoffs of 1,500 people are planned in Texas by Texas Instruments Inc. and the General Dynamics Corporation. The two leading military contractors cited expected military budget cuts. [33.] Donald J. Trump could give his bankers a bigger stake in his properties as he tries to persuade them to lend him more money on top of the $2 billion he already owes, a banker said. [33.]
 
 
 
Today's Columns
 Loads, as mutual fund commissions are known, are aptly named. They weigh down investors' returns, so financial experts advise becoming the educated consumer. Your Money. [32.] A method for using low-powered lasers to reverse gum disease, which troubles many middle-aged and older people, has been patented by a New York ophthalmic surgeon. Patents. [32.]
