HEADLINE: Report Warns of Decline Of U.S. Electronics Industry

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 8

 BODY:
In a study that could cause the White House some discomfort, the Commerce Department warned today that the $200 billion-a-year American electronics industry, long considered a bellwether of the country's competitiveness, is losing its edge in the world market and may be eclipsed in this decade by Japan and newly emerging producers like South Korea.
Neither the conclusion nor the recommendations for future action are startling. But the study is the most comprehensive yet by any Government agency of what had generally been expected to become the country's flagship industry and biggest employer by the turn of the century. The analysis, ordered by Congress two years ago, is bound to set off more heated debate about the Government's role in promoting industrial welfare. 
So controversial has this issue become that in the foreword there is a disclaimer that the report represents only the views of the Commerce Department, and ''not necessarily'' those of the Bush Administration.
This could signal that the Administration is uncomfortable with the implications.
''If the Commerce Department does not speak for the Administration, then who does?'' asked Representative Mel Levine, a California Democrat who is co-chairman of the House Export Task Force. ''The climate is so threatening that nobody wants to face the truthful assessment of this report.''
The report found that although the United States remains the overall electronics leader, American suppliers of a broad range of products -from silicon wafers and memory chips to computer displays and telecommunications network switches -have rapidly lost their shares of the world market in the last several years.
The situation is even more bleak for some of the newest technologies, like X-ray lithography, optical storage devices and flat panel displays, the report said.
''If the current relative growth rates continue, the Japanese will be the world's No. 1 electronics producer and trader by the early 1990's,'' said the report, which was prepared by electronics sector specialists of the International Trade Administration of the Commerce Department. The report also drew on the overseas resources of the U.S. and Foreign Commercial Service, which monitors competitive conditions in foreign countries.
The report recommends familiar Bush Administration policy proposals: tax credits for research and development, antitrust exemptions for joint manufacturing consortiums, relaxed export-control regulations and cuts in the capital-gains tax to reduce the cost of raising capital.
Over the last decade, prominent Democrats, including the party's Presidential candidates, have warned that the Government needs to take a more active role in industrial policy. Hands-Off Policy But the Bush Administration, like the Reagan Administration, has avoided such a role, arguing that instead of picking winners and losers, the Government should create an economic atmosphere that allows all industries to flourish.
A spokeswoman for the Commerce Department said the department had decided to publish the report now rather than wait for the formal interagency clearance that would have made the report an Administration document. In response to the report, a representative of the electronics industry and some members of Congress said the Government should be doing more to promote the industry.
''The Government has to be far more creative,'' said Representative Doug Walgren, a Pennsylvania Democrat who is chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee's Subcommittee on Commerce, Consumer Protection and Competitiveness.
Mitchell E. Kertzman, chairman of the American Electronics Association, which represents 3,500 electronics and information-processing companies, said the report ''accurately presents where the industry is, but doesn't go far enough in identifying ways in which the Government and industry can work through the problems together.'' Partnership Is Urged In a briefing for several reporters, J. Michael Farren, Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade Administration, said: ''I think it's important that the Government and the private sector operate as partners, and that's something this Administration has clearly demonstrated a willingness to do.
''I've been around politics long enough that I don't want to see the political process making these decisions. You need the market to do it.''
Because it was considered a technical and analytical study under the International Trade Administration, Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher asked Mr. Farren to handle the briefing, department officials said. The report noted that one of the many indicators of the American decline was the downward trend in the American share of electronics patents.
The Japanese have more than doubled the number of United States electronics patents they have received since the mid-1970's, the report said, and their patents have been licensed more frequently than those of their American counterparts.
Three Japanese companies -Canon, Hitachi and Toshiba - topped the list of companies receiving American electronics patents in 1987, the most recent year for which figures are available. Only four American companies were in the top 10. Previous Role of Government In process materials, American companies lag behind the Japanese. American companies also trail in many processing equipment technologies, like those used to produce semiconductors.
While there has never been a coordinated set of Government policies applied to the electronics sector in particular, some policies have nevertheless affected the sector's direction in a significant way.
The Defense Department, for example, has paid for much of the industry's research and development. In addition, through the huge military buildup of the last decade the Pentagon has been an important market for the industry's production. The Pentagon has also provided, through the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, money to support basic research in specific electronics sectors, including high-definition television.
The study found some shortcomings in the industry itself, citing its focus on ''short-term tactical'' considerations, in contrast to the longer-term strategic perspective taken by Japanese companies.
It reported on a survey on the corporate objectives of Japanese and American executives, and noted that Japanese executives placed market share and return on investment as their first and second objectives, whereas American executives were primarily concerned with return on investment and raising the price of shares, with market share in third place.
''This downward trend in the U.S. share of patents is reflected in the declining capabilities of U.S. firms relative to the Japanese in the research and development phases of bringing key electroncs technologies to market,'' the report said.

HEADLINE: Pier 1 Finds Success Beyond Brass

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
The recent push by Pier 1 Imports Inc. into Manhattan caps a four-year overhaul that has transformed the company from a retailer of inexpensive imported goods into one selling moderately priced home furnishings for successful young professionals.
Three weeks ago, the Fort Worth-based company opened a store at 40th Street and Fifth Avenue, the first of four locations planned in Manhattan in the next three years. Pier 1 expects to open more than 80 stores nationwide this year, expanding the chain to 582 outlets.
Pier 1 is seeking new customers in new markets, but it also hopes to attract many of the same customers it had in the past - only now they have established careers and higher incomes. 
''These buyers, and there are a lot of them - about 79 million out of 230 million Americans - have about 67 percent of the discretionary income in this country,'' said Clark A. Johnson, chairman and chief executive of Pier 1. ''But they are hardly captive customers. We sell wants, as opposed to needs, so we have to earn our way into their hearts and pocketbooks.''
The new outlet in Manhattan is similar to the nearly 300 that Pier 1 has opened since 1985, when Mr. Johnson joined the company and began to spruce up its image. With an all-glass exterior that exposes two floors of merchandise to the street, the new store is bigger and more elegant than those opened before 1986.
Only one corner of the store is devoted to brass and wicker from Asia, a predominant offering in the early stores that appealed to college students in the 1960's and 70's. The rest of the space is filled with lamps, tableware, ceramics, rugs and sportswear.
While the company views department stores and large specialty stores as its main competitors, its outlets sell many of the same items as chains like the Pottery Barn and Conran's.
The repositioning has made Pier 1 one of the most closely watched and respected retail stocks on Wall Street. Today, the average customer spends $25.44 on a visit to a Pier 1 store, up from $17.46 a few years ago. In the last five years, the company's net income has grown almost 34 percent, compounded annually, and its sales have risen 24.4 percent a year.
For the fiscal year ended March 3, 1990, the chain earned $25.5 million on sales of $516.9 million. Its 5.5 percent profit margin on sales compares with the industry average of 3.5 percent.
With continued expansion, Mr. Johnson predicted, sales should double again by 1996. ''By the end of fiscal 1998,'' the tall, confident Mr. Johnson insisted, ''we will have opened our one-thousandth store.''
Analysts are impressed with the improvements. ''The company's merchandising prowess and consumer franchise are vastly stronger than they were in 1986,'' said Donald I. Trott, a specialty retail analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds in New York.
While Kenneth M. Gassman Jr., an analyst at Wheat First Securities in Richmond, views the company as a ''high-growth retailer,'' he is cautious about whether it would thrive in a recession.
''Our only major concern is that Pier 1's merchandise appears to fill discretionary consumer needs,'' he said. ''Therefore, in an economic slowdown, it is possible that Pier 1 would feel a negative impact.''
But Mr. Gassman promptly added, ''Pier 1 targets a higher-income consumer who traditionally has not cut back on overall spending in prior economic slowdowns.''
Pier 1 now aims at a customer whose average family income is $50,000 a year. For years, the family income of its average customer was $39,000 a year.
 
Began in California
Conceived as an importer of inexpensive merchandise called Cost Plus, the company was formed in 1962 with a single store in San Mateo, Calif., featuring mostly wicker and rattan furniture. Charles Tandy, the founder of the Radio Shack chain, had made a loan to a rattan furniture wholesaler who owned a store by that name, and in return received the rights to operate shops under the name. The company expanded to 16 stores within three years.
To express the stores' exotic foreign flavor, the company changed its name to Pier 1 Imports - a name picked in a contest for store managers.
In 1966, the Tandy Corporation sold Pier 1 to a management group. The new owners continued to expand the business, and in 1970 made the 42-store chain, concentrated in the West and Southwest, a public company. Intermark Inc. purchased 58 percent of its shares and is still the biggest shareholder, with a 51 percent share.
While Pier 1's formula worked well in the 60's and 70's, it proved less successful in the 80's. Its core following, the college students of the 60's and 70's, had tired of Pier 1's inexpensive merchandise.
In 1985, management hired Mr. Johnson in hopes of putting the company back on track. Pier 1 was then operating 265 stores, each contributing almost $1 million in annual sales, and net profits were $15 million.
Mr. Johnson, who has an entrepreneur's flair and a salesman's pitch, had been honed in the highly competitive home-improvement sector - he is a former top executive of the Wickes Companies, and later as a partner of Jack Nicklaus in a sporting-equipment company.
 
Sought Advice of Customers
Mr. Johnson attacked the problems of Pier 1 head-on, by starting a series of consumer ''focus groups'' in five cities. Looking back on those discussions, in which customers were asked their perceptions of the stores and how they could be improved, Mr. Johnson said, ''They set the course for us.''
The consumers said they wanted larger stores, where it would be more convenient to see and handle the goods. They liked the merchandise, they said, but would pay more for higher-quality, more fashionable goods. Despite the popularity of shopping malls, they said they preferred free-standing stores for their convenience and ease of parking.
Putting many of these suggestions to work, Mr. Johnson urged his buyers to pick better goods and bring in additional foreign suppliers. (Today there are 44.) He also insisted that new stores be more accessible, with wider aisles and shorter shelving. Indeed, today's stores average 9,000 square feet, double the size of those opened before 1985. The company has been closing older stores and replacing them with larger ones.
 
New Policy on Returns
Hoping to insure customer satisfaction, he took the unusual step of giving store managers complete authority in handling returned goods, even on sales made months earlier. ''I know that some customers take advantage of us,'' Mr. Johnson said, ''but we feel it is a worthwhile public-relations effort on our part.''
The real test has been in the financial results, which have steadily improved. Pier 1's stock closed yesterday at $11.375 a share, down 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. It has traded as high as $13.25 a share this year, and as low as $9.50.
''We look favorably on the company's stock,'' said Mr. Trott of Dean Witter. ''We estimate 1990 earnings of 90 cents a share, and $1.10 a share in 1991, against 1989's 71 cents a share.''

HEADLINE: Dow Falls by 34.95 in Fourth Straight Loss

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
The slide in stock prices extended to a fourth day yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average fell sharply, dropping 34.95 points, to 2,862.38. The blue-chip index is now down by 72.81 from its historic high on Monday and off 38.69 from last Friday's close.
The industrial average finished the week with some computerized sell programs magnifying the trend downward in relatively light trading. Retail and technology stocks were among the weaker groups. 
The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was also off, by 4.44 points, to 358.71. Declining issues outnumbered gainers, by 1,010 to 458. Volume reached 142.6 million shares, down from 160.4 million on Thursday.
''It was a sleepy market, with not a lot of volume and no conviction on the downside,'' said Tracy G. Herrick, an economist at Jefferies & Company. Soft bond prices contributed to the weakness.
Bernard Spilko, senior vice president at Bank Julius Baer in New York, said there was little news to move stocks and the fact that the Dow closed below the 2,900 mark on Thursday ''was mentally a little upsetting and that is just feeding on itself.''
Some advisers have been telling clients to sell some of the major stocks as overvalued, he said. A favorite, Walt Disney, for example, dropped 4 7/8, to 123 3/8.
Some other big stocks with losses were Eastman Kodak, off 3/4, to 41 3/4; Philip Morris, 5/8, to 44 1/4; Coca-Cola, 1/2, to 44 1/4; Procter & Gamble, 1 5/8, to 80; Merck, 1 1/2, to 80, and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, 1 1/8, to 82 7/8.
Financial stocks were mostly lower as enthusiasm about the possibility of lower interest rates waned. Among money-center banks, BankAmerica dropped 1/2, to 32; Citicorp, 1/8, to 24; Manufacturers Hanover, 7/8, to 36 5/8; J. P. Morgan, 5/8, to 37 3/4, and Chemical Banking, 1/8, to 28 3/8.
Mortgage issues also slipped. Federal Home Loan Mortgage (Freddie Mac) fell 1 1/8, to 78 1/2, and Federal National Mortgage (Fannie Mae), 1/2, to 42 1/8.
Several analysts said that bearish comments by Barton Biggs, Morgan Stanley's investment strategist, helped to dampen the market.
Looking ahead, Mr. Herrick of Jefferies said that next week was a big week for economic numbers and there was a hint that they could hurt the market. The Producer Price Index is scheduled to be issued Thursday, followed by the Consumer Price Index and industrial production figures on Friday.
The economist said these statistics might show an upturn in inflation, giving the Federal Reserve more reason to hold credit tighter.
 
Sell Programs Cause Drop
In yesterday's trading, four sell programs pushed the market down, said Birinyi Associates, a research firm. The largest sell program started at about 10 A.M. and pushed the market down 15.77 points in 15 minutes. Another took place starting at 1:12 P.M. and took 12.62 points. One buy program pushed the market up by 3.15 points.
Among computer stocks, I.B.M. fell 1 7/8, to 118 3/4. despite reiteration of a Paine Webber buy recommendation by an analyst, Stephen Smith. He said I.B.M. had aggressive plans for its mainframe computer business.
 
Microsoft Rises by 1 1/2
Apple Computer, trading over the counter, lost 3/4, to 38 1/4. Sun Microsystems also was down 3/4, to 30 5/8, and Compaq Computer fell 2 5/8, to 119 1/8. Microsoft, however, rose by 1 1/2, to 73 1/2.
Among retail stocks, the Gap continued to drop as analysts expressed unhappiness with its May sales figures. It lost 2 3/8, to 56 1/8. Melville dropped 1 1/4, to 50 1/4; the Limited lost 1, to 46 3/8; Dillard Department Stores fell 2 5/8, to 85 1/4, and Home Depot was off 5/8, to 56 3/4.
Conagra, the big agricultural company and food processor, added 1 1/4, to 33 1/4, a day after it announced plans to buy Beatrice Foods.
Maytag jumped 2, to 19. The appliance company said it did not comment on unusual activity in its stock.
The Amex market-value index sank 2.40, to 361.17. The Nasdaq composite index fell 3.22, to 460.87.

HEADLINE: New Disputes Threaten Pact on U.S.-Japan Trade

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 8

 BODY:
Negotiations between Japan and the United States to conclude a major trade agreement before an economic summit meeting in Houston next month may be derailed by a struggle within the Japanese Government and resistance to American demands for more specific commitments, people on both sides of the talks said today.
Japanese and American negotiators warned that failure to meet the summit deadline - a possibility seriously mentioned today for the first time - might have high political costs. It could sour relations between the countries just after they had again begun to warm and possibly set off a new round of protectionist legislation in Congress.
An American official involved in the discussions described them as ''close to a crisis,'' while Taizo Watanabe, the Foreign Ministry's chief spokesman, complained that American demands ''are rather embarrassing to us.'' 
 
Main Sticking Point
''The United States does not understand how much effort we have exerted,'' Mr. Watanabe told reporters.
Several issues separate the two countries, but the main sticking point is an American demand that Japan commit itself to spending a fixed percentage of its gross national product within Japan on projects like new bridges, roads, sewage plants and public housing.
The American aim is to narrow the gap between what the Japanese save and what the country invests. Many economists maintain that that would reduce the country's trade surplus by creating a better balance between what Japanese companies produce and what Japanese consumers buy.
Japan spent the equivalent of 6.7 percent of its gross national product on public works last year, and the Americans are now demanding at least 9 percent. Negotiators said the Japanese Finance Ministry was refusing.
 
Friction Between Ministries
A Japanese official said there was fear of being held to a fixed percentage of public investment in an uncertain economic climate. But another official conceded that part of the reluctance stemmed from longstanding rivalries between the Finance Ministry and other ministries that would benefit from a new flood of domestic spending, like the Construction and Transportation ministries.
The impasse has come in talks designed to remove what are believed to be fundamental structural barriers that have created the yawning American trade deficit with Japan - $49 billion last year. The talks are a novel approach to trade frictions, concentrating on broad and presumably deeper-seated problems than on the traditional approach of focusing narrowly on specific markets where trade restrictions are believed to exist.
On April 5, participants produced a long interim report after lengthy talks in Washington. That report seemed to resolve most of the basic issues by pledging Japanese business practices that would be more open and more fair to foreigners. The final report, for what is known as the Structural Impediments Initiative, was expected to be concluded in a meeting on June 25 and 26 in Tokyo.
 
Timing of Summit Meeting
That would have allowed Japan and the United States to issue the final report before the economic summit meeting of the leaders of the seven leading industrialized democracies, to be held in Houston in early July.
The first sign of serious problems came late last month at a meeting in Hawaii. American negotiators said they began to feel that their efforts to ''add flesh'' to the principles outlined in the interim report were going nowhere.
Meanwhile, disputes broke out on the Japanese side, with the Finance Ministry fighting the effort to set a specific amount for public investment, a matter on which the Foreign Ministry and the Ministry of International Trade and Industry were willing to concede, Japanese officials said.
 
I.M.F. Report Is Cited
Finance Ministry officials have gone out of their way in recent weeks to use a recent International Monetary Fund report to argue that Japan must maintain moderate surpluses to help pay for the reconstruction of Eastern Europe and the development of the third world. The United States has rejected this view, but it is now at the heart of the trade dispute.
President Bush and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu had a telephone conversation at the beginning of the week to discuss the outcome of President Bush's summit meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, sources on both sides have said. At that time, President Bush raised the trade problems, and reportedly urged Mr. Kaifu to use his influence to bring about an agreement or risk another breach in relations.
Asked about that conversation by Japanese reporters today, Mr. Kaifu was said to have retorted, ''I am exerting leadership without having to be told to do so, and am doing my job to the utmost.''
An American official said that these are among a range of issues on which there is still a gap between Japan and the United States:
* The United States is pushing for Japan to detail the increased penalties it had promised to impose on those found guilty of violating antitrust laws.
* The Americans have asked for quarterly reports monitoring progress in carrying out the changes Japan has agreed to, a frequency Japan has refused.
* Japan is reportedly resisting American demands that Japanese bureaucrats produce in writing all of their ''administrative guidance,'' an informal means of forcing companies to hew to Government policies. The Americans are seeking to make it easier to trace and discuss this guidance.
Finally, the Japanese are reportedly reluctant to create an interagency board of Government and business leaders to promote imports and open Japan's ports, airports and other facilities to more imports.

HEADLINE: Prices of Long-Term U.S. Bonds Ease

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of long-term Government securities eased yesterday, but the market in shorter Treasury maturities was essentially unchanged in unusually lackluster trading. One reason was the absence of any significant economic news.
The fixed-income market showed little response to the weakness in the stock market because, dealers said, they found little interest in Treasury bills, which usually benefit from any ''flight to quality.'' 
Another reason for the bond market's inertia, dealers said, was the reluctance of investors and traders to take positions before the flood of economic data due out late next week.
 
Biggest Move by Long Bonds
As it was, the usually volatile Treasury long bond, which serves as a bellwether of long-term fixed-income maturities, showed the largest price move. The 8.75 percent Treasury bonds maturing in 2020 were being offered late in the day at a price of 103 13/32, off 5/32 on the day. This raised the long bond's yield to 8.43 percent, compared with 8.42 percent the day before and 8.44 percent a week ago.
The Treasury's long notes, the 8 7/8 percent issue due in 2000, slipped by 4/32, to 102 24/32, to yield 8.46 percent. By comparison, the yield on 10-year Japanese Government bonds, Tokyo's longest maturity, was 7.02 percent. The yield on the also closely watched 10-year West German bonds was 8.82 percent. The yields on all three 10-year maturities were basically steady for the week.
Among the shorter Treasury issues traded in the secondary market, the 8.5's of 1992 were unchanged at 100 10/32, to yield 8.32 percent; the 8.5's of 1995 dipped 2/32, to 100 10/32, for a yield of 8.41 percent. 90-Day Rate Unchanged The discount rate on the Treasury's 90-day bills was unchanged at 7.71 percent; six-month bills rose four basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.64 percent, and the one-year bills edged up a basis point, to 7.52 percent.
''We believe next week's flow of Government economic statistics will be negative on balance for the fixed-income market,'' said Steven R. Ricchiuto, chief economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities Inc. ''The data will probably show that the economy is not as weak as many think, but the numbers will also support policy makers at the Fed who remain concerned about inflation. Both factors are negative for the fixed-income market.''
Consequently, Mr. Ricchiuto and his staff do not believe the Federal Reserve will be inclined to move interest rates either way. ''Recently, interest rates have declined because the market expected the Fed to cut rates in order to resuscitate the economy,'' he said. Technical Move by Fed The Fed did intervene in the credit markets to add reserves to the banking system over the weekend in what analysts interpreted as a technical move. This was borne out by the steady Federal funds rate that banks charge each other for temporary loans. The funds traded all day at 8.25 percent, which is widely believed to be the Fed's target for this key interest rate.
The economic reports due out next Thursday and Friday include last month's producer and consumer price indexes, industrial production and factory utilization rates, as well as the nation's merchandise trade balance and business inventories for April.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Gold Ends on a High Note; Dollar Advances Broadly

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold prices finished a sluggish week on an upbeat note yesterday, and the dollar ended the day stronger against major currencies.
Gold, which has been increasingly shunned by investors, may have hit bottom on Thursday when the price in London reached a four-year low at $351.50 in morning trading, one analyst said.
''I think if the market was going to break $350 it would have happened this week,'' said Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst at Paine Webber Inc. ''It was the perfect climate for the market to collapse and it didn't,'' he said, referring to reports Thursday of Middle East selling. 
Many traders fear Saudi Arabia has been selling large amounts of gold lately, leading to at least two sharp drops in recent weeks.
Bullion for current delivery rose $1.10, to $355.70 a troy ounce, on the New York Commodity Exchange. The Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $355.00 a troy ounce, up $1.40 from late Thursday.
Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $354.50 a troy ounce, from $354.15 late Thursday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $354, from $353 late Thursday.
Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose 39 cents an ounce, to 356.06 an ounce.
Silver bullion was quoted in London at $5.02 an ounce, up from $5.01 bid late Thursday. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, silver for current delivery slipped 0.6 cent to close at $5.007 a troy ounce.
The dollar was stronger as investors anticipated next week's economic reports. Many apparently felt the Consumer Price Index and Producer Price Index could show stronger inflation, which could lead to higher interest rates, said Robert Hatcher, corporate trader at Barclays Bank P.L.C. in New York.
The dollar began its trading day in Tokyo, rising 0.10 yen to a closing 152.65 Japanese yen. Later, in London, it was also quoted higher at 153.48 yen, and in New York, it rose to 153.49 yen, from 152.55 late Thursday.
In London, the dollar rose against the British pound, which was quoted at $1.6843, compared with $1.6880 late Thursday. In New York the pound also dropped against the dollar, falling to $1.6840, from $1.6895 on Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday's late rates, included: 1.6975 West German marks, up from 1.6930; 1.4495 Swiss francs, up from 1.4445; 5.7145 French francs, up from 5.7035; 1,248.00 Italian lire, up from 1,244.75, and 1.1743 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16975.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's levels, included: 1.6973 West German marks, up from 1.6913; 1.4480 Swiss francs, up from 1.4385; 5.7155 French francs, up from 5.6993; 1.9088 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9028.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe: East Berlin Journal;
A First U.S. Visit, and Maybe a Last

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST BERLIN, June 5

 BODY:
For Lothar de Maiziere, the idea that he is about to be the first East German leader to visit the United States is not really that extraordinary.
''Everywhere I travel it's for the first time,'' said the former orchestra musician who emerged as much to his own surprise as anyone else's as the first democratically elected Prime Minister of East Germany. ''After all, I'm a citizen of the German Democratic Republic and always have been.''
The statement played both on the fact that East Germany's former Communist leaders were not widely welcomed in the West and that for ordinary citizens, Western travel used to be a rare privilege. 
Mr. de Maiziere is to make his first trip to the United States on Saturday, after a visit to Moscow to talk with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The East German leader will see President Bush in Washington on Monday, and before that he will be a guest at a banquet given by the World Jewish Congress in New York.
The paradox of the breakthrough -a paradox that accompanies most of what Mr. de Maiziere does - is that his many firsts are likely to be lasts. If German unification proceeds at the pace set so far, he may also prove to be the last East German leader to pay an official visit.
 
Enjoying Contradictions
A refined man who came to law and then to politics after an ailment forced him to abandon his career as a professional violist, Mr. de Maiziere, who is 50 years old, seems to enjoy the many contradictions that the role has thrust on him.
''If someone had told me a year ago that I would be sitting here with you in this role, I would have called him an idiot,'' he said in an interview in the Prime Minister's office of the Council of Ministers building.
A year ago, in fact a half-year ago, this was the realm of Willi Stoph, one of the old-guard Communists who ran East Germany with an iron hand under Erich Honecker. In the lobby, the old Communist emblem was still there only a week ago.
The pace of change has been Mr. de Maiziere's greatest challenge. His own rise is a case in point: he came to office largely because the old Christian Democratic Party in East Germany, tainted by its long association with the Communists, had no one else with any credibility last fall to make its leader. Then, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany decided to throw his formidable political weight behind the Christian Democrats in the East German elections in March.
But to the surprise of many in East and West, Mr. de Maiziere has shown an unexpected degree of independence and political skill. He has succeeded in resisting Mr. Kohl's pressure for moving up all-German elections to December without creating a split.
''In my party and my Government, we have always said that unification will have to come as soon as possible, but also as well as possible,'' he said. ''Now we have taken a big step forward with the treaty on economic, currency and social union, and we have to make as many laws as some parliaments write in a whole term. And people have to learn how to follow these laws.''
''The day has only 24 hours in the G.D.R., and I can assure you we cannot tackle the problems of unification any more quickly,'' he added.
 
Seeking U.S. Investment
In talking of his trip to the United States, Mr. de Maiziere is distinctly a lobbyist for his country. ''We hope that we can meet with representatives of American industry during the visit,'' he said. ''You know that our country faces great economic problems and that now, with the state treaty we signed with West Germany, we are creating a legal order that allows favorable investments for those who are interested.''
The economic problems that Mr. de Maiziere referred to are a matter of dispute. The economic unity scheduled for July 1 is expected to sound the death knell for many antiquated East German industries, leaving hundreds of thousands of workers without jobs. Some politicians have warned of major social unrest once the difficulties of union set in next fall.
Mr. de Maiziere sought to play down the threat, but also to blame the former Communist Government for any troubles.
''I think that with the measures we have decided on now there will not be a 'hot autumn,' but at most a warm one,'' he said. ''We do not want to underestimate the difficulties we are facing, but we do not want to dramatize them either.
''We have to make clear that problems, when they come about, are the aftershocks of socialism, and not the first shocks of the new market economy. We will not stand trial for thing we have not done.''
The main issue that Mr. de Maiziere is likely to confront in his foreign talks is the debate of the future Germany's place in European security arrangements. The issue was left essentially unresolved in talks between Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Bush last week.
 
Caution on NATO Issue
Mr. de Maiziere seemed to take extra care in discussing the problem so as not to be seen as criticizing the Soviet Union, which still has 350,000 troops stationed in East Germany.
''The Soviet Union makes it clear again and again that in the process of German unification, their legitimate security interests have to be maintained and that this would not be the case if a unified Germany became a member of a structurally unchanged NATO,'' he said.
Moscow has rejected Western demands that a united Germany belong to NATO, and has proposed instead the creation of a pan-European security system, possibly in the framework of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, in which all European and North American nations take part. In the interim, some Soviet troops are expected to remain in Germany.
Mr. de Maiziere indicated that he did not expect the Soviet Union to delay reunification if talks between the wartime Allies and the German states found an acceptable formula.
''We think also that we can recognize after talks with the Soviet side that the Soviet Union aims for an all-European collective security system in the frame of the C.S.C.E., and that transitional solutions are no longer the main problem, if you make it clear that this is in a time framework,'' the Prime Minister said.
''There must not be a solution so that those who say Gorbachev lost World War II would not be proven right,'' he added.

GRAPHIC: Photo: ''Everywhere I travel it's for the first time,'' said Lothar de Maiziere, who was elected Prime Minister of East Germany in March. He is to be the country's first leader to visit the United States. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Needed: A Tough Exec for Two States

 BODY:
Running the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is one of the most challenging executive jobs in government. The Port Authority's operations are vast and so is its impact on the region's economy. It oversees airports, commuter rail systems, bus terminals and bridges; runs container ports and the World Trade Center, and deals with airline executives and commuters. It pays for all its own operations.
The impending departure of Stephen Berger, the Port Authority's executive director since 1985, presents the two states' Governors, Mario Cuomo of New York and Jim Florio of New Jersey, with the formidable task of finding a highly qualified successor.
Overseeing so complex an organization demands political, financial and managerial skills that are hard to find in the best of times. And now is not the best of times. The Northeast's troubled economy will make it even harder for the Port Authority's next director to win political support for toll and fare increases. Such increases are unpopular. They're also critical to the Port Authority's fiscal integrity and to the completion of Mr. Berger's ambitious $6 billion capital plan.
Mr. Berger was successful partly because he understood the Port Authority's many constituencies. He was comfortable with the private sector and the political establishment; his successor will need to be just as comfortable in both worlds. Other requirements are experience in managing a very large staff, and skill as a conciliator and firm bargainer.
Because the Port Authority's board chairman, Richard Leone, is from New Jersey, the next executive director will likely be a New Yorker. That gives Governor Cuomo a greater say in the selection, but both states need a choice of distinction.

HEADLINE: Florio's Puzzling 'Vision' for New Jersey

BYLINE: By Chuck Hardwick; Chuck Hardwick, Republican of Union County, is a member of the New Jersey State Assembly.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
When you put together a puzzle, no one piece gives you the whole picture. But piece by piece the puzzle becomes clearer, until the picture is complete.
Gov. Jim Florio says he has a vision for New Jersey; piece by piece he is assembling it, and the picture of his vision for the state is becoming clearer. As a state legislator for 13 years and former Assembly speaker, I can see a distinct pattern - and I believe that the future of New Jersey's middle class is in jeopardy. 
The first piece of the puzzle is the so-called auto insurance reform bill. The Governor calls the bill ''The Fair Automobile Insurance Reform Act.'' But the act isn't reform and it certainly isn't fair.
It only shifts costs and adopts a new criterion for rating the risks of drivers. But that criterion will result in low-risk drivers (senior citizens, married couples, women, suburbanites) subsidizing high-risk drivers (young, single males, particularly those in the inner cities).
The Florio administration already admits that insurance companies, after onerous state surcharges are eliminated, may raise rates to make up any losses. So the $212 per car surcharge will be gone, but the companies will raise basic rates the same amount to make up the difference.
The second piece of the puzzle, the Governor's tax package, hits the middle class especially hard. It will make New Jersey's income tax the second-highest in the country and bring a 17 percent hike in the sales tax to consumers.
It will also eliminate homestead rebates and property tax reductions. These will add substantially to the total tax burden of all New Jerseyans, but especially working families and singles.
The Governor says with pride that his is a progressive tax proposal, that the bulk of the added taxes will be paid by the ''wealthy.'' The trouble is that he is having a tough time defining what he means by ''wealthy.''
First he told us that families with an income over $55,000 were among New Jersey's richest. But the 300,000 New Jerseyans who work in New York, pay taxes there and will pay the new, higher New Jersey Transit fares proposed by the Governor know that $55,000 in family income does not make them rich by any means.
Then Governor Florio defined ''wealthy'' as a single person earning $35,000 or more - with no regard for whether the person was a parent.
The final piece of the puzzle came last week: the distribution formula for aid to education. The Governor plans to cut aid to suburban communities - so-called high-income communities. Bergen County, for example, will lose more than $100 million in school aid. The Governor's goal is to direct more aid to cities such as Camden, which would receive an additional $45 million in school aid. The plan is partly based on the belief that all residents in ''high-income'' communities have high incomes.
Unfortunately, that's simply not true. The selective aid cut will result in an increase in taxes and a reduction in municipal services for property owners regardless of income. The Governor's plan will have exactly the opposite impact that he desires: Lower-and middle-income families will no longer be able to afford to live in suburban communities.
The cumulative effect of higher transportation costs and taxes and reduced aid will result in a massive redistribution of wealth. That's a philosophy that failed and was discredited in Massachusetts and New York a decade ago and has been discarded by the Eastern Bloc countries.
Wealth-redistribution schemes stifle economic growth. The plan proposed by Governor Florio will hurt the people of New Jersey in the decade ahead. Why would a start-up business want to locate in a non-competitive environment? It wouldn't.
What New Jersey needs are policies that attract economic activity and build a bigger economic pie so that all can benefit. Our state urgently needs policies that encourage growth through low taxes and a favorable climate for new jobs.
Of course, the missing piece of the puzzle is the voice of the taxpayers. In the weeks ahead, they could very well overturn the Governor's puzzling vision for New Jersey.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD;
Paying for Electric Power by the Time of Day

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
A growing number of consumers are paying a price for electricity based on the time of day they use it.
Utilities, either on their own or on the orders of regulators, are merging the clock and the electric meter to create ''time-of-day'' pricing. The idea is to make the price reflect production cost, which also varies by time of day.
In Maryland, Minnesota, New York, Ohio and other states, utility companies are picking up an idea that has been practiced by airlines and long-distance phone companies for years. The goal is to spread demand over all hours of the day and to make better use of expensive generating equipment that, in the current use pattern, often sits idle. 
Meeting everyone's needs when demand reaches its peak is an especially severe problem for power companies because the costs of building and maintaining generating equipment is very high. Manufacturers solve the problem by building up a surplus of their product in off-peak periods, but electricity cannot be stored; it must be produced at the instant the consumer wants it.
 
A Decades-Old Method
Utilities, using a system called ''economic dispatch,'' run their cheapest generators continuously, and start up the more expensive ones as demand increases. Thus at 2 A.M. a utility might meet all its needs from a hydroelectric dam that produces power for 2 cents a kilowatt-hour. But on a summer afternoon when every air-conditioner is running, demand would be so high that the utility would use its most expensive generators, perhaps an oil-fired plant where electricity cost 8 cents a kilowatt-hour.
Under the traditional pricing system that has been used for decades and is still by far the predominant system for residential use, customers are charged the same amount, a standard rate, for all hours. There is increasing interest among utilities and state governments in promoting more efficient use of electricity.
Primarily because of the increasing use of air-conditioners in summer and heat pumps in winter, the demand during peak hours is growing strongly in many parts of the country, and few utilities have much spare capacity or plants under construction. Shifting peak demand to off-peak hours could save millions of dollars in construction costs for new plants, experts say - costs that are eventually passed on to consumers.
''The purpose of the time-of-use rate is to give an improved price signal,'' said Charles J. Roncaioli, manager of rate analysis at Northeast Utilities of Berlin, Conn. He meant that under this new system, the consumer is now told what the product costs to make at various hours of the day. ''An economist would expect a customer would react and shift load to other periods of the day,'' he said.
Northeast implemented such rates in Connecticut a decade ago with mixed results. The company found that customers either could not or would not shift activities like running a clothes washer or dryer, a dishwasher or an oven to off-peak hours.
Technological changes are making such rates easier to implement. Clock meters have been used in homes for more than a decade, but are getting more sophisticated. For example, DPL Inc., the company that owns Dayton Power and Light, of Ohio, builds meters with microprocessors that can be read automatically by a central computer at the utility over the customer's telephone line. Other companies are using meters that can be controlled by radio signals.
In New York State, the Public Service Commission has ordered that time-of-day rates for residential customers be phased in, beginning with the biggest customers. For Consolidated Edison Company of New York, for example, beginning in January 1992 time-of-day rates will be required for homes that used more than 4,000 kilowatt-hours in a summer month in 1988. In practical terms, that means a very big house with a high air-conditioning load.
Homes that used between 3,000 and 4,000 kilowatt-hours will follow in January 1993, and then homes using more than 2,500 kilowatt hours in January 1994.
For Con Ed, electricity used between 8 A.M. and 10 P.M. weekdays will be billed at about 27 cents per kilowatt-hour; from 10 P.M. to 8 AM, and on weekends, the charge wil be three to five cents.
About 700 volunteers are already on the system and have cut their costs about 10 percent, according to the company.
In New Jersey, about 40,000 residential customers pay on a time of use basis. As in New York, the system is mandatory for large users and voluntary for smaller ones.
Public Service Electric and Gas has three rates, peak, off-peak and intermediate. The price spread is as large as 15 cents per kilowatt-hour in summer.
The system does not reduce total energy use among residential customers, according to Con Edison. But it can shift use. A study of a two-year experiment in time-of-day rates at Pacific Gas & Electric Company of San Francisco published earlier this year in The Energy Journal, an academic publication, found that participants in that voluntary program moved 21 percent of their electric use between noon and 6 P.M. to other hours of the day.
In contrast, Northeast's program was mandatory, and proved unsuccessful and unpopular. It was ordered by regulators for new houses with electric heat in a peak period defined as 8 A.M. to 8 P.M. People resented its mandatory nature, the company found, and customers did not shift much energy use. The price difference was small, about a penny a kilowatt-hour, or less than 20 percent, said Mr. Roncaioli, largely because Northeast has a relatively small difference in cost between peak hours and off-hours.
Faced with thousands of unhappy electric customers, Connecticut regulators allowed the company to make the program voluntary, Mr. Roncaioli said. Several hundred Connecticut households are still on the time-of-day rate, said Mr. Roncaioli, mostly childless couples who both work outside the home. Their use is mostly in off-peak times anyway. ''They save by doing nothing,'' he said.

HEADLINE: How the $8 Billion Space Station Became a $120 Billion Showpiece

SERIES: Big Science: Is It Worth the Price? - A periodic look at the largest new research projects.

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
America's planned space station, sold to Congress in 1984 as an $8 billion project, will actually cost at least $120 billion when operating and other expenses are counted, and even then it will not meet what has become the Government's top objective in space.
Achieving that goal, sending Americans to the Moon and Mars as planned by President Bush, would mean adding costly new elements to the station, or perhaps building a separate spaceport in orbit.
The 500-foot-long, 290-ton space station Freedom is planned as the centerpiece of the nation's program for the manned study of space. It is to be lofted piecemeal in the late 1990's.
 
'World's Greatest Invention'? 
Experts say its story is a case study in cost escalation, bureaucratic sleight of hand and the inflexibility that often plagues science projects when they reach giant proportions. Some experts even question its importance for the advancement of knowledge.
''It's advertised as the world's greatest invention,'' said Dr. James A. Van Allen, the University of Iowa physicist who discovered the earth's radiation belts. ''But its scientific uses are pretty dubious.'' Those uses, he went on, could easily be accomplished on ''a much less grandiose scale.''
Many scientists fear that in the competition for Federal dollars, the station will drain money from highly productive small-scale research, especially as its budget rises.
Frederick N. Khedouri, who was a White House budget official in charge of the space agency's budget in the Reagan Administration, said NASA officials had consistently underestimated the station's cost. ''They always talk about a stripped-down model that doesn't exist,'' he said.
Supporters admit that they are frustrated with the station's delay-ridden six-year history, in which much paper has been shuffled but nothing has been built and no science accomplished. ''We've spent $4 billion so far and there isn't a nut or bolt to show for it,'' said one supporter, Dr. Jerry Grey, director of science and technology policy for the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, the world's largest aerospace engineering society.
Current and former officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration dismiss much of the criticism as unfair. The station's cost may be high, they say, but it is a fair price to pay for the scientific and commercial benefits it promises. And while conceding that the program's management had problems in the past, they say that the station is now on track and that it can serve as a sound basis for a host of scientific and exploratory goals, including those of Mr. Bush.
''The station by its very design can be modified to suit a wide variety of missions,'' said Dr. Earle K. Huckins 3d, head of station engineering at NASA headquarters. ''It can evolve.'' Perhaps nowhere is enthusiasm for the station greater than at the National Space Society, a 30,000-member private group based in Washington that backed the idea before the Government did.
''This station suits us fine,'' said Lori B. Garver, the society's executive director. ''It's a first step on the road to space colonization. This station is critical to expanding the human presence into space.''
As now envisioned, the station will be an orbiting outpost in which astronauts fashion new materials, study the physics of fluids, grow crystals, perform medical experiments, scan the stars and examine the possibility of living in space for long periods. Most basically, it is seen as a bold venture for America that will have a host of scientific, economic and cultural payoffs throughout the 21st century.
This year's budget for the station is $1.8 billion, and the Bush Administration has requested $2.5 billion for next year. So far $3.9 billion has been spent on design studies and the building of prototype parts. By far, it is the most complex spacecraft NASA or anyone else has ever tried to build - five times as long and many times as sophisticated as the Soviet space station Mir, launched in 1986.
Starting in 1995, about 30 space shuttle flights are to carry aloft its trusses, solar power panels, supplies and nine pressurized modules in which astronauts would live and work. Assembly is to be completed in late 1999. The station would orbit about 250 miles from Earth and house as many as eight crew members.
 
Early Problems
Falling Morale, Rising Budgets
The space station's troubles can be traced to its earliest days, experts say. The main problem was that in the early 1980's the thing uppermost in NASA's mind was the decline in its ranks and budget since the Apollo era of sending astronauts to the Moon.
James M. Beggs, an aerospace executive who was NASA's director in the early 1980's, conceded that the station was seen as a way to help keep the agency in business. ''The feeling was that unless we could get a station, the manned activities would truncate and we'd run out of mission,'' he said in an interview.
Mr. Beggs said the agency rejected the idea of putting up small self-contained units that could be linked together and expanded, slowly achieving complexity - a method adopted by the Soviets. Instead NASA planned a single large unit that would function only when fully assembled.
Critics have faulted that decision, saying the emphasis on bigness was a political move to secure hefty budgets and a large political base. Ronald D. Brunner and Radford Byerly Jr., analysts at the University of Colorado, recently wrote in the journal Space Policy that the plan was driven less by a search for technical excellence than by a drive to ''meet NASA's own institutional needs and to secure program approval and survival.''
Mr. Beggs disputed that, saying the design was the best possible technical choice, both ''economic and utilitarian.''
Seeking support for its idea in Government, industry and the academic world, the space agency in the early 1980's said the station's large size would allow a variety of uses. But scientists themselves were often skeptical. President Ronald Reagan's own science adviser, George A. Keyworth 2d, told Congress in 1983 that a space outpost would be ''a most unfortunate step backwards.''
 
Costly Visions
How $8 Billion Grew and Grew
That counsel was ignored. Hans Mark, a former deputy adminstrator of NASA, wrote in his book ''The Space Station'' that Mr. Reagan was dazzled by the commercial possibilities of the project. In January 1984 the President called on the nation to build its first permanently manned space station ''within a decade,'' saying it would advance ''research in science, communications and in metals and life-saving medicines.''
Its price was put at $8 billion and the likely date of completion at 1992. But costly delays soon arose as new users, contractors and political supporters joined the cause.
''They made sure there was something in it for everybody,'' said John E. Pike, head of space policy at the Federation of American Scientists, a nonprofit policy group based in Washington.
Station development was seen as employing tens of thousands of people in more than a dozen states and scores of Congressional districts. And though it was the commercial possibilities that excited Mr. Reagan, NASA quickly planned to add elements that would expand the station's use as a base for planetary exploration.
 
The Vicious Cycle
Then came a vicious cycle of financial shortfalls that led to delays, delays that led to cost increases, increases that necessitated less costly new designs, and new delays.
In 1986 NASA acknowledged that the station's projected cost had nearly doubled to $16 billion. So in April 1987 the Reagan White House scaled back the plan. The smaller station was to cost $12.2 billion. But the price of the cutback was high - $2.2 billion for the new design, according to the Brunner-Byerly paper from the University of Colorado.
Lost in the cutback were the features that would have helped make the station into a spaceport - including the ability to service and fuel spacecraft, to construct large structures and to prepare for the staging of exploratory missions.
Even so, it was still big, ''about double what we started out with,'' said Mr. Beggs, the former NASA director, who had left the agency by then.
 
Skepticism, Then a Study
Skeptics in the executive branch doubted NASA's newly advertised price. So the National Academy of Sciences, the prestigious private society that advises the Government, was asked to study the problem. In September 1987 it gave the most thorough estimate to date of the station's construction costs. These ranged from $25 billion to $30 billion, including expenses (usually excluded by NASA) like ground operations, personnel and the lofting of station parts into space.
The academy report also warned, ''High space station operating costs could potentially absorb a significant portion of the civilian space budget.''
The General Accounting Office, an investigative agency of Congress, examined that issue, finding in May 1988 that annual operating costs could be $2.7 billion, or $81 billion over its 30-year lifetime. That figure included food, fuel and transportation to and from the outpost.
Last year, spending limits imposed by Congress again delayed the station, pushing back its completion to 1999 and driving up its cost. Malcolm Peterson, director of NASA's resources analysis, said the best current construction estimate was $37 billion, excluding science equipment to outfit the station. NASA will give no estimate of that cost; industry analysts say it will be many billions of dollars.
Mr. Beggs, the former NASA Administrator, said the station's overall cost was still reasonable, despite the increases.
''It's like building a house,'' he said. ''If you start to calculate what it's going to cost over a lifetime, to furnish it and heat it and operate it, you'd never buy it. The lifetime cost is very high. But you say, 'I want a house.' We wanted a space station.''
 
New Worries
Every Solution Is Expensive
Scientists, including some who receive grants from NASA, worry that the station has become so costly that it will siphon money from fundamental research in space science. Such a tradeoff clearly occurred in the 1970's and early 80's, in the $25 billion program to develop the space shuttle.
''I watched with great sorrow and frustration as NASA sacrificed the great American enterprise of robotic planetary exploration in its desperate attempt to make good on overblown shuttle expectations,'' Dr. Bruce Murray, former director of NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, wrote in his book ''Journey into Space.''
Last month, Dr. Athelstan F. Spihaus Jr., executive director of the American Geophysical Union, the world's largest society for the study of the earth and its space environment, last month warned Congress of the danger, adding that his group ''cannot justify'' the station on a scientific basis.
Dr. Spihaus said he knew of ''no other scientific society prepared to justify space station Freedom.''
Experts say other problems loom on the horizon. For instance, experts at NASA's Johnson Space Center in Houston worry that station repairs will be far greater than originally planned. Most solutions now under discussion involve money - improving parts to make them last longer, having advanced robots do repairs and developing a new generation of spacesuits to ease astronauts' chores.
 
Whirling Debris Up There
Another threat involves orbiting debris, including rocket parts. About 24,500 of these objects, as small as an aspirin or as large as an abandoned spacecraft, now whirl about the Earth, threatening the planned station with catastrophic damage, according to a recent G.A.O. report. Station designers, it said, ''greatly underestimate the seriousness of the debris environment.''
Again, solutions are expensive. Better shielding would increase the station's weight, driving up costs to transport it into space. NASA is also considering an on-board system to warn of impending collisions.
A different kind of danger involves a shuttle accident like the explosion that destroyed Challenger in 1986. If a shuttle were disabled or destroyed, the crew of the space station might have no way of getting back to Earth; depending on the damage, it could take months or even years to send another shuttle to rescue the astronauts. A shuttle catastrophe is considered statistically likely in this decade.
NASA's solution, still under study, is known as the Crew Emergency Return Vehicle. This capsule could return astronauts to Earth. Not yet part of the station budget, it might cost as much as $2 billion, said Mark Hess, a NASA spokesman.
 
Unanswered Questions
Moon and Mars: At What Price?
The biggest cost riddle of all involves the feasibility of making the station into a transportation hub from which Americans could go on to the Moon and Mars. To achieve this goal, a host of costly modifications would be needed, including powerful new solar collectors to nearly double the station's electric power, living areas for more crew members, and large new booms and hangars to assemble, store and service the exploration vehicles. Plans for such an expansion have yet to win approval.
Some experts question how well a bustling spaceport could coexist with delicate scientific tasks like growing crystals in near weightlessness. Now there is discussion of whether it might be better to build a separate spaceport.
Further modifications of space station Freedom would be needed to study ways to avoid the debilitating and possibly fatal effects of prolonged human exposure to zero gravity - a critical hurdle for astronauts making the long voyage to Mars. Soviet astronauts who have stayed aboard Mir for months have developed a variety of medical problems, some of them serious.
 
Unbearable Lightness
''The current design isn't up to it,'' said Dr. H. Guyford Stever, a former White House science adviser who was chairman of a recent National Academy of Sciences study of NASA's plans for the exploration of the Moon and Mars.
In March, Dr. Stever's report urged NASA to consider building devices in space to study artificial gravity on humans. For instance, a slowly spinning cabin would generate its own gravity through centrifugal force. Such research would help determine whether a slowly spinning Mars ship could keep astronauts fit by inducing a fraction of the earth's normal gravity.
NASA has no plans for such a research unit on the space station, although it is considering the addition of an eight-foot rotating drum where such studies could be conducted on rats.
 
Mixed Signals
Dr. Murray, a planetary scientist at the California Institute of Technology who was director of the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, advocates a manned mission to Mars. But he warns that the Federal Government is sending mixed signals on the issue of exploration. After years of turmoil in planning, he said, the station is so embattled that NASA dreads making any further design changes, especially ones that would sharply increase its cost.
''NASA is kind of ignoring Moon-Mars,'' he said in an interview. ''And the White House is plunging right ahead and ignoring the station. There's a disconnect developing, which I personally watch with anguish.''
Despite its formidable cost and other problems, many experts say the station will probably move forward to some level of completion, if not as a base for space exploration, by the sheer power of political momentum.
''It's going to get built,'' said Mr. Pike of the Federation of American Scientists. ''When you've got all those employees and contractors, and that big an operation at stake, a project has to be more obviously preposterous than the station in order not to happen.''
 
HIDDEN COSTS OF THE STATION
 
NASA's estimates for the cost of the space station often exclude the following: scientific equipment for the station's laboratories; the expenses of about 30 shuttle flights to loft parts and supplies during construction; dozens of dozens of gorund stations to train astronauts, prepare payloads and administer the project; salaries for personnel; food and supplies for crew members, and operating and maintenance expenses for the stations 30-year lifetime.

HEADLINE: In AIDS-Stricken Uganda Area, The Orphans Struggle to Survive

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MUTIKULA SOUTH, Uganda

 BODY:
Josephine Senyonga, a diminutive woman with decades of hard farm labor etched into her face, sat on the floor of her one-room house, surrounded by 12 grandchildren.
What in normal circumstances should have been a tableau of warmth was one of tragedy, repeated in thousands of houses and huts in a 30-mile swath from this village in Rakai County to Lake Victoria.
Mrs. Senyonga's three sons and three daughters-in-law died of AIDS last year and left her, a struggling 69-year-old widow, to care for their children.
In a grove of banana trees in her backyard, heaps of red pebbles, dappled with sunlight, mark the graves.
In another village closer to the lake, 70-year-old Salongo Mawawu looks after his 12 orphaned grandchildren. Six graves, five of them freshly dug, are at the side of his house, reminders to his grandchildren that their parents - teachers and traders - had died of AIDS. His last daughter, who is also a mother, is expected to die soon. 
 
A Disease Crueler Than War
The AIDS epidemic here is perhaps more haunting, more depressing than Africa's hard-case wars and famines. In war, the women and children are often spared. In famine, only segments of the population, the very young and the elderly, seem vulnerable.
In Rakai, a county of about 300,000, AIDS kills the breadwinners and leaves behind the most helpless: children.
From all the thousands of AIDS deaths of mothers and fathers, up to 40,000 children in the county have been are orphaned by a disease they understand to mean continual and uncurable sickness, uninterrupted mourning, daily funerals and impoverishment.
In many villages of Rakai, rows of houses stand silent, shuttered and abandoned, the parents dead and the children taken to usually less prosperous and aging grandparents.
''We are losing everyone,'' Mr. Mawawu said., after showing a visitor the graves in his garden.
Doctors here say that the transmission rate of AIDS from infected mother to baby - during pregnancy or while giving birth - is 30 to 50 percent, about the same as in the United States.
But since they have no measure of when mothers died or how old their children were when they died they cannot estimate, they say, how many of the surviving children in Rakai are infected with the virus.
The people of Rakai have always thought that AIDS, commonly known as ''Slims Disease,'' was different from malaria. For a long time they believed that AIDS afflicted those who stole or were ''bewitched'' by relatives.
 
Now They Know the Cause
Many now say they know it is caused by heterosexual transmission but seem unprepared to accept it. Elizabeth Nakabago, whose 52-year-old husband died of AIDS last year, appeared very thin. She felt well, she insisted. But a visitor from Kampala, the capital, said he had watched her deteriorate.
Scientists are studying why heterosexual transmission of the virus is such an important factor in Africa but have not yet reached any conclusions.
AIDS testing is virtually impossible for men and women deep in the villages. And as one man argued: ''Why should we have tests if you have no medicines to cure us.''
A member of Parliament from Rakai, Manuel Pinto, who organized a house-to-house survey recently, says there are about 40,000 children in Rakai who have lost one or both parents through AIDS.
An American statistician with the United Nations Children's Fund, Susan Hunter, reports 25,000 such children as of last fall but cautions that her figure was conservative even at the time.
In Uganda, an orphan is defined as a child who has lost one or both parents. In families where one parent has died, the grandparents commonly take charge of the children, particularly when the remaining parent moves away to try to remarry.
It is the question of how to lift the morale of these orphans in a country bereft of social services that Mr. Pinto and others are trying to grapple with.
 
The Background
 
War's Ravages And Now Disease's
 The Rakai district, an area of greenery and red soil, ravaged in the 1970's and early 1980's during the civil war, was the first place in Uganda to report cases of AIDS. Once a flourishing region of the Baganda Kingdom, railroads used to run to the lake shore. Crumbled milestones poking out of papyrus reeds attest to a road, now a potholed track barely suitable for bicycles, that once was alive with buses.
The area was neglected after independence from Britain. But during the 20-year civil war, the traders of Rakai prospered, buying soap, tires and beer from across the water in Tanzania and selling them to the capital, Kampala.
It was those who profited and led a high life who became the AIDS carriers and casualties, says Juvenalis W. Kibira, the deputy chairman of the orphans' organization of Rakai, which was founded last year by Mr. Pinto.
 
AIDS Spread From Area
After the first AIDS cases were reported in 1982 around Kasensero - the first known concentration of AIDS in Africa - the disease moved through Rakai county and then spread north to the entire country.
In Uganda as a whole, the figures are dramatic. Last December, the Minister of Health, Zak Kaheru, reported that 790,522 Ugandans had tested positive for the HIV virus and of these, at least 10,000 had developed the disease. The figures compiled for 1988 showed that, discounting children, about 1 in 8 Ugandans was infected.
In Kampala, the Health Ministry reported that 1 in 4 was infected. And in Rakai, new figures from a survey by the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta show that half the women at the trading posts are HIV positive.
The infection rate compares to a rate of 1 in 200 in the United States and 1 in 500 to a thousand in Britain, said Martin Foreman, director of the AIDS unit of the Panos Institute, a London-based group specializing in development issues.
Rakai remains the region in Uganda most affected by AIDS, with the death toll steadily rising after 1986. While the total number of deaths apparently leveled off last year, deaths among women are inexplicably increasing, according to Miss Hunter's figures. There are no precise figures on the total number of AIDS deaths.
 
The Despair
 
Parentless Children Survive on Own
 The despair in Rakai is evident in the almost universally sullen expressions of children almost uniformly dressed in ragged clothing. In some cases there are no guardians and they must fend for themselves. In one case, Mr. Pinto's group found five sisters and brothers cared for by the eldest, a 17-year-old. They cooked in an old paint can. Even in Rakai households where one parent has survived, there is no escape from the disease. In Kimote, a village along the road that rises from Lake Victoria, the chief, Leo Muddu, died of AIDS just before Easter.
On a recent Saturday afternoon, a visitor found one of the chief's sons, Munyumya, a vigorous boy of 14, at home. A 26-year-old sister died of AIDS two years ago. His mother and four brothers were away at an AIDS burial.
In a side room of the house lay his dying 26-year-old brother. When a European face appeared in the doorway, the young man, Tofa, pleaded in a scratchy voice for medicine. His left leg had a large sore, he was suffering from diarrhea and he had been unable to walk for a month. ''We are all dying. We are all dying,'' he whispered. ''I bring him water and juice,'' explained Munyumya.
 
Widow Cares for 9 Children
Up the track, Elizabeth Nakabago, a 49-year-old widow, was walking home from the burial rites of a girl of 17 who had died in childbirth, probably of complications arising from AIDS.Mrs. Nakabago's 52-year-old husband, part-owner of a bus in Kampala, came home to die last year, leaving her seven children aged 5 to 17. She also cares for two grandchildren left her by three of four grown sons and daughters who died of AIDS.
As in many homes, the inside of Mrs. Nakabago's one room showed remnants of a better past. A faded photograph of a fancy wedding, probably in the 1940's, hung on one wall. But now Mrs. Nakabago can only afford the $3 yearly school fees for two of the seven children. The rest stay home.
 
Medical Help
 
Basic Dispensary Almost Inaccessible
 Rakai County's medical services consist of a derelict dispensary and an overworked medical center on the most northern edge and thus inaccessible to most. The only two doctors in the county are posted there.
During an inspection of the dispensary one night, Mr. Pinto found the place in darkness because there were not even candles. Patients, women with young babies, sat on the veranda and three unattended babies slept inside. The senior officer, known as a medical assistant, who is trained in hygiene and no more, had left for home three days earlier.
The dispensary is supposed to receive four cartons of essential drugs a month from a Danish medical program but receives two - the contents of which are usually sold for profit by the staff, Mr. Pinto said.
 
Burdens of Debt and War
AIDS has hit Rakai and the rest of Uganda at a time when the Government of President Yoweri Museveni, trying to recover from 20 years of war, is strapped for cash. About 50 percent of the national budget is spent to fight rebels in the north. Most of the meager revenues that come from coffee are spent on repaying debts.
A tight economic reform program from the World Bank allows no room for social services: $1 a year per person is a generous estimate of the amount spent on medical services, some economists say.
Inadequate medical services and traditional inclinations not to trust them anyway, makes many AIDS sufferers in Rakai seek other means of treatment. Last year, thousands of AIDS patients flocked to a woman in neighboring Masaka County after she asserted that soil from a certain place, drunk with water, would cure AIDS. The government put an end to her practices but not before vast quantities of soil had been consumed.
More enduring is Brother Anatoli Wasswa, a Roman Catholic priest of Kyotera in Rakai who dispenses herbal medicine - bark, roots and leaves - to AIDS patients. On a recent day, a 24-year-old woman who had been diagnosed as being HIV positive a year ago, arrived for her first treatment.
''We treat each symptom differently, so you can give a person up to five different herbs,'' he said. He doesn't promise cure. ''But a person can live longer, to six months longer,'' he said.
 
The Future
 
Surveys Conducted But Not Much Else
 The future of the children in Rakai has caught the attention of various international aid groups. But so far, little other than surveys of the numbers of orphans has been accomplished.
This irritates the energetic Mr. Pinto who, like his wife, Marie, was born in Baloole, a village not far from the lake. A former manager of the Esso Oil Company, before he fled from Idi Amin into exile in Kenya for 10 years, he has founded the association to help the orphans, as well as the Rakai Development Association. The main challenge, says Mr. Pinto, is to show people hope.
''We have to persuade people to do something for themselves,'' he says. He believes it is paramount that the children stay in the area with relatives and not be transplanted to orphanages, as has been proposed by some groups.
In Ugandan culture, all adult members of a clan are responsible for the clan's children. ''Everyone in your clan is a mother or father,'' said Mr. Kibira. ''That's why we believe the orphans can be looked after in our homes. If you don't take an orphan then the spirit of a dead mother or dead father will come and curse. This strong force will make sure orphans are taken in.''
Already Mr. Pinto's association is paying the school fees - compulsory for Government schools in Uganda -of orphans who are doing well in school but whose guardians cannot afford the outlay. New classrooms have been added to Lugonza Primary School in the district; one day-care center for 30 children has been started.
Mr. Pinto plans to turn an overgrown plantation into plots for the unemployed young men who remain idle and set a depressing tone for the children. A clay brick-making factory to be run by women is also in the works.
And he is going to ask the multinational corportions that have remained in Uganda to pitch in. It would cost about $125,000 for 40,000 orphans to go to school for a year, he said.
''We need help now because a child of 8 will be 12 in four years time and a real social outcast if he hasn't been to school,'' Mr. Pinto said.
