HEADLINE: A Cafe Reopens: Lunch Returns to the Prairie

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOUISBURG, Minn., June 8

 BODY:
When Louisburg's last cafe closed its doors in 1988, Keith Hansen and John Lund and the other men who farm the rich, rolling prairies of western Minnesota found themselves confronting a new and lonely challenge: lunch.
Not only had they lost their midday refuge in town, a place to gather over coffee and talk prices and politics, but they had no one back at the house to cook for them either.
''My wife's got a job now,'' Mr. Lund said. ''So does Keith Hansen's and Spence's and Elmo's. You want to keep your farm these days, you need two incomes.'' $4,500 to Reopen the Doors So a few months ago, Mr. Lund and his neighbors near Louisburg did what seemed natural. Nearly 50 of them got together, raised about $4,500 in contributions and reopened the little cafe that has served this remote town of 60 residents since the turn of the century. 
For the farmers in Louisburg and other small towns across America, the cafe represents more than just a yearning for hearty home-cooked meals at noon, which the men say they do not have the time or the skills to make for themselves.
The campaign to reopen the cafe is a measure of the way in which the rhythms of rural life have changed.
More and more farm women now have jobs off the farm, forcing their husbands and their children to adapt to life in families in which both parents are wage-earners just as their counterparts have in the cities.
What has happened in Louisburg also reflects the concerns that are shared by residents of many small towns who have watched their communities wither away, bled by declining populations and failing businesses along Main Street.
''There is not much left here in Louisburg, but we're not ready just yet to let go of it,'' said Mr. Hansen, surveying the afternoon crowd in the cafe, where Emily Hansen, who is no relation, and her husband, Harold, were busy filling coffee cups and chatting up the customers. ''At least we managed to bring a little bit of action back to town.''
 
Creation of the Railroad
Like most places in the far reaches of western Minnesota and the Dakotas and Montana, Louisburg was a creation of the railroad, one of hundreds of small towns built at regular intervals along rail lines during the late 19th century so that nearby farmers could deliver a horse-drawn wagon of grain to the rail siding and be back home again by nightfall.
The grain elevator is still the town's biggest enterprise, and its most imposing structure. Its tin-sided towers dominate the long, low prairie horizon, and it is easily seen from several miles away.
But Louisburg, almost straight west from Minneapolis and close to the South Dakota border, is not on the railroad's main line. It is not even on some highway maps, since it is several miles from the nearest state road. Although the population nearly reached 100 in the 1950's, mostly the progeny of the Scandinavian and German farmers who first settled the area, it began slipping in the 1960's.
In the mid-1970's the farm implement dealership closed, and the town's only gasoline station shut its doors a decade later, along with the last grocery store. Except for two soda machines on the sidewalk in front of empty storefronts, the only retail commerce conducted along the main street these days is at the cafe.
 
Services Move Farther Away
Steve Padgitt, a sociologist at Iowa State University who specializes in rural areas, said residents of Louisburg were confronting a plight common to farm people throughout the region: as small communities and their populations have shrunk, services have been concentrated in fewer and more distant places.
''From the house where I was raised, I could always see the smoke from two or three other chimneys,'' Mr. Padgitt said. ''Now the countryside has thinned out so that people have to drive 10 miles to get their mail, or 30 miles to find a restaurant.''
When the old cafe closed in 1988, Mr. Lund said, it meant that he was traveling 10 miles to Madison, the closest town, to buy lunch. It was either that or make do alone at home. ''You can only eat Campbell's soup for so long,'' said Mr. Lund, whose wife, Nancy, works as a bank teller in Appleton, about 12 miles to the east.
As farm profits have declined in recent years, particularly among the operators of small family farms, both husbands and wives have been forced to seek work off the farm. A 1988 Agriculture Department survey estimated that 50 percent of all farm households had someone in the family who was working off the farm. As often as not it is the wife, as most farms are operated by men. In farm communities closest to urban areas, Mr. Padgitt said, some studies suggest that more than half the farm wives now hold jobs off the farm. In any case, sociologists say the number has been growing slowly but steadily over the years.
 
Offer From Former Resident
The idea of reopening Louisburg's cafe took root last December, when Catherine Wiese, who grew up in Louisburg but now lives in California, came home to visit her father. Since the cafe had closed her father, Arnold, an elderly widower, had lost a place to go for meals and companionship. She said she would help buy the cafe if others in the town could help fix it up and find someone to run it.
Mr. Lund and the men down at the elevator started taking up a collection, asking for donations of $50 or $100. ''The names on the list just kept coming and coming,'' Mr. Lund said. Some nearby banks and businesses contributed, too, and the local power company offered three months of free electricity.
Most of the work was done by Harlan Wiese, who is Ms. Wiese's cousin. Along with helpers, he tore out the interior of the old cafe, a one-story storefront, and put up plywood paneling and installed floor tiles and new kitchen equipment. Dining tables were ordered and a new menu board was mounted on the wall for notice of the dinner special, which costs $3.50 and changes daily. Today it was roast beef with mashed potatoes.
Then they painted the facade and put out an American flag and a sign that reads: ''Louisburg Cafe: Service with a Friendly Smile.'' At least that is what it was supposed to say: on one side the painter misspelled service as ''sevrice.''
 
Celebrating the Opening
The restaurant had its formal opening in mid-April. Toby Haug and His Playmores, a polka band from Madison, performed on the street out front, and most of the town turned out to dance and drink a little beer. Radio station KQLP from Madison broadcast live from the scene. So many people showed up to sample Mrs. Hansen's swiss steak that they had to wait in line for tables.
Since then, there have been some problems. The roof started leaking and the farmers had to go $4,000 into debt to replace it. Then the electrical system blew. Now they say they are going to have to install a new circuit box.
But Emily Hansen, who was managing a convenience store in Madison when she was asked to take on the cafe, says she and her husband, who had been laid off from his job, will stay on as long as they can. They work every day as it is, including Sunday, when the church crowd comes in for coffee.
''Even if we don't get rich, it's such a great feeling just to be here,'' said Mrs. Hansen, who had just finished baking a fresh batch of homemade doughnuts. ''Whatever else, we feel like we're helping to hold this little community together.''

Emily Hansen, who now runs the cafe, poured coffee for Lorraine Sorenson. (Steve Woit for The New York Times); map: Minnesota indicating Louisburg (The New York Times) (pg. 28)

HEADLINE: Peruvians Vote Today in Neck-and-Neck Runoff

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, June 9

 BODY:
After a bitter campaign, Peruvians go to the polls on Sunday to choose a President to lead them out of a decade of economic collapse and spreading guerrilla war.
Final opinion polls released Friday indicate a neck-and-neck race in the runoff election between Alberto K. Fujimori, an agronomist supported by the left, and Mario Vargas Llosa, the writer who advocates a free-market revolution.
''We have a statistical tie,'' said Manuel Torrado Bermejo, president of one polling organization, Datum. Mr. Torrado's survey gave the novelist 42.9 percent of respondents and Mr. Fujimori 41.5 percent. Another nationwide poll, by Apoyo, gave Mr. Fujimori a slight edge, 41 to 39 percent. In both polls, the remainder were undecided or planning to cast blank ballots. 
For the 10 million voters in this nation, South America's third largest and perhaps most troubled, the election comes after a punishing decade of economic and political mismanagement that stretched civic patience and civilian institutions to the breaking point.
''Peru is producing a situation very similar to Lebanon - polarization, a lack of political center, incapacity of consensus and a genuine collapse of the state,'' said Alfredo Barnachea, a member of Congress.
Prices have increased 1 million percent since the current President, Alan Garcia, took office on July 28, 1985. Also during the Garcia years, combined unemployment and underemployment climbed from 45 percent to 80 percent in Lima, home to one third of Peru's population of 22 million.
Mr. Vargas Llosa has proposed a detailed free-market ''shock'' program designed to bring Peru's 2,000 percent annual inflation down to 10 percent. The program calls for privatizing most of Peru's 200 state companies and for phasing out subsidies, tariffs and price controls. To ease the social costs of the transition, the writer called for an internationally fiananced $1 billion program to provide jobs, health care and food to Peru's poorest people.
Mr. Fujimori, who finished a strong second to Mr. Vargas Llosa in the first round of voting in April, espouses a more gradual version of Mr. Vargas Llosa's free market blueprint. But he opposes privatization and charges that his opponent's plan would throw millions out of work.
Mr. Fujimori's ''no shock'' anti-inflation formula calls for improving farm production and creating a new currency pegged to the United States dollar. The son of Japanese immigrants, Mr. Fujimori promised to attract millions of dollars in Japanese aid and investment. On voter worry lists prepared by pollsters, ''economic crisis'' is invariably followed by ''terrorism and subversion.'' In the 1980's, the Shining Path guerrillas spread from a mountain stronghold to carry out actions across the country. So far this year, more than 1,200 people are listed as having died in violence associated with the rebellion.
Mr. Vargas Llosa advocates giving the military better equipment and more political support for the counterinsurgency war. Mr. Fujimori advocates undercutting the rebellion with more social services - health clinics, schools, roads and higher prices for farm produce.
Although Peru is the world's largest source of coca leaf, the raw material for cocaine, Peruvian surveys list combating drug trafficking as the sixth most important priority. The illicit export is believed to infuse about $1 billion a year into Peru's economy.
Both candidates favor gradual crop substitution. Because of overproduction and disruption of flights to Colombian laboratories, price trends favor substitution. In the Upper Huallaga Valley, the main growing area, prices have dropped from $1.10 per pound of leaves a year ago to 35 cents today.
Complicating the election outcome will be Peru's tortoiselike vote count. Only on Friday, two months after the April 8 elections, did officials announce the winners of Lima congressional seats.
In Sunday's vote, some returns will be available on Sunday night. But the National Elections Board has warned that official results will be known only in early July.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Alarmed at Turn in Israel, Arabs Forecast War

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, June 9

 BODY:
Arab and Palestinian commentators responded today to the formation of a new, right-wing Israeli Government with forecasts of war, reflecting a mood across the region that blends apprehension, anger and a deepening hostility toward the United States, Israel's main supporter.
''It is a war Cabinet, the worst in Israel's history,'' Salah al-Khalaf, a senior Palestine Liberation Organization official, told reporters in Tunis, where the P.L.O. has its headquarters. He was referring to the announcement yesterday by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of the first coalition Government in Israel's history to be formed exclusively of right-wing parties.
Commenting on the new Government, one Jordanian newspaper, Sawt Al Shab, said the Arab world should ''brace for the ugly option of a new war imposed on the Arab nation. Praising peace does not mean dropping our weapons and burying our heads in the sand.'' 
 
Hostile Mood
Western diplomats said the Arab mood toward Israel and the United States was generally more hostile than it had been for many years. ''The situation is very dangerous,'' one said, speaking in return for anonymity.
An immediate focus of concern is the United States threat to break off its dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization over the group's refusal to condemn a seaborne raid on Israel on May 30. President Bush said on Friday that his Administration was considering a possible breach with the P.L.O. but had made no final decision.
Egyptian officials said President Hosni Mubarak and President Bush held a 15-minute telephone conversation on Friday and diplomats here said the Egyptian leader apparently urged Mr. Bush to avoid a complete break with the P.L.O.
 
Egypt on the Spot
Egypt is the United States' leading ally in the Arab world and the only Arab country at peace with Israel. It has sought to pursue moderating policies, but, with Arab frustration mounting over the failure of American efforts to set up direct Israeli-Palestinian negotiations, Cairo faces taunts from hard-line Arab governments that its diplomacy has gotten nowhere.
Yasir Abed Rebbo, who leads the P.L.O. side in the dialogue with the United States, said in Jordan that a break in the contact would ''encourage a fierce Israeli crackdown on the Palestinians'' who have been embroiled in a 30-month uprising in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.
The dialogue itself has been challenged by some Palestinians who say it has produced no results. But other Palestinians and Arab diplomats say Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman, wishes to retain it because it represents the only political gain secured since the start of the uprising in the occupied territories.
 
From Moderation to Belligerence
Diplomats here and elsewhere said that with the shift in mood away from avowed moderation, a shift confirmed at an Arab summit meeting in Baghdad, Iraq, last month that endorsed more bellicose tones, the region's confrontation could escalate.
In this atmosphere, the diplomats said, a break in the United States-P.L.O. dialogue could be taken by Arab and Palestinian hard-liners as proof of the futility of pursuing the diplomacy of peace and justification for new efforts to pursue armed actions against Israel.
Mohammed Abbas, leader of the P.L.O. faction that took responsibility for the May 30 attack near Tel Aviv, said in an interview published today that he planned further attacks using hang gliders.
''Who said the price of this dialogue was to halt armed struggle?'' he was quoted as saying by Sawt Al Shab. The P.L.O. draws a distinction between terrorism, which Mr. Arafat renounced in December 1988 as part of a deal to open the dialogue with the United States, and guerrilla warfare or ''armed struggle.'' No Response From P.L.O. The United States has been insisting that the P.L.O. denounce the May 30 attack. But, when the P.L.O. Executive Committee met in Baghdad last week, it made no public reference to the attack and announced no moves against Mr. Abbas or his Palestine Liberation Front, a small faction with close ties to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader.
The 21-member Arab League said in a statement on Thursday that the United States policy lacked credibility.
''The Arab states believe,'' it said, ''that the strategic alliance between Israel and the United States, the amount of military and economic aid and political support which Israel receives from the United States and the lack of adequate effort to make Israel respect international law have enabled Israel to persist in its attitude.''
 
Forces Pulling Further Apart
Western and Arab diplomats in the region said they feared that the belligerent Arab mood, coupled with the right-wing profile of the new Israeli Government, could draw Arab states more closely into greater violence.
''The region will now face an extremist Government that will heighten tension, carry out acts of aggression on some Arab countries, especially Libya, Iraq and Jordan, and clamp down on the intifada,'' Tayeb Abdul-Rahim, a Palestinian official in Jordan said, using the Arabic word for the Palestinian uprising.
Others in the Arab world expressed similar sentiments. A newspaper in Oman said, ''The present climate in Israel, reflected by the new Cabinet, pushes the region more and more to a state of war.'' In the United Arab Emirates, the newspaper Al Ittihad said, ''While not dropping the olive branch, the Arab nation should not forget the language of war because it is not through diplomacy alone that liberation can be achieved.''

HEADLINE: AN ABORTION BAN GAINS IN LOUISIANA

BYLINE: By FRANCES FRANK MARCUS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BATON ROUGE, La., June 7

 BODY:
The Louisiana House is preparing to take up a bill that would create the strictest abortion law in the country, banning all abortions except to save the life of the woman.
Moments after hearing the last witness in two days of hearings, a committee in the House voted Thursday to send the legislation to the full House in the next few days. The bill, which many lawyers say is unconstitutional, has no exceptions for pregnancy resulting from rape or incest. It carries a penalty of up to 10 years in prison at hard labor for anyone who performs an abortion. Although sponsors of the bill say a woman who has an abortion would not be penalized, opponents of the bill say it is written so broadly that they would face the same penalties as those who perform abortions. 
Not since the bitter fights in the 1970's over the proposed equal rights amendment to the Constitution has an issue attracted so many women's groups to the State Capitol, where there are only 3 women among the 144 legislators.
 
Emotions Running Strong
''The decision was made without discussion,'' said Terri Bartlett, executive director of Planned Parenthood of Louisiana. ''There was no discussion, no questions, no amendments. There was total disregard for women and the right to privacy. This is a new decade in Louisiana. The Legislature just hasn't gotten it yet.''
In testimony at the hearings, Sharon Fontenot, a City Council member in Eunice, La., who is executive director of the Chamber of Commerce and a lobbyist for Louisiana Federation of Right to Life, said: ''Today what you're witnessing is a tremendous increase in the grass-root movement. You've got every pro-life group in Louisiana behind this bill.''
''We will be lobbying on the floor, on the phone and in the districts,'' she said after the hearings, adding, ''In the House, it looks good.''
The battle in the Legislature here was set up last year when the United States Supreme Court handed down a decision allowing states to restrict abortions.
 
Move for Tough Legislation
Soon after the Court ruled last summer, in a Missouri case, Webster v. Reproductive Health Services, state legislators in Louisiana passed a resolution asking district attorneys to enforce the tough anti-abortion law that was in effect here before the 1973 Supreme Court decision in Roe v. Wade that legalized abortion.
The state and the New Orleans District Attorney, Harry Connick, went to court and sought to revive the old law, one of the strictest in the nation. But a panel of three Federal judges decided in January that the law had in effect been repealed because the Legislature, after Roe v. Wade, had enacted other laws regulating abortion.
''What we simply want to do is re-enact the old law,'' said Representative Woody Jenkins, a Democrat who is an author of the bill now before the House, in testimony at the committee hearings this week.
The bill is intended to be ''a rifle shot, clear and simple,'' to strike down Roe v. Wade, said John Baker, a professor of law at Louisiana State University, who testified at the hearings. In passing a strict new abortion law, Representative Jenkins said, Louisiana has the chance ''to make history'' since it is the last legislature in session this year considering abortion legislation and since ''the mood of the Supreme Court is right.''
 
Moves in Other States
The American Civil Liberties Union has reported that similar bills were introduced in Utah, Alabama, Minnesota and Idaho in the past year. The Idaho bill was the only bill passed by a legislature, but it was later vetoed by Gov. Cecil D. Andrus. Much of the testimony in support of the Louisiana bill centered on medical opinion that life begins at conception and that the proposed law should not be amended to allow abortion in cases of rape and incest. Gov. Buddy Roemer has vowed to veto a bill that does not have these exceptions to the abortion ban, and some legislators predict the bill will be amended on the House floor to include the exceptions.
Testimony by those opposed to the bill centered on the privacy issue, the state's high teen-age pregnancy rate, and what witnesses said was the state's pressing need for better reproductive health care for the poor, more sex education and more accessible family planning services.
Representative Arthur Morrell warned the committee against approving the bill. ''You will awaken a sleeping giant,'' he said, ''and if that giant awakens, beware.''
Privately, many legislators say they would rather not vote on the issue because their constituents are so divided.
Planned Parenthood, only six years old in Louisiana, has pitched much of its argument on the cost of defending an abortion ban, litigation that many people say the state cannot afford. Among the knottier issues now before the Legislature is how to balance the budget, which has been battered by low oil prices and a recession.
A recent poll, conducted for state newspapers and television stations, showed that of 805 voters questioned, 53 percent favored allowing a woman to decide, in consultation with a physician, whether to have an abortion, and that 67 percent believed the state should not spend money on a constitutional challenge. The margin of sampling error in the poll was four percentage points.

HEADLINE: SOUND;
SUITCASE MUSIC TRANSPORTS PEOPLE AND VICE VERSA

BYLINE: By HANS FANTEL

 BODY:
Skipping town is an old summertime urge. Even in ancient Rome, those who could afford it headed for their seaside villas when the weather got hot; and in the backwoods of New England, where this column is written, cabins and cottages are now filling up with summer people from the cities.
Those among them who require regular rations of music to get through the day face the problem of setting up a sound system in their temporary homes - a system that is easily transported to and from those summer houses. Yet despite their necessary compactness, such sound rigs should be musically enjoyable. 
These requirements may seem contradictory. Good sound and portability don't usually go together. But a few recent designs have managed to resolve that conflict. Even demanding listeners can now live out of a suitcase - literally.
The suitcase in question is the Model 11 by Cambridge SoundWorks, a company headed by Henry Kloss, whose name is famous in audio history. Among Mr. Kloss's earlier achievements was one of the first portable sound systems using transistor technology and miniaturized circuits. Made by KLH in the early 60's, it was also called the Model 11 and set new performance standards for its day. The present Model 11 is an adaptation of those ideas for the digital age.
The key element in the new Model 11 is the suitcase, which does double duty as woofer and as carrying case for the other components. It measures 16 1/2 by 19 1/2 by 6 1/4 inches, small enough to fit under an airplane seat.
Arriving at your destination, you open the case, pull out two upper-range stereo speakers and a small amplifier that delivers 18 watts per channel and works on both American (110 volt) and European (220 volt) power supplies. It may also be plugged into the lighter socket of a car. Because separate amplifying channels are used for the woofer and the upper-range speakers, the unit can produce a far greater volume of sound than its nominal power rating suggests.
The bass frequencies projected from the suitcase woofer are nondirectional. Thus a single woofer (or suitcase) is needed. The small upper-range speakers unpacked from the case are enough to furnish the stereo effect. Despite the compact dimensions, little if anything has been sacrificed to portability; and in terms of its sound, the Model 11, priced at $749, compares favorably with other systems in that range. It is not available in stores but can be ordered on a 30-day trial basis by calling 1-800-AKA-HIFI. The Model 11 is intended to work with a portable CD or tape player, which is not included. But there's room for such items in the suitcase.
A somewhat similar approach has been taken by Atlantic Technology, a company affiliated with the well-known audio company NAD. Though not conceived exclusively for portable use, its Pattern system fits in a tote bag.
Here too, a single woofer conserves space, and its enclosure also contains separate amplifiers for highs and lows with a combined power of no less than 60 watts - astounding for such a compact system. The upper range is handled by small outrigger speakers measuring a mere 4 by 4 by 7 inches. These can be angled to provide different sound radiation patterns to suit the acoustics of various environments.
The $500 list price does not include a music source, such as a portable CD or tape player, and the protectively padded tote bag is $99 extra. Even so, the Pattern system is an outright bargain.
Sonically, it is remarkable for its size and holds its own against many respectable midpriced home stereo rigs. The overall sound is clear, true in its musical timbres and well balanced.
The bass, in particular, is impressive, reaching down to about 35 Hertz. That lends credibility even to the lowest instruments of an orchestra and represents a remarkable achievement for a portable sound system. Of course, the term ''portable'' is relative. We're dealing here with a 31-pound package measuring 21 by 17 by 10 inches. ( In contrast to the high capability of the two portable systems mentioned above, the most common form of portable sound gear - the ubiquitous boom box - has not risen to the challenge of digital sound. Granted, some of the newer models now sport built-in CD players. This adds to their weight and price but doesn't make them sound any better.
Their blatant shortcomings lie in their puny amplifiers and raspy little bassless speakers. Unable to cope with the tonal range or the dynamics of a CD, the boom box screeches - perhaps in frustration and dismay at being assigned an impossible task. The discrepancy between the good CD signal going in and the flawed sound coming out is even greater than with tapes or the radio. So, if anything, the addition of a CD player to a boom box makes matters worse.
Of course, boom boxes are important. They add millions to the economy, and their popularity indicates that they serve a need. But they don't serve the cause of music.

HEADLINE: DANCE VIEW;
Amid Dire Warnings, Glimmers of Optimism

BYLINE: By Anna Kisselgoff

 BODY:
''Internationalism in dance, Past, Present and Future'' seemed like the usual call to brotherhood and cooperation when Dance/USA, the 200-member service organization for nonprofit professional dance companies and presenting organizations in this country, opened its biennial roundtable in Philadelphia last weekend.
Instead, nationalism, both noted and then embodied at the conference itself, gurgled up to the surface like a geyser. ''We are seeing a retribalization of the world,'' as one American panelist put it in a another context.
Amid all the frank talk, the following positions were stated: A Belgian held that American dance had nothing new to say and was unwelcome at the avant-garde festival he directs; American festival directors denounced the Immigration and Naturalization Service for its ''obstructionism'' in delaying or refusing visas to foreign dancers; an official of the French Ministry of Culture hoped for an end to this ''cultural protectionism'' but also noted that national differences in dance should be preserved after 1992, when the unified European Common Market is scheduled to go into effect. 
A Yugoslav dance festival director warned of patronizing attitudes from abroad and the tendency to see culture in terms of blocs (East and West) while the East Europeans, bloc or no bloc, bemoaned the advent of a market economy that has not only accompanied their new freedoms but also demoralized their performing artists. Having lost their subsidies, the Eastern Europeans now see hordes of Western dance companies rushing in to play a dominant role (projects for sending American choreographers to the Soviet Union were sketched out at the conference).
The issue of censorship was a leitmotif at the conference, but it was not unrelated to the international theme. John E. Frohnmeyer, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, received a standing ovation when he began his address on the urgency of the campaign to have Congress reauthorize the Endowment without restrictions on content. ''We are in the midst of what can only be described as a war, and we need to bring sanity to the hysteria we have had in this country,'' he said, urging the arts community to speak less to the converted than to a broader public.
There is, understandably, a tendency to view the controversy over the Endowment, stemming from its financial aid to works that Senator Jesse Helms and his supporters have defined as obscene, as a national issue.
Yet, it is an issue that should not be seen in isolation. The outcry, mainly from the forces of the right in this country, comes at a time when right-wing forces in Eastern Europe, especially in their echoes of pre-World War II ethnic and religious hatreds, have resurfaced in highly nationalistic form. Participants at the conference stressed that Senator Helms receives support from evangelical groups in the United States.
Is there a global connection between the attempt to restrict publicly financed art in the United States and the nationalistic currents in Europe, both East and West?
This question was put to a session convened by W. McNeil Lowry, president of the San Francisco Ballet and a former vice president of the Ford Foundation. The panel members were Marc Wilson, director of the Nelson-Atkins Museum in Kansas City, Mo.; Edward Albee, the playwright, and Andrzej Lipicki, a member of the Polish Parliament who is an actor-director and an adviser to the leader of Solidarity, Lech Walesa.
In Mr. Wilson's view, the connection between the controversy surrounding the Endowment and the divisions in Eastern Europe are clear. The ''retribalization of the world'' that he sees is also, he said, a ''retribalization of the United States, where our nation is being fragmented into groups, each with its own codes. There is a separation of identities, of tribes, instead of one nation, who are competing to say that my values should be those of the nation. It is the droit moral over the rights of common law.''
Mr. Albee called current attacks of the Endowment ''religiously motivated, a cultural fear.'' The function of art, he said, is ''clarity to comprehend ourselves'' even if it means expressing disturbing truths.
Mr. Lapicki said the right-wing forces in Poland were small in number. As chairman of his Parliament's cultural commission, he personally ''liquidated'' the censorship laws. Censorship, he said, ''is nothing but the mainstay of any totalitarian regime.''
At another panel, entitled ''The New Europe,'' a young Hungarian dance impresario named Gyorgy Szabo noted that the new Hungarian parties sought, in Hungary's weak economy, to distinguish their respective programs on grounds that in some cases took on a nationalistic tone. ''I hope in the next five years that this will change completely,'' he said.
In the meantime, Mr. Szabo added, such a tone in Hungary would mean that whatever government subsidy existed would go to opera-house companies rather than to the kind of avant-garde troupes he himself had already been presenting in Budapest. Mr. Szabo, who said he had often been called in by the secret police in the past, founded the Petofi Csnarnok, an exhibition and performance space that he ran as a disco on Saturdays to finance the presentation of dance companies. One of his programs several years ago included a concert by Yves Musard, a French choreographer who now lives in New York. A member of the Budapest Opera House Ballet who performed in the concert wore a mask because her teacher was sitting in the front row.
Mr. Szabo, whose programming has survived through ingenuity, is better trained to deal with the market economy than state-supported institutions. If he does not get financing for his dance programs, Mr. Szabo said, he will try to start a foundation.
For all the dire warnings, optimism pervaded this extremely stimulating conference. Its statement of purpose summed up: ''Our future, depends on our ability to work together.''
Along the way, Dance/USA gave its Honors award to Paul Taylor and Agnes de Mille. A posthumous Honor was also given to Alvin Ailey.

HEADLINE: Backstage, Bands on the Run Have Cleaned Up Their Acts

BYLINE: By KAREN SCHOEMER; Karen Schoemer writes frequently about popular music for Spin, Mademoiselle and other publications.

 BODY:
In the mid- to late 1970'S, when Aerosmith was one of hard rock's most popular and powerful bands, the scene backstage at their arena concerts reflected the excesses of a very rich, very spoiled group of musicians. The band members were known to be heavy drug users. At every show they demanded a Thanksgiving-style roast turkey, which usually went untouched, as well as several cases of Budweiser and assorted bottles of liquor. Right before they went onstage, each member drank a shot of Bacardi 151-proof rum. 
Earlier this year Aerosmith played a sold-out show at the 20,000-seat Brendan Byrne Arena at the Meadowlands complex in East Rutherford, N.J., in support of their 12th and most recent album, ''Pump.'' After the show, in which the lead singer, the 42-year-old Steven Tyler, cavorted onstage like a teenager, the atmosphere backstage was calm, peaceful, almost domestic. Mr. Tyler bounced his year-old baby on his arm. The tables were littered with half-empty bottles of mineral water and bowls of Greek salad left over from the band's supper. At one point someone handed Mr. Tyler a small brown jar. He opened the top and popped a Geritol. The new atmosphere backstage at Aerosmith's concerts is one of the more conspicuous examples of how the business of rock tours has evolved over the last decade. By the end of the 1970's the game of excesses played by both rock-tour promoters and the bands themselves had reached ludicrous proportions, with each act attempting to one-up the last with their demands - the more idiosyncratic the better. Rob Reiner's 1984 film ''This Is Spinal Tap'' captured the mood with its parody of rock musicians who refused to go onstage if the sandwich bread was too small or the olives didn't have pimentos.
As the indulgent 70's became the health- and business-conscious 80's, even rock-and-roll cleaned up its act; much of the excess seems to have gone out of style. A primary reason is money.
On many tours everyone from concert promoters to managers to musicians themselves have stripped shows of profit-gobbling perquisites like large quantities of alcohol, extravagant catering and other ego boosters so costly that even the biggest touring acts of the 70's were often hard-pressed to break even on the road. At the time rock tours were primarily intended to boost sales of a new album; they were not seen as moneymakers in themselves. But now, although tours are still used to promote recordings, they are also regarded as profitable ventures in their own right, with the emphasis on efficiency and organization rather than frivolity and self-gratification.
 
Getting Kicks From Carbohydrates
 And as the rockers themselves have aged, they've found that they don't have the physical tolerance for the old excesses. Concerts now usually last a strenuous two to two and a half hours, and tours often go on for several months (Aerosmith will have been on the road for nearly a year when the tour ends next month), demanding an athletic endurance and concentration that is difficult to sustain on the steady diet of alcohol, drugs and junk food that used to be a standard part of life on the road. Backstage at Aerosmith's Meadowlands concert not a drop of alcohol, a trace of drugs or even much cigarette smoke was to be found. In 1984, after years of severe alcohol and drug problems, members of the band underwent drug rehabilitation treatment; this is their second ''clean'' tour, and ''Pump'' is the group's best-selling album since the 70's, with more than two million copies sold. Aerosmith has dictated that the band's touring contract (a 40-page document known in the business as a rider) include a clause that states, in big bold letters, that no alcoholic beverages are allowed anywhere on the tour. That goes for band members, crew members, backstage or on the buses - everyone, everywhere, at every minute.
''Other bands ask me about drugs,'' says Mr. Tyler. ''They just want to hear my war stories. I tell them I almost died. I tell them how it raped our creativity. I mean, what are you really doing? Who are you fooling? Now we have Skippy chunky peanut butter, Sorell Ridge preserves, rice cakes, dry-roasted soybeans and distilled water. Good stuff like that. Before we go onstage we have a huge, hot plate of al dente spaghetti and six baked potatoes, one for each guy - you know, to fill up on carbohydrates.'' Even the Rolling Stones, who are renowned for past excesses, both onstage and off, implemented some changes for their 1989 North American tour. The band's dressing room was stocked with Evian, fresh juice and Earl Grey tea; their ''rumpus room'' was outfitted with a pool table, video games and a jukebox - low-key compared with the scene backstage during their previous tours.
''I don't like all this lavish, pretentious sort of stuff that was in the 70's,'' said Mick Jagger in a telephone interview. ''We have a cappuccino machine - that's very yuppie. You don't see so many drug pushers anymore. That seems to have gone a bit out of fashion.''
 
The Old Days: Nothing Exceeded Like Excess
 A 1972 concert film by Robert Frank documents Mr. Jagger sniffing cocaine backstage and crew members shooting heroin. Other bands' behavior was just as extreme. By the early 70's, Led Zeppelin had earned a reputation for throwing giddy groupie parties, destroying entire floors of first-class hotels and lobbing color TV sets out of upper-story windows.
Such tales are now rare. But back then, the logistics of touring fostered extravagance. A concert promoter in each city was responsible for laying out the money up front to produce the show, supplying sound and lighting systems, renting the concert space and outfitting the backstage areas according to the needs specified in the band's rider. With the money earned through ticket sales, the promoter would cover expenses first, then divide whatever was left over with the artist, usually in a 50-50 or 40-60 ratio.
As top-grossing road acts became more and more excessive in their requests, promoters likewise became more flamboyant, setting up elaborate backstage scenarios to greet the artist after the show. Mick Jagger remembers coming backstage to find the promoters had installed ''big ice sculptures - huge tongues, or replicas of the band. And there'd always be a theme, like Hawaii. There'd be hula dancers and things like that. A roast pig. They'd go absolutely mad.''
Among the most famous for such scenarios are Bill Graham, the San Francisco-based promoter, and Ron Delsener of New York. Mr. Delsener points out that such theatrics tended to happen in larger cities, where the artists were more concerned with upholding their extravagant image in front of friends, family, celebrities and the media.
''There'd be a New York theme, and we'd set it up to look like a street scene, with hydrants and people dressed as old-time policemen giving out chocolate egg creams,'' he says. ''In the 70's, Elton John once wanted to play tennis, so we arranged with Nassau Coliseum to set up a court backstage, and he played with Billie Jean King. I've had a pool table assembled, a golf driving range, caviar by the truckloads, you name it. Topless bartenders.''
Gregg Perloff, an executive with Bill Graham's company, Bill Graham Presents, says, ''Things didn't happen overnight. First there was no food backstage. Then there was food backstage. Then bands started traveling in limousines. Then each member went in a different limousine. Another band member would say, 'Well, I want two bottles of champagne in my limousine.' Bands made $100,000 a night, but at the end they hadn't made any money. People find that hard to believe, but when you spend $6,000 a night on limousines it's very easy not to make any money.''
When the requests came directly from the performers, promoters would pull out the stops to give them what they wanted. But the promoters' own sturdy profits prompted them to add their own embellishments. As late as the early 80's Bill Graham employed a designer, Eleonore Hockabout, whose job was to decorate the backstage area.
''Bill always liked to surprise artists,'' she says. She designed mannequins filled with colored lights and hung with trash jewelry for a Cyndi Lauper concert. When Peter Gabriel did a Christmas show, she set up enormous Christmas trees with presents underneath, and all the band members were given lace stockings stuffed with gifts. For a U2 show, Ms. Hockabout's team brought huge pieces of black paper, chalk and crayons out to fans waiting before the show, and had them write messages to the band which were then hung up backstage.
Performers and promoters eventually realized that such gimmicks were bleeding their profits. ''A lot of bands were broke after a tour,'' says Mr. Delsener. ''They didn't know what they were doing in those days. They'd come off the road and say, 'God, that's all the money we made? We have to cut down our expenses.' ''
 
The New Economy: Less for the Promoters
 Bands not only cut their expenses, they cut the promoters' profits. As early as 1972, Led Zeppelin had capitalized on their massive touring popularity by knocking the promoters' cut down from 40 or 50 percent to as little as 10 percent. In return, the band's organization took on many of the promoter's expenses. By the 80's it became standard practice for bands to take their own sound and lighting systems from city to city, since the quality of equipment on the road could vary.
The relationship between promoter and performer was essentially reversed. Whereas once the promoter was in control of nearly every aspect of a concert except the actual playing - and was paid accordingly - now the promoter is more a hired hand who follows the band's directives.
When promoters were making all the arrangements, Mr. Delsener says, ''acts were getting ripped off and cheated. There were a lot of deals supposedly going down where people were piling on the bills, getting rebates they weren't passing along to the artist. Now bands carry accountants on the road. They scrutinize every bill and every expenditure. You can't go overboard spending the band's money like you could in the 70's.''
The new economy is reflected in bands' riders. For the most part, says Bob Garcia, a promoter for Radio City Music Hall, riders have become standardized (occasional eccentricities do pop up; in 1986, the rap group the Beastie Boys requested condoms in various colors). Mr. Perloff notes that most groups he's worked with, from the Grateful Dead to R.E.M. to New Kids on the Block, have straightforward, streamlined contracts.
Other bands may have unusual catering needs (in the B-52's case, three band members are strict vegetarians), but these acts either bring along their own food-preparation staff or send meticulous guidelines to the concert hall well in advance.
''What's in the rider is what's necessary to do the show,'' says Mr. Perloff. ''There isn't a lot of fluff.''
Says Tim Collins of Aerosmith's current rider, ''We don't ask for anything we don't need. We're just not into wasting. What they didn't know then, and what they know very well now, is that, ultimately, the artist pays for everything. Ticket prices can only go so high.''
Rock performers aren't the only ones who have trimmed their budgets. Mr. Garcia says that the pop crooner Julio Iglesias has changed his rider significantly over the years. ''Ten years ago, he asked for a lot of catering, especially expensive caviar,'' he said. ''Now he doesn't. His contract is very standard, very simple. It's more of a business now than it used to be.''
Since most of the financial burden to organize a tour now rests on the band's side, many artists, such as the Rolling Stones, have developed deals with corporate sponsors to defray costs.
''The performers get a million dollars or whatever,'' says Mr. Delsener, ''which will help underwrite the plane fares, the cost of rehearsing - things that have to be done before they collect a nickel.'' The role of the promoter, he says, has decreased to the point where now ''all you have to do is follow the rider and do the promotion and advertising as they direct.''
Despite all the changes, Mick Jagger says that a lot of the aspects of touring are still the same. ''Take a band that's been around forever,'' he says dryly. ''In the big cities, you have lots and lots of people backstage, and every groupie that was ever around has to be let in just on a nostalgia basis. I still rather like to have pretty girls backstage, rather than ancient old journalists that turn up, trying to remind you they wrote a great story on you in 1969!
''I think the big difference in touring is that in the 60's you used to go out and do 20 minutes, which was wonderful. Now you go out and do two hours and a half, and it's still not enough.''
 
THE M & M WARS
 A band's touring contract, called a rider, spells out a band's requirements - food, alcohol, technical specifications such as how many electrical outlets are needed in the dressing rooms. By the late 70's, bands were caught up in an almost perverse contest to see whose rider could be the most excessive.
The competition reached the height of absurdity in 1980, when the pop-metal group Van Halen, on their first arena tour as the top-billed act, put a clause in their rider requesting bowls of M & M's candy with the brown ones taken out. In 1981, the Rolling Stones production coordinator, Michael Ahearn, added a clause to the Stones' rider asking for only brown M & M's.
A spokesman for Van Halen insists that the M & M clause existed solely to test whether promoters were actually reading the rider, but the band continued to specify the demand on subsequent tours. As for the Stones, Mr. Ahearn says, ''I did it for fun.''
Tim Collins, Aerosmith's manager since 1984, insists that his band was the first to be really excessive in the rider. ''They started the M & M's thing,'' he says. ''They had to have a four-gallon jar of M & M's and the promoter had to pick out all the green ones.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: June 10, 1990

SECTION: Section 3; Page 6, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1937 words

BYLINE: By M. A. FARBER with DIANA B. HENRIQUES

 BODY:
At no time since he burst upon the scene as a New York City developer and then as an Atlantic City casino operator has Donald J. Trump seemed in more financial trouble than in the last few weeks. The 43-year-old entrepreneur has been closeted with his bankers amid concerns that he lacks the cash to make timely payments on his huge business debt. In New Jersey, worried gaming regulators have undertaken a broad review of his holdings and financial condition.
In a wide-ranging interview recently, however, Mr. Trump was as irrepressible as ever, asserting that his resources were still enormous, striking out at those who he said were ''jealous'' of him and affirming his plans to continue as a force in the economic life of the city and the region.
At his cherrywood desk on the 26th floor of Trump Tower, at Fifth Avenue and 56th Street, surrounded by framed magazine covers of himself and by baseball bats into which his name had been carved, the sandy-haired chief executive of the Trump Organization seemed mindful of everything that had been written about him. But the talk of his demise, he said, was indeed premature. 
What follows are excerpts from that interview, interspersed with observations by his wife, Ivana, who may soon be seeking a divorce, and by a number of financiers, builders and other professionals who have dealt with Mr. Trump since 1977, when he first came to notice with his conversion of the decrepit Commodore Hotel on East 42nd Street into the Grand Hyatt.
 
'Things Could Be Tougher'
 Mr. Trump was asked about speculation that his financial worth was much exaggerated.
 ''They say I've slimmed down to $500 million,'' he said. ''Things could be tougher. The latest hot rumor is that I'm trying to get my net worth down as far as possible for the benefit of the divorce. That's total [expletive]. I don't want to get it down real low or up too high . . . Let me tell you something, just so you understand. If I'm worth $500 million, if I'm worth $3 billion, I really don't give a [expletive]. I really don't. I truly don't.''
Mr. Trump pointed to the Plaza Hotel, visible from his wall-size office window, and likened it to the two Impressionist masterpieces that had been purchased at auction by a Japanese bidder at record prices.
''What is that building worth? You tell me,'' he said. ''See, the whole point is, what are my assets worth? The Plaza Hotel is like those paintings that sold the other day at numbers nobody believed possible. The Plaza is the same thing as those paintings. If I were to sell the Plaza, I would get a number that would knock you off your seats. I don't even know what that number is. I couldn't tell you what it is. But that number would be tremendous.'' He recalled his sale last year of the St. Moritz Hotel to Alan Bond, the now-struggling Australian financier, for approximately $100 million more than Mr. Trump had paid for it.
''There's always somebody to pay more,'' he said. ''The St. Moritz was not a trophy - it was only a modest trophy. The Plaza is the ultimate trophy in the world. There is always somebody that is going to want to buy the greatest hotel in the world.''
 
Ivana's View:'Donald Is Fine'
 Few have ever faulted Mr. Trump's energy. Despite widespread reports that Mr. Trump has had an affair with a model, Marla Maples, Ivana Trump was generous with her praise. During a luncheon interview early this month in a corner table at the Edwardian Room of the Plaza, which she has continued to manage, she called her husband the ''hardest-working man I have ever met. He is a great businessman and a great promoter. You don't have those both very often in the same person.''
She said she believed he would weather his current financial difficulties - ''I think Donald is fine, I think he will be all right.'' A few days later, as headlines about Mr. Trump's uncertain fortunes flared, Mrs. Trump issued a brief statement: ''Donald and I are partners in marriage and in business. I will stand by him through thick or thin, for better or worse.''
Irving Fisher, head of the HRH Construction Company, which has built all of Mr. Trump's major projects in New York, also portrayed Mr. Trump as a shrewd developer whose image as a fun-loving, sports-loving ''people's billionaire'' could be deceptive. ''He is a master at projecting his image,'' Mr. Fisher said, but ''there's the public image versus the smartness. He doesn't want people to understand how smart he really is.''
Conrad Stevenson, a former banker who helped finance the Commodore Hotel project and Trump Tower, said Mr. Trump ''has more perseverance than many other developers, who tend to be impatient.''
Mr. Stevenson, agreeing that bank credit is increasingly tight across the board, divided real estate developers into three categories. There are ''the small number who have no troubles, like Leonard Litwin and Lewis Rudin, the ones at the other end that have real trouble - and I won't name any names there - and then there's the rest of them, who are not in trouble but who have problems. And Donald is there.''
 
Criticizing His Managers
 Just as Mr. Trump has recently taken to criticizing the executives who had previously managed his casinos in Atlantic City, he expressed displeasure in the interview with the people now running his Trump Shuttle, which links New York with Boston and Washington.
Mr. Trump bought the shuttle in October 1988 from Eastern Airlines for $365 million. Although it was once believed to be one of the most profitable airline operations in the nation, its ridership had suffered severely during the protracted strike at Eastern. It competes with the Pan Am shuttle, which is up for sale, and there have been conflicting reports about whether it, too, is on the block.
 Q. Is the Trump Shuttle a success?
 A. The Trump Shuttle is an esthetic success. It will be a financial success. But right now, I'm upset with the people running the Trump Shuttle, for one reason: We give a much better product than Pan Am, and yet we only do about 50 percent of the business.
 Q. Is that their fault?
 A. Yeah, I think it's their fault. [Noting that the shuttle had only about 12 percent of the market when he purchased it, because of the labor troubles, Mr. Trump continued:]
 A. I've spent a lot of money making it a great operation. We took that 12 percent up to 50 percent. Now, there are people who would say that is a great job. I am not satisfied with it, because I think our product is so far better than Pan Am. I am disappointed in my people.
 Q. But those are the same people who brought you from 12 percent to 50 percent?
 A. That's right. But I am not satisfied with 50 percent.
 Q. Would you sell it?
 A. Only if I get the right price. I'm very proud of the Shuttle.
 
The Unbuilt Trump City
 Mr. Trump describes himself as the biggest landowner in Manhattan, based primarily on his ownership of 76 acres of railroad yards along the Hudson River on the Upper West Side, where he has been planning to build Trump City. The keystone of the project would be a 150-story skyscraper, the world's tallest.
Mr. Trump bought the site for about $95 million in 1984, and is paying roughly $20 million a year in debt service to keep it. He has yet to get city approval for this gargantuan project, which has drawn a storm of protest from people living in the neighborhood.
Mr. Trump said that, given the downturn in the real estate market, it was probably a lucky break that he had not undertaken the project sooner. ''I could have had a job under construction and coming on now, into a bad market,'' he said.
For Mr. Trump, the city's current economic situation resembles the climate in which he negotiated the renovation of the Commodore Hotel. Because the city's fiscal plight was so acute at that time, he said, ''They were begging me to take 40 years of tax abatement. I got 40 years of tax abatement. They were begging me to build a restaurant over the street. And I built a room over the street - the only room in New York that is built over the street. You could get anything you wanted because times were so bad in New York that the Planning Commission and the city were just begging me to go ahead with the building.
''Now there is no construction going on. It's all timing. You've got to get your zoning when it's going like this,'' tilting one hand down, ''and do your construction and get to market when it's going like this,'' tilting his hand up.
Mr. Trump hinted that the idea of having the world's tallest building at the West Side location might have to be abandoned. ''I have a whole development plan over there. There will be give and take and there will be negotiation. There always is. Things will be given to the city.''
Peter Paden, a lawyer for People for Westpride Inc., said that almost any form of the project as outlined by Mr. Trump would be battled through the courts for years. ''That is as certain as the night follows day,'' Mr. Paden said. Even some of Mr. Trump's oldest real estate associates question whether the West Side project will ever work out.
 
'What Else Is New?'
 But Mr. Trump remains undeterred. ''Remember when I put up Trump Tower,'' he said. ''Everyone laughed when I said I was going to build a 60-story building right next to Tiffany's. They said, 'No way.' But I got it. My whole life, I've gotten zone changes. People say, 'Oh, you've got to get a zone change.' I say, 'What else is new?' That's all I've done. I'm a guy that goes out and gets zone changes and builds buildings.''
Mr. Trump also suggested that too many people were simply jealous of his accomplishments. ''I don't think anybody has done what I've done. Because what I've done is not only Manhattan real estate but Atlantic City and stock deals that have been tremendous,'' he said. ''People in my business that are 80 years old and have been there forever, they don't like that I own the Plaza Hotel.'' Mr. Trump lamented that ''these are the 'beat up Trump' months.'' He has always been sensitive to criticism and in the past, was said to have had newspapers with unfavorable articles removed from the gift shops of his casinos. When things weren't going right, he was also known to occasionally flash a photograph of his lawyer, the feared Roy Cohn, and demand of his antagonists: ''Would you rather deal with him?''
Vincent DeSimone, a well-regarded structural engineer who has worked on several Trump residential projects, finds the criticism of Mr. Trump very much misplaced.
''Trump-bashing has become a popular form of social intercourse,'' Mr. DeSimone said. But ''when you do business with Donald Trump, you've got visibility. It says you're good. Every time I ever thought I had second-guessed Donald Trump and that he had made a mistake, I didn't fully realize what he was thinking.''
Mr. DeSimone donated his firm's services to Mr. Trump's restoration of the Wollman Rink in Central Park, completed in late 1986. He recalled Mr. Trump telling him, ''Vince, I'll make you famous.'' And he did, Mr. DeSimone said. ''At the opening ceremony, Donald personally thanked me in front of everyone. Lee Iacocca was there. The Cardinal was there. Koch was there. And I heard it all that night on the radio.''
Suddenly, such celebratory days for Mr. Trump seem, if not gone, at least remote. But veterans of the New York real estate scene are philosophical. ''This business is like the Bible,'' said Mr. Fisher of HRH Construction. ''You have seven good years, and seven bad years. The cycle turns. No one is immune from what's happening.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: June 10, 1990

SECTION: Section 3; Page 15, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 961 words

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
The Gumshoe of Annual Reports

BYLINE: By Alison Leigh Cowan

 BODY:
Do not expect to see Behind the Numbers spreading sunshine on coffee tables throughout greater corporate America. In the two years since the pricey, and influential, investment newsletter made its debut, it has recommended the stock of only one of the 78 companies it has written about.
Behind Behind the Numbers, is David W. Tice. He is a 35-year-old accounting gumshoe who scrutinizes annual reports and other published documents for clues to a company's financial health. They are the sorts of tantalizing tidbits that have been overlooked by the public and the analysts who watch public companies, in part as a service to investment-banking clients. 
''There are so many other people out there touting stocks,'' said Mr. Tice ''I can add value because I don't have the conflicts of interest in telling people what to be wary about.''
Sometimes, the tip-off is a bloated inventory. Other times, management's alibi fails to check out or Mr. Tice discovers that a profitable company is not reporting expenses in a timely fashion. And like any detective, he sometimes hits a dead end. ''You end up going down a lot of blind alleys before you find something,'' he said.
The approach may have made him a scourge of public companies, but it has made him popular among the 30 or so investors who each pay $10,000 a year to subscribe to the newsletter, which has 10 issues a year. (The subscribers can pay in cash or do an agreed-upon amount of trading with any of several brokerage firms Mr. Tice works with.) Most of the subscribers are institutional investors. A handful are short-sellers, speculators who sell borrowed stock on a bet that the price will drop and they will be able to buy it back at a cheaper price.
The subscribers have presumably done well. The 77 stocks Mr. Tice has issued warnings on have underperformed the market by an average of 8.5 percent, said Mr. Tice, whose policy is not to personally buy or sell any stock on the list until at least one week after publishing his recommendations.
Mr. Tice, who grew up in Independence, Mo., has a bachelors degree in accounting and a masters in business administration from Texas Christian University. ''I never planned on being an accountant,'' he said, ''but thought accounting would just help me be a better businessman.''
He spent 10 years in industry, first at the Atlantic Richfield Company's management training program, then at the Enserch Corporation, where he evaluated mergers for the diversified energy company. Even then, he was not known for clamming up when things did not look right. ''They made a bunch of dumb acquisitions that I tried to keep them out of,'' Mr. Tice said.
He then joined the Concorde Financial Corporation, an investment adviser in Dallas. In 1987, however, his life changed when he read ''Quality of Earnings,'' a classic by Thornton L. O'Glove, the editor of another newsletter on accounting shenanigans.
''What I liked about him was he was a skeptic and a critic of the conflicts of interest that exist between brokerage firms and the companies they recommend,'' said Mr. Tice, who soon quit his job to start a competing product out of his Dallas home.
Today, Behind the Numbers occupies a 500-square-foot office in Dallas overlooking a golf course, and is still primarly a one-man show.
His best call was on Aug. 24, 1989, when he predicted the slow demise of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, the big publishing house that had restructured at great cost to avoid a takeover. Unnerved that the stock moved from $10 to $18 in the span of one quarter, Mr. Tice investigated and found that the company's separate pieces, when the debt is repaid, will be worth a mere $1.70. Yesterday, the stock closed at $3.50 So far, his worst call has been the Blockbuster Entertainment Corporation , a large chain of video stores whose stock has risen sharply despite Mr. Tice's warnings on October 1988. Then. the stock was trading at $9.50, adjusted for a later split. Yesterday, it closed at $22.50. Mr. Tice was one of a few analysts who had criticized the company for taking three years to write off the expenses of purchasing its library of hit tapes. The critics contended that hit tapes lose their economic value faster than that. The company has since agreed to speed up in certain cases. An inventory write-down is still possible, said Mr. Tice, whose analysis included visiting several Blockbuster stores and counting the number of hit tapes on the shelves.
On his latest warning list are several popular blue chips. including Merck & Company, the pharmaceutical giant, and the Philip Morris Companies, the consumer products giant. In both cases, the negative reviews have to do more with concerns over fundamentals than with any quarrels over their accounting.
After interviewing some physicians, Mr. Tice soured on Merck, he said, because, ''the company's research and development pipeline will not generate the blockbuster drugs that it needs.'' He also thinks investors are ignoring subtle hints by management that this quarter's earnings will be up modestly compared with last year's, not the 20 percent most of Wall Street is expecting.
As for Philip Morris, he is concerned that too much of its 1989 profits came solely from sharp price hikes on its cigarettes. ''Eighty-eight percent of their earnings gain came from tobacco and 94 percent of that came from price increases,'' he said.
Sometimes, Mr. Tice's intuition is on the money but still backfires. He criticized the Noxell Corporation, a cosmetics company, for its rapid buildup in inventories. At the time, the stock was trading at $22. It turned out that the company was indeed experiencing slower growth, but its stock rose. Reason: it agreed to be sold in late 1989 for about $35 a share.

GRAPHIC: Photo: David W. Tice publishes Behind the Numbers, a newsletter. (Brian Payne for The New York Times)

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: June 10, 1990

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1705 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:

 
 
COMPANIES
 
The Trump Seesaw - Headed for a Downswing?
 
He flashed onto the scene more than a decade ago. (''I wasn't satisfied just to earn a good living. I wanted to make a statement.'') He flourished. (''I like thinking big. I always have.'') And now, could Donald J. Trump be in danger of flaming out? ''I want to be king of cash,'' he said recently. His bankers wish him the best in raising that cash, having spent last week meeting with him about debts that have left his New York and Atlantic City properties mortgaged up to their minarets. Casino regulators, who gave Trump his first license after a one-day hearing in 1982, were inquiring about his financing as well. One regulator said that Mr. Trump's Atlantic City employees were ''terrified,'' and ''hiding under their desks.'' But a Trump executive called a press conference Thursday to say the casinos' performance was ''fabulous,'' recent layoffs were merely ''streamlining,'' later bill payments were the result of better cash-management and that no casinos were for sale. ''Junk bond'' traders responded by pushing some of the Trump paper down below the value of Chilean debt. 
 
Greyhound on the Ropes
 
The survival of the nation's only coast-to-coast bus system is at stake. With creditors about to seize some of its buses, Greyhound Lines Inc. filed for bankruptcy last week. Greyhound Lines has been staggering under a heavy load of takeover debt and a three-month drivers strike. As the company rebuilt its network with replacement workers, 52 shooting incidents, more than 100 bomb threats and uncounted cases of vandalism chased riders away. Creditors are likely to pressure Fred G. Currey, the angry, adamant chief executive, to make peace with the drivers. But the bigger question is whether creditors will agree with Mr. Currey that for a bus company to profitably serve Chicago, for example, it must also serve Olive Hill Junction, Ky. If they say no, they would probably sell off buses and leave small-town service to regional bus lines or none at all.
 
Beatrice on the Slopes
 
Who says a successful investment banker has to spend all the time at the office? In a profession where those who have hobbies and family lives are accused of lacking commitment, Eric Gleacher sometimes preferred broad golf courses and ski slopes to the confines of Morgan Stanley, where he was head of mergers and acquisitions. But it was on a lift line in Vail, Colo., in January that he and Charles M. Harper, chief executive of Conagra Inc., discussed a bid for the Beatrice Company. On Thursday, Conagra announced that it had agreed to buy Beatrice for $1.34 billion, creating the nation's second-largest food company after Philip Morris. It was Mr. Gleacher's first deal since he formed his own company at the beginning of the year.
 
A Billion for the Lada
 
Lada on the outside, General Motors on the inside: The General Motors Corporation signed a five-year contract on Thursday to sell auto parts to the Volga Automobile Works, the Soviet Union's largest automaker, for $1 billion - in hard dollars, not rubles. The parts will help two models of the Lada passenger cars meet the European Community's clean-air standards so that they can be exported to Western Europe after 1992. But if the Soviet Union expects to sell cars anywhere west of Minsk, the cars had better work more smoothly than the Soviet phone system. G.M. executives in Detroit didn't know the details of their Soviet contract because communications with Togliatti, where the Soviet company is based, have been spotty. The city has only two international telephone lines and no fax machines. Not to worry, says G.M.; let's think about hauling in our own satellite dish to bypass the Soviet telephone system.
 
Niet to Underground Calls
 
Serving him medallions of Maine lobster at the White House is one thing. Letting an American telephone company lay fiber-optic cable across his country is another. And so, the day after President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union left the United States, the Commerce Department told US West Inc. to drop its plans for leading the effort to build a $500 million communications system linking Europe and Japan. Technology transfer is at most a secondary concern, since US West planned to install outmoded equipment. American defense officials worry that Soviet communications, now transmitted by microwaves, would be more difficult to intercept if they traveled on underground cables instead.
 
Chip Maker Loses a Leader
 
Sematech is suddenly without a leader, and the electronics industry without one of its pioneers. Robert N. Noyce, an inventor of the computer chip, died last Sunday at the age of 62. His work led the way to everything from personal computers to programmable coffee makers. A co-founder of the Intel Corporation, Mr. Noyce was chief executive of Sematech at his death. The company is a government and industry research consortium trying to help American chip makers catch up with the Japanese.
 
An Isolationist Institute
 
The prophet of American corporate nationalism has attracted some unlikely followers. Clyde V. Prestowitz opened his Economic Strategy Institute in Washington last week with the goal of keeping American companies from becoming stateless global enterprises. One study under way is likely to dispute the value of recent trade agreements with Japan; Mr. Prestowitz, a former Commerce Department official and businessman, has become the Mike Tyson of Japan-bashers. Another study probably will question foreign investment in the United States. Still, among the 10 corporations financing his center are Motorola and Ford, both dedicated global marketers, and North American Philips, owned by the Dutch.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
On the Wings of Druk-Air
 
The Druk-Air Corporation stunned Bhutanese airline analysts last week by reporting load factors 25 percent to 50 percent above industry expectations. Druk-Air has going for it an absolute monopoly at its hub in Paro, in the Himalayan kingdom of Bhutan. The fleet, one 80-passenger British Aerospace 146, flies a total of six weekly round trips. The Bhutanese expected average load factors of less than 40 percent. ''It was anticipated we wouldn't make any money,'' said Ugyen Tshering, Bhutan's Ambassador to the United Nations. Instead, Druk-Air has load factors of 50 percent or 60 percent, sometimes filling the plane. And, besting those New York hotels that boasted of a queen standing guard, Druk-Air counts King Jigme Singye Wangchuk among its passengers. On operating costs, the airline already is close to breaking even, Mr. Tshering says. Another few years and Bhutan might begin privatizing it, selling shares to the public and maybe even establishing a stock market, he adds.
 
Argentina Makes a Payment
 
Like a compulsive shopper gone repentant, Argentina has made a token payment to start settling its bills. It paid $40 million last Thursday on $6.1 billion in interest that has piled up since it defaulted two years ago. Bankers are encouraged that President Carlos Saul Menem has reduced inflation, built up a budget surplus and convinced the International Monetary Fund to resume lending. Argentina's debt, which traded for less than a dime on the dollar earlier this year, struggled back to about 15 cents last week before softening. ''What you're seeing is selling on good news,'' said Peter Albano, a trader at Salomon Brothers.
 
In Brief
 
Hitachi Ltd. of Japan has developed an electronic memory chip that can store 64 million bits of information, or more than 5,000 double-spaced typewritten pages, in an area about the size of a thumbnail.
 
*
 
Japan chose American technology last week as the standard for a new generation of cellular telephones. The use of the technology, from Motorola Inc., will make it easier for American companies to sell their equipment.
 
THE ECONOMY
 
Credit Yes, but for the Small?
 
Maybe the banks aren't such tightwads after all. The Federal Reserve Board said that the amount of loans and investments by banks in the United States, reported as annual rates, rose by 8.4 percent in February, 9.2 percent in March and 5.1 percent in April. Commercial and industrial loans, down in the first two months of the year, were up at a 9 percent rate in March and 10 percent in April, with real estate loans rising about as much. ''I doubt we have credit conditions that would keep the economy from experiencing modest growth,'' said William V. Sullivan Jr., director of money market research at Dean Witter. Banks have been chastened by bad loans and tough examiners, and some regulators fear that banks might react by becoming so stingy that the economy's health would be at risk. The Fed's figures hint that small businesses, at least, might be justified in complaining about tight credit: an increasing percentage of commercial and industrial loans are coming from foreign banks, which tend to concentrate on large accounts.
 
Alas, Productivity
 
Productivity fell at a 2.7 percent annual rate for the first quarter. Many economists saw the news last week as inflationary, with employers having to pay more for labor or hire less-able workers. As Robert Giordano, director of economic research at Goldman, Sachs, said, ''It is definitely something to be depressed about.
 
In Brief
 
The Government has joined with businesses, and universities to develop data highways allowing the transmission of the equivalent of 160 novels a second. By the middle of the decade, the new network could allow the sending and manipulation of lifelike, three-dimension images between researchers, doctors, business people and weather forecasters.
 
*
 
A New York State court upheld the power of utility regulators to set electric rates to encourage conservation rather than higher consumption.
 
*
 
A Commerce Department report warns that the $200 billion American electronics industry risks being eclipsed by Japanese and Korean competitors.
 
*
 
The Senate Commerce Committee passed a bill on Thursday to strengthen Federal and local regulation of cable television.
