HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
On the Road With Grace Pineda

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
Grace Pineda, daughter of a Filipino diplomat, lived in France, Switzerland and the Philippines before her family settled in the United States. Here she studied Russian, one of four languages she now speaks, and later earned a graduate degree in international business from Fordham University. She has specialized in the Pacific markets since 1982, when she got her first money management job and was assigned to watch a promising spot called Japan.
The many roads that Grace Pineda has traveled now all come together in Princeton, N.J., where she has been managing the Merrill Lynch Developing Capital Markets Fund since it opened for business last September. The $79 million fund, which invests mostly in stocks in the smaller international markets, ranked No. 1 among international funds in the first quarter, returning 6.1 percent while the group dropped 5.4 percent, and ranked 16th among the 1,700-plus funds tracked by Lipper Analytical Services. 
The 33-year-old Ms. Pineda makes five worldwide trips each year to scout companies and countries. Right now, she considers Mexico ''the most interesting part of the world'' because of the reforms underway there, but she is also watching South America, especially Brazil and Argentina, ''because those countries are seeing what Mexico is able to do.''
Her biggest holdings, 10.8 percent of her portfolio, are in Mexico, with Malaysia (10.2 percent) a close runner-up. She is also looking at - but not yet buying - stocks in Turkey, Greece and Sri Lanka.
Her fund invests in 23 countries and defines ''emerging markets'' broadly: It focuses on economies where capitalism is developing or where there is great growth potential. Ms. Pineda says Austria, Switzerland and France fit the bill, and so too do India, Chile, Venezuela and Indonesia. She avoids the mature United States, Japanese, British and West German markets.
Her strategy is bearing fruit. To deal in emerging markets, managers must ''have experience, know the countries, understand the psychology of these markets and ride some markets' ups and downs,'' said Antoine W. van Agtmael, president of the Emerging Markets Investors Corporation, a Washington-based investment management firm and a competitor. ''I think she has all that.''
She certainly knows her geography. She has just returned from a whirlwind trip that sent her to five countries in two weeks. She travels, too, when she is on vacation, looking at ''churches, not companies,'' she said. But on a recent vacation to Chile, she added, she was buying a shirt in Santiago and couldn't help turning a critical eye on the traffic and prices in the shopping center. When she got back, she bought more shares in the closed-end Chile Fund to increase her exposure to the market there.
Her investing strategies are guided by the theory that developing markets are driven by sentiment, liquidity and rumors. ''That's the way the locals invest,'' she said. ''They hear stories, get excited and the momentum builds.'' And because those markets can grow so rapidly - the forecast for this year's growth rate in Indonesia, for example, exceeds 40 percent - they offer potential for big gains. So she is willing to pay as much as 20 times earnings for a company.
But there is risk involved. Because of its focus on smaller markets, the fund is riskier than many international ones. In an attempt to control risk, Ms. Pineda avoids some markets, such as Africa, which she said is politically unstable and lacking the economic reforms of other developing regions.
In Mexico, where she is targeting many of her investments, she likes Cifra, a Mexico City-based mass-market retailer, which she expects will benefit from the country's strong growth in manufactured exports. Another favorite: Telefonos de Mexico S.A. de C.V., the state telephone company that is soon to be privatized.
In Hong Kong, she likes Dickson Concepts Ltd., a luxury wholesaler and retailer in Asia. She expects Dickson to grow at a yearly rate of 15 percent or more over the next two or three years and considers its luxury retail niche a good bet because ''that part of the market is recession-proof and Tiananmen Square-proof.''
She also favors Skala Aktie, Hungary's largest mass-market retailer, which is traded on the Austrian over-the-counter market. It is her sole holding in Hungary, which she calls the most backward of the markets she follows. But a recent visit gave her hope for change. ''I was one of the last Westerners to see the Communist red star on top of their stock exchange,'' she said.
She says there is opportunity in the pent-up demand for infrastructure in developing nations and taps into it by buying stocks of companies that deal in cement. In Denmark, she likes FLS Industries, which supplies engineering services to companies in the cement industry. She also likes the Siam Cement Company in Thailand and P.T. Cement Cibinong in Indonesia.
 
KEEPING MORE FUNDS IN THE PORTFOLIO
The number of mutual funds grew sharply in the 1980's - there are now about 3,000 - and so too has the number of funds that individual investors keep in their portfolios.
In 1984, 40 percent of the 1,007 people queried by UAI Technology Inc., a North Carolina financial services and consulting firm, owned shares in one mutual fund - and just 6 percent had invested in six or more funds. By 1989, things were pretty much reversed. Only 20 percent of 851 investors polled by the firm had shares in one fund while 15 percent had invested in six funds or more.
There are good reasons why people invest in more than one fund and why that trend will continue, said Larry Cohen, vice president of Phoenix-Hecht/Gallup, a division of UAI that also does market research and consulting. As more funds become riskier investments, it makes sense to diversify to reduce risk and enhance total return. Furthermore, investors are using different funds for different financial goals, such as saving for retirement or for a child's education.

HEADLINE: All About/Dairy Farming;
Cows on a Technological Tightrope

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
American agriculture has few symbols more popular than the Holstein cow. Her wholesome, black-and-white form decorates bedsheets, coffee mugs and countless other household items.
Dairy farmers, however, have found that the warm feelings do not necessarily extend to them. The industry's use of drugs to make cows more productive, its contribution to pollution and soil erosion, and its dependence on import quotas and taxpayer-funded subsidies all alienate consumers. Though retail dairy sales continue to edge upward - topping $43 billion last year - the health-conscious tend to associate dairy products with cholesterol.
Farmers complain that consumers take plentiful supplies at some of the world's lowest prices for granted. ''Most farmers feel underappreciated, especially when the milk check arrives,'' said John Nye, whose family has a 200-cow farm in Washington Depot, Conn. 
The industry rebounded last year from a dismal 1988, and 1990 looks promising because prices for most products are strong. But support prices have fallen to a level where many farmers will face huge losses if production hikes or an unexpected drop in demand reproduces the surpluses of the 1980's.
Farmers say that making capital improvements to expand production has become more risky. They are becoming less receptive to environmentalists demanding that they limit their use of agricultural chemicals or take some of their cropland out of production to protect wetlands. ''Farmers fear that people want changes but will balk at paying the bill,'' said Stephen Kerr, chairman of the Council of Northeast Farmer Cooperatives, which lobbies for 10,000 dairy farmers.
 
The Politics
Washington Weighs Price Support System
The biggest immediate fear of most farmers is that Congress and the Bush Administration will further whittle away at Government supports.
Dairy supports and pricing are bewilderingly complex. When prices are high, the free market rules. When prices are low, Government supports come into play. First, milk processors negotiate monthly prices with farmers in Minnesota and Wisconsin, the dairy heartland. Federal milk boards in major cities around the nation then use these to set minimums that processors in their areas must pay farmers - depending on variables like distance from the Midwest and how much milk is processed into other products. California has its own pricing system.
Underlying everything is the Federal support price - currently $10.10 per 100 pounds (about 11.5 gallons) of milk - that farmers get if market prices are no higher. The Government also calculates support prices for other dairy products. Last year, with milk soaring to a peak of nearly $16 per 100 pounds, nearly all of the $600 million the Government spent was on one product: butter.
Dairy executives say that the butter glut is primarily a side effect of the rapid growth in demand for skim and low-fat milk. They say that heavy Government purchases of butter created an illusion that dairy supplies in general are abundant, leading to support prices too low to guarantee reasonable supplies of other milk products. ''Ten dollars and 10 cents is a non-support level,'' said James Barr, head of the National Milk Producers Federation. But the federation and other farm groups figure that, with a deficit-conscious Congress, they will have to fight just to keep the current levels.
Farmers also fear that the Administration will agree to drop quotas limiting dairy imports from countries like New Zealand, the world's major dairy exporter. They anticipate more political clashes this fall, when Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter plans hearings to review the entire pricing system.
 
Economics of Scale
The Cutting Edge? California, Of Course
An average farm in the Northeast or Midwest is still a small business, with herds of 50 to 75 cows. In California, dairy farms are more like factories, averaging 500 cows, with a growing number of farms exceeding 2,000. To raise more cattle on less land, California dairymen buy feed instead of following the traditional practice of growing it themselves. Needing neither cold-weather barn nor the land and equipment for raising feed, they have lower production costs.
In California, therefore, farmers are prospering even though prices are $1 per 100 pounds of milk lower than elsewhere. Low milk prices have encouraged a rapid expansion in dairy processing plants there. ''Cheese production is growing at 20 percent to 25 percent a year,'' said Fred Douma, chairman of the Milk Producers Council in Southern California. ''Morale here is pretty good.''
Mr. Douma, who has 2,500 cows on just 120 acres in Southern California's San Bernardino Valley, says farmers have steadily raised their estimates of the most profitable size for a herd. Investments are soaring too. Farmers sink $5 million into a 1,200-cow operation, 10 times the investment in the average Eastern farm. ''You won't survive with 300 cows, even if you have no debts,'' said Mr. Douma.
The assembly-line dairies have farmers elsewhere worried, especially since the California style is spreading to New Mexico and Texas. ''People aren't very happy about it because the growth in California can create oversupplies which will lead to more cuts in Government support prices,'' said Bob Wellington, chief economist for AgriMark Inc., a dairy cooperative in the Northeast.
Tensions between regions are one reason for this autumn's pricing hearings. More pressures come from upper Midwestern farmers who feel that other regions benefit from excessive pricing premiums. They argue that if farmers in the Southeast were not guaranteed such large margins over the price paid to Wisconsin and Minnesota farmers, the Midwesterners would sell more dairy products to that region throughout the year. They already supply a large portion of the Southeast's needs during the summer and autumn because dairy cows, like many of their owners, slow down in hot weather.
 
Techological Gains
From Hormones to Automoted Milkers
Dairy farming is awash in new technology. Genetically engineered drugs, computer monitoring and automation are increasing productivity and challenging regulators.
Take the case of bovine somatotropin, a naturally occurring growth hormone in cows that genetic engineers have managed to grow in bacteria. By injecting this artificial BST into their milkers, farmers can boost production by up to 20 percent.
Studies so far indicate that the injections have no measurable impact on milk's nutritional value. But critics argue that added BST can harm the health of cows and that the long-term effect on consumers is unknown. Some farmers say that its use will create a milk glut, driving more farmers out of business. Others believe the hormone is valuable but not worth using if it damages milk's image for purity. The Food and Drug Administration has repeatedly delayed issuing its findings on BST injections, allowing their use for at least the time being. But in recent months, Wisconsin and Minnesota have imposed BST moratoriums.
More farmers are using computers to monitor the health, feeding, and reproduction schedules of their herds. Other computer programs help farmers select bull semen and help breeding companies track the success of their animals.
Farm machinery also continues to evolve. In automated milking parlors, sensors turn suction cups off when a cow's udders are drained, automatically detaching the cups and pulling them away to allow the cow to exit. Gascoigne-Melotte, a Dutch company, hopes by 1993 to market a device that makes the feeding and milking entirely automatic.
 
IT'S ALL A MATTER OF BREEDING
In an industry where better breeding has accounted for 75 percent of increased productivity in recent years, Walkway Chief Mark is a star. Currently the nation's highest-rated Holstein bull, Mark will probably produce 80,000 daughters - and 80,000 sons, who usually end up as veal - by the end of his career, according to Richard Chichester, general manager of Select Sires Inc., his owner. The art of cattle breeding is steadily becoming more scientific thanks to computerized record-keeping, better understanding of genetics and more experience with artificial insemination. Bulls continue to offer the quickest path to improvement since a single bull produces enough semen for 25,000 to 100,000 inseminations in a top year.
Developed in the late 1930's, artificial insemination is used today in more than half of all dairy cow breeding. About 1,100 bulls are tested annually for their ability to reproduce desired characteristics in their female offspring: high milk output, high fat and protein content, ease of milking and durability. Only one in 10 bulls makes the grade and most of them will be culled from the steadily improving breeding pool within five years.
Meanwhile, to multiply the offspring of the best females, embryos are repeatedly flushed out of the cows, to be implanted in their less productive sisters.
According to the Department of Agriculture, genetic progress is accelerating. Selective Holstein breeding increased the average annual milk output per cow by 42 pounds during the 1960's, 151 pounds in the 1970's and 257 pounds in 1981-85, the most recent years for which there are figures. The average production for an American dairy cow is 1,650 gallons (more than 14,000 pounds) a year, with top cows producing more than 2,900 gallons.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
The Forgiving Municipal Bond Market

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
Is it a hard time for debtors? Not in the municipal bond market.
Last week, the once-notorious Washington Public Power Supply System came to market to sell $600 million worth of tax-exempt bonds. This agency's nickname is ''Whoops,'' in recognition of its apparent inability to get nuclear power plants finished on time and on budget. In 1983, it mothballed two unfinished plants and defaulted on $2.25 billion in municipal bonds, despite dire warnings from Wall Street that any debtor who committed such a heinous act would never again be welcome at the lender's trough. 
But ''forgive and forget'' is apparently the muni market's motto. When the W.P.P.S.S. issue came to market last week, its second sale since the default, it was very happily received, according to the bond analysis firm of Delphis Hanover in Litchfield, Conn. Indeed, demand was so strong that the power authority was able to boost the size of the issue to $875 million and still get yields that showed no trace of retribution.
Of course, the overall market was in a good mood early in the week, with the Dow Jones industrial average shooting up more than 34 points on Monday. It later gave up those points and more, plunging almost 35 points on Friday, to close at 2862.38. But Laszlo Birinyi, head of the investment analysis firm of Birinyi Associates, does not believe the market has made a fundamental turn. ''This was the first day for real significant profit-taking, but there is no indication that anything has changed,'' he said. Through all of this unheaval the bond market remained unruffled.
And defenders of the muni market's mentality pointed out that the credit agencies recently upgraded the power authority's rating. Fair enough - but that hardly explains the reception the same market gave to the short-term notes sold on Thursday by New York State, whose deteriorating fiscal health has led to its credit rating being lowered in recent months.
The New York State tax and revenue anticipation note issue, totaling $4.1 billion, was as warmly welcomed as the W.P.P.S.S. bonds. Originally priced to yield 6.15 percent, the notes were so popular that their yield was cut to 6.10 percent. ''It was as if there had been no downgrading at all,'' one trader marveled.
Does this mean that New York is a stronger state than the credit-watchers think it is? Probably not. Short-term investments are so scarce in the tax-exempt market, and demand is so high, one analyst said, ''that if Donald Trump sold tax-exempt notes today, the market would snap them up.'' You listening, Donald? The big test for the bond markets will come at the end of this week, with the Government's back-to-back inflation signals: the producer price index on Thursday, the consumer price index on Friday. ''I think the figures will be roughly in line with a 4 percent annual inflation rate,'' said Jay Goldinger, a principal at Capital Insight, a specialty brokerage house in Beverly Hills, Calif. ''It will take something better than that to get the bond market to rally.''

LENGTH: 1976 words

HEADLINE: The Long Campaign for a Perfect Prom

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD

 BODY:
Esther Truzman, the class secretary, fiddled with her notes and spoke up: ''The club has to be a nice space. A lot of clubs, you walk in and they're so blah. Hot Rod last year was nice, but the music wasn't so hot.''
A possibility was broached by Larry Kang, the senior class president. Meltem Bozkurt, the class vice president, shot him an oh, brother look. ''A lot of hoodlums go there,'' she said. ''It's a good place to go if your aim is to get beaten up.'' ''We better settle on the boat soon,'' interjected Mr. Kang. ''Don't worry,'' said Ms. Bozkurt, effusing confidence. ''It's going to be the greatest prom ever. The greatest.''
As on many afternoons of late, the members of the prom committee at the Edward R. Murrow High School in Brooklyn were huddled in the principal's conference room, assailed by decisions. Although this was only October, nerves were already fraying as the trio embarked on its longest odyssey in economics: the dogged task of choosing among the gaggle of businesses that wanted to make their senior prom an unforgettable - and profitable - experience. 
The high school prom is an American institution, and at thousands of high schools across the country, from rural schools in South Dakota to inner-city institutions in Chicago, students like the Murrow committee members were doing exactly the same thing. That's why the staging of proms has coalesced into a substantial industry worth millions of dollars, pursued by hotels, boats, dance clubs, photographers, disk jockeys, balloon makers and limousine companies.
For small businesses that serve prom-goers, the parties allow massive sales in one night, though they sometimes have to dangle discounts or other incentives to land the contracts. ''It's a cut-throat business,'' said Nathan Tsukroff, head photographer at G & B's Photography, which will shoot the Murrow prom. ''We know of companies that get the business by citing a low price and then, on prom night, the price is suddenly three times higher. This is not high-profit business, but there's a lot of it, and you make your money on volume.''
 
Sifting Through Options
 There are even companies that tackle the arrangements and book the halls and the entertaintment - like Promoceans, the Manhattan company that is doing some work for the Murrow students. Its founder, Steven Salsberg, has been booking proms for 12 years. A prom disk jockey before he formed his company, he now arranges some 35 affairs a year, most of them on boats, bringing his company revenues of more than $750,000.
The large number of enterprises competing for prom business means more possibilities have to be scrupulously sifted through by young adults entrusted with tens of thousands of dollars, even though they're often bewildered about how to stretch an allowance through a full week. It is not for the weak-kneed senior. The Murrow prom committee - consisting of Mr. Kang, Ms. Bozkurt and Ms. Truzman, with Carl Lefton, a genial art teacher, as the faculty adviser - started its planning early to lock in the date it wanted - Wednesday, June 13. After all, roughly 300 private and public high schools in the New York metropolitan area hold proms during the prime prom months of May and June.
Some 500 students were expected to attend the Murrow gala, and the plan was to charge $80 a person, enough to cover the affair itself and a party afterward at a Manhattan club. That meant a total budget of $40,000. ''I hope it's enough,'' Ms. Truzman said. Hotels, party rooms and boats were all eager to welcome prom students, especially the ''prom factories'' like the big catering halls Marina Del Ray in the Bronx and Terrace on the Park in Queens, as well as hotels like the Waldorf-Astoria and the Plaza. Many of these flooded high schools with promotional literature, often gushy testimonial letters from satisfied schools, saying things like, ''I was astonished by the caring, the kindness, the helpfulness, the work ethic, the skill, the efficiency and the smiles of each and every person on your incredible staff.''
Staying on land seemed awfully pedestrian to the Edward Murrow committee. In recent years, it has become de rigueur at Murrow and many other schools near the water to charter a boat, and the committee wished to prolong the aquatic tradition. They emphatically did not wish to repeat last year's somewhat odious result, when the boat wasn't scrubbed after the previous party on it. ''We went there in formal wear and all,'' Ms. Bozkurt said, ''and like the floor had gum stains on it, and you thought, like why didn't I wear shorts?''
To begin the hunt, Ms. Bozkurt called Metropolitan Charters, which offered the dinner yacht Mystique at $48 per person. It was keen enough to get the business that it invited the Murrow committee for a complimentary cruise on Oct. 30. The boat's promotional package vowed: ''The Mystique is the place where memories are made. We have a single goal in mind - to make your prom or after-prom the talk of the town!!!''
 
Seeking a Ship
 Mr. Kang and Ms. Bozkurt liked that talk, but the moment they boarded they squinched their eyes. It was simply too small. Knowing this, the two seniors proceeded to have a wild time and scarfed down monstrous quantities of food. ''We felt a little guilty,'' Ms. Bozkurt confided afterward. ''But only a little.''
Meanwhile, Mr. Lefton contacted Promoceans. It said it was in the process of acquiring its own boat, but it wouldn't be available in time.
In November, the committee inspected the Spirit of New York, part of Cruise International, a Norfolk, Va., line. The bulk of the yacht's business is corporate cruises, social parties and weddings, but it is the site of about 25 proms a year. ''Proms are a good market,'' said Thomas D'Amato, the general manager. ''What happens is you get alumni business and social parties off of them.''
But proms can be a little dicey. ''They can be crazy business,'' he admitted. ''To have 600 people between the ages of 16 and 18 on a boat is different than a dinner party of people from I.B.M. We've never had anyone hurt, but I have had to give restaurant managers weekends off.''
The Murrow students liked the Spirit, a vast, swank vessel with three decks. Shortly before Thanksgiving, they agreed to rent it. They would have it from 8 until midnight, at a price of $45 per student, for a cruise that would follow a horseshoe path around lower Manhattan. The package came with singing and dancing waiters and waitresses, a nice touch.
 
On to the Clubs
 Hot Rod? Red Zone? Emerald City? Mars? What club to retreat to after the cruise was no easy decision - you wanted to be hip but not burst the budget - and so the committee elected to work with Mr. Salsberg of Promoceans. Mr. Salsberg says he can negotiate lower prices because of his volume, and he also extends scholarships: faculty advisers can identify a limited number of needy students who will be charged about half-price. He initiated the program because he relied on a scholarship when he attended Ramaz high school in Manhattan, for which he planned a prom in 1982 at a SoHo loft. His brother, David, was more inventive: in 1985, he orchestrated his class's prom on a barge.
''Everyone in New York is happy to take money from kids,'' Mr. Salsberg said of his work. ''Everyone. That's why I do so well.''
On a dank Monday in early December, Mr. Salsberg showed Meltem Bozkurt and her prom date some clubs. Before beginning, he couldn't resist doing a rapid pitch to try to persuade them to scrap the yacht in favor of the Great Hall of Science in Queens. He felt museum proms were the next wave, and had designed a package that would include 25 videotapes of the prom and a 1,000-balloon balloon drop from 90 feet. Ms. Bozkurt adored balloons but she said they were going sailing. By now, the committee members had already done some checking and had a rough feel for club prices.Though it was remaining open-minded, the prom committee truly had its heart set on Red Zone. ''I asked kids at the school what clubs they liked, and they said 'Red Zone, Red Zone, Red Zone,' '' Ms. Bozkurt mentioned. ''It's really hip.''
 
Selling the Site
 Mr. Salsberg escorted them through Hot Rod, the site of last year's after-prom party. The committee recoiled at the thought of duplication, but Mr. Salsberg pushed Hot Rod hard. ''Last year, you had croissants, bagels and coffee,'' he said. ''This year we can do eggs, bacon and home fries, so it's a bigger breakfast. We can also do nonalocholic tropical drinks. I realize you don't want to go to the same place. But we can outdo last year.'' Doubt pervaded Ms. Bozkurt's face. ''Listen, you want to make sure the kids come here,'' Mr. Salsberg said. ''Take $3,000 - that's just $5 or $6 per kid more - and get Andrew Dice Clay to do 45 minutes of comedy. Nobody is going to miss that.'' ''Uh-huh,'' Ms. Bozkurt nodded in a mood of forbearance. A few Saturdays later, Mr. Salsberg escorted them through Red Zone, and there was no more doubt. Hence Mr. Salsberg struck a deal: they could book the club for $22.50 per person. This was met with delirium.
When spring rolled around, the committee turned to hiring a disk jockey. It can cost more than $1,000. The committee had heard a Murrow student who went by the name D. J. Scott at sweet-16 parties, and liked his sound. His fee was $600, which sounded best of all. He had all the gear - smoke machine, bubbles - and they figured he would work extra hard because of his Murrow spirit.
''He plays a lot of disco,'' Ms. Bozkurt said. ''We said we don't want disco all night long. We want a little reggae. A little rap. A little house music. Some slow songs. We don't want anything childish, like 'Shout.' ''
In early May, with the big day nearing, arrangements were made with Flora Tech, which does balloon decorations, to make a balloon arch for the students to walk through when boarding the boat. The company said a really nice arch would be $500. The committee settled on a pretty nice one for $300.
Limousines are considered obligatory for proms, and students began booking rides. They would not come cheaply; limousine companies typically require 10-hour minimums at a cost of about $500, plus a 20 percent tip.
Many students were sharing cars. Ms. Bozkurt and Ms. Truzman hooked up with four other couples. They phoned 15 companies before hiring a 44-foot white limousine from Amex Limousine. It comes with two VCR's and a compact disk player. They would have it for 14 hours for $2,400. They wanted extra time, for as Ms. Bozkurt said, ''It takes a long while just for the thing to turn around.''
Limousines can be problematic. Anthony Gurino, who runs the Superior Limousine Company in Queens, which gets about 10 percent of its business from proms, said: ''It's a shame to say, but there are more treacherous, unprofessional, scheming thieves in limousines than anything. Limousine companies collect money up front from kids and then fold up.''
 
A Surge of Expenses
 Last year, for instance, 500 students from John Dewey High School came out of Bentley's looking for the limousines and were less than happy when none were there. To insure reliability, Mr. Gurino likes to have off-duty and retired policemen drive his cars on prom nights. ''Listen,'' he said, ''a cop in the car doesn't hurt.'' Expenses kept mounting. Tuxedos and prom dresses. Corsages. Hair styling. Money was flying out of parents' pockets. Ms. Bozkurt was having a dress made especially for her for $475. ''O.K., that sounds like a lot,'' Ms. Bozkurt said. ''But you have to remember, a prom comes just once.''
Finally, with everything all booked, it was just a matter of counting down the last few days until the big event. Then it would be time for next year's senior class to begin figuring out a way to outdo it.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
The Guys in White Hats from Sony

BYLINE: By SHELDON WEINIG; Sheldon Weinig is chairman and chief executive of the Materials Research Corporation.

 BODY:
In 1989, the Materials Research Corporation, which I founded, was faced with a critical challenge: raise capital or probably fail. The capital we finally raised came from Japan. We are now a wholly owned subsidiary of Sony U.S.A.
Our company makes manufacturing equipment for the semiconductor industry, and in all the generations of this equipment, there has never been a time when our machines were not the most advanced technologically. We also produce the expendable materials that are used to produce thin-film layers on semiconductor wafers - a type of electronic material that was virtually invented by M.R.C. and has served as the model for all other subsequent entries in the field. 
Possibly, with that sort of pedigree, we might be considered an important American technological asset. But in 1988 we realized the company could not develop the next generation of equipment without fresh capital. Because of lower-than-expected activity in the worldwide semiconductor markets, we were capital-short. In fact, we had considerable debt funded by a bank syndicate.
American banks do not understand technological cycles. At the very time we needed more money for new development, they pressed us for repayments and restructuring. We knew that bank loans were no way to move forward, so we explored other sources of capital.
Our customers, including the International Business Machines Corporation, are among the largest companies in the world. Some of them have assisted their suppliers in the past, earning handsome dividends in the process. But when we turned to major customers, we were met by a wall of silence.
We turned to Wall Street financiers and found two varieties - those who were prepared to raise money for bottom-of-the-barrel buyouts with dismemberment plans for the company, and those who were prepared to sell ''junk bonds'' for the company at costs beyond our ability to generate profits.
We turned to a European-based competitor, which was interested in an acquisition but, unfortunately, also needed help. It showed a great interest in our short-term ability to improve its bottom line.
Then Sony appeared - from our point of view, a white knight. Our technologies are closely related. The president of Sony U.S.A., Mickey Schulhof, is a friend of mine, and Sony is an aggressive technolgy and marketing company.
When the deal was done, we ran into a familiar bugaboo: selling a high-technology company to the Japanese. Government restrictions were overcome, but that did not eliminate the bruised American sensibilities of our customers, the American press and even some of our employees.
Well, what if we had not sold? Would our brilliant team of scientists and engineers still be together, working on the next generation of processing machines and improved materials? Would the employee base that we had jealously guarded over 30 years - providing lifetime employment for most of those years - be as gainfully employed as it is today? Or would some of those employees be out on the street, forced to accept lower-paid jobs with far fewer benefits? Would the Rockland County and New York state economies still be benefiting from our operations? Or the American economy?
And these questions may not touch the most basic issue. The main point for a company like ours is, would we have been able to continue to make significant contributions (as we have in the past) to world technology?
The likely answer to all of these questions was no. But with our purchase by Sony, the answer to all of them seems to be a definite yes.
It has been claimed that lower-cost capital, more patient capital and greater capital availability are necessary to prevent the continued crumbling of the American technology industry. Actually, all may be necessary, but none may be sufficient to keep the corporate edifice standing. An editorial in The New York Times last month lauded I.B.M. for suddenly taking a leadership role in trying to sustain a viable semiconductor industry in the United States. I agree with their actions and hope that my prodding a year ago was of some influence in their decision-making.
But for M.R.C., necessity opened a different path. A great artist, a great craftsman, virtually anything great, can receive the appellation ''National Treasure'' in Japan.
After we were purchased by Sony there was an outcry about how M.R.C., an American national treasure, had slipped into the hands of a foreign company. No one said we were a national treasure before we were sold.
It is apparent by now that industry has entered a new phase dictated by the demands of the world economy. Technology is being globalized. Little has been lost by our sale to a foreign company. Much has been gained. Now we can strive to be a world treasure. In a time of shrinking geography and global business, that is not a bad title.

LENGTH: 1895 words

HEADLINE: Turning Short-Lived Fads Into Steady Growth

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

 BODY:
Strolling into his debut fashion show in 1987, Rick Fayer had little more than an idea for a new pair of pants. He was a fashion designer with no name recognition, no track record and not even enough money for a display booth.
Feeling a bit like a gate-crasher at a society ball, Mr. Fayer carried only a briefcase with a product sample, a few swatches of fabric and a willingness to buttonhole buyers with an idea: cotton doctors' pants, with the drawstring, but in bold plaid prints instead of staid operating-room green.
It wasn't much of a launch in a business known for lavish promotions. But the pants caught the attention of George Kucin and Ken Rodriguez, top buyers for Merry-Go-Round Enterprises Inc. While other merchants clustered around established designers, Mr. Kucin and Mr. Rodriguez gave Mr. Fayer a test order. 
Within weeks, Mr. Fayer's new brand, called Skidz, was a hit. Today, fueled by Merry-Go-Round, Skidz has expanded into shirts and accessories. Its sales exceed $15 million a year and its customer base has widened to include Barneys New York, Macy's and Dillards. Mr. Fayer said recently of Merry-Go-Round: ''If they asked me to make three-legged pants, I'd do it.''
Based in Joppa, Md., a suburb north of Baltimore, Merry-Go-Round has emerged as the leading merchant devoted to trendy fashions for the mercurial tastes of people between the ages of 14 and 35. It doesn't matter whether the rage is for savagely ripped Get Used jeans, Zum-Zum party dresses made with ''63 percent metal,'' or the deep-crotch pants popularized by Bobby Brown, the rapper. The company has displayed a consistent knack for spotting fads long before other retailers do so.
''They're always out there beating the bushes for new ideas,'' said Alice Ruth, a retail analyst for Montgomery Securities. ''By the time Macy's picks up on a product, Merry-Go-Round has often moved on.''
Stuart M. Lucas, president of Merry-Go-Round's Menz division, is not reluctant to agree: ''Whoever's hot,'' he said in an interview, ''9 times out of 10, it's going to be somebody we've had a good relationship with long before they were hot.'' New designers know that Merry-Go-Round is receptive and helpful to them, he added.
The results are impressive. Since 1987, the company has expanded from 388 stores to 625. Sales have skyrocketed, from $207 million in fiscal 1987 to $478 million in the year ended last February, and earnings almost tripled from $7.4 million to $22.2 million. This year, predicts Miss Ruth, Merry-Go-Round will earn $33 million on sales of $615 million. Adjusted for stock splits, Merry-Go-Round's share price has grown almost fivefold from less than $6 in early 1989.
In sharp contrast to the disastrous acquisition binges of retailers like the Campeau Corporation, Merry-Go-Round has shown success based on merchandising prowess. Comparable-store sales - the measure of sales growth at stores within the company that have been in operation at least one year - have increased more than 42 percent during what has been a sluggish year for the rest of the industry.
Even more dramatic is the transformation of Silverman's, a lackluster chain of 124 stores acquired by Merry-Go-Round in February 1989. As of April, those units had doubled their sales from the levels of a year earlier.
That is not to say Merry-Go-Round faces no challenges. It did not escape a dip in earnings during 1986 and 1987, and a recession-induced drop in consumer spending would hurt again.
In addition, some of Merry-Go-Rounds's success stems from being in the right place at the right time: about two-thirds of its sales are to young men, a relatively underserved niche in the otherwise overserved clothes market. But that gap will not exist forever. A few youth-oriented competitors - like Edison Brothers Stores Inc., which operates J. Riggings as well as other chains - have posted good gains in the last year. The department stores also are angling for position. Some analysts are casting an eye on the heretofore un-hip J.C. Penney Company as a potentially serious competitor.
After two decades of stready growth, however, Merry-Go-Round has proved itself far more enduring than the clothes it sells. Underlying that is a blend of tough-minded management and a sensitivity to the rhythms of fashion. At a time of turmoil for overleveraged department-store chains, Merry-Go-Round paradoxically demonstrates the value of old-fashioned principles. Among them: the importance of management continuity, an emphasis on merchandising skills rather than acquisitions and an ability to stay close to customers.
The chain was founded in Baltimore in 1968 by Leonard Weinglass - who was the basis for the flamboyant character named ''Boogie'' in the movie ''Diner'' - and his boyhood friend Harold Goldsmith. Although the two men retain a combined 35 percent stake in Merry-Go-Round, and are still vice chairman and chairman, both dropped out of day-to-day operations in the late 70's. (Mr. Wein-glass now runs ''Boogie's Diner,'' a clothing store and restaurant in Aspen, Colo. Merry-Go-Round licensed the concept and built a similar store in Chicago, but Mr. Weinglass owns his store separately.) Under Michael D. Sullivan, who joined the company as chief financial officer in 1974 and became chief executive in the early 80's, Merry-Go-Round has been subdivided into three divisions. The biggest division is the original Merry-Go-Round chain, catering evenly to men and women in the 15-to-25 age group. Following in size is the Menz division; it carries more expensive clothing for men aged 18 to 34 and comprises four chains: D.J.'s, DeJaiz, Attivo and His Place. Third is Cignal, an upscale chain for both sexes emphasizing European fashions.
Like other successful specialty retailers, such as the Limited and the Gap, the company applies technology to fashion. It has installed computer systems that poll stores daily to track products. Merchandise managers crunch numbers ruthlessly, to enable them to add hot items and slash prices as needed to weed out mediocre ones. ''It takes a lot of the clairvoyance out of things,'' Mr. Sullivan said.
Evidence of management strength comes in different ways. Inventories, for example, have creeped up only 8 percent in the last year, even though those of comparable stores soared at more than five times that rate. In addition, the company's stores rotate merchandise faster than traditional retailers: instead of changing stock once a season, outlets receive a continous stream of small shipments of new products. Thanks to its strong balance sheet, Merry-Go-Round has avoided the credit crunch imposed by the lenders, called factors, who finance shipments from vendors to stores.
But what makes Merry-Go-Round hard to imitate is its flair for satisfying trendy young customers. Like other retailers, it sends its buyers to fashion shows around the world. While others gravitate toward established designers, however, Merry-Go-Round buyers cull ideas from everywhere, drawing heavily on MTV music videos, new movies and obscure designers like Mr. Fayer.
Back in the 70's, it was Merry-Go-Round that placed the first order with New York-based Bugle Boy, a clothing manufacturer primarily for young people, which now has sales of $500 million a year. In the early 80's, the company scored huge hits with jackets like those worn by the singer Michael Jackson in his music video ''Beat It'' and by Tom Cruise in ''Top Gun.'' More recently, Merry-Go-Round was among the first retailers to ride the popularity of Jimmy Cavaricci, a casual-wear designer.
''They are more in touch with the market today than anybody else,'' said Gary Olsaver, a top executive at Bugle Boy. ''The department stores are so focused on a few vendors that if you're not well known, they won't buy from you. They'll tell you things like, 'You're not in the matrix - I can't buy from you.' ''
Unlike Mr. Sullivan, an unreconstructed square who talks about the ''guys and gals'' who buy his goods, the others in top management roam the executive offices in flowing Shang-Hai suits, designer jeans and other items sold in Merry-Go-Round stores. The division presidents - Paul D. Levine, Mr. Lucas and Ken Rodriguez - started out as store clerks in the early 70's and share a passion for fashion. ''They're garmentos,'' commented one designer, a term that rankles Mr. Sullivan because it implies in the trade a kind of facile arrogance.
Certainly, most analysts and industry experts credit Merry-Go-Round with the best antenna in the market. ''There's a lack of buying talent in the young men's business, and they seem to have it,'' said Steven Roorda, a retail analyst with the Banc One Corporation in Columbus, Ohio. The competitors who do not, he said, are at a serious disadvantage in getting in on new products.
The most important key to Merry-Go-Round's success may be the continuity of its top management. Mr. Lucas, for example, rose up from store clerk in 1974 to store manager and through a succession of buying jobs. The same is true for most of the buyers and other managers.
Under Mr. Lucas, the companylaunched its first major in-house label, I.O.U. sportswear for Merry-Go-Round stores, which now accounts for more than $100 million in sales. It also has started labels for more expensive clothing for the Cignal stores.
The chain also plays a major role in helping and influencing designers. When the buyers pushed for a line of denim pants several months ago, Mr. Fayer said, ''They told me the specs, the wash, the silhouette - everything about how it should look.
Despite the company's grasp on emerging trends, however, Mr. Lucas is wary of smugness: ''You always have to be angular,'' he likes to tell people, by which he means being able to switch directions quickly. ''A buyer is never right,'' he went on, ''if something is hot, and you didn't buy enough; if it's not, you bought too much.''
 
A HISTORY OF FASHION HITS
 
MERRY-GO-ROUND hits:
 
1974 Prewashed jeans with a patchwork of dark and light areas. They sold for $23 a pair - far more than the previous price for fashion jeans - and rescued Merry-Go-Round from a recession.
 
1976 Discomania. Sparked by the movie ''Saturday Night Fever,'' the chain shifted to three-piece polyester suits and nylon shirts. It also was first to order Cheeks, pants with no seams or pockets. A hit for three seasons, theyaccounted for as much as 75 percent of the chain's dress-pant sales at the height of their popularity.
 
1983 Parachute pants. Tight-fitting models made from nylon-parachute cloth became a hit at $50 a pair. Because of limited supplies from the one small manufacturer, Merry-Go-Round was the only chain offering them for a year. The craze surged in late '84, when other companies copied the idea, but died abruptly in '85.
 
1984 Michael Jackson jacket. Merry-Go-Round originally sold 60 jackets - at $750 each - modeled on the one worn by the singer in his video ''Beat It.'' The company then turned to cheaper manufacturers and by spring 1985 had sold 50,000 of the jackets for as little as $29 each.
1985-86 Z. Cavaricci, an obscure manufacturer in Los Angeles, comes out with its ''975'' line of casual pants. It propels Cavaricci's sales to more than $100 million by 1989, with Merry-Go-Round accounting for more than $30 million.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
The Cookie Monster Makes Policy

BYLINE: By STEPHEN BERGER; Stephen Berger is stepping down next month as executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. He will become president and chief executive of the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company, a municipal bonds insurer.

 BODY:
A not-so-funny thing happened to Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner on the way to the White House, where he was to deliver America's new national transportation policy. The policy got eaten up by a Cookie Monster named Richard Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget.
The Skinner policy offered many new ideas: it would involve the private sector as a full partner in the transportation system, support research into new technologies that overcome problems of limited capacity, use transportation investment as a tool of environmental protection and harmonize the various transport modes - rail, sea, air and highway - to work together. 
But Mr. Darman's hungry budgeteers stripped the policy bare of any resource commitments that might have brought the words to life. Bold pledges in the policy's early drafts to ''rebuild'' infrastructure were reduced to ''maintain'' existing facilities. A commitment to spend down the transportation trust funds now being held to mask the true size of the Federal deficit were banished. No effort to address real environmental concerns, like controlling aircraft noise, was permitted. And the Federal Government's traditional bias against mass transit remains secure.
Mr. Skinner legitimately noted that most criticism of his work ignores the new ideas and focuses on the demand for more Federal subsidies. But by not bringing any resources to the table, the Bush Administration guaranteed that the debate will not proceed. Washington cannot expect its talk of creative new partnerships to be taken seriously if it will not put up any equity.
Since 1960, public infrastructure investment relative to gross national product has fallen by more than half. At the same time, our competitiors were investing. Hundreds of billions of dollars are being spent by the European Community, Asian nations, Australia and others for new airports and marine terminals, high-speed railroads, computer-controlled ''smart cars'' and ''smart highways'' and state-of-the-art waste treatment facilities.
In making these commitments, our competitors have shown they understand a lesson that Americans have forotten: public investment is a long-term proposition. Whether it's in human capital or physical capital, the dividends don't start for years.
A 50 cent-a-gallon increase in gasoline taxes, dedicated to infrastructure, would raise $60 billion a year to invest in our future. It would still keep average American gas prices almost a dollar lower than the gas sold by any of our competitors. In constant dollars, it would still be only two-thirds of what we were paying at the pump 10 years ago.
The transportation debate America should be having now is how to break through the artificial barriers created by Federal programs that are organized, administered and competing for money in distinct categories, like rail, air and sea. Sadly, that discussion was pre-empted when Mr. Darman decided that Washington would be the one player at the table who did not have to ante up.
Mr. Skinner made a serious effort to develop a program that would help shape America's future. He did not deserve to run into Mr. Darman before breakfast. Neither did our children.

LENGTH: 1333 words

HEADLINE: Numbers Crunch;
Getting a Mental Grip On The Dimensions of The Savings Disaster

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
ONE of the more curious aspects of the savings and loan debacle is how much money has been lost and how little anyone seems to be upset about it. ''Twin Peaks'' appears to have generated more intense national discussion.
Recent revelations that the ultimate cost of the bailout is likely to be in the $325 billion to $500 billion range seem finally to be catching people's attention. But for months the public took in stride news that the effort would cost billions and even tens of billions of dollars. Perhaps such enormous numbers are so hard to envision because they seem as abstract and meaningless as the age of the solar system or the distance across the Milky Way.
This is, after all, a nation that faces an almost daily barrage of billion-dollar statistics. With $150 billion Federal deficits, $300 billion military budgets and $8 billion supercolliders perhaps it is not surprising that a certain numbness has set in. 
''I can't grasp what a billion is,'' conceded George J. Benston, a finance and accounting professor at Emory University in Atlanta. ''We go from $100 billion to $300 billion like we're counting one, two, three,'' said the exasperated professor.
To help his students appreciate the enormity of the amount the savings and loan industry has lost, Mr. Benston said he tries to get them to think about how hard it is to become a millionaire. Then he asks them to imagine 1,000 millionaires, then 150,000 millionaires. The savings and loan industry's losses are the equivalent, he explains, of reducing all of those millionaires to paupers. Another way to think of the total is to imagine Donald Trump building 150 of his Atlantic City Taj Mahals.
And that doesn't include the cost of financing and overseeing the bailout. Unlike earlier Administration projections, the latest tally sheet from Congress's Government Accounting Office includes $133 billion in interest on the money the Government must borrow over 40 years to pay for the $155 billion of estimated losses at failed savings and loan institutions. And on top of that is $37 billion in administrative costs. The bill could go to $500 billion if interest rates rise more than is now expected, or if a recession further depresses the value of real estate and topples more already weakened thrift institutions. Some economists have estimated that the total could exceed $1 trillion, but nobody really knows.
Now that people are talking about hundreds of billions of dollars, the discussion seems to have finally entered the zone of ''real money.'' The mega-numbers led many evening news programs, and Phil Donahue seized on these latest estimates and hammered them home to his 10 million television viewers. ''Five hundred billion dollars,'' he exclaimed repeatedly, waving his arms with evangelical emphasis. ''Nice people like you'' are not going to be able to get loans, he told an increasingly dismayed studio audience, because savings and loan industry executives were allowed to gamble with depositors' money.
Members of the talk-show audience shook their heads in disbelief when they heard that the debacle could cost each household thousands of dollars. Some estimates put the figure at $5,000 a household.
Part of the reason for the new concern is that the latest estimates have coincided with discussions of a tax increase. There seems to be a growing recognition that the need for additional tax revenue has arisen in part because of the ever-increasing cost of the savings and loan bailout.
The financing of the rescue is already beginning to have a discernible economic impact. Since April, the amount of short-term notes that the Treasury has had to sell each week to finance its needs has risen by $1.2 billion, to $17.2 billion. William V. Sullivan Jr., director of money market research at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., says that the increase comes almost entirely from the need for more money to cover the savings and loan industry's losses.
That is also an important reason, he said, why short-term interest rates remain high. While long-term rates on 30-year bonds have fallen since April to 8.39 percent from 8.63 percent, short-term rates have hardly dropped at all. In a recent Treasury auction, for instance, investors demanded a 7.69 percent yield on 3-month bills, just a slight drop from the 7.75 percent level in April.
The economy and the outlook for inflation will still be the determining factors in whether interest rates shoot up to, say, 11 or 12 percent levels, or glide back down to 5 or 6 percent. But whatever level interest rates go to, they will be higher than they otherwise would have been, said Mr. Sullivan, because of the Treasury's need over the next 40 years to finance the cost of the savings and loan industry's losses.
The multi-billion-dollar bailout means that it will be harder to get mortgages and small business loans. And for those who succeed in becoming borrowers, it will mean paying higher rates. It means the Government will be able to spend fewer dollars on programs that many Americans seem to care about, like those that would improve the environment and the schools, or address the AIDS crisis, the drug epidemic or the homeless problem.
Even though the public may finally be awakening to this calamity, many academics and financial experts complain that all the arguing and finger-pointing have not led to any real changes in the policies that allowed the savings and loan industry to lose all that money in the first place.
By continuing to guarantee deposits of up to $100,000 at banks and thrifts, the Government is still underwriting a risk-prone financial system. Troubled institutions that would otherwise be taken over or forced out of business can instead attract a steady flow of deposits by offering higher rates than sound institutions, and investing the money in high-risk ventures. After all, if their strategy fails, it is the insurance funds that are on the hook and whose obligations are guaranteed by the United States Government and, ultimately, the taxpayers.
At the same time, many academics and industry specialists believe that far more thrifts and banks are allowed to exist than is economically justified because restrictions on interstate banking have prevented consolidation.
Many of the hard questions, then, have still not been seriously confronted. Does the United States need a specialized industry to finance housing when it now has an efficient mortgage market?
Does the nation need 13,000 independent banks and 3,000 independent thrifts, or should institutions be allowed to consolidate across state lines, which would also enable them to spread their risks by diversifying their sources of loans and deposits?
Most important, is it time to consider changing the system for insuring deposits so that there is less of an incentive to gamble with taxpayers' money? Some industry experts believe that if deposit insurance reform is not undertaken the taxpayers could find themselves paying an even bigger bill to rescue the banking system.
To be sure, bank regulators have done a better job of policing that industry than have their counterparts in the thrift industry. But despite those efforts, the same forces are at work. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has just $14 billion in reserves to act as a cushion for losses in a system that now has $1.8 trillion of bank assets. And given that there are already tens of billions of dollars of questionable loans to third world countries, real estate developers and overly indebted companies already on the books, some financial experts believe now is the time to start focusing on changes to the country's deposit insurance system.
''If nothing is learned from this, then we will be going through the same process with the banking system in relatively short order,'' said Gerald L. Smith, a managing director in Salomon Brothers' financial institutions group. At that point, even $325 billion and $500 billion would seem like chicken feed.

HEADLINE: The World;
With Luck and Ingenuity, Ethiopian Aid Gets Through

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya

 BODY:
WHEN the rains failed in northern Ethiopia last year and the civil war reached new levels of destruction, with thousands of casualties inflicted each month, the specter of skeletal children and mass starvation loomed again, recalling the suffering of 1984.
But early awareness of the drought, followed by creative disaster management by Western governments and relief organizations over the last five months, have averted the worst. Despite nightmarish logistical difficulties of moving food into one of the most remote, undeveloped and war-torn corners of the world, relief officials say about three million Ethiopians who were on the brink of starvation have received monthly food rations since January.
''It has been a very, very significant problem but it has been addressed through a jerry-rig set of solutions,'' said Willard J. Pierson, the director of the United States Agency for International Development's office in Addis Ababa. Mr. Pierson said that food would have to keep coming at its current pace for the next six months or ''a crisis will flare up in a matter of weeks.'' 
The summit announcement that the United States and the Soviet Union would work together to deliver relief supplies to Asmara, the Government-held capital of Eritrea, as well as to the rebel-held port of Massawa, was welcomed by relief officials. But the rebels, who are poised to seize Asmara, where food for civilians is becoming scarce, have said no to the summit plan. The Eritrean Peoples Liberation Front, which can sense that victory is near after three decades of fighting the Government, said Soviet planes trying to bring in American wheat would fly into Asmara at their own peril.
Indeed, the whole character of the war has changed in the last year. Soviet support has receded as Moscow withdraws from its role as a Government ally, and the fighting has moved into a decisive phase. The level of combat has increased so much that American officials describe it as the deadliest conflict under way in the world. The rebels seem on the verge of complete victory, and now are in a position to deny food to people on the Government side in much the same way that the Government has tried to deny food to starving people on the rebel side for years.
 
Coping Artfully
So far, the relief handlers have been able to cope without Massawa, which was taken by the rebels in February and has been bombarded ever since by the Ethiopian Air Force. But the aid officials have had to be dexterous. Ships with food from Europe and America were diverted to Assab. The food was then trucked - after arduous negotiations with the Government - by an Ethiopian church group through Government-held territory into the rebel-held province of Tigre. With an expected donation of 300,000 tons of food by the end of the year, the United States is the biggest single donor to the international operation. While it does not formally acknowledge it, Washington has dispatched most of the grain through what is known as the ''back door,'' an overland truck route through the Sudan from Port Sudan to rebel-held Tigre and Eritrea.
Given the reluctance of the Government of Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam to let enough food cross its lines into Tigre and Eritrea, Washington has had little choice but to deal directly with the rebels, with whom it has no formal ties. An estimated 70 percent of Ethiopians affected by drought live in the rebel-held areas, which now include all of Tigre and most of Eritrea.
In addition to importing food, Washington has found an unusual undercover way of acquiring food inside Ethiopia. Serendipitously, the western region of Tigre produced surplus crops earlier this year, and this trove of up to 80,000 tons of grain is being bought for the province's drought-stricken eastern section by the United States Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance. Officials familiar with the plan say the disaster office has hired Fred Cuny, a relief expert with years of experience in Africa, to travel to Jiddah, where he changes $500,000 of agency money at a time on the black market for Ethiopian currency, the birr. He then travels the ''back door'' route into Tigre and purchases grain, which is then trucked from western Tigre to the east. Officials said the disaster office has dedicated $4 million to the operation, which a Scandinavian relief agency is also helping.
The intensity of Washington's effort to avert another Ethiopian famine seems to illustrate that the humanitarian impulse has replaced the strategic drive that dominated American policy in the Horn of Africa during the cold war. In the neighboring drought-stricken Sudan, Washington has also given aid on both sides of a civil war. ''The one thing the State Department can't stand,'' one diplomat said, ''is having Congressmen hammering them because constituents are calling up after seeing starving Africans on the television screen.''

HEADLINE: The World;
Sound of Hands Shaking Wakes Asia

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
AFTER fretting that it was being left out of the changes transforming Europe, Asia received its first bracing encounter with the global diplomacy of the 1990's last week as a Soviet leader met a South Korean President for the first time. The hastily arranged visit in San Francisco handed President Roh Tae Woo a diplomatic windfall and gave President Mikhail S. Gorbachev a chance to maneuver in a region he has largely ignored until now.
But as the excitement died down, diplomats and experts added a dose of realism to the hopes the meeting had raised. Northeast Asia, they said, is likely to remain frustrating for those trying to undo the last but most thorny vestiges both of the cold war and of the hot wars that created the intricate political fault lines that fragment the region. 
The concern that the potential changes may only bring greater risks was made clear in the headline on an editorial that appeared in the Asahi Shimbun, a leading Japanese daily: ''Asia on Thin, Melting Ice.''
The caution was not misplaced. The complex reactions of the region's major political players all underscored how difficult it is likely to be to soothe the irritants each feels.
The Soviet Union subsequently played down the meeting as little more than talks with a commercial partner. Partly, it seemed, this was an attempt to avoid alienating Communist North Korea completely.
A humiliated North Korea lashed out at the talks as treachery, and there was speculation that Pyongyang would just be driven closer to its other principal ally, China, rather than toward reunification.
China, for its part, was so consumed by domestic problems a year after the killings in Tiananmen Square that it took little official notice of the Roh-Gorbachev encounter. There were no substantial signs that China's hard line at home was softening.
And the Japanese brooded, saying the meeting represented no real change because the Soviets had said nothing about returning the four northern islands they took from Japan in the closing days of World War II. There were reports that Mr. Gorbachev had suggested to American officials in Washington that the Soviets might consider swapping the islands for substantial economic aid. But Japanese officials, who have been working on a visit by Mr. Gorbachev that is planned for next year, said they had heard nothing of such an offer.
Some Japanese felt especially slighted when their long-planned debut as a diplomatic problem-solver - as host of a meeting here for the warring Cambodian factions to sign a cease-fire accord - was totally upstaged by their economic competitors, the South Koreans.
 
A Question of Speed
''We had been saying that the reforms in Eastern Europe hadn't reached the Far East as quickly as we'd hoped,'' said Kuniko Inoguchi, a professor of international politics at Sophia University in Tokyo. But then the Roh-Gorbachev meeting ''happened much faster than we'd expected in Japan,'' she said. ''That still leaves us wondering where it will go and whether Japan is really doing everything it can to make progress.''
On the Korean peninsula, diplomats and scholars had not expected any positive responses to the Soviet-Korea meeting from Pyongyang, and they were not disappointed. Underdeveloped North Korea, which has watched in anger over the last two years as most of its former East European allies exchanged ambassadors with prosperous South Korea, was left even more isolated by Mr. Gorbachev's move.
But there were no signs that Pyongyang was budging from its hard line against an opening to Seoul.
A senior Japanese diplomat suggested that Asia might have to wait for Pyongyang to reach a more dramatic moment of truth. ''In the short run,'' the diplomat said, ''It's probably a minus for dialogue between the North and the South. North Korea is going to have to reach some kind of Buddhist enlightenment to deal with some of the new realities of the world.''
 
Different Pressures
A Western diplomat in Seoul also pointed out that, unlike the breakthroughs last year that set the stage for German reunification, none of the preliminary confidence-building steps that had been present in Europe exist now in Korea. North Korea still blocks deliveries of mail and telephone calls from the South, has sharply limited reunions of divided families and has almost no trade with its enemy.
In addition, the diplomat added, economic pressures are unlikely to work in North Korea as they did in Eastern Europe, because the Government has so effectively cut the country off from the world, making economic backwardness a measure of ideological purity. ''It's a very spartan society and they are inured to a lot of hardship,'' the diplomat said.
Feelings in Japan were more complex. Many resented what they saw as a Soviet effort to play a ''South Korea card'' - using the opening to Seoul to dislodge Japan from its rigid insistence that the four islands, Habomai, Shikotan, Etorofu and Kunashiri, be returned before Japan will expand relations with the Soviets.
Japan and the Soviet Union opened diplomatic relations in 1956, and they have extensive trade, but they have yet to sign a peace treaty. Many Japanese businessmen would like to expand trade and investment, and the Soviets would love access to Japanese capital and technology. But progress has been stalled and the resentments remain.
''I'm not saying that nothing is happening in Asia,'' said a senior Japanese Foreign Ministry official. ''but we have to strike the right balance between saying what's new and what's not.''

HEADLINE: The Region;
The Latest Plan for the Adirondacks Leaves Adirondackers Skeptical

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK

DATELINE: CHESTERTOWN, N.Y.

 BODY:
WITH dozens of majestic peaks, 31,000 miles of rivers and streams and millions of acres of forested wilderness, New York's Adirondack Park is often referred to as the largest park in the lower 48 states. Indeed, the area encompassed within the Adirondacks Park's boundary - larger than Yellowstone, Grand Canyon, Glacier and Olympic National Parks combined -qualifies for the designation.
But park is far too simple a term for the Adirondack Park, which is actually a complex patchwork of public wilderness, vast timber tracts and smaller plots of privately held land. That explains some of the growing tension caused by the recent recommendations of a special commission appointed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. 
The commission, warning of a ''last clear chance'' to preserve much of the Adirondacks' wilderness character, recommended a sweeping program of state land acquisition and zoning restrictions that would channel almost all future construction to about 10 percent of the park's 6 million acres. The remainder would in essence be preserved as open space, with much of that land set aside as wilderness areas where human intrusion would be sharply limited and motorized vehicles prohibited altogether. The land purchases would raise the state's ownership to more than 50 percent of the Adirondack Park's area, from 42 percent, and the zoning regulations would extend far beyond measures enacted in the 1970's to control development.
But for all the natural grandeur there is another side to Adirondack Park. It is the year-round home of 130,000 people, some of whom live in communities that are among the poorest in New York State. Per capita income within the park is less than three-quarters of the state average and unemployment is widespread.
''We're trying to get people to understand that this is not just a playground up here,'' said Mike Connery, the supervisor of the town of Ticonderoga. Charlie E. Bartgis, who directs a public-access television project in the Adirondacks, said, ''If you really travel around, you know you're also talking about a place that has pockets of Appalachia. There's dirt poverty.''
 
Local Opposition
So far, dozens of local governments have officially voted to oppose the commission's overall approach, which includes a one-year moratorium on permits for new construction in much of the park, saying it could be crippling to the local economy.
The commission's report contains several recommendations for revitalizing the Adirondack economy, such as creation of special development corporations to build low-income housing and other local projects, to be financed by a special tax on the sale of luxury residences within the park. The larger goal was to foster both ''great open spaces'' and ''dynamic hamlets,'' said Peter A. A. Berle, the president of the National Audubon Society and chairman of the panel, the Governor's Commission on the Adirondacks in the 21st Century.
But such ideas have been met with skepticism by people in the park, many of whom complain that the commission is seeking to ''herd'' them into the hamlets. ''This wasn't a commission created to help people in the Adirondacks,'' said Frederick H. Monroe, a former town attorney in Chestertown who is chairman of the Adirondack Fairness Coalition, one of several citizens' group formed in opposition to the report. ''And any bones they throw in there about helping the locals are just that - bones tossed to try to placate us.''
There is an even angrier side to the opposition. Another group, the Adirondack Solidarity Alliance, has at times shut down parts of the Interstate highway through the Adirondacks, and some members have threatened to take up arms or burn parts of the forest if the recommendations are implemented by the Legislature. Others have put up posters accusing members of the commission of trying to commit ''genocide against the Adirondack people.'' The commission's executive director, George D. Davis, has been shouted at in several meetings while trying to explain the report. In Plattsburgh last week he was forced to give up altogether and was escorted off the stage by state troopers.
 
Specter of Development
Amid all the arguments about whether the state should save the Adirondacks or save the Adirondackers, the danger is that it will do neither. Sales of subdivided land tripled from 1982 to 1985 and had doubled again by 1988, the commission reported. Much of the vast, forested back country remains open to the kind of large second-home developments whose specter caused Governor Cuomo to form the commission after one major forest-products company had been forced to sell off the land for quick cash in the early 1980's.
Meanwhile, there is virtually no consensus in the Legislature, which would have to approve most of the commission's proposals. Although the commission's report was issued more than a month ago, Mr. Cuomo has yet to embrace any of the proposals. When he recently listed the 15 top priorities for the remainder of the legislative session, which is expected to end within the month, the implementation of the Adirondack study was not among them. Aides said he preferred to study all reactions to the report before deciding how to proceed.
When he formed the commission early last year, the Governor said the Adirondacks appeared to be threatened by ''an era of unbridled land speculation and unwarranted development.'' The commission concluded that such dangers were real, but Mr. Cuomo's deputy secretary for environmental affairs, Francis Murray, said recently that the Governor ''has a lot of questions about the factual predicate for the Berle commission's recommendations.''
In an interview inside the park last winter, Mr. Davis, the commission's director, spoke not just of protecting the North Country's wilderness and diversity, but also of preserving something he defined as ''Adirondack culture.''
''It would be shame if 20 years from now, you and I come back to the Adirondacks,'' he said, ''and all you see of the local Adirondackers are the service people. I think it's kind of important to stop at the Miss Tupper Diner, or the Lumberjack Diner back there in Blue Mountain Lake - although that's closed now - and some of these others, the Long Lake Cafe, and you can see the plaid shirts and you can see some real people.''
Many of these real people, however, remain doubtful that the state has their interests in mind. The challenge to the state will be to find a balance for both the humanity and the wilderness whose home is the Adirondacks: otherwise, both might fairly be said to remain endangered.
