PUB-DATE: June 10, 1990

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2, Page 20, Column 1; Business World Magazine

LENGTH: 4227 words

HEADLINE: A CROWBAR FOR CARLA HILLS

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE; Louis Uchitelle covers economics for The Times.

 BODY:
The office of the United States Trade Representative is housed in a 19th- century building that once served as Union Army headquarters. Gen. Ulysses S. Grant occupied the spare, high-ceilingedroom that now is the office of Carla A. Hills, the nation's chief trade negotiator.
Hills has filled the narrow room with framed family-style snapshots; some of herself with her husband and four children, others of her with President Bush - as if he, too, were family. One photo, taken at her swearing in on Feb. 6, 1989, has been blown up to poster size and hung in the conference room adjoining Hills's office. It records a scene in which Bush hands Carla Hills a crowbar. They are laughing, and Hills's hand rests lightly on the President's back. The inscription, scrawled in black felt pen: ''To Carla, I know you'll use this with finesse and strength.''
No foreign trade negotiator, looking across the table at that photo, can miss the point. Hills speaks for her friend the President. She is the ally Bush selected from his political retinue in December 1988 to pry open foreign markets. As the nation's Trade Representative, or Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary (her ceremonial title), the 56-year-old California attorney has been thrust into some of the most troublesome political and economic issues in the world today. 
An intractable trade deficit has become emblematic of the nation's slide as an economic power - and of the often unsuccessful struggle of American corporations to outsell the Japanese, the Germans, the Italians, the Koreans and other vigorously industrial nations. Hills, a persistent, fiercely competitive, sometimes thin-skinned, workaholic, leads the campaign to increase American sales abroad. For most of her 16 months as Trade Representative, Congress has been goading her to concentrate particularly on Japan, which accounted for 44 percent of the nation's $113 billion trade deficit last year.
''Trade is the goose that laid Japan's golden egg,'' Hills comments. ''And Japan just happens to be the bad boy of trade internationally.''
Hills is under pressure to make full use of the 1988 Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act, which enhanced the Administration's power to retaliate against unfair traders. With the Act's new Section 301, called Super 301, Congress in a sense created for Hills her own crowbar, the authority to cite Japan, among others, as unfair trading partners: countries that seize an advantage by breaking American trade rules. Under the new 301 the punishment is a tariff of as much as 100 percent if the country doesn't mend its ways within two years.
One month after taking office, Hills named Japan, Brazil and India as unfair trading partners, but recently the Bush Administration decided that Japan apparently was mending its ways and should not be cited further. Just weeks before the Trade Representative's office was due to take another look at the situation, the Japanese agreed to purchase from the United States more finished-wood products, supercomputers and communications satellites, the three areas for which Japan had been cited under 301 last year. Many critics argue that these agreements, as negotiated by Hills's young staff, are vague and that the Japanese will backslide, as they have in the past. But for the Bush Administration, eager to avoid friction with Japan, the new commitments appear to be sufficient.
''The President is guided in his priorities by defense and foreign policy considerations, and not trade issues,'' says Pat Choate, vice president for policy analysis at TRW Inc., a defense contractor. Choate urges stepping up pressure on Japan to buy American goods.
Whatever the President's priorities, he has given Hills another task with Japan: the pursuit of a revolutionary strategy in trade policy. This effort, bureaucratically dubbed the Structural Impediments Initiative, is aimed at getting the Japanese to change the very nature of the way they do business.
Talks have produced an interim report in which the new Japanese Prime Minister, Toshiki Kaifu, says he will seek ways to speed the stores in Japan that carry American products, in competition withthe small shops that now dominate retailing and handle mostly domestic merchandise. Kaifu will also encourage his nation to buy on credit, tighten antitrust and patent laws and take other steps that would make the Japanese marketplace friendlier to American companies and products.
''We have never had these commitments before from the Japanese,'' Hills says. ''If the Japanese do the things that they say they will do, that will make a difference.''
If not, Congress may take matters into its own hands. Hills says that Senator Max Baucus, the Montana Democrat who heads the Finance Committee's trade subcommittee, has told her, ''Either you get results or I'm going to convert the Structural Impediments Talks into a mandatory Super 301 action.''
While the Bush Administration must mollify Congress, its own preference on trade is neither Section 301 nor the Structural Impediments Initiative. The President's chosen forum is the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT, which functions, United Nations style, mostly out of the headlines. GATT operates on the assumption that a body of rules will open borders for American products and for those of other countries as well. In this setting, neither Japan nor any other country gets blamed for the United States trade deficit. Instead, delegations from 97 countries seek ways to notch down everyone's tariffs and remove other obstacles to trade.
Hills heads the American GATT delegation that is trying to do this in drawn-out talks known as the Uruguay Round, named for the country in which these sessions began in 1986. The talks, carried out mostly in Geneva, and intended to end in December, are the first major GATT negotiations in a decade, but Hills sometimes despairs of awakening Americans to their importance: ''I've had too many bright people - I mean this not in a disparaging way - ask, 'What's the Uruguay Round?' You say, 'We're trying to develop international law governing trade in 15 areas.' It sounds so technical. It's just very difficult for the human mind that's not fascinated by arcane details on trade to get enthusiastic about that.''
Hills herself was no expert on trade when she accepted the job as chief negotiator. She had been Secretary of Housing and Urban Development in the Ford Administration. In private life, she was a lawyer with a specialty in antitrust and she served on the board of directors of several major corporations, gaining a name for herself as perennial nominee for a top post in any Republican Administration. With Hills and Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole, Bush made women visible in his Cabinet.
In the Bush Administration, trade policy is set at the highest levels. Hills is included in the deliberations of the Economic Policy Council, a select half-dozen people who decide trade issues along with President Bush. Armed with marching orders from these deliberations, Hills then wades into the arcana of trade: the quotas, tariffs and talks that define her office. ''I negotiate,'' she says. ''That's my life.''
President Bush announced last July 25 that he would extend for two and a half years the quotas that since 1984 had limited foreign steel imports to less than 20 percent of the American market. The decision apparently surprised Hills's staff. ''I was talking to Mrs. Hills's people after the announcement, and they had been preparing for a four-year extension,'' says an aide to Senator John Heinz, a Pennsylvania Republican and the co-chairman of the Senate Steel Caucus. ''They were caught short.''
According to several accounts, Hills had sought two two-year extensions of the quotas, during the first of which her staff would negotiate agreements requiring each of the 19 nations participating in the quota program to phase out their unfair trading practices: low-cost government loans to steel companies and other subsidies. During the second extension the 19 nations - including Britain, Brazil, France, Italy, Spain and Portugal - would then phase out those practices. The argument was that the steel industry needed the longer period of protection.
Even before the issue reached the Policy Council, lower-level aides from various agencies had developed position papers on the alternatives. There was the steel industry view - extend the quotas for another five years - which Labor Secretary Dole and Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher favored. The more orthodox free-traders among Bush's top people - in the steel case, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, and Richard G. Darman, the budget director - wanted the quotas extended for two years, at most. Their view reflected in part the pressure from a coalition of steel users, led by Caterpillar Inc., that wanted no quotas at all. By eliminating quotas, they said, supply would increase and prices come down.
''Mrs. Hills did not carry our case,'' says Timothy Elder, a Caterpillar executive. But Hills did endorse one of the major steel users' requests: an easing of import restrictions on specialty steels not available from domestic producers. And Elder praises Hills's analytical skills: ''She goes around the table and she says, 'Now wait a minute, he said that and you said this. Which is it?' She has an unnerving ability to ferret out facts.''
Bush was present at one of the three Economic Policy Council sessions at which the steel case was argued. A few days after the last session, the President announced his decision, one that he reached in the privacy of the Oval Office. Bush did incorporate Hills's main idea: a 19-nation negotiation to phase out unfair trading practices, but they could last only two-and-a-half years, not four. Most of the agreements have in fact been achieved.
Soft-pedaling any disagreement on duration, Hills, the team player, says that the steel quota debate was ''a perfect illustration of working toward a round consensus.'' Her chief of staff and counselor, Gary Edson, who sat in with her at the Policy Council meetings, insists there was no disagreement: ''Ambassador Hills never took a position on duration in the Policy Council meetings.'' What was all-important to Carla Hills, he says, ''was to make increases in quotas conditional on country commitments to eliminate unfair trading practices.''
Hills acknowledges the communal nature of making trade policy in the Bush Administration. She says that she never issues a policy pronouncement nor does she take an action that will surprise the upper reaches of the Bush Administration. ''I think that I have a lot of running room on trade,'' she says, ''and the reason that I do is that my style is to consult.''
Carla Hills Remembers herself as a tomboy who excelled in sports. She rode five-gaited horses, sailed and, at the private girls' high school she attended in Los Angeles, played varsity basketball and volleyball. In college she became a champion tennis player. An Alexander Hamilton biography that she read at the age of 12 propelled her toward the legal profession. ''Law represented capability to me,'' she says. ''You look at people like Hamilton, great contributors to our history, and many of them have been trained in the law.''
After an undergraduate degree at Stanford, Hills defied her father by traveling East and entering Yale Law School. The dean of Stanford's law school had praised Yale, and she wanted the best, she says. She paid for the first year out of her savings until her father, who had made a fortune in his own building supply business, gave in.
''Her father became very proud, once he understood that a woman could succeed as a lawyer. But his first reaction had been to keep her close to home,'' her husband, Roderick Hills, says. ''He also did not want her to marry me. He was suspicious of lawyers.''
Carla Anderson graduated from Yale Law in 1958, 21st in a class of 167, and married Hills, a graduate of Stanford Law, soon after. She took a job as an assistant United States Attorney in Los Angeles, doing trial work. Private law firms, she says, offered women only routine jobs. ''I did not want to find myself not having an opportunity down the road,'' she says.
Her first child, Laura, who is now also a lawyer, was born in 1961. The next year, Carla and Roderick Hills formed a Los Angeles law firm -Munger, Tolles, Hills & Rickershauser - with three others. Though eventually she negotiated a full salary, initially Carla was paid far less than Roderick - because she was a woman.
''She was just furious privately, but publicly she said forget it,'' says her son, Roderick Jr., a Yale law student. ''My mom tends to be very quiet about grievances.'' While working 12-hour days, she raised three daughters and a son. It is simply, Carla Hills says, a matter of managing one's time.
She arrived in Washington in the dying days of the Nixon Administration and took a job at the Justice Department as head of the Civil Division. Roderick Hills, who by now was known as a corporate trouble-shooter, became chairman of the S.E.C. in the Ford Administration and Carla Hills became Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, the third woman in history to hold a United States Cabinet post.
Carla Hills did not practice law again until a year after leaving H.U.D. in 1977, more than fulfilling Government ethics requirements for former officials. But in 1985, as a partner at Latham & Watkins, she went to see Samuel R. Pierce Jr., then H.U.D. Secretary, on behalf of her client, DRG Funding. DRG, a major mortgage lender, was the largest in H.U.D.'s $5 billion co-insurance program but had run afoul of H.U.D. standards and was having trouble obtaining new loan guarantees.
Shortly after Hills's visit, Pierce issued a nine-page letter summarizing DRG's sins. Nevertheless, he renewed the loan guarantees - on which H.U.D. now has a liability of $769.5 million and has paid claims of $122.5 million. Hills's visit to Pierce surfaced last year during a Congressional investigation into the H.U.D. scandal. Trade Representative Hills spent nearly six hours answering questions before the House Employment and Housing subcommittee.
She pointed out that there had been no payoff, only $33,500 in fees for 150 hours of legal work. She argued that in 1985 DRG was still a respected mortgage lender, and that she had worked through proper channels. ''I can tell you, never in a million years did I think this case would come back and haunt me,'' she says.
Although Congress did not censure her, the episode casts a shadow. ''It was unfair to put her in the Hall of Shame, as Time Magazine did,'' says Stuart Weisberg, staff director for the subcommittee. ''But I wouldn't put her in the Hall of Fame either.''
If Hills is the flag bearer in trade, her authority is hard to pinpoint in the process of negotiating trade agreements. One of her deputies, Julius Katz, recently negotiated a new Long-Term Grain Agreement with the Soviet Union. The United States position was developed almost entirely at the interagency level - Katz meeting with his counterparts at Agriculture, State and Commerce - and in consultation with farm groups.
Katz led the delegation to Vienna that negotiated the final terms, and he carried with him instructions that gave him enough power to settle on an agreement that allows the Soviets to purchase a minimum of 10 million tons of grain a year and a maximum of 14 million tons.
Although the Trade Representative's office has only 150 staffers and a meager $18 million annual budget, Carla Hills won a turf battle last year with Mosbacher and his much bigger Commerce Department over the right to negotiate a new Russian Trade Treaty. Last year, the United States had a trade surplus of about $3 billion with Russia. Here, too, Katz has been the lead negotiator, and again details have been worked out at the interagency level. But some issues have required decisions by Hills, among them how long the Soviet Union can take to pass legislation governing intellectual property rights, such as copyright and patent protection.
In weighing alternatives, Hills operates like a newspaper editor, Katz says. ''Some editors can take on more authority than others,'' he says. ''They know what decisions their reputations can sustain and what has to be referred to higher authority. Hills has to make this sort of judgment.''
Skilled lawyer that she is, Hills has worked out a way to make the two contradictory thrusts in the Bush Administration trade policy sound like components of the same logical strategy. One is the effort to pry open the Japanese market and the other the Bush Administration preference for multilateral negotiations.
''My objective is to get the world's trading system open,'' Hills says, ''so that entrepreneurs, wherever they are located, can sell and buy and expand trade without government interference.'' For Hills, the avenue to open markets runs through the multilateral GATT negotiations.
The 97 signatories to GATT account for two-thirds of the $3 trillion in merchandise traded each year. Since the original agreement in 1947, GATT has been altered six times, with tariffs reduced each time - from an initial 40 percent to an average of less than 5 percent for most items traded today. For 30 years, that reduction benefited the United States, which filled the world with its superior and low-cost manufactured goods.
But after the last GATT revision - the Tokyo Round, which started in 1976 - many American industries were outclassed by others. During the 1980's, the United States trade deficit ballooned, leading to protectionism in this country and such rules as Section 301, which is intended to force others to buy American.
Free trade, however, means that governments remove the tariffs, subsidies and other protectionist measures that give one nation's goods an advantage over another's. In spirit, Hills is a free trader, but one who prefers not to use the label. ''Those are words that are loaded with emotional baggage,'' she says. She prefers ''open markets.''
''If you open the Japanese market, you will not necessarily create an opportunity for U.S. entrepreneurs,'' she says, in effect applying the GATT negotiations to the Japanese problem. ''I do not open their market to create sweetheart deals for American entrepreneurs. I open markets so that we can trade in a competitive fashion.''
But many in Congress are not satisfied with this reasoning. Senator John C. Danforth, the Missouri Republican who has taken a hard line on Japan, accuses Hills of trying to fool Congress. ''The Administration is really trying to finesse trade policy into something that is vague and indefinite,'' he says.
Whatever the thrust of the trade policy, a third theory is jostling for Hills's attention: managed trade. Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., a Japan expert and a former Commerce Department official, argues that the Japanese go at business differently than Americans. One of their goals, he says, is to gain leadership in certain industries - autos, semiconductors, VCR's, machine tools, supercomputers. They try to prevent American manufacturers from selling these products in Japan, while they flood the world with their goods.
The solution, says Prestowitz, is managed trade: making deals with the Japanese. The Japanese, for instance, sell cars in the United States through Chrysler, Ford and Chevrolet dealers, so American auto makers should have similar rights in Japan. Currently they cannot sell through Japanese dealers.
The Hills reply draws on her skill in steering between the two thrusts in trade policy. ''I do agree with Clyde that you have to be constant, firm and decided in dealing with the Japanese,'' she says. ''But that doesn't mean that I have to be strident and shrewish in my approach. I don't belong to the Japan-bashing school.''
But Hills might not be free to indulge the Bush preference for free trade, if the Japanese fail to keep their 301 promises. The agreements on satellites and supercomputers, for example, make bidding more open to American companies, but do not require Japanese companies to buy many more American products.
Nevertheless, Congress raised little protest this spring when the Bush Administration decided not to cite the Japanese again under 301. One reason is that the nation's trade deficit has declined. Another is Hills's success in convincing Congress that the agreements constitute progress. Carla Hills is not a deal-making, back-slapping politician like her predecessors, Clayton K. Yeutter and Robert S. Strauss. She is formal, precise, ever ready to testify on the Hill and thoroughly briefed on each trade issue.
''I find her very logical, very legal, very rational in her explanations to the committee,'' says Senator Robert W. Packwood, ranking Republican on the Finance Committee, which has oversight on trade. ''You can ask her for a detailed explanation of some matter that someone only in the bowels of the negotiations would be expected to know, and she knows it.''
Maybe she is too wrapped up in details, says Strauss, who was President Carter's Trade Representative. ''The only thing I would say critical of her I have said to her directly,'' Strauss says. ''I told her, 'I would like to see you make a speech every day, and go all over the world.' '' As it is, Hills speaks or makes public appearances at least eight times a month and has traveled twice to Japan and to Europe.
If Japan continues to abide by 301 and mend its ways under the Structural Impediments Initiative, if the Trade Representative gets everything she wants out of the Uruguay Round, does that mean the United States trade deficit will decline? Not necessarily, says Hills: opening markets and reducing the trade deficit are different kettles of fish. Explaining the point during an interview, she jumps up from a stuffed armchair in her office, takes a legal pad and outlines an economic theory that seems unassailable to her.
''The budget deficit creates a big problem for me because it creates a bad political climate in which to make good trade policy,'' Hills says. ''But if I were to tell you that I had a bag of fairy dust, and I could open all markets tomorrow, the question would be, 'Would we necessarily have a zero deficit in that year?'
''I couldn't answer that question. I would have to ask, 'Are we, in that year, going to spend more than we save? Are we going to invest more than we save?' If we are going to use last year's standard of investing about 15 percent of our gross domestic product, but only save 13 percent, then we will have a gap of about $110 billion that we have to import from overseas to finance our investment.''
Hills, in sum, is reciting Economics 101. If Americans spend more than they save, they have to go overseas to borrow the shortfall. The way they do that is to import on credit - import more than they pay for with exports.
Others say that this argument ignores a more important point - that the United States should develop high-tech industries that would be competitive in world markets. Akio Morita, chairman of the Sony Corporation, would agree. As he said in a television interview: ''If your business runs shortsighted, and if your industry is buying Japanese products, the imbalance of trade will never decrease.''
Hills's staff promotes and embellishes her image as a persistent and hard-working trade chief. Victoria Clarke, the assistant trade representative for public affairs, displays her boss's daily calendars, which show frequent 14-hour days. There are countless briefing papers to read, numerous visitors. And sometimes her negotiators barge in on Hills for help in resolving a crisis.
The relentless pace continues most weekends. On Sundays, Hills can often be found at the office, where if necessary she will wash out the coffee cups. ''Carla's favorite expression is that she likes people who do windows,'' says Gary Edson, her chief of staff. ''She is not a prima donna.''
In the future, Hills will undoubtedly become a candidate for another high Government job. If one does not materialize, there is always the private sector. Pat Choate, of TRW, charges that many trade officials take private-sector jobs, working for Japanese and other foreign companies.
That is not likely to happen in Hills's case. When she took her current position, she and her family went to great pains to avoid conflicts of interest. Her husband, operating these days as a lawyer and consultant, dropped Japanese clients. Her daughter, Laura, steered clear of trade cases, although that is her legal specialty. And Hills herself set up a procedure to withdraw from trade issues involving clients of her former law firm.
Carla Hills's name has cropped up in recent years on speculative lists of potential Supreme Court candidates. In the 1970's, in fact, Hills says President Ford asked her if she would be interested in going to the Supreme Court. She replied that she liked her job at H.U.D.
She gives a similar answer now, insisting that she cannot think beyond her present post. ''I don't know how to dispel the Supreme Court rumor,'' she says. ''I guess that once you're on a list, you can't get off it.''

PUB-DATE: June 10, 1990

SECTION: Section 3; Part 2, Page 26, Column 1; Business World Magazine

LENGTH: 4544 words

HEADLINE: BETTING THE FARM ON BIOTECH

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER; Keith Schneider is a New York Times national correspondent based in Washington.

 BODY:
The sun beats down on green fields of corn that have never seen chemical insecticides or weed killers. Over the ridge, docile Holsteins are producing more milk on less feed than has ever before been possible, and piglets are growing into lean adults at uncommon speed. The air is free of dust from eroding topsoil and a stream drains the gentle slopes, its waters as sweet and pure as a mountain spring. Supermarkets are jammed with the bounty of a skillful, careful farming that is as safe as it is productive.
This is the agricultural landscape of the 21st century as envisioned by Howard A. Schneiderman, senior vice president of research and development and chief scientist at the Monsanto Company. In the past decade the St. Louis-based chemical manufacturer has invested over $800 million - more than any other company in the world - in agricultural biotechnology, the business of altering plants, animals and microbes by artificially mixing and matching their genes. It is the 63-year-old Schneiderman, a Manhattan-raised scientist who learned his farming from textbooks, who has set Monsanto on a course that could forever change how food and fiber are produced. ''Monsanto is developing a way to use Mother Nature to modify organisms to serve us better,'' says Schneiderman, whose favorite word for the technology is ''fantastic.'' 
Eleven years after Schneiderman came to Monsanto to reinvent farming, the company remains one of the most profitable in the chemical industry, even though it has yet to reap the first dollar of pay back from its genetic-engineering efforts in agriculture. Monsanto is standing ready with its first biotechnology product, a genetically engineered growth hormone for dairy cows, and is eager to follow up with a similar product for pigs. In the mid-1990's, Schneiderman says, Monsanto plans to introduce gene-altered crops capable of resisting viral diseases, insects and - to the alarm of environmentalists - Monsanto's own weed killer. In all, the company has 15 farm-biotechnology products in the pipeline, and Monsanto executives believe the combined sales and royalties could approach $1 billion a year by the end of the decade.
Yet strewn across Monsanto's path to the next century are a variety of cultural, political, scientific and economic barriers. As the acknowledged leaders in farm biotechnology, Schneiderman and his Monsanto colleagues find their work at the center of an international debate. The controversy, which once focused solely on the prudence of releasing new life forms in fields and feed lots, has broadened to include questions about the technology's impact on farm economy and food safety. critics are also challenging Monsanto's assertion that biotechnology will make farming more profitable and less destructive to the air, water and soil.
''The kind of biotechnology that Monsanto has embarked upon is silver-bullet technology that will prolong the system of agriculture we have now,'' says Jack Doyle, director of the agriculture and biotechnology project at Friends of the Earth, an environmental group in Washington. ''We have the potential to understand biological systems in agriculture like never before, such as understanding the entire cycle of how pests attack crops and how crops respond. But the way the technology is being capitalized and developed, we're intervening for the convenience of a product.''
Monsanto has spent $300 million developing the genetically engineered growth hormone for cows, bovine somatotropin, or BST. The hormone, which three other companies have also been racing to bring to market, has been shown to increase milk production by 10 percent to 25 percent. But BST is the target of a furious philosophical and economic struggle in dairy states across the upper Middle West, New York and New England - where many dairy farmers argue that BST will cause a milk glut and force prices down.
Several of the nation's largest supermarket chains barred experimental use of BST in their suppliers' herds last summer, pending approval by the United States Food and Drug Administration. Last March, Wisconsin lawmakers voted to ban BST temporarily in the nation's largest dairy state - the first time a product of genetic engineering had been restricted by a legislative body.
According to the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment, more than 400 American companies may be spending as much as $2 billion a year on biotechnology research and development, not only for farming but for medical and industrial uses as well. The major players in agricultural biotechnology include American Cyanamid, Dow Chemical, Du Pont, Eli Lilly, Upjohn and W. R. Grace.
It is a business requiring huge investments that offer no immediate, or certain, return. Many small biotechnology startups, especially those concentrating on agriculture, have been forced to merge with or sell out to bigger companies - or have failed altogether. The pressure to show results is even falling on corporations the size of Monsanto, the nation's fourth-largest chemical company, with sales last year of $8.68 billion.
One Wall Street investment house, Mabon, Nugent & Company, estimates that research for BST alone is costing Monsanto up to $50 million a year, and Mabon analysts predict that Monsanto may abandon the project if the company is not at least breaking even on BST sales by 1993. But Monsanto's Schneiderman, who expects the Food and Drug Administration to approve BST next year, insists that Monsanto will not waver on the cow hormone and other farm biotechnologies.
This is a company with a history of patience: its best-selling agricultural product, the herbicide Roundup, was approved for the market in 1974, a full 23 years after investigators set out to find an antidote to Johnson grass, a rugged weed. With biotechnology, Monsanto is once again thinking long term.
''Let's imagine the year 2030 or 2050,'' says Schneiderman. ''Where will food come from? We're going to have to have a sustainable, renewable agriculture forever.''
The progenitors of biotechnology were two California scientists, Stanley N. Cohen of Stanford University and Herbert W. Boyer of the University of California at San Francisco. In 1973 they managed to isolate fragments of a gene from one bacterium and insert them into another to create a bit of living cellular material that had never before existed. Their work, and all genetic engineering since, has focused on the substance that controls the growth and behavior of every living organism: deoxyribonucleic acid, or DNA.
A long, twisting molecule, DNA consists of linked pairs of chemicals that are identical in the cells of a virus, a frog, a person and every other living thing. These so-called ''base pairs'' form the ladder-like steps of DNA's characteristic double-helix strand. A single gene is a section of DNA made up of 1,000 to 1 million base pairs.
Though the number of genes varies among organisms - viruses have 10 genes or fewer, humans have as many as 100,000 - all of life, in effect, is assembled from the same parts department. This biological unity enables genetic engineers to bypass natural evolution and create whole new varieties of living organisms.
The Cohen-Boyer breakthrough came at a pivotal moment for the chemical industry. John W. Hanley, who was then Monsanto's chairman, recognized that core elements of the company's business faced a limited future. The basic ingredient of many Monsanto products was petroleum, and the 1973-74 Arab embargo provided graphic evidence that oil was growing more costly. The use of farm chemicals, moreover, was coming under attack by environmentalists and consumer groups.
Hanley saw potential salvation in the emerging field of genetic engineering. But Monsanto, an old hand in the making and marketing of chemicals, knew next to nothing about the branch of science that had conceived gene splicing - molecular biology. The company went shopping for expertise.
Schneiderman was dean of the School of Biological Sciences at the University of California, Irvine, when Hanley invited him to Monsanto headquarters for a job interview in March 1979. As a member of the National Academy of Sciences, and a recognized expert in the techniques of genetic engineering, Schneiderman struck Hanley as the ideal person to oversee Monsanto's biotechnology efforts.
''We spent $170 million on research in 1978,'' Hanley told Schneiderman. ''We probably should have spent $275 million. Do you have any good ideas?'' It was a striking proposition, Schneiderman recalls. ''If you're a red-blooded American who has chosen research as a career, and a guy comes and says, 'Do you have any good ideas for $100 million worth of research?' it's a fantastic temptation.'' Howard Schneiderman came aboard and helped Monsanto spend its money.
A major outlay has been more than $165 million to construct and outfit the Life Sciences Research Center, a 210-acre campus 25 miles west of downtown St. Louis in suburban Chesterfield, Mo. The center is known around the company as the House That Howard Built.
In the center's four buildings and 250 laboratories, 900 researchers spend their days hunched over petri dishes and centrifuges.
Richard J. Mahoney, Monsanto's current chairman, hopes that the products these scientists create will account for half of the company's sales 20 years from now. Fervor and portent give this place the kind of electricity that must have charged the atmosphere at Columbia University in the years just before World War II, when Enrico Fermi and Leo Szilard were testing theories for sustaining a nuclear chain reaction. Indeed, genetic engineering could be as pervasively influential - and as enduringly controversial - in the 21st century as atomic energy has been in the 20th.
One of Schneiderman's star recruits was Robert T. Fraley, a farm-raised Middle Westerner with a doctorate in biochemistry and microbiology from the University of Illinois, who joined Monsanto in 1980 at the age of 27.
Fraley was put in charge of the plant molecular biology group, whose task it was to develop better crops through genetic engineering. Since gene-altering techniques had never been successfully performed on plants, the group started out with a more basic problem: how to move genes through a plant's cell walls without destroying the cells.
Fraley's group settled on the novel approach of harnessing bacteria, which have the natural ability to invade plant cells. The bacterium chosen, Agrobacterium tumefaciens, causes an infection called crown gall. The scientists reasoned that if they could disable the disease-causing genes in Agrobacterium, it could provide a wagon for hauling foreign genes into any plant.
Like watchmakers attempting to repair a precision timepiece they had never seen before, the young scientists disassembled Agrobacterium's genetic code and studied its parts. They identified those regions of the DNA that produce crown gall and proceeded to remove them. This took the better part of two years.
It was now time to devise a system for testing their theory. Using another bacterium, E. coli, Fraley and his colleagues isolated the gene that makes E. coli immune to an antibiotic called kanamycin. They tinkered with that gene so that it could make petunia cells resistant to kanamycin, which is normally lethal to the plants. They inserted this gene into the Agrobacterium. Fraley's group then put cells from a petunia - a simple species, well suited to experimentation - into a petri dish containing kanamycin. They added the altered Agrobacterium. If the system worked properly, the Agrobacterium would transfer the immunity gene to the petunia cells and they would survive.
In a few weeks, Fraley recalls, new, healthy petunia cells began to appear in the petri dish. ''I was looking at the plates in the laboratory one day and saw the colonies growing there and ran down the hallway yelling, 'It worked! It worked!' ''
In 1983 Fraley announced that Monsanto had produced a petunia that was the world's first genetically engineered plant. Since then, Fraley's group has used the same system for more elaborate, and commercially important, plant transformations. Monsanto has conducted 28 of the 77 outdoor experiments in the United States approved by the Department of Agriculture since July 1987, more than any other company. Its first successful gene-altering experiment with a staple crop came in 1987 with soybeans, which were modified to resist damage from the company's herbicide, Roundup.
Monsanto scientists also have developed an array of crops - tomato, potato, alfalfa, tobacco and cucumber - that are resistant to viral infections. (See diagram.) And the company has altered cotton, tomatoes and potatoes with bacterial genes that produce proteins fatal to budworms, bollworms and other pests.
The insect- and viral-resistant plants are intended to sharply reduce a farmer's need to use insecticides. According to Monsanto, genetically engineered cotton could save farmers hundreds of millions of dollars a year.
''Two years from now every crop in the world will be easily manipulated,'' says Fraley. ''Ten years from now, in some plant we'll know every gene, every protein, every function. There are no longer any technical restraints.''
There may be other types of restraints, however. Many environmentalists, for example, oppose Monsanto's decision to create crops immune to its Roundup herbicide. ''Monsanto's rhetoric is a low- or no-pesticide agriculture,'' says Margaret Mellon, a molecular biologist and lawyer with the National Wildlife Federation in Washington. ''But in fact, what they are delivering is a whole new generation of herbicide-tolerant plants that will shackle us to chemicals for the foreseeable future.''
Monsanto contends that Roundup is an environ mentally sound way to do what crop plants cannot - eliminate the weeds that compete for nutrients and sunlight. Roundup's active ingredient is glyphosate, a substance the Environmental Protection Agency considers to be among the safest farm chemicals. But Roundup does contain other substances that opponents say can be toxic to fish, if it makes its way into ponds and streams.
Because Roundup does not discriminate between weeds and crops, farmers currently must use it with extreme care - and avoid it altogether in soybean, corn and cotton fields. The development of Roundup-resistant crops could allow farmers to spray the herbicide freely; that troubles environmentalists. Monsanto executives maintain, however, that planting Roundup-proof crops could let farmers abandon other, more environmentally threatening herbicides.
Mellon remains unconvinced that Roundup will be as good for the environment as it may be for Monsanto's profits. Sales of the weed killer, approaching roughly $1 billion a year, yield more than 30 percent of the company's annual profit. Because Monsanto's patent for Roundup has already expired in some countries, and expires in the United States in the year 2000, the company must prepare for the coming competition. Roundup-resistant crops would help the company to create a larger market.
''Rather than needing new kinds of pesticides,'' Mellon argues, ''we need methods of cultivation that avoid the use of pesticides.'' The problem, she says, is that ''the private enterprise system, which does so many things so well, has no incentive to come up with new processes; they have every incentive in the world to come up with new products.''
Last summer the ''Branches of Promise,'' a 15-foot-high abstract sculpture of a grove of trees wrought in glass bonded with Monsanto's Saflex plastic interlayers, was erected at the center of the courtyard outside the office of Monsanto's 56-year-old chairman, Richard Mahoney. The sculpture is meant to impress the viewer with the company'svision of fusing nature and technology.
Mahoney, the former vice president and managing director of Monsanto's agricultural products division, became company president in 1980, C.E.O. in 1983 and chairman upon Hanley's retirement from that post in 1986. He has continued his predecessor's campaign to take the company in new scientific directions.
During the 80's, Monsanto prepared for the future by sloughing off the past. From 1980 to 1987 the company sold or shut down $4 billion worth of businesses in markets deemed too cyclical: commodity chemicals and basic oil and gas exploration. In 1985 bulk petrochemicals comprised 30 percent of Monsanto's assets; by 1988 the figure was 2 percent. Last year the company sold its silicon manufacturing operation, saying it did not fit into Monsanto's plans for the future.
In 1985 the company - which was founded in 1901 to make the artificial sweetener saccharin - paid $2.8 billion to buy G. D. Searle & Company, the Chicago-based pharmaceutical manufacturer and developer of the artificial sweetener, aspartame, better known by its trade name Nutrasweet. Monsanto spun off the Nutrasweet Company into a separate division that same year.
Monsanto's $679 million profit last year was a company record, but 1990 has started poorly: first-quarter sales were flat and profit down 13 percent from a year earlier. Mahoney pegs the problem to the soft automotive market (Monsanto chemical compounds are used extensively in auto manufacturing) and a seasonal shift in agricultural chemical sales - temporary setbacks, he insists. All the same, he is anxious for Monsanto's biotechnology investment to begin paying off.
Mahoney expects Monsanto to have the first of its genetically engineered plants on the market by 1994 or 1995. Instead of selling whole plants or seeds to farmers, the company intends to establish royalty agreements with seed companies, food manufacturers and other buyers and sellers of agricultural products - providing gene-altered parent plants in return for a share of future profits from the progeny.
The first-generation inventions have focused on changing single genes to make plants resistant to disease, pests and pesticides. The second generation, expected shortly after the year 2000, will focus on improving what plants produce - bigger seeds, better oils, more nutrients.
''The real value added is when you improve properties,'' says Mahoney. ''Changing oil ratios for food processing - that's big money. Changing the structure of grains for processors - that's big money.''
Long before its gene-altered plants hit the market, however, Monsanto hopes to start reaping big money from the genetically engineered veterinary drug BST, the dairy-cow hormone that can stimulate milk production. But those hopes were put on hold in late April when Governors Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin, a Republican, and Rudy Perpich of Minnesota, a Democrat, each signed legislation banning use of BST in their states until mid-1991.
Proponents of the ban, including thousands of dairy farmers, see the genetically engineered drug as the latest example of increasingly sophisticated tools that keep farm output high and prices low for urban consumers, enriching only the chemical and drug companies.
Monsanto and BST's three other manufacturers - American Cyanamid, Eli Lilly and Upjohn - spent tens of thousands of dollars in Wisconsin battling the legislation. Wisconsin State Senator Russell D. Feingold, a Democrat who led the charge against BST, says the manufacturers chose the wrong defense strategy. ''They ruled out social and economic arguments, claiming that the only valid issue for us to consider was whether a product is unhealthful. What Monsanto has learned the hard way is that farmers and consumers and environmentalists take a broader view.''
''It was not great news for biotechnology to have two major dairy states pass this kind of legislation,'' observes Paul T. Leming, a principal in the equity research department at the investment bank Morgan Stanley & Company. ''I've contended for some time that BST is the litmus test of biotechnology products getting into the human food chain.''
''It's not a good sign,'' concedes Walter P. Hobgood, the 41-year-old director of Monsanto's Animal Nutrition and Health division and the man in charge of BST development. ''It says you can invest in technology and meet all of the regulatory hurdles - only to have a political decision be made just prior to commercialization. If that were to be a continuing trend, the uncertainty is a huge disincentive to do any research in agriculture.''
Monsanto's work on BST began in the mid-1960's. The hormone could be extracted from the pituitary glands of slaughtered animals and injected into live ones, but the process proved too expensive for commercial applications.
The advent of genetic engineering in the 70's, however, made it possible for scientists to isolate the appropriate cow gene and produce unlimited quantities of BST. In 1979 the newly hired Schneiderman struck a deal with Genentech, a young biotechnology company in South San Francisco, Calif. In return for rights to the bovine growth hormone, Monsanto paid Genetech $990,000, agreed to make several subsequent milestone payments and promised royalties on future BST sales.
Genentech delivered the first 600 milligrams of BST in December 1981, and initial tests showed that it worked like natural BST. Monsanto launched an aggressive field-testing program in the United States, South America, Africa and Europe. Two years ago, at a cost of $50 million, Monsanto completed a factory in Austria to produce the hormone.
The United States Food and Drug Administration is expected to approve the drug in 1991 - perhaps around the same time the Wisconsin and Minnesota bans expire. Yet opposition to BST seems to be increasing. Dr. Samuel Epstein, a professor at the University of Illinois College of Medicine in Chicago, has raised questions about BST's effect on humans. Epstein contends that its chemical structure is sufficiently different from natural bovine somatotropin that its risks are unknown. The F.D.A. takes the position that the man-made hormone is a protein nearly identical in chemical structure to natural BST and, just as any protein, will quickly break down in the stomachs of adults and children. The F.D.A. intends to take an unusual step to assure the public of BST's safety by publishing an article in the journal Science later this summer.
The loudest, most effective opponent of BST - indeed, of all agricultural biotechnology - is Jeremy Rifkin, president of the Foundation on Economic Trends in Washington. It was Rifkin who, in April 1986, organized a coalition of farm groups and environmentalists in Wisconsin and other states into the first formal crusade against BST and its manufacturers.
''Monsanto sees all living creatures as resources to be subject to whatever manipulations are required for the market,'' says the 45-year-old Rifkin. ''That type of strict utilitarian mentality has created the global environmental crisis.''
Rifkin and Monsanto have clashed on other biotechnology fronts. In 1986 the company announced it was ready to field-test genetically engineered bacteria designed to live among the roots of corn plants and kill destructive worms. The Environmental Protection Agency, which was still establishing rules for such outdoor experiments, blocked Monsanto after Rifkin bombarded the agency with a series of petitions and threatened a lawsuit. Monsanto shelved the field test after an investment of roughly $2 million, saying it had never intended to create a marketable product from the microbes, but the episode - like the more recent BST flap - helped convince Monsanto of the need to sell biotechnology to the American public.
''I think the ability to communicate in plain language to nonscientists hasn't been a fine art,'' says Schneiderman, ''and a lot of people in the industry haven't thought it was very important. There has been a certain arrogance about science, sort of like the church in the Middle Ages.''
Moreover, Monsanto, like many other chemical companies, is dogged by a checkered public-safety record. In one of several lawsuits, for example, Monsanto, was accused of polluting the soil and air of Sturgeon, Mo., in a 1979 train accident that leaked a toxic chemical along a half-mile of track. A jury assessed $16 million in punitive damages, which Monsanto is still appealing.
Last August Monsanto created a new position, vice president of public policy. Filling this poase as official corporate conscience is Dr. Virginia V. Weldon, a 54-year-old pediatric endocrinologist and a former deputy vice chancellor at the Washington University School of Medicine.
''The public gives us the privilege to operate,'' says Weldon, ''particularly in the case of a company that makes the products that we do. It's absolutely essential that management decisions, business decisions, are made in the context of knowing what the public is thinking about.''
It was also Monsanto that, beginning seven years ago, called for the Government to spell out the Federal rules for biotechnology. In June 1986 the Reagan Administration responded by giving the F.D.A. responsibility to review and license genetically engineered drugs for people and animals; assigning similar responsibilities to the Environmental Protection Agency for biotechnology pesticides, and empowering the Department of Agriculture to oversee gene-altered crop plants and livestock.
''A lot of our competitors thought we were out of our ever-loving minds,'' remembers Will D. Carpenter, a Monsanto vice president who led the company's drive for regulations. ''But it was the right response, and it is the accepted position of the industry today.''
Will the future uphold Monsanto's vision of profits and plenty or, instead, confirm the critics' worst fears about the technology? ''In the modern age, we continually attempt to produce and consume nature's bounty faster than the environment can recycle the pollution and replenish the stock,'' says Jeremy Rifkin, who believes biotechnology can only accelerate this trend.
But for Monsanto's designated seer, Howard Schneiderman, biotechnology represents the best means for feeding tomorrow's multitudes. ''There are five billion people in the world today,'' he says. ''Some people say there should be two billion. Well, that's great. That's wishful. But that's not the way it's going to be. In the year 2030 there will be ten billion people.''
Indeed, regardless of how Monsanto proceeds, the biotechnology horse already may be out of the barn. The United States currently holds the international lead in most phases of biotechnology research and development. Yet according to Mark D. Dibner, director of the information division of the North Carolina Biotechnology Center, an economic development organization, only 90 or so American companies have made major investments in genetic engineering - compared with 230 large Japanese corporations.
Dibner worries about the consequences of further regulatory or legislative delays in this country: ''The bleakest scenario I can imagine would be to see our substantial investment in biotechnology R&D translated into more revenues for Japanese companies than for U.S. companies. Fortunately, the race has only just begun.''

SECTION: Section 7; Page 12, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1765 words

HEADLINE: COOKING

BYLINE: By RICHARD FLASTE; Richard Flaste, the deputy editor of The Book Review, is the co-author of ''Pierre Franey's Low-Calorie Gourmet.''

 BODY:
Suddenly and for no apparent reason, on a recent azalea-brightened late spring day, I started to think about barbecued ribs, spicy-sweet and moist, and was captured by the thought of them.
Like anyone in the hot grip of an obsession-compulsion - like a serial killer or a crazed lover - I could not get the image out of my mind until I'd done something assertive, something cathartic. Fortunately, the cure in this case is benign: you cook the things slowly and well and then you devour them. But I wasn't going to eat ribs and nothing else (I wasn't that crazy), so I decided to surround them with vibrant Southern dishes. Here's that rib-provoked menu: Missouri ribs Buttermilk biscuits Tidewater coleslaw Honeyed tomatoes Mint julep peaches All those dishes came from this season's cookbooks, which, as a group, show distinct signs of the conservative retrenchment in cooking. The trend hallows regional tastes, the freshest ingredients and traditional techniques that are often pleasingly simple to execute. Servings can be large, and they don't have to be pretty. A warm-weather advantage is that this sort of cooking so often lends itself to outdoor activities: grilling, picnics and parties. 
There is no one true Southern food, since it varies so much from Maryland to Texas, but taken as a whole, Southern cooking is among the most enduring regional fare we have. Stubborn to the point of being oblivious, it relies on fats that are frequently scorned these days, but its earthiness and its bountiful use of seasonal vegetables give it a wholesome feeling, anyway.
The buttermilk biscuits I made came from Bill Neal's BISCUITS, SPOONBREAD, AND SWEET POTATO PIE (illustrated, 334 pp., Knopf, $19.95), an authoritative journey through the baking and related confectionary cooking of the South. Mr. Neal, the chef at Crook's Corner, an exuberant restaurant in Chapel Hill, N.C., is maturing into one of the most interesting and readable spokesmen for Southern cooking, which he likens more to Mexican than European cuisines.
Before I got going on those buttermilk biscuits I was led by Mr. Neal toward a deep appreciation of them. In a clear and lively writing style he expounds on the appeal of sour over sweet biscuits and explains the chemistry of why they rise (it's the carbon dioxide that emanates from the combination of cream of tartar and bicarbonate of soda in the commercial baking powder that is a staple of Southern baking). The astonishing thing about biscuits, if you've never made them before, is that they are baked in a matter of just a few minutes, ready long before the kitchen has had a chance to break into its sauna routine.
Other recipes here are authentic guides to the likes of shortbread, peach pudding and fried mush. An earlier book, ''Bill Neal's Southern Cooking'' (University of North Carolina), revised in 1989, is broader in scope, and the sensible companion to the current volume. (He has also edited a collection of Southern garden writing, ''Through the Garden Gate,'' reviewed on the facing page.) The Missouri ribs in my menu have their provenance partly in Missouri and partly in Cambridge, Mass., where Chris Schlesinger is the proprietor of the East Coast Grill. In a book they've titled THE THRILL OF THE GRILL: Techniques, Recipes, & Down-Home Barbecue (illustrated by Laura Hartman Maestro, photographs by Vincent Lee, 395 pp., Morrow, $24.95), Mr. Schlesinger and John Willoughby offer a wide-ranging, informative and inviting survey of grilling possibilities. Mr. Schlesinger is a professionally trained chef and a wellspring of practical tips. For instance, if you want to grill duck, a bird with enough flammable fat to qualify it as an incendiary device, it should be roasted first to remove most of the fat, and then finished on the grill.
The book manages to take you the considerable distance from sake-marinated grilled frogs' legs to grilled ham hocks and black-eyed peas. The section on barbecuing (a time-consuming process that is distinct from grilling) is written casually - it's a bit too folksy for me, actually - but it is an intense excursion into traditional approaches. It's all here: the pungent spare ribs of Kansas City as well as the smoky chopped pork of eastern North Carolina, the latter anointed as Mr. Schlesinger's ''personal favorite'' and the ''real original.'' The dish Mr. Schlesinger calls Missouri-style ribs (the ''style'' is there to signal a departure from traditional smoking in favor of more convenient first-stage cooking in the oven) is rubbed with dry spices and then very gently baked at 180 degrees for three hours before it is finished on the grill and doused in a vinegary sauce. The result is crusted on the outside and a miracle of tenderness inside. The Tidewater coleslaw I prepared also came from Mr. Schlesinger. It is a simple, biting mayonnaise-based slaw whose main flavorings are celery seed and vinegar.
A book that is more narrowly focused than its title might indicate is LEE BAILEY'S SOUTHERN FOOD & PLANTATION HOUSES (photographs by Tom Eckerle, 176 pp., Clarkson N. Potter, $30). What Mr. Bailey, a prolific food writer, did this time is go back to his aunt's home in Natchez, Miss., and - along with the Pilgrimage Garden Club there - create a collection of recipes inspired by that one small region of the South. Some are true to the letter of tradition, others true to no more than the spirit.
He offers elegant Southern menus, each framed by one of the grand houses of the area: ''Lunch Under the Trees at Edgewood'' is centered on an artful arrangement of shrimp, crawfish and crabmeat that he calls Natchez seafood salad. The photos here are, as they have been in Mr. Bailey's other books, stunning, with an emphasis in this volume that is as much on the mansions as it is on the food. Although he frequently diverges from strict Southern approaches (soy sauce and ginger on the barbecued brisket!), I will always have him to thank for my introduction to those honeyed baked tomatoes, Natchez-style (honey is drizzled over seeded tomato halves, and then they are topped with tarragon and bread crumbs).
The mint julep peaches - fruit quickly warmed in butter, sugar, bourbon and mint - came from a book with no Southern intentions at all, Betty Fussell's HOME PLATES: A Shopping, Cooking, Eating & Wine Guide for Everyday (illustrated, 224 pp., Dutton, $12.95), which will be available in a few weeks. In the past, Ms. Fussell has often demonstrated her scholarly appreciation of American regional cuisine. Here she offers up an idiosyncratic small book of efficiently written recipes that are meant to be lively but not exhausting. Ms. Fussell likes variations on a theme. So you get a recipe for beef strips cooked quickly with a Chinese-style star anise sauce, and then she urges you to use the same cut of beef with a Mexican sauce or a green sauce or brandied butter with peppercorns. It's all very simple, and playful, too.
As I continued to read and cook from the summer books, that simplicity of execution and playfulness kept popping up as themes. One of the happiest of the current books is THE YACHTING COOKBOOK: Glorious Menus and Quick Dishes Afloat and at Home by Elizabeth Wheeler and Jennifer Trainer (photographs by Kristen Brochmann, 160 pp., Crown, $30). No one actually needs a yacht to cook the dishes in this book. Cooking on boats forced these authors to use space and ingredients economically, and that sense of discipline is, of course, useful in small urban kitchens as well as mountaintop campsites. An offering that seems to please them especially - they testify that their ''friends are crazy about this dish'' - is a grilled butterflied leg of lamb with a mustard vinaigrette.
Although a boned leg of lamb is awkward to maneuver on a grill, everything else in the preparation and cooking is usually a snap, and the finished dish is almost always impressive no matter whose recipe you're following. This one calls for a heavy mustard marinade and then a thick mustard sauce (accented with mint). It's pungent, wholly successful, and it gave me the confidence to keep working my way through the book and its other, often splendid, straightforward recipes. The recipes are couched in menus that emphasize fruit and fresh vegetables and often minimize the cooking. For instance, there's the ''cozy cabin dinner'' with its chili, corn bread, green salad, sliced tomatoes and banana crisp.
Mark Charles Miller's COYOTE CAFE: Foods From the Great Southwest (illustrated, 192 pp., Ten Speed Press, $24.95) arrived on bookshelves earlier than some of the other books, but it looks as if it were meant for summer all along. On nearly every page, brilliantly colored illustrations evoke the American desert, its people, wildlife and vegetation. Mr. Miller owns the Coyote Cafe in Santa Fe, N.M. He appears to be an extraordinarily skilled chef, and he writes well. The food he offers here is Southwestern, which is to say it is strongly influenced by the lusty peasant cooking of Mexico: refried beans, chicken tamales and the like. But since Mr. Miller has evidently scaled the heights of cuisine, there's a lot of elegance here as well: lobster and scallops with vanilla in corn husks or confit of duck tamale begins to show some of his creativity at work. One of the most popular dishes at his restaurant is a lot simpler, a fried steak with red chili onion rings, and a recipe for that is included, too.
A book that's bound to be welcomed by many cooks this summer is THE LOAVES AND FISHES PARTY COOKBOOK by Anna Pump and Sybille Pump with Gen LeRoy (illustrated by Melanie Parks, 238 pp., Harper & Row, $19.95). It's organized around the seasons, and the section on summer parties includes recipe suggestions and menus for occasions ranging from a brunch for six to a wedding reception for 40. The dishes are often intended for early preparation, like the chilled veal rolls, filled with a mixture of veal, bacon, mushrooms and onion, or a lemon-basil chicken salad. The aim is to help you plan an event so well that when the guests arrive ''you should be free to be outside with them,'' soaking up as much good weather as everyone else.
The book is written with the kind of enthusiasm that often degenerates into treacle in recipe books, but in this case it escapes that pitfall and is cheerfully reassuring instead. Maybe too reassuring. That wedding reception for 40 calls for serving a shrimp salad that begins with 10 pounds of shrimp, poached and shelled. Now, let's see. That's about 300 shrimp to shell. Better get help.

LENGTH: 679 words

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
They're Just Wild About Trail Blazers

BYLINE: By NAOMI KAUFMAN

 BODY:
PORTLAND, Ore.
Hillary Bella could manage only a hoarse whisper after four hours of surgery on the night last week when Portland took on Detroit in Game 1 of the National Basketball Association finals.
''What happened in the game?'' she asked as she awoke.
Then there's the synchronized-swimming team that has had practice on game nights. They swim to the play-by-play, and dive when the Trail Blazers make a basket. 
Such is the extent of Blazermania, the rabid devotion here to the home team.
Forget Californians moving in by the condo-loads. Forget drug-dealing youth gangs. Forget the inexorable drip, drip, drip of the rain. Forget even ''Teen-age Mutant Ninja Turtles.''
''The Blazers are doing good now, and the Ninja Turtles were a hit a long time ago,'' explained 10-year-old Sean Meehan.
Blazermania started here in 1977, the last time the Blazers won the championship or even went to the finals. It has barely abated for 13 years, but this year has reached a pitch that transcends divisions of class, race and politics.
''How about those Blazers?'' a demonstrator asked Officer Derrick Foxworth between throwing eggs and spitting during a protest of President Bush's visit last month.
''It's something that just brings the city together: it's pride,'' said Foxworth, who has taken to wearing a Blazers baseball cap to work.
The team is counting on its rabid following to help it against the Pistons today as it begins the first of three games here with the series tied at 1-1. The fervor of the Portland fans is widely credited with helping the team to a 44-6 home record, including playoff games, this season.
Part of Blazermania is the city's location. Portlanders are a parochial lot, isolated from big-city attention. The Trail Blazers are the only major league team in the city, which has a population of 432,000 in a metropolitan region of 1.36 million.
The city's relative obscurity in times zones east of the Mississippi prompted The Detroit Free Press to run a locator map on its editorial page; that led the Portland daily, The Oregonian, to respond that when the Detroit Tigers won the World Series in 1984, its ''fans celebrated by setting the city on fire.''
''We're a medium-size city that wants some of the benefits of the big city, like recognition, which we envy, without some of the problems,'' said Elliot Weiner, executive director of the Oregon Psychological Association. ''This is boosting our civic ego.''
''It's like your high school team going to the state finals,'' said Kevin Kelly, a former all-state forward who is president of U.S. National Bank of Oregon. ''No matter what size we get, Portland will always be a small town.''
While no one expects Roger Smith to up and move General Motors to Portland if the Blazers beat the Pistons, the city sees an economic boost from the games.
Mayor J. E. (Bud) Clark said the championship ''heightens the excitement about the city of Portland off the top of the scale more than you ever see it.''
''The team,'' said Kay Bryant, marketing manager of the Oregon Economic Development Department, ''represents the state of Oregon extremely well: tough individuals who know how to come together when it counts.''
It's almost impossible to avoid the team colors, black and red. The Compleat Fan can start with a cap with the signatures of the starters on it; a T-shirt showing Portland's Clyde Drexler going up against Detroit's Isiah Thomas; black and red sweatpants; boxer shorts with the Blazers' logo, or, for women, panties emblazoned with ''Red Hot'' on one side and ''Rollin' '' on the other. Key chains. Earrings. Refrigerator magnets. A clothes hamper bearing the logo that is called a Dirty Dunk.
''It looks like a goal and backboard and net, so a kid can dunk his clothes in,'' said J. Isaac, the team's director of game operations.
The city is so excited and engrossed, said Weiner, the psychologist, that if the team loses, ''we're going to need a Blazers loss crisis hot line.''
''Those people who are so up now are going to be so down,'' he said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section 8; Page 4, Column 1; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 778 words

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
Long-Magical Charm Is Wearing Out

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
My first encounter with Saab's 900 Turbo was not a case of love at first sight. For one thing, the car looked like nothing else on the road. For another, it was different in the way that it approached almost everything.
But it did zero to 60 in less than 10 seconds, and it grew on me quickly. 
That was in 1982, and I had taken a gray 900 Turbo to Vermont for a class in high-speed driving. It was me and about a hundred cops, and I learned, among other things, that the reason you get stopped on the road is that your driving or your car is somehow different from that of the otherwise boring parade.
So, in truth, I should know better than to be driving 1990's eye-catching red version of that long-ago standout. But I have been careful, and as much as this year's Turbo Saab wants to get down and flat-out go, I haven't had any official conversations.
The tester was a top-of-the-line SPG, a moniker that stands for Special Performance Group, and the accouterments of its 2-liter four make the limited-production hatchback quite different from lesser 900's, of which there is a quartet.
The SPG has a new Mitsubishi turbocharger and it puts out 175 horsepower, the most for any Saab ever to visit these shores. That is 15 more than the standard Turbo and a whole herd more than the 128 horses available in the naturally aspirated Saab.
All the same, economy is up, and a week of driving averaged 27 miles per gallon, considerably better than the Federal estimate of 20 m.p.g. in the city and 28 on the highway. The new car also has a larger fuel tank, which now holds 18 gallons of gas, which in the SPG's case is spelled p-r-e-m-i-u-m.
In keeping with the car's speed, there are standard antilock brakes and an airbag in the hub of the four-spoke wheel, although it should be said that those items are standard on all of Saab's models. And the company is to be complimented. It is high time that someone recognized an across-the-board need for ABS, which shortens braking distances and allows retention of steering control in panic stops.
Pretty much everything else is standard on the SPG, too, and the car - which comes only in Talladega Red and black - is a symphony in leather-smelling technology.
That is the good side. And on that side, there are the other things that will please Saab aficianados: the odd hood that slides forward and then tips vertically to expose the longitudinally mounted engine, the ignition lock on the floor between the front buckets, the concave swoop of the huge hatch.
There is the craftsmanship and the solidity. The implied ''but,'' however, may be a big one these days, when far less expensive cars offer many more toys to a buyer. And, frankly, the car that appealed to me in 1982 is a car that feels outdated today.
For 1990, the SPG has aerodynamic lower panels and a slick look that extends to its special wheels, smoothly molded in a three-spoke aluminum exercise. There is central locking and the usual power equipment, but the car lacks a lot of the niceties.
There are no lighted mirrors in the sun visors. There is no electronic display, no systems check or driver information center to tell you instantaneous fuel economy or average speed. Unlike a lot of automobiles today, this car can't estimate your time of arrival.
The top of the dash slopes all over the place, and there is a shelf that is useless because its bottom slants. Electric window buttons are on the floor and the temperature controls are mismatched arrows that tell you nothing. The 900 is a vehicle that makes the owner's manual required reading.
The airbag in the leather-wrapped and four-spoked wheel has resulted in two small and hard-to-find buttons for the horn. At that wheel, you discover a seat that is manually adjusted, and the fore-aft lever and large round knob for seatback position leave much to be desired.
The seats are firm, and they gang up with a very stiff suspension to make potholed pavement a serious trial.
Cargo capacity is awesome, but the hatch that covers it is equally awesome and as heavy as it is high and hard to pull down.
None of this will much matter to true Saab fans, though. The 900's design is one that you love or hate. It has been around with few changes since the mid-70's, and the company has counted on what it calls ''the unique Saab soul'' to win converts.
That has worked for a long time, and the magic was surprising eight years ago when the price of a Turbo seemed hefty at $16,550. Today, the sticker on an SPG reads $28,995, and that pits the car against some truly heavy competition. It might be that Saab needs to come up with a new car, one that is, well . . . different.

HEADLINE: GYMNASTICS;
Spirited Comeback Has Its Rough Side

BYLINE: By FRANK LITSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DENVER, June 9

 BODY:
What a wonderful drama it almost was.
In 1988, Charles Lakes became the first black American, man or woman, to compete in Olympic gymnastics. He placed 19th in the Olympic all-around competition, the highest by an American man in Seoul, South Korea.
Then he stopped competing for 19 months to earn a living. Six weeks ago, he started training again. This week, ready or not, he competed in the United States championships, at age 25 the oldest in the field. 
It would be nice to report that his comeback was a smashing success. It was not. He was enthusiastic and exciting. He was also rusty.
He had three comparative disasters, and this afternoon he finished 31st among the 47 senior men with 104.88 points. John Roethlisberger, a 19-year-old Minnesota sophomore from Minneapolis, won with 114.30. Fourteen-year-old Kim Zmeskal of Houston won the women's title.
In Thursday night's compulsory exercises, Lakes had low scores on the horizontal bar (8.15 of a possible 10 points) and the pommel horse (7.15). On the horizontal bar, the judges and a jury of appeals said he had left out a required move.
 
Disaster on Horizontal Bar
Today, in the compulsory exercises, he scored only 8.2 on the horizontal bar after falling twice.
Still, Lakes said he had no regrets about his return. He obviously loves gymnastics, a love that began with the 1976 Olympics.
''I was 11 years old then,'' he said. ''I had a bed with slats, and I kept breaking it with front flips. Then I watched the Olympics on TV and I said, 'Oh my God, all that stuff I've been doing all these years at the playground and at home, it's a sport.' The next year, I started training with Dan in Van Nuys, Calif.''
After the 1988 Olympics, Lakes decided to take at least a year off.
''But I always planned to come back,'' he said. ''I was far from reaching my potential, and I thought I had a lot more to offer America and the sport. There was no important competition for me in 1989, anyway.
''But coming back hasn't been easy. I had been on the road all of 1989, flying almost weekly, talking to kids and corporations, giving autographs, doing exhibitions, making appearances, lots of things.''
Lakes intended to resume training in January. Then he learned a basic lesson in economics.
''I discovered it's very expensive to try to train full time without funds,'' he said.
Six weeks ago, Lakes decided to return to the gym. Three weeks later, he qualified for the nationals. But Dan Connelly, Lakes's longtime coach, said time was too short.
''You have to have meet experience,'' he told Lakes. ''Certain things have been missing here. You should have been in two other meets before this one.''
Others agreed with Connelly that this was not the Charles Lakes of old. Lakes hardly heard. ''I'm strong,'' he said. ''I've been going all out. We're playing a comeback game. We're doing well. We're on track. So I can't possibly be discouraged. I may be down, but I'm not out. I will be back.''
 
 JOHNSON DROPS TO THIRD
 Seventeen-year-old Brandy Johnson of Altamonte Springs, Fla., the women's defender, led until her last two events. Then she fell off the balance beam and tumbled off the mat in the floor exercise. She finished third with 76.97 points behind 77.42 for Zmeskel and 77.00 for Betty Okino of Elmhurst, Ill.
Behind Roethlisberger were Chris Waller of Mount Prospect, Ill., with 113.90 and Lance Ringnald of Albuquerque, N.M., with 113.78. Bill Roth of Mohegan Lake, N.Y., scored a 10 on the horizontal bar, the first ever by a man in these championships.
The junior champions were 13-year-old Hilary Grivich of Huntsville, Tex., among the women and 18-year-old Jair Lynch of Washington among the men.
