288 of 761 DOCUMENTS

Copyright 1990 The New York Times Company 
The New York Times

PUB-DATE: June 10, 1990

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 33, Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 977 words

BYLINE: By CAROLYN BATTISTA

 BODY:
DRUGS, violence and death may be all too familiar on the streets of Hartford, but hope is there, too. That is what art students at Weaver High School say in ''The Streets of Hartford: An Exhibition of Provocative Art and Information.''
The exhibition, which opened on Thursday evening and runs through June 20, fills the auditorium lobby at Weaver, where 95 percent of the students are black, and 5 percent are Hispanic.
Among the exhibition's works are life-size statues, including a young man crucified by the drug economy; large painted panels, with one depicting a ''drugmobile''; a work 8 feet high and 25 feet long on preventing AIDS; photographs, and posters on topics like ''Black Females and Their Life Chances.'' 
The works feature dismaying images and statistics. One poster says, for instance, that one black girl in five drops out of high school.
''We wanted to give something to the community, and at least make them aware of what's going on,'' a senior, Jacqueline Lock, said. ''Our peers are committing the crimes, selling the drugs. We want to make the young people think twice about doing it.''
The works are mainly group projects by 40 students of John Karrer. Mr. Karr has taught art at Weaver since he arrived 23 years ago as an intern pursuing a master's degree in teaching.
Mr. Karrer said that two years ago, after seeing the movie ''Cry Freedom,'' his students organized a large exhibition on apartheid. It included life-size statues from plaster casts of the students' bodies.
This year, the students wanted to present another large exhibition, focusing on their city, ''including apartheid closer to home,'' said Mr. Karrer. He noted that ''Streets'' dealt with many of topics in the earlier show, like health care.
''Streets,'' which took two months to prepare, is dedicated to the children of the community.
''It is to them that we present this exhibit,'' a poster says. ''For without a determined effort on our part, they will inherit the same problems that we illustrate.''
 
'I Look for Reality'
An eight-foot-square panel introducing the exhibition shows a little boy sitting on a step. The panel is based on a photograph by a senior, Trina Cashaw. Several of her other photographs are on view, including one of a teen-age mother playing with her child.
''I don't look for beauty,'' Miss Cashaw said. ''I look for reality.''
Many panels represent a grim reality. ''Chariots of Death,'' eight feet square, in red and black, shows a drug dealer's van. Students wrote that such vehicles, with their booming speakers, ''announce the merchants of death'' and that their presence ''robs the community of the right to use city streets without fear of being killed.''
On another panel is a life-size statue of a young man, hanging as if on a cross. The ''skin'' is made of brown-washed newspaper clippings with headlines like ''Shooting Kills City Youth.''
The students covered the panel with paintings of $5 bills. Mr. Karrer said that the young man was sacrificed not so much to drugs as to ''the economy of drugs.''
An art student, Derrick Perkins, said: ''This shows an inner-city youth who thought drugs were the only way of life. The money represents death.''
 
Infant-Mortality Rate
A panel on infant mortality has numerous black footprints painted on it, with three marked in red, ''Deceased.'' Mr. Karrer said that in some neighborhoods in the state capital, the infant-mortality rate was worse than in some third-world countries.
An eight-foot-square panel depicting a bright yellow school bus deals with integration. Mr. Karrer noted that some city parents were pressing to regionalize schools, which could disperse the students who now attend Weaver.
''We have mixed feelings about that,'' Mr. Karrer said. ''We're quite quite proud of Weaver.''
A poster near the bus panel has a quote from Mr. Perkins, ''The world is really paisley, but somehow the white always shines through.''
Another panel is largely blank. ''We brainstormed and discussed the streets of Hartford for months,'' the text says, ''and only then, we thought of them - the elderly. This panel represents the 'invisible' elderly residents in our community.''
Also in the exhibition is a full-size copy of an 8-by-25-foot billboard on AIDS prevention. The original, by students of another art teacher, Genie Odoms, visited high schools around the state for the State Department of Health until it wore out.
 
'Famous Last Words>
The billboard's colorful panels include ''Famous Last Words.'' The quotes, like ''Let me borrow your works,'' and, ''It won't happen to me,'' are in yellow letters on gray tombstones.
Other works in the exhibition, which was mounted with a grant from Aetna Life and Casualty Company, deal with law enforcement, housing and ''black males and life chances.''
As the show's opening drew closer, students pasted text onto posters, drew Hartford skyscrapers on a large panel and prepared other statues, including one of a young drug dealer bedecked with gold jewelry and another of a more experienced dealer wearing shackles - painted bright gold.
Mr. Karrer smiled when a metal-shop teacher presented a sample shackle and said other colleagues had helped, too. He also ground a pair of ears, trying to make them smooth before attaching them to a statue.
''Each statue takes 60 hours to do,'' Miss Lock said. She described the procedure - making a mold and wood frame, modeling with automobile-body putty, letting the statue dry and then painting it.
A poster - ''Where Do We Go From Here?'' - was printed with the names of colleges where members of the high school's Class of 1990 have been accepted, including the University of Connecticut, the University of Hartford, Harvard and Howard Universities. ''They're super kids,'' said Mr. Karrer. The show can be seen during school hours.

GRAPHIC: Photos; Jacqueline Lock working on ''The Streets of Hartford'' and Therean Byers, Zachary Nettles and Shawn Joseph, right, painting a work from a photo projection (NYT/Steve Miller) LYoung Artists See Suffering On Hartford Streets

HEADLINE: Cuomo Neglected To Cite Lilco Deal

 BODY:
The article by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo (''Helping the Island Helps the State,'' May 6) mentions the amounts of money that the state is spending on high-tech industries, research and transportation to help the Island's economy. But it neglects to mention the much larger amount that will be removed from the Island if the Governor's deal with Lilco sticks.
This state is the most heavily over-taxed in the nation, and we are the most debt-ridden, with three times more debt than the runner-up (California). But the deal with Lilco tops even those figures. Island ratepayers now pay the highest rates among the 800 or so United States utilities; and while the average U.S. utility rate will show a slight decrease by the year 2000, ours will increase by another 60 to 100 percent. 
There never was any technical reason for Shoreham, especially in this hydro-rich area. New York may be the worst among 50 states when it comes to debt and taxes; but thanks to an Islander (Robert Moses), we rank no. 2 in hydro-power, and we border the largest hydro region in the world: Quebec. Hydro would be the ideal source of electric power for the Island, especially since we already paid for part of it. New Jersey was even able to win a share of this power from New York by suing in Federal court, but we on the Island who are part of the Governor's ''Great Family of New York'' receive only a trickle (about 6 percent). And while this part of the state has the highest national rates, the other side of the state (Solvay, N.Y.) has the lowest, on hydro. Hydro that we all paid for.
In the past, the Governor has rightfully complained about the largest Federal scandal in history: the savings and loan mess, but the Shoreham mess impacts the Island even more than savings and loan. Compare the numbers:
Savings and loan cost $300 billion for 240 million Americans Shoreham cost an easy $10 billion for 3 million Islanders Now we are to believe that the state is actually helping us, and the numbers mentioned in the article look impressive; but they are chickenfeed when compared to the damage that has and will be done by the Governor's Lilco sellout.
 
JOHN HURLEY
 
Remsenburg

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: letter

HEADLINE: Is the Governor A Long Islander?

 BODY:
As someone who is employed on Long Island and resides in Queens, I agree with Governor Cuomo that Long Island is a critical economic part of New York State. 
I don't understand Governor Cuomo's statement ''having been a Long Islander all my life.'' I had thought that the Governor was a Queens native, not a ''Long Islander.'' Please clarify this.
 
LISA MENZA
 Middle Village
A spokesman for the Governor said that Mr. Cuomo considers Queens, and Brooklyn, as geographically part of Long Island.

PUB-DATE: June 10, 1990
Correction Appended

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1, Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 2082 words

HEADLINE: Surprise Charges Upset Condo Buyers

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
Apartment buyers in the expensive new Belaire condominium in Manhattan's Upper East Side got the news in April that their monthly common charges were going up 16 percent, and when the annual meeting of owners convened last month, many were in a mood to argue.
''A lot of people showed up and the general tone was one of griping,'' said Richard H. Truitt, a member of the Belaire's board of managers, and president of Gavin Anderson Doremus & Company, the public relations firm. ''Among the gripes were statements that people didn't anticipate that common charges would go up this much.''
The disgruntled owners were not alone. The New York State Attorney General's Bureau of Real Estate Financing reports that complaints of condominium sponsors' underestimating monthly common charges - which pay for upkeep, insurance and building-staff salaries - come in regularly. 
''We get frequent complaints about it,'' said Frederick K. Mehlman, the assistant attorney general who supervises cooperative and condominium sales. ''As a general rule we don't get too involved in it because these costs are projections, and it's difficult to be exact. Otherwise it comes down to showing that fraud has been committed in the projections of carrying costs.''
The law, Mr. Mehlman added, lets owners rescind their purchase contracts if common charges have been underestimated by more than 25 percent.
Buyers of newly developed or converted co-ops should expect the same unpleasant surprises, said Mary Ann Rothman, executive director of the Council of New York Cooperatives, whose members are officers of co-ops and condominiums throughout the city.
''It's typical in a conversion co-op that the budget set by the sponsor is not the budget that will be passed by the board,'' she said.
''You see maintenance charge increases in the first year on the order of 15 and 20 percent to bring things up to the level the owners want.
''They may want the floors cleaned more often or better materials used or an extra employee - there are any number of extra expenses that may be needed to bring the building up to snuff.''
Mrs. Rothman cited her first rule of buying a co-op or condominium: Have an expert read the offering plan, and if monthly common charges are an important part of a buyer's budget, the sponsor's estimated costs should be scrutinized with special care.
But among some of the buyers in the Belaire, at 524 East 72d Street, between York Avenue and the East River Drive, as well as in some other new buildings, there is a sense of having been snookered. Managing agents say that particularly hard hit are the many foreigners who do not speak English and who plan their budgets by the sponsor's monthly cost projections.
THEIR budgets go out the window with the projections after the first year when the elevator and air-conditioning and garbage compactor warranties expire, among other things, and additional tens of thousands of dollars that were unbudgeted in the sponsor's offering must suddenly be raised.
''It's not just the elevators,'' said Michael Graff, president of the board of managers of the Alfred, a three-year-old condominium at 161 West 61st Street between Broadway and Columbus Avenue. ''It's the boiler, the air-conditioning, the compressors, the marble and brass polishing. All of the routine maintenance charges had been tremendously underestimated.''
Charges at the Alfred rose modestly, by just 5 percent, in the first year of apartment-owner control, Mr. Graf said, but only because the sponsor had greatly overestimated insurance costs, producing savings in the new budget that largely offset about $70,000 in unexpected maintenance costs.
Annual budget increases at condominiums and co-ops are running about 5 percent, driven largely by increases in labor costs and, in the case of co-ops, by tax increases, said Allan Rogers, managing director of Douglas Elliman, the management firm.
As for fights between sponsors and owners of recently sold-out condominiums, they are part of the real estate landscape, said Edward Coleman, managing director of Brown Harris Stevens, another of the city's leading management firm.
''Generally any time the board of directors takes control from the sponsor there are complaints about everything,'' Mr. Coleman said. ''It's the general nature, because once they take control, they see things differently.''
At the 181-unit Belaire, the budget in the final amendment to the offering plan was $1,195,302. The second-year budget - the first controlled by the owners instead of the sponsor - had to be raised to $1,324,634.
Among the increases were $129,600 in previously unbudgeted building repair and maintenance expenses. Of that amount, a $25,000 increase in insurance costs - to $98,300 - was an unforeseeable product of a ''volatile'' insurance market, said Arthur W. Zeckendorf, the building sponsor and a member of the prominent family of New York developers.
Most of the rest of maintenance and repair increases were for costs that were either unbudgeted or involved items that the offering plan showed costing very little. Elevator costs rose from $3,500 in the first-year budget to $30,000 for a half-year's maintenance contract in the second - meaning that a full year's cost will be $60,000. The $20,000 for plumbing and heating repairs in the new budget, $38,000 for window cleaning, $8,600 for air-conditioning service contracts and $5,000 for painting were not even budgeted in the offering plan.
Speaking of the offering-plan budget, Mr. Truitt said: ''I am not able to tell whether these were just promotional figures, which the sponsor knew would go up later, or simply bad guesses. Some people in the building see this as a plot to attract buyers by advertising the lowest common charges and making a kind of bait-and-switch.''
In fact, two owners are withholding their monthly common charges, in an action reminiscent of a tenant rent strike, to protest the building's management. A total of 167 condominiums have been sold, and 14 are still on the market. A typical two-bedroom apartment in the Belaire costs about $500,000, with monthly common charges averaging $525 before the increase and $609 after.
Mr. Truitt believes the complaints of a deliberate underestimate of monthly charges are unfounded.
''I don't see it that way,'' he said. ''I've been involved in starting up two other buildings and I went into this building expecting it to happen. It's like building a house or anything else: You don't know what things are going to cost until you move in.''
Monthly common charges have become an integral part of many condominium developers' advertising campaigns. A few year ago, when the market was still rising, typical ads featured elegant couples in evening clothes posing with lush automobiles in front of the project.
These days, the condominium ads are just as likely to look like an accountant's spreadsheet, with rows of figures showing purchase prices, financing, taxes, monthly common charges and mortgage-interest tax savings to the buyer.
Mr. Zeckendorf defended his building's fiscal record by pointing out that the offering plan warned buyers of the expiration of the elevator guarantee and the consequent need for a service contract. Labor and insurance costs are unpredictable, he went on, and their volatility was also disclosed in the offering plan.
As for the $38,000 window-cleaning charge, Mr. Zeckendorf, whose family has built other expensive condominiums in Manhattan, said, ''You can't think of everything.''
''When you're just starting construction of a building,'' he said, ''your biggest concern is getting the windows in. You don't think about cleaning them.'' He said the common window-cleaning contract would prove to be a benefit to all the owners.
As it happens, the new owners of another Zeckendorf Company condominium, the three-year-old Copley at 68th and Broadway, also experienced a surprise over window cleaning. The offering plan stated that the windows would be cleaned, said Steven Sklar, president of the condominium's board of managers, but no money was budgeted for the work there either.
Co-ops are subject to the same problems, the experts say, although co-ops operate differently from condominiums in their management and in the fact that monthly maintenance charges, as they are known, include payments on the building's mortgage and taxes. In a condominium, each unit is taxed separately, and owners pay for their own mortgages, if they have one.
''So the only good news in this is that carrying charges for a condominium are reasonably modest, compared to a co-op,'' said Mrs. Rothman of the Council of New York Cooperatives. ''Twenty-five percent of $200 may be painful but not back-breaking, but 25 percent of $700 is much more serious.''
Richard Clurman, head of real estate law practice for the firm of Phillips Nizer Benjamin Krim and Ballon, said that common charge shock was more likely in the current soft market for condominiums because sales people are pressing harder to make sales. Mr. Clurman, who wrote the state's modern co-op and condominium law during his tenure as an assistant attorney general in the early 1960's, added that vigilance is the only prevention for surprise.
''There's a general pattern of high-pressure selling in condos,'' he said, ''and sales people are doing a lot of talking and promising that they never used to do. So I always warn my clients to expect higher charges, because you can't rely on projections.''
MR. GRAFF, the president of the Alfred's board of managers, said all misunderstandings would be solvable by having offering plans include second-year budget estimates.
''There should have been estimates of the costs after the one-year guarantees expire, and there weren't,'' he said. ''That's a question that the Attorney General should easily be able to make part of the process and there would be fewer surprises.''
Mr. Graff noted that ''a careful reading'' of the offering plan would have revealed the expiration of the manufacturer's warranty on the building's three Otis elevators, and the consequent addition of more than $50,000 in annual costs.
The principals at Carroll Management, the Alfred's sponsor, are out of the country, said a woman who took a request for comment. She refused to give her name, but said that ''a 5 percent increase [in charges] after one year does not seem like particularly bad budgeting.''
Two-bedroom apartments in the Alfred have sold for about $400,000, Mr. Graff said. There are 214 units in the building, and common charges run about $530 a month.
Among the frustrations of being an unpaid director of a new multimillion-dollar housing corporation are the elevators. At both the Alfred and the Belaire, the elevators employ new, proprietary computer systems whose technical mysteries their manufacturers refuse to share with independent repair firms. A result, as Mr. Graff put it, is that boards are handed elevator service contracts on a take-it-or-leave-it basis.
''We're completely at their mercy because they can charge whatever they want,'' he said. ''In fact, they made us take a five-year contract and there was not much we could do. We can either go along with them or install new elevators.''
The servicing controls that modern elevator manufacturers are putting on their products show up in the maintenance charges. While a new, computerized elevator in a high-rise condominium tower may cost upwards of $20,000 each to service, a service contract for a manual elevator in a midrise prewar building, using a technology serviceable by several companies, costs about $6,000 a year.
MR. TRUITT, of the Belaire, made the point that problems over steep cost increases can be more difficult to handle in a condominium than in a co-op, since co-op boards exercise much more power over the operation of the building, starting from governing the admission of new owners.
''Speaking as the public relations man, I have always argued that communication is the best way to head off these problems,'' he said. ''Too often sponsors go from no communication at all to a kind of militaristic approach to owners.'' As for the costs, they will not stand still. ''I wouldn't be surprised at all if the rates have to go up again, inflation being what it is,'' he said.
''All members of the board are concerned about keeping those rates down, but it is not a mature building yet, and rates are going to bounce around a lot.''

While a ne, computerized elevator in a high-rise condominium tower may cost upwards of $20,000 each to service, a service contract for a manual elevator in a midrise prewar building, using a technology serviceable by several companies, costs about $6,000 a year.
MR. TRUITT, of the Belaire, made the point that problems over steep cost increases can be more difficult to handle in a condominium than in a co-op, since co-op boards exercise much more power over the operation of the building, starting from governing the admission of new owners.
''Speaking as the public relations man, I have always argued that communication is the best way to head off these problems,'' he said. ''Too often sponsors go from no communication at all to a kind of militaristic approach to owners.'' As for the costs, they will not stand still. ''I wouldn't be surprised at all if the rates have to go up again, inflation being what it is,'' he said.
''All members of the board are concerned about keeping those rates down, but it is not a mature building yet, and rates are going to bounce around a lot.''

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Times Square Novelty;
North of Duffy Sq., a Butler-on-Every-Floor Hotel

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
THE Latin Quarter. Cotton Club. Coca-Cola. Castro Convertibles. With its hot nightclubs, dazzling signs and sprawling showrooms, the block at the northern end of the ''bowtie'' formed by Broadway and Seventh Avenue was always an important part of old Times Square. The developer Jeffrey Katz is betting that a $220-a-night hotel with butlers on every floor will suit the new Times Square, as well.
Five years after Mr. Katz bought the first of two parcels on the trapezoidal block between 47th and 48th Streets, demolition has begun on the small buildings and enormous signs that have been there for decades.
By the end of 1991, if all goes according to plan, the 25-story Ramada Renaissance Times Square hotel will be standing in their place, with a 310-foot-high sign tower at its ''prow.'' Mr. Katz, who heads Sherwood Equities of Manhattan, will develop the building, with financing from the Chase Manhattan Bank. Ramada International Hotels and Resorts of Hong Kong, a division of the New World Development Company, will lease the hotel space for 49 years, with a 50-year option. Mr. Katz would not discuss the terms. 
The architects reponsible for the design were Mayers & Schiff Associates of Manhattan, who worked with Costas Kondylis Architects, also of Manhattan.
The building will have about 200,000 square feet of space. Zoning rules prescribe a floor-area ratio of 14.4 on the 14,000-square-foot lot. Mr. Katz briefly entertained the dream of building at a floor-area ration of 21.5 (about 301,000 square feet), taking advantage of West Midtown zoning incentives, plus a subway improvement bonus. But the incentive expired in May 1988, before he could begin work.
Mr. Katz said he ''never expected to beat the zoning deadline,'' although he thought that the floor-area ration would be reduced to 15 -not 14.4 - when the bonus ended. ''We got nicked a little bit,'' he said, ''but the loss of 0.6 F.A.R. in a project of this kind had little impact. What would have killed us would have been if they had prevented signs.''
While other developers in an around Times Square have looked for lots that would permit large floor areas and balked at large signs, Mr. Katz said his project ''always was a completely different animal.''
''From the inception, it was about signage and retail,'' he said. ''The third leg - and the least important, financially - was what happened upstairs. The concept was maximum retail value and maximum signage value.''
Mr. Katz's involvement in Times Square began in 1985, quite unexpectedly. As he recalled it, ''I got a call from a broker on a Friday afternoon in summer - you know the feeling, when you think your're the only person left in New York City?''
The broker, Stanley H. Kovak of Julien J. Studley, told Mr. Katz about a 10,000-square-foot parcel on 48th Street. The two-story building on the site had been the Latin Quarter, and before that, the downtown home of the Cotton Club.
The attraction was immediate and within two weeks, Mr. Katz had signed a contract. That left a 4,000-square-foot parcel on 47th Street, overlooking Duffy Square, where the Coca-Cola sign had long been a fixture and where Castro Convertibles did business until 1983. But the sellers of the 48th Street lot discouraged Mr. Katz's ambitions.
''We were told that the owner, who was then in his 80's, had promised his father on his father's death bed that he would never sell the property,'' Mr. Katz said, ''and that if we had any expectations of getting this parcel, we should just forget them.''
In approaching the owner, the team from Sherwood Equities was prepared for extremely tough bargaining. ''Just the opposite happened,'' Mr. Katz said. ''We came to an agreement in 20 minutes and went to contract in a few days.''
SHERWOOD purchased the north parcel in December 1985 for $6.85 million and the south parcel in April 1986 for $5.1 million, a land cost that amounted to about 60 a developable square foot.
''We knew we had just about the most extraordinary site in Times Square,'' Mr. Katz said. But for all its prominence, it was not very large. The developer first envisioned a multiple-tenant office tower called Two Times Square. ''If this were to be viable,'' he said, ''it would have to wait for the small users that follow large users into an area'' - int his case law offices or advertising agencies.
That meant that the building was not likely to attract tenants until it was clear who was moving into the larger skyscrapers, and when. ''In our holding period,'' Mr. Katz said, ''the hotel market was heating up. We were approached by a number of people asking, 'Are you interested in a hotel?'''
''I was hesitant,'' he conceded, ''because we're real estate people, not hotel people.'' But with the help of the Laventhol & Horwath accounting firm, a deal was structured that made Mr. Katz comfortable. ''I have zero to do with operating the hotel,'' he said, ''which is what I needed until I get as brave as Harry Macklowe.''
The 310-room Ramada Renaissance is intended for ''upper-end'' travelers who want a more intimate environment than the nearby Marriott Marquis or Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza afford, said Mark F. Kaiser, vice president of development in Ramada's North America office.
''There is 5.5 million square feet of office space under construction'' in the vicinity, he said. ''When we open will be right when that market starts to fill up.''
Among its features the hotel will have a butler-concierge on each floor, who will do everything from unpacking a guest's bags to arranging for theater tickets. ''We're like 21 15-room hotels,'' Mr. Kaiser said.
Given that the hotel was striving for a ''very residential, kind of Old World style,'' to use Mr. Kaiser's words, Ramada executives looked for ways to distinguish their property from the blazing sign tower.
''What we've done is pushed all of the signage over on to the Broadway side of the buiding or the dead end facing Times Square,'' Mr. Kaiser said. ''Our side of the building - the Seventh Avenue side - is very, very clean. We don't have an entrance on Broadway. We're positioning ourselves as a hotel that's on Seventh Avenue.''
But, he added, ''we understand the economics of signage and are not necessarily opposed to it. We think it will draw a lot of attention to the building.''
The total surface of the seven signs - five stacked vertically over Duffy Square, two jutting obliquely from the Broadway facade - amounts to 23,000 square feet, or about 4,700 more than required under zoning rules. Two signs are already leased, one to Suntory whisky, the other to Coca-Cola, which has had a sign at the spot for 58 years.
''WE wanted very much to stay there,'' said Mark E. Preisinger, a spokesman for the Coca-Cola Company of Atlanta. ''It's our belief that the Coca-Cola sign in Times Square has become quite a well-known landmark. It's just tremendous visibility for the company and the trademark.'' The old sign was 40 by 44 feet. The replacement willbe 41 by 65 feet. How much will Coca-Cola pay for this prominent spot over the Times Square crossroads? ''We don't talk about that,'' Mr. Preisinger said.
Beneath these signs, at the narrow, southern end of the building, will be a 2,500-square-foot entrance to the major retail space. From there, escalators lead to an additional 11,500 square feet on the second floor.
''It's the world's most visible store,'' Mr. Katz said, by way of marketing the space. ''People still refer to this as the Castro Convertible site. And they haven't been there for years.''

HEADLINE: When You're Older and Out of Work

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
THERE is a dark side to capitalism. Take the experiences of the 20 educated, skilled, out-of-work executives who recently participated in a job-search workshop program in an effort to find jobs.
The free seven-session workshop was part of an employment-planning pilot program sponsored by the American Association of Retired Persons for unemployed people older than 50. It was held at MONY Financial Services headquarters in Purchase from April 23 to May 23.
Most of the members of the group were executives, still at the peak of their productivity, who were victims of the down-sizing, mergers and acquisitions that has led to a thinning of executive ranks in the county and surrounding area. 
The program was conducted by an A.A.R.P. employment-planning volunteer team and representatives from community agencies. Explaining why MONY donated the space to the group and provided a farewell luncheon, Salina Wilson, director of corporate relations, said: ''We believe that A.A.R.P. is doing an important job. We're glad to be part of it.''
The program, called the A.A.R.P. Works Workshop, is designed to help participants return to the job market. It was set up after several surveys of retirees, including one by the organization, that revealed that one-third of all retirees preferred to work. Other polls have reported that 51 percent of all workers surveyed said they would like to work past the age of 65.
''Yet, most do not,'' said Clair Watsky, who headed the volunteer team. ''Even though mandatory retirement has almost been eliminated in this country, many employment policies and practices discourage older workers from extending their careers.''
The organization sponsors the program at 12 locations nationwide. Westchester was chosen as one of the locations, Miss Watsky said, because of the low unemployment rate here - and the fewer available jobs.
''The focus of the program is to prepare people to find jobs that meet their needs and abilities,'' she said. ''All have college degrees or professional training and want to work. But many have been forced into early retirement or terminated when their jobs disappeared. They come into the program still in shock. And because Americans tend to identify people's worth with their job, those who lose them, although through no fault of their own, still suffer from low self-esteem.''
The team members - Myra Fisch, Janet Lillienstein, Gerry Michael, Mortimer Newburg and Miss Watsky - all are volunteers, who help participants assess and redefine their skills and work experience, and teach them how to conduct effective job searches. Speakers, such as Roslyn Tanner, a State Department of Labor employment counselor in White Plains, address the group and make additional suggestions and recommendations.
The participants evaluated the program in a discussion after the last session.
''We learned how to re-evaluate ourselves and our goals,'' said Robert Mundie, a 57-year-old research engineer. ''I, for instance, came away with a much better understanding of how to sell my experience and skills to prospective employers.''
Another member, a 61-year-old former bank president, said he lost his job after a policy dispute with his boss, the chairman. ''When I signed up for the program, I admit I was skeptical,'' he said. ''But I've found that this program was better than the out-placement services I was offered by the bank. At the bank, there was no healing process, and after you lose a job that's really what you need. Here, I feel I have support. We've all shared a common experience and it makes it easier for us to talk.''
Yet, when the conversation turned to his prospects, the bank president, who asked to remain anonymous, was not optimistic about a new job.
 
Process Can Get Complicated
''Part of my problem is that I was very good at my job,'' he said. ''My bank outperformed the competition for five years running. I've been told by people in the industry that the people who could hire me perceive me as a threat.'' Also, he added, ''At age 61, there aren't a whole lot of opportunities in banking for me out there.''
But he said he did learn during the workshop sessions that there were other opportunities in the financial industry for former bankers.
''We heard about companies that place executives in short-term assignments. They sound interesting,'' he said. ''And so does the organization that heads a retired-executive corps and financial people on assignments overseas. I intend to explore both avenues.''
Charles M. Anson, 57, spent 33 years as an engineer in the service operations department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in White Plains.
''My job was highly technical,'' Mr. Anson said. ''I was field director of the new equipment inventory. But when the technology began to change, we were able to do more with less - and then equipment, and people with skills like mine, began to be phased out and I was offered early retirement. I wasn't surprised, but I admit I was a little bitter.''
Mr. Anson said he received a ''golden parachute,'' generous severance benefit, when he retired. ''I have no money problems,'' he said. ''My wife and I like to travel and we've been doing a lot of it since I retired. But my wife is still working, she has a good job and she won't retire for eight years. What am I going to do with that time? I want to work.''
The job-search program, he said, ''showed me how to put all my experience in perspective and make an assessment of what I can do. I realize now that the general-management skills I have can be applied to other industries.''
Mr. Anson also said he felt the A.A.R.P. program did more for him than the out-placement counseling he had received as part of his early-retirement package.
''Talking to the other people in the group has made me feel better,'' he said. ''When you're unemployed, everything takes on a different hue. I, like so many others, miss the camaraderie the job afforded. A group of us keep in touch. All of us retired from A.T.& T. meet on Fridays for lunch at the Elks Club in White Plains.''
Dr. John Hayes, 54, has four degrees, including his doctorate in chemistry. Yet, he said, he has found getting a job extremely difficult.
''I'm here because I'm weary of hearing I'm over-qualified,'' said Dr. Hayes, who worked as a chemist in product development at the General Foods technical center in Tarrytown for more than 17 years.
''I was one of those in the first wave who were terminated by General Foods. We were working on advanced new product development, namely developing high protein meat-like food from soybeans, when General Foods changed direction and new product development became market-driven.''
Dr. Hayes recalled that he was offered out-placement counseling and took it. ''But jobs in the food-chemistry industry were scarce. I finally got a job teaching high school chemistry at a private school in Tarrytown, but I was advised by the headmistress that if I wanted to keep it I'd better get a teaching degree, so I added a fourth degree to my resume.''
Shortly after he got his teaching certificate, he said he had a serious accident that hospitalized him for several months.
''When I was able to go back to work, I had no job. The school had replaced me. So, here I am. I've got some very good ideas out of this workshop, and I am hopeful now that I will be able to land something soon.''
Louise Snow Brodsky, one of the three women taking the program, said she had a varied business background. Mrs. Brodsky said that the workshops were useful to her and ''forced me into self-assessment.''
''I didn't know how to go about presenting my past experience in the proper context to a prospective employer,'' she said.
Another participant, a sanitary engineer who did not want his name published, noted that he had received valuable advice from members of the group. ''The kind of brainstorming that went on during the sessions helped me clarify my own ideas,'' he said. ''I wanted to go about setting up my own business, but I guess I was scared. During the sessions, suggestions were made that I try a new industry, recycling, and I'm going to explore the possibility.''
 
Team Wins High Marks
The group unanimously gave the A.A.R.P. volunteer team high marks.
''Not only did they explain to us in detail how to go about finding a job and take us through all the necessary drills, but they also gave us confidence,'' Mr. Mundie said. ''And when you're unemployed, that's what you seem to need the most.''
Ms. Lillienstein, a member of the team, is an occupational counselor at Mount Vernon High School. ''There is enough talent in this group to run the country,'' she said. ''I hate to see it go to waste. That's what makes this work so satisfying, helping these people get back on track. This is my second year with the A.A.R.P. program, and it's the kind of volunteer work I thoroughly enjoy.''
Miss Watsky noted that according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, America's work force is aging. ''Given current economic and business trends, we have to make better use of the knowledge and experience older workers have if we're going to remain cometitive with the rest of the world,'' she said.

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
Sisters Torn Apart by the Holocaust

BYLINE: By LEAH D. FRANK

 BODY:
OCCASIONALLY, the story that a play tells transcends its plot, characters and quality of production. The audience fills in pauses in dialogue with personal or familial memories that expand whatever is unfoldling on stage.
Such is the case with Barbara Lebow's affecting drama, ''A Shayna Maidel,'' now at the Studio Theater in Lindenhurst through Saturday.
The play is about the reunification of two sisters at the end of World War II. One of them, Rose Weiss, has been fortunate enough to have been raised by her father, Mordechai, in America. The other, Lusia, was prevented by illness from leaving Poland with Rose. She and her mother stayed behind. 
But by the time they could join Rose and Mordechai in New York, economic misery had given way to the horrors of the Holocaust, and the family was ripped apart by much more than distance.
In ''A Shayna Maidel,'' Mordechai has been searching lists of war refugees for the names of members of his family. He has finally located Lusia and has arranged for her to come to New York.
By using a dramatic structure in which time is fluid, Ms. Lebow weaves together the past and present lives of Rose, Lusia, their mother and Mordechai to create a vivid and multitextured family tapestry.
The play does not dwell on details of atrocities suffered in the concentration camps. Rather, by illuminating moments in the diverse pre- and postwar lives of Rose and Lusia, it incorporates audience memory and knowledge of world events of the 1930's and 40's.
It is a form of involuntary fill-in-the-blanks audience participation, and it is very effective. By the time Lusia recites the names of murdered relatives, her list silently includes the names of departed beloveds of everyone in the theater.
By the end of that scene, there is not a dry eye in the house. The tears are not so much for the Weiss family as for those who are missed by each individual listening to Lusia's grim recitation.
So, too, the tears at the happy ending are not as much for the on-stage family as they are over whatever memories of friends and family members the audience evokes.
''A Shayna Maidel'' is a play full of love, understanding and forgiveness that has the power to transcend its own story by embracing the myriad personal stories surrounding it. By the time Lusia and her father check off names on the list of relatives who may have survived the Nazis, the cellophane-wrapped candies that have been occupying the audience during the first few scenes remain in pockets and purses, and the gum snapping and casual chattering have stopped.
The quality of this production is not up to the level of the playwrighting, but it does not matter in the long run. Nuances and subtleties in the script remain out of the grasp of the director, Reva Kaufman, but she does manage to provide an unimpeded flow of action to the multiple scenes.
Ruthie Pincus does a fine job as the somewhat shallow Rose, who matures as her sister brings to life memories of their mother. Sally Kaye Kaufman, as Lusia, misses in the development of the full range of Lusia's anger, pain and fear, but she is nonetheless tender and touching as this brutalized war survivor.
Howard Mann is believable as the stern father, a man who can never compensate for the loss of his wife and family. John Ferry as Duvid, Lusia's husband, and Kasey Hawkins as Hanna, Lusia's childhood friend, both do solid yeomen's work. Evelyne Lune is warm and loving as the ill-fated mother. Jett Matteo's set design turns the tiny Studio Theater stage into a three-room New York apartment, and Marvin Lune's lighting design enables that apartment to become, as needed, various locations in Poland.
''A Shayna Maidel'' is a play that will make you feel and, in the process of catharsis, probably even cry. What more can you ask of an evening of theater?

GRAPHIC: Photo; Ruthie Pincus and Sally Kaye Kaufman in 'A Shayna Maidel'

LENGTH: 1182 words

HEADLINE: Indians Bill New York Town As Its 99-Year Leases Expire

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SALAMANCA, N.Y.

 BODY:
In 1892 it seemed like an idea with a future.
The people of Salamanca, a railroad town in western New York that had been illegally established on Indian land, received leases to rent the property, each lasting 99 years. The Seneca Indians, in turn, received total payments of $17,000 a year.
Today, however, only eight months are left to the Salamanca lease. And the once bright future of this town has become a grim obsession. 
Hoping to make up for the inflationary decades they spent collecting 1890's rents, the Senecas have set the price of a new lease at $800,000 a year. They have also asked for an immediate payment of $60 million to make up for the inequities of the original lease.
 
Homeowners Alarmed
Already a tentative agreement has been reached that would grant the Senecas their requests, and that has alarmed the town's white residents, who have been paying as little as $1 for the land under their homes. Many say they would rather burn down their houses than pay the price of the new lease.
''I shouldn't say this, but I have no intention of paying $2,000,'' said Nancy O'Brien, who owns a dry-cleaning store with a $24-a-year lease.
As for the immediate one-lump payment of $60 million the Senecas are seeking, Mrs. O'Brien said, ''the whole town isn't worth that much.''
What makes the Salamanca lease situation different from most modern-day Indian causes is that the Senecas clearly have the upper hand. And they say that while they were badly taken advantage of in the last round of lease negotiations, they have no intention of giving up their advantage this time.
''When they negotiated the original leases, they thought we weren't going to be here at the end,'' Dennis Lay, president of the Seneca Nation, said. ''I guess we fooled them.''
Anyone who does not like the terms of the new lease can leave town, he said. ''We're not going any lower,'' he said. ''It's either go or no go.''
Perhaps the situation in Salamanca, a quiet town of 6,600 people, would be easier to resolve if it had a precedent. But it does not. While ranchers out West often lease grazing land on Indian reservations, no other town in the country is built on land leased from an Indian nation, experts say.
''The situation up there is rather unique,'' said Steve Gleason, a staff assistant at the Bureau of Indian Affairs in Washington.
 
Tensions Always There
Roughly 90 percent of Salamanca -1,700 acres - lies inside the Allegany Reservation, which is nestled against the Pennsylvania border south of Buffalo. The rest of the 22,000-acre reservation, New York State's largest, is home to 3,400 members of the Seneca Nation.
The Seneca Nation does not own the stores and houses in Salamanca, just the land under them. That means the 2,700 lease owners can buy and sell houses but never hold title to the land.
Tensions between the whites and the Indians have always been present in Salamanca, though not always spoken about. A main source of friction has been taxes. Many Senecas have moved into Salamanca over the years, but because Indians are exempt from state and local taxes, their presence has increased the tax bill for the town's white residents.
Now, with the leases about to expire, the hostility is coming out into the open.
 
Government Help Sought
A pamphlet being circulated among whites says: ''White man, you pay Federal, state, county and city taxes, plus $800,000 rent on pieces of earth that the Indian made with his own two hands. Indian, you get a Free Ride!!'' Recently, the consternation over Salamanca's future has begun to spread beyond the town's borders. In Albany and Washington, Salamanca's representatives are pressing the state and Federal governments to split the initial $60 million payment.
Both of these governments have pledged to help resolve the situation. But both are constrained by financial problems of their own.
A first-time visitor to Salamanca might have a hard time understanding what all the fuss is about. The town's economy deteriorated long ago, in part because the uncertainty of the lease situation made it impossible to get a mortgage. Half the stores on Main Street are closed, giving the place a half-asleep look, and many of the young people have already left to find jobs elsewhere.
 
Nowhere Else to Go
To many residents, however, Salamanca is the only home they have ever known. The stagnant economy and the uncertain lease situation make it an inexpensive place to live - many homes sell for less than $20,000 - and a large proportion of residents are older people on fixed incomes who have nowhere else to go.
''People are very uptight about it,'' said one lifetime resident, who identified herself only as a retired school teacher.
The earliest Salamanca leases were negotiated between the Seneca Indians and white settlers in the mid-1800's when the first railroad companies began to lay tracks through the Allegheny River valley. By many accounts the leases were illegal, but by the time anyone got around to questioning them, Salamanca had become an important railroad hub, and in 1875 Congress, responding to intense lobbying, validated the leases for five years.
When the five years were up, Congress extended the lease for another 12 years, then for 99 years. The last extension is to expire on Feb. 19, 1991.
 
Countdown Begins
Salamanca has been jittery about its future for years now. Municipal officials have been negotiating a new lease with the Senecas off and on for more than a decade, and for the last three years the local paper, The Salamanca Press, has been printing the number of days left before the lease expires.
That anxiety only worsened last month, when the team negotiating the new lease announced that it had struck the best deal it could with the Senecas. The deal calls for payments on a new 40-year lease to total $800,000 a year, and it asks the Federal and state governments to pick up the $60 million initial payment. It contains an escalation clause under which payments would increase in tandem with Salamanca's land values.
Whites in Salamanca greeted the deal with rage, and its fate remains uncertain. For a white owner of a home or business in Salamanca to extend his lease, he will have to sign on to the deal himself, and many whites say they simply will not do so.
''I think we should say forget it,'' said Shirley Weast, a real estate agent whose lease payments would increase from $7 to $4,700 under the new lease. ''What they're proposing is an absolute death sentence.''
Just what will happen in February if white residents have not signed new leases is unclear. Some say that their cases would then go to arbitration, while others say it is possible that the land would revert to the Senecas.
Whatever the whites in Salamanca decide to do, Seneca leaders say they are confident that they will not be cheated this time around. And if the town is frustrated with them, they say they do not have much sympathy.
''These guys had 99 years to think about the future,'' Mr. Lay, the Seneca president, said. ''It's just poor planning.''

HEADLINE: Flaming Oil Is Spilled Into Gulf as Blasts Rack Tanker

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GALVESTON, Tex., June 10

 BODY:
Five explosions in 10 minutes aboard a Norwegian tanker spewed flaming plumes of oil into the Gulf of Mexico this afternoon, about 36 hours after a large section of the 853-foot vessel first burst into flames.
Coast Guard officials here said the fire on the tanker Mega Borg was still burning out of control, not only on the ship, 50 miles off the Texas coast, but in the oil on the water as well, and was expected to burn through the night.
Until the ship could be boarded and the damage assessed, they said, it would be unclear how many gallons had been released and what effect the spill would have on the environment.
''We have a potentially serious situation,'' said Lieut. Comdr. F. L. Whipple, the commanding officer of the Coast Guard Marine Safety Office here. ''We are trying to prevent a catastrophic loss of oil.'' 
 
A Giant, Unstable Hulk
A Coast Guard spokesman said firefighting efforts were hampered because the nearest equipment to spray foam onto the burning hulk was in Louisiana. It was on its way to the fire scene this evening, and additional equipment and crews were being sent from the Netherlands.
The 38 million gallons of oil carried by the 15-year-old Mega Borg is more than three times the amount spilled by the Exxon Valdez off the coast of Alaska last year in the largest oil spill ever in the United States. The fire and explosions on the Mega Borg, which is burning and tipping toward stern, make her less stable than the Valdez was when she ran aground on Bligh Reef in March 1989. But the fire is a benefit as well: it appears to be consuming much of the oil spilling from the Norwegian tanker.
 
Stern Reported Stable
The ship's stern has dropped 58 feet since the first explosion on Saturday, indicating either that the cargo has shifted or that the Mega Borg is taking on water, Commander Whipple told a Sunday evening news conference. But by 9 P.M., the stern had stablized with 5 feet of it above the water, said Petty Officer Howard J. Holmes of the Coast Guard.
The explosions today on the Mega Borg, coming three days after the 260,000-gallon oil spill in the Kill van Kull in New York Harbor, are sure to focus new attention on legislation pending in Congress addressing the ability of the oil industry and government to prepare for and respond to such accidents. An effort to require and pay for more aggressive responses has been bottled up in Congress for months.
Officials are wary of making too much of comparisons to the Valdez accident because the Mega Borg was carrying a different type of oil, light crude, which is brown and evaporates more quickly than the heavier crude carried by the Valdez. If it washes ashore, it is not as likely to heavily coat beaches, birds, sea creatures and animals.
 
A Small Sheen Now
The Valdez spill eventually stained about 1,100 miles of coastline. The sheen of oil behind the Mega Borg was a mile long and half a mile wide this evening.
''A layer this thin will not cause serious, extensive damage,'' said Richard Golob, publisher of Golob's Oil Pollution Bulletin of Cambridge, Mass. ''The real concern is if this tanker was to start losing a large amount of crude oil and form a slick that would not be able to evaporate.'' That slick would be potentially toxic to marine organisms like fish larvae and plankton, said Mr. Golub, who is recognized as an authority on oil spills. ''It also could prove problematic for sea-going birds.''
Oil has been flowing from the tanker since the initial fire and explosions killed two of her crew members and injured 17 others Saturday. Two were missing and presumed to be dead and two others from the 41-man crew remained hospitalized this afternoon.
The containment effort is being coordinated by Smit American Salvage, a Galveston-based company, which was hired by the ship's owner, K. S. Mega Borg II of Norway.
 
Willing to Take Over
The Coast Guard, which was criticized for not stepping in to supervise the containment efforts after the Valdez spill in Alaska, is monitoring the actions of Smit American Salvage. ''We've been meeting with them all day,'' Commander Whipple said. ''As long as they do what they're supposed to be doing, we will simply advise.'' If the Coast Guard differs with the company, he said, ''we will federalize the process and do it ourselves.''
Early this evening, there were eight ships circling the Mega Borg, equipped with skimmer booms and fire-fighting equipment. More than a dozen other ships were on their way. An aircraft owned Elf Acquitane Petroleum Company of Houston, a subsidiary of Societe Nationale Elf Acquitaine, the French energy company. and the owner of some of the cargo spread dispersants within five miles of the ship late this evening.
Dispersants are detergent-like chemicals that disperse oil by breaking it into microscopic droplets that settle in the water. A Coast Guard spokesman, Todd Nelson, said the dispersant aboard the plane. which is known by the product name of Co-Rex It 9527, has never been used near a flaming spill before.
There was criticism after the Valdez spill that dispersants were not used soon enough. ''This is the same product that was used, or, more to the point, that wasn't used, during the Exxon spill,'' said John Leonard, the Coast Guard's liaison with the scientists who are advising firefighters.
 
Letting It Burn
Mr. Nelson said that there was no effort being made to stop the oil from burning on the surface. ''We're going to let it burn,'' he said. ''We're not going to fight the fire on the water.''
The fire, he said, causes much of the oil to evaporate into the air. ''It causes some air pollution, but that dissipates,'' he said. ''What would be worse would be for it to sit on the surface and drift toward shore.''
The rescue ships owned by Smit are expected to start pumping foam onto the Mega Borg on Monday morning. ''If we can stop the fire, we can board the ship, and that's the only way we can stop the spill of oil,'' Mr. Nelson said.
''It's far away, there isn't a fire department on every section of the ocean,'' he said. ''Maybe that's a deficiency. I'm not sure. It sure would have been nice to have it here a day earlier.''
Tankers are inspected by the Coast Guard, which performs yearly official examinations and random unofficial examinations. The last recorded inspection of the Mega Borg was in April, said Chief Petty Officer Rich Muller. ''The indications we have from its case history shows there have been no problems on any of its boardings,'' he said.
Asked if a double hull might have reduced the damage of a spill, Petty Officer Muller said, ''In this case, I don't see where it would have made a difference.'' There has been renewed debate recently on whether double hulls should be required on tankers to minimize the risk of major spills.
''Right now, as far as we can tell the oil that's escaping is from the double pipes in the pump room,'' Petty Officer Muller said. ''We think those were damaged in the initial explosion.''
 
Too Large for Port
The spill began at 1 A.M. Saturday, when the Mega Borg, which was too large to come all the way into port, was unloading some of its cargo onto another vessel. The tanker began its voyage in Palanca, Angola, and was scheduled to travel to Aruba after unloading the oil off Galveston.
The bodies of the two dead crew members were taken off the deck of the ship this morning. Their names have not been released, and the Norwegian Embassy is attempting to contact their families.
The cause of the explosion has not yet been determined, Mr. Nelson said. ''The people who were in the pump room at the time and were in the best position to tell us were among the injured,'' he said.
At first, officials said they were not concerned that the tanker would sink, resulting in a disastrous spill, but the five explosions between 12:05 and 12:15 this afternoon changed their thinking.
''The danger has certainly increased as a result of the events this afternoon,'' Mr. Nelson said. The explosions caused the cargo to shift toward the hole blown in the stern of the ship, increasing the rate at which it is spilling oil into the gulf, he said.
Good weather that has favored the effort to put out the fire and contain the spill was expected to continue for at least a day, forecasters said. Light winds and waves of two to three feet posed no extra danger to the burning tanker.
Weather and ocean currents, in addition to the amount of oil released, were thought to be important factors in how much damage the spill causes.
Environmentalists said several species of vegetation and fish in Galveston Bay could be at risk.
Should the oil reach the bay, it could jeopardize a national wildlife refuge there, as well as several oyster reefs and salt marshes, said Brandt Mannchen, who serves on the National Sierra Club's subcommittee on the off-shore continental shelf.
''I hate the thought of it,'' Mr. Mannchen said.
Alan Allen, the executive director of the Sportsmen Conservationists of Texas, an environmental group based in Austin, said he is particularly concerned about a reed-like plant, Spartina alterniflora, that grows in tidal flats and shallow water. ''It's a very good cover for larval forms of game fish and other marine species,'' including shrimp, speckled trout and southern flounder, he said.
''The entire Galveston Bay is extremely valuable for both recreational fishermen and commercial fishermen,'' Mr. Allen said.
Mr. Mannchen said the beaches along Galveston Island, a barrier island that serves as an entrance to the bay, are popular tourist attractions that might be in the path of the slick, depending on its direction.
''Tourism is one of Galveston's main industries,'' Mr. Mannchen said. ''This really couldn't have come at a worse time for the city, economically.''
 
In the Spotlight Again
Even though the causes of the most recent spills remain unknown, the blazing ship off Texas, has called attention once again to the continuing delays in addressing tanker safety issues.
Comprehensive oil spill legislation passed by both houses of the Congress has been held up for months in a Congressional conference committee, where House and Senate members have failed so far to resolve such issues as how soon to require double hulls on tankers. Another divisive issue has been whether to join an international liability fund to help clean up major spills caused by foreign vessels.
The proposed oil spill legislation would establish several new Federal response teams around the country. The teams would have special equipment, such as booms and skimmers, for containing the spread of oil slicks.
An oil company group announced a year ago a similar plan to establish emergency response teams to react to spills, but none of the teams are in place and the industry is still studying how to carry out the plan.
One oil company, Conoco Inc., has acted on its own to order two new tankers with double hulls.
The Coast Guard, for its part, has dozens of new regulations and programs under consideration that would affect oil shipping, but most of them are far from being put into effect. They would address such issues as the certification of local harbor pilots, the qualifications of ships' officers, the equipment that should be carried by ships or used in harbors for safe navigation, and the need for more thorough inspections of vessels entering United States waters.
 
Using Dispersants
 
A dispersant is a detergent sprayed on oil spills from planes or boats. It breaks up oil into tiny droplets that sink below the surfact and are diluted in the water. The droplets are gradually degraded by the natural action of microorganisms.
 
Advantages
 
Inexpensive.
Remove oil quickly from the water's surface.
Work well in rough water.
Can be used on very large spill.
 
Disadvantages
 
Must be applied within 24 hours of a spill to be effective.
Slightly toxic. Effect on marine life is not fully understood. May cause damage to organisms that ingest them.
Do not work well in calm water. Wave action is needed to mix them with the spilled oil.

HEADLINE: 2 BOROUGHS FACE A BAN ON BUILDING

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD

 BODY:
New York State is threatening to halt new building in lower Manhattan and downtown Brooklyn if the city does not decrease the amount of sewage flowing to the city's largest treatment plant.
The plant, the over-burdened Newtown Creek plant in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, has been accepting more sewage and waste water than allowed by state permit, and passing more inadequately treated waste into local waterways.
Under the permit issued in September 1988, the state can bar new sewer hookups in the plant's service area after July 31 if the plant exceeds its design capacity of 310 million gallons of sewage a day.
 
Development Could Be Disrupted
Such a move would stop construction in the neighborhoods served by the plant, like the multimillion-dollar Battery Park City on the southwest edge of Manhattan, and curtail plans in downtown Brooklyn. Moreover, a sewer-hookup ban would disrupt planning for large-scale developments of all kinds. 
The state has said that imposition of a moratorium is not an idle threat, and has already shown that such bans can be costly. It only recently lifted a 30-month moratorium on sewer hookups in 26 municipalities in Westchester County, which had been penalized for operating the Yonkers sewage-treatment plant beyond capacity. Builders in Westchester say the ban cost them $50 million.
Even if New York escapes a state ban in the coming months, the threat indicates that serious troubles lie ahead for the city's sewage-disposal system, which is stretched beyond the limit in many quarters.
City officials and the real-estate industry say they are taking the threat of the ban seriously.
 
More Waste, Dirtier Discharges
''We knew the ramifications when we put the permit conditions in,'' said Carol Ash, regional director of the Department of Environmenal Conservation. ''We anticipate that it is fully enforceable.''
A hookup moratorium in New York City could have far-reaching economic effects at a time when the area is already in a slump. And the threatened cutoff has implications for building throughout the city. All but one of the permits for the city's 14 sewage-treatment plants contain sewer-hookup provisions, and several plants are operating at or near capacity.
Built 23 years ago, the Newtown Creek plant accepts sewage from downtown Brooklyn, parts of Queens and from Manhattan below 12th Street on the West Side and below 72d Street on the East Side.
When a sewage-treatment plant operates above capacity, the waste receives less treatment, resulting in dirtier discharges, which violate state and Federal law.
 
Could Get Eight More Months
Ms. Ash said the state expects to begin talks with the city on what steps can be taken to reduce the flow to the Newtown Creek plant. The city could be given up to eight more months from the end of July before a ban would be imposed if it is found ''currently engaged in an effective remediation program,'' according to the permit.
Some environmental groups and one government regulation agency are watching the situation closely. They won a lawsuit last year forcing hearings to determine whether permits should be tightened in areas like discharges of toxic metals. The groups see the Newtown Creek issue as a test of how serious the state is about cleaning up New York's waters.
''We certainly would expect the state to uphold whatever is in the permit,'' said Alan I. Mytelka, director of the regulation agency, the Interstate Sanitation Commission.
Last year, the state and city signed a consent order modifying a permit for the Wards Island sewage-treatment plant that removed the threat of a sewer-hookup ban until 1996 if the city pursued stronger water conservation measures and added plant capacity. #16 Million Gallons Over Capacity The average flow at Newtown Creek for the 12 months between April 1989 and March 1990 was at least 326 million gallons a day, 16 million gallons over capacity, according to estimates by the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group. Joseph T. Miller, chief engineer for the city's Department of Environmental Protection, also put the flow in the 320-million-gallon-a-day range. The plant serves about 1.1 million people.
''Such conditions, over a long period, may lead to premature failure of plant equipment and water-quality violations,'' according to testimony last year from Richard L. Newman, regional water engineer for the Department of Environmental Conservation.
New York has undertaken a big water conservation program, including a vast metering effort. One of its goals is to reduce waste water that flows to plants like Newtown Creek.
The city is also planning a $1.2-billion, 50-million-gallon-a-day expansion of Newtown Creek that will take almost 10 years. At the same time, the plant's treatment process will be upgraded to comply with Federal law requiring 85 percent of pollutants to be removed from waste water. New York fought unsuccessfully for a waiver to the requirement.
 
Blunt Instrument to Get Attention
Besides Newtown Creek, four of the city's 14 treatment plants - North River, Coney Island, Bowery Bay and Wards Island - are accepting sewage and waste water beyond or near permitted levels. Groups have opposed new development projects that would hook into the Coney Island and Bowery Bay plants.
A ban on sewer hookups is a blunt instrument aimed at getting the attention of local officials. To end the Westchester County ban, officials agreed to correct leaks, broken sewer mains and illegal sewer connections.
The two-and-a-half-year ban had a severe impact, builders say. ''The economic effect was devastating,'' said George Frank, executive vice president of the Builders Institute of Westchester and the mid-Hudson region.
The Westchester example has city officials and the real-estate industry worried about whether the state would impose a similar ban in New York.
 
'I Take It Pretty Seriously'
''I don't think it can be ruled out,'' said Albert F. Appleton, commissioner of the Department of Environmental Protection, which operates the city's sewage-treatment plants. ''It's clearly a remedy.''
Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, said, ''I take it pretty seriously.''
Mr. Spinola said few projects would be immediately affected by a ban. But planning by builders for future developments would become much more difficult, he said.
City officials have more than just the state to answer to about the Newtown Creek plant.
 
Answering to Residents
Neighbors say they are disturbed by the prospect of increasing the plant's capacity. Some residents say they resent that a plant in a Brooklyn neighborhood has to accept so much Manhattan waste. ''I think that really burns a lot of people,'' said Deborah Lalor, a member of Greenpoint Against Smell and Pollution, which formed to protest plant odors.
Mr. Appleton did not offer specifics about what the city might do to better control flow to Newtown Creek. But he said he hoped that some agreement could be worked out with the state.
''Everyone is acutely aware of what you're talking about here is using the atomic bomb,'' he said, ''and you don't use the A-bomb unless you're pushed to the wall.''

CORRECTION-DATE: June 16, 1990, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on Monday about the Newtown Creek sewage treatment plant in Brooklyn referred incorrectly to the area it serves. It accepts waste from much of northern Brooklyn, but not from downtown Brooklyn.

HEADLINE: Too Little Deregulation

SERIES: Second of two articles.

 BODY:
Deregulation has worked. Over two decades, consumers of airline, transportation and telephone services have benefited from lower prices and improved services as new companies were allowed to enter, old companies allowed to exit and prices allowed to reflect competitive pressures. The net benefit to the economy totals tens of billions a year. 
Yet there are plenty of grievances, and they are not all inescapable consequences of deregulation. Egregious mistakes were made in deregulating cable television and the savings and loan institutions. Some mistakes can be corrected with tinkering. Others will require radical measures. But in no case is re-regulation Congress's best option. In fact, many of the problems are explained by too little deregulation, not too much.
Airport congestion could be alleviated if Federal regulations would allow airports to levy higher takeoff and landing fees for peak-hour travel. That would spread flights evenly throughout the day, making more effective use of existing capacity. The higher fees could then be used to build new capacity. In this case, less regulation is the answer. Congress can also guarantee bus and railroad service to rural towns without re-regulating surface transportation. Direct subsidies would accomplish the task, without wreaking havoc on the rest of the industry. Cable television is more troubling. Rates were deregulated even though cable operators faced little effective competition. No wonder that fees skyrocketed. Here, prudent re-regulation, perhaps along lines already proposed in Congress, is an option. But even that may be unnecessary.
Roger Noll, a telecommunications expert at Stanford University, holds out the tantalizing prospect that satellite broadcasters could effectively compete with cable if existing regulations were different. That seems increasingly likely with new low-cost satellite technologies coming on line in the next year or two.
Residual regulations also hamper the ability of cellular phone companies to compete effectively for local residential phone customers. Here, too, regulation has needlessly crimped competition by blocking the installation of non-mobile cellular phones in homes.
Deregulation is not a panacea. Without adequate safeguards, it can backfire. Nor does the experience of removing restrictions on entry, exit and price suggest that it would be wise to relieve other types of regulations - like environment controls or rules about workplace and consumer product safety. These remain important duties of government.
Even so, the experience of deregulation under Presidents Carter and Reagan suggests that Congress has been too timid. Given all the halfway measures, it's a wonder deregulation has worked as well as it has. That knowledge whets the appetite for Congress to finish the job.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial; Series
