HEADLINE: Past, Present Clash in Race To Be Mayor Of Trenton

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 7

 BODY:
History fits comfortably on the streets of this city, where the Hessian barracks stormed by George Washington still stand and the 18th-century home of William Trent, the city's namesake, is open to all.
But the recent past - dark years of fear, factory closings, and neighborhoods shred to tatters - has been more difficult for the city to bear. And a central issue in Tuesday's runoff election for mayor is how closely Trenton is connected to that past.
On the surface, Carmen J. Armenti, a 61-year-old former restaurateur and City Council President, would seem to represent the old order. Last November he was selected to finish the unexpired term of Mayor Arthur J. Holland, who died after serving in the office for nearly three decades. 
Douglas H. Palmer, a 38-year-old Mercer County Freeholder who would become Trenton's first black Mayor, uses ''A new vision for Trenton'' as his campaign slogan and might be assumed the candidate champing for a break with the past.
 
Many Residents Confused
But in a city where a nominally nonpartisan election nonetheless spotlights each candidate's party affiliation, it is Mr. Palmer, a Democrat, who says his new vision is ''no more than making Trenton what it used to be in the 50's and 60's, a city of safe streets and decent housing.''
And it is Mr. Armenti, a former Democrat turned Republican who served as Mayor from 1966 to 1970, who insists Trenton can never go back to what it once was.
''We're not an old industrial town where they make pottery, steel and wire anymore,'' Mr. Armenti said. ''We're a governmental city, the state and county capital. That's where we have to gear our energies.'' Many residents are confused. ''To be painfully honest, I'm not sure what differences there are between the two of them,'' said Martin P. Johnson, executive director of Isles Inc., a community organization.
Mr. Armenti and Mr. Palmer, both lifelong residents of Trenton, were the highest vote-getters in a field of four candidates in the municipal election May 8. #2 Candidates Run Closely Mr. Armenti took as much as 75 percent of the vote in Trenton's Italian and Polish neighborhoods, finishing second with 8,787 votes, or 280 behind Mr. Palmer.
Pedro Medina, a police detective, won 3,537 votes. The fourth candidate, a former lottery director, Barbara Marrow-Mooring, received 461 votes. Because no candidate received 50 percent of the vote, a runoff is necessary.
Mr. Medina later endorsed Mr. Armenti, and a big question now is how many of Mr. Medina's supporters, many of them Puerto Rican residents who live in the old downtown section near the imposing maximum-security walls of the New Jersey state prison, will follow his lead.
Some politicians believe Hispanic voters, most of them Democrats, might reject Mr. Medina's endorsement and vote for Mr. Palmer. Despite the nonpartisan nature of the election, Mr. Palmer's campaign literature clearly identifies him as a Democrat. Mr. Armenti's literature does not mention his party affiliation.
 
Small-Town Politics
The campaign so far has been low-keyed and decorous. The advertising is restrained in tone and limited to bus posters, lawn signs and a few commercials on radio and cable television. Race has not become a major issue. Some people say that is because Trenton, despite being the state capital, harbors a small-town look on life.
''People pretty much agree that race was not foremost in the campaign,'' said Ingrid W. Reed, assistant dean of the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University and chairwoman of the Capital City Redevelopment Corporation, a downtown revitalization organization.
''One might have expected it to be, but Trenton is more of a small town. People do know each other, and they do know these candidates.''
With roughly 90,000 people, Trenton is clearly no country village, although it is shrinking. It has lost about 14 percent of its population since 1970, when more than 104,000 people lived here.
Trenton suffers all the ills of other major Northeast cities: drugs, crime, poor schools and high unemployment. It has no movie theaters and no major supermarkets.
 
Rise of State Offices
To fight competition from suburban shopping malls in the early 1970's, the city blocked off West State Street through the downtown shopping district and created an outdoor mall, called the Trenton Commons. It flopped. The city plans to reopen one of the streets in the fall.
By the early 1980's, downtown Trenton seemed so incapable of helping itself that the state government stepped in. The Capital City Redevelopment Corporation was formed to encourage new construction, and new state office buildings were built on downtown streets.
It was a controversial move that in some ways signified a surrender of the city's identity to the state. New office towers, built at a cost of more than $200 million, have transformed the downtown area, but some merchants contend business is worse than ever. West State Street remains desolate after the state workers go home at 5 o'clock.
Mr. Palmer, a bachelor and longtime Little League coach who wears a Gucci watch on one wrist, believes Trenton has become too reliant on the state. He said that during the 1980's, when new office buildings were sprouting alongside Route 1 near Princeton, about 10 miles away, Trenton was unable to attract either jobs or housing because the city was not aggressive enough in seeking development.
Mr. Armenti - chubby, bald and partial to pinstripes - said the state and its 20,000 daily workers must, by necessity, remain the power behind Trenton's economic engine. But he also said current agreements required that at least 20 percent of new downtown buildings be occupied by private businesses. Before those agreements took effect, he lost his own downtown restaurant to a new state office building.
 
Education Issue Raised
Other current concerns in Trenton are homelessness and the lack of affordable housing, drugs, street crime and the battered state of Trenton's schools.
At a League of Women Voters debate this week at the Mercer County College campus in downtown Trenton, Mr. Palmer, who works for the Board of Education as director of purchasing, criticized Mr. Armenti for not paying attention to education except during budget time.
Mr. Armenti, who is legislative liaison for the New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency, in turn charged that Mr. Palmer lacked experience and had been criticized by community groups for mismanaging the purchasing department.
In January the Trenton Council of Civic Associations, consisting of 39 community organizations throughout the city, reviewed the Board of Education budget and found the purchasing department overstaffed and inefficient.
Trying to keep cool before a noisy debate crowd of about 150 residents, the candidates traded barbs several times. Mr. Palmer said Mr. Armenti had done little in his six months in office to solve any of the city's problems.
 
Competence Debated
''The past six months proves Carmen believes in the Greyhound bus tour school of management,'' Mr. Palmer said. ''Instead of sitting down with people and solving problems, he takes tours.''
Mr. Armenti said repeatedly that Mr. Palmer was not competent to run the city. In one exchange, Mr. Armenti said to the audience, ''I'd wager now that if you ask Mr. Palmer the tax rate, he doesn't know.'' Mr. Palmer replied that the rate was $4.84 per $100 and said ''If it's wrong, it's because it went up since you took office.''
The city's effective tax rate, which takes into account Trenton's assessments at just 20 percent of real value, is $3.32 per $100 according to county tax officals. It was $4.85 in 1986.
The campaign has attracted some attention from outside Trenton. Last Sunday Mayor David N. Dinkins returned to the city where he was born. His family lived on Spring Street, where Mr. Palmer now lives.
Mr. Dinkins campaigned with Mr. Palmer. ''He told me to hang in there, to hang tough,'' the candidate said later.
Mr. Armenti said he was working hard to be elected mayor, but he pledged that he and Mr. Palmer would join in an embrace the day after the election no matter what the results, because neither wanted racial rivalries to divide the city.
''Nothing,'' Mr. Armenti said, ''is more important than having a city that is together.''

LENGTH: 985 words

HEADLINE: With More Say in Budget, City Council Finds a Guide

BYLINE: By DON TERRY

 BODY:
The finance director for the New York City Council, Marc V. Shaw, looked too tired to get up from his chair the other day. The late nights and cigarette butts were beginning to accumulate.
''I have two children,'' he sighed, ''ages 5 and 1 1/2, the last time I was home.''
This is the busiest time of year for Mr. Shaw - budget time. And it is his job to supply the Council leadership with the numbers and the analysis - the ammunition - that they will use in their annual budget battle with the Mayor over what is included in the sprawling document and what is not. 
For years the battle was one-sided, in favor of the mayor, in part because the Council lacked detailed budget information of its own. Its budget analysis was superficial at best. Instead, the main policy goal of many of its 35 members was ''adding on as many goodies as possible,'' said Paul Dickstein, a former city budget director.
 
'How Can We Pay for It?'
By most accounts, Mr. Shaw, who is 35 years old, is trying to change that. In his 18 months as director he has worked to improve the finance staff and to provide the Council with better budget information.
Politics and parochial interests still have a strong influence in the wood-paneled Council chamber. But since Mr. Shaw arrived, Mr. Dickstein said, Council members have been asking, '' How can we pay for it?''
The changes in the Council come at a time when its powers are expanding. Under the new City Charter, the Council for the first time will have sole authority to approve the city's $28 billion budget, a duty it had shared with the Board of Estimate, which will be phased out by late summer.
The new budget leaves little room to maneuver. The Dinkins administration and the Council have to fill a budget gap of nearly $2 billion for the fiscal year beginning July 1.
Both sides say reduced city services and higher taxes are as inevitable as fireworks on the Fourth of July. The question is what combination of taxes and cuts they will finally agree on.
''If one likes chaos, this is the place to be,'' Mr. Shaw said as his telephone rang almost incessantly. ''I happen to like chaos, but I think it's reaching the limits for even my tastes. We have a new Charter, a new Mayor and a new fiscal crisis.''
Mr. Shaw joined the Council after eight years as an analyst and assistant director of fiscal studies for the State Senate Finance Committee in Albany. Peter F. Vallone, the Council Speaker, who hired Mr. Shaw after a one-year search, said Mr. Shaw is a keen guide through the fiscal woods because he not only knows the most influential leaders and their top aides in Albany but ''also what taxes they're likely to pass or reject.''
About $550 million of the $859 million in taxes proposed by Mayor David N. Dinkins to help fill the budget gap must be approved by the Legislature.
No one, Mr. Shaw said, can be entirely certain what taxes will be acceptable in Albany. Taxes are a bad word in any legislative body. But Mr. Shaw said he hopes to help put together a tax package that ''provides the best beginning for a dialogue that will get us the money we need to balance the budget.''
Three taxes suggested by Mr. Shaw and his 30-member staff have been incorporated into the Mayor's budget proposal - an estate and gift tax, a wine tax and a tobacco tax. And for about two weeks the two sides haggled, sometimes bitterly, over $116 million in alternative taxes the Council wanted. On Thursday the Mayor agreed to drop his proposals for a tax on gasoline and a higher auto use tax and to replace them with a compromise package.
 
Democracy in Nervousness
Mr. Shaw is not an apolitical number cruncher. The line between public policy and politics is thin, and the nature of his job forces him to cross and recross that line every day. Each morning, he and several other senior staff members meet with Mr. Vallone and Herbert E. Berman, the chairman of the Council's finance committee. Over coffee, the group studies the budget and discusses its strategy for negotiating with Mr. Dinkins's office.
Although the leadership ultimately determines the Council's political direction, Mr. Shaw and the staff have an influence on it.
''It is the job of the budget person to provide the numbers to substantiate what we want to accomplish,'' Mr. Berman said.
Gene Russianoff, a lawyer for the New York Public Interest Research Group, said, ''Shaw and his staff are every bit as good as the folks at O.M.B.,'' referring to the City's Office of Management and Budget. ''That has O.M.B. very nervous. And that's a good thing for democracy.''
But Mr. Russianoff said Mr. Shaw's final report card would not be complete until after the budget was adopted. ''Then I'll be able to say whether we've been seduced and abandoned,'' he said.
These are hectic but heady times to be working for the City Council with its expanded powers, Mr. Shaw said. He is paid $105,000 a year. But lately, he said, his 16-hour work days have denied him time with his family. He lives in Bayside, Queens, with his wife, Mary, who is a lawyer, and their two children.
 
A Real Legislative Body
The Shaws met while they were students at the State University of New York at Buffalo, where Mr. Shaw majored in anthropology. He has a master's degree in urban anthropology. In 1979 he took a job with an economic forecasting concern owned by the University of Pennsylvania. He then went to work for the State Senate and its finance committee.
His goal, he says, is to help turn the Council into a legislative body that is taken seriously as a full partner in governing the city.
But some think Mr. Shaw may be too optimistic.
''I think he's capable of giving them professional support,'' said Charles Brecher, the director of research for the Citizens Budget Commission, a private monitoring group. ''The question is how much they want to use it. That remains to be seen.''

HEADLINE: COMMENCEMENT;
Valedictorian at Dartmouth Cites College's New Diversity

 BODY:
In the valedictory address at Dartmouth College yesterday, Michael Lowenthal, a senior from Chevy Chase, Md., cited himself as an example of the school's new diversity, but he questioned whether its students had unified into a community.
''Through need-blind admissions, coeducation and minority recruitment, our doors have been increasingly open,'' Mr. Lowenthal said at the college's 220th commencement, in Hanover, N.H. ''And today, Dartmouth is 'integrated' in a new way, as I am its first openly gay valedictory speaker.'' 
But Mr. Lowenthal said the new groups had ''too often been viewed as mere add-ons to the existing Dartmouth, rather than as equal participants whose presence necessitates a new, different community.'' His classmates gave him a standing ovation.
In a commencement speech, Jill Ker Conway, a former president of Smith College, prodded the school's 987 graduates to look for rewards beyond the starting salaries of their first jobs.
''Here you are, conscious of gifts and talents, burdened by student debt, by family expectations, ready to rush to wherever the fashionable place may be, to the nearest consulting firm, to the best specialty,'' Ms. Conway said yesterday. ''But I am here today to tell you, Don't do it.''
Ms. Conway, president of Smith from 1975 to 1985, said she was not advising the graduates ''to scorn the market and capitalist incentives,'' but rather to ''search for your real vocation,'' and find ''that connection between your moral and spiritual self.''
Dartmouth presented honorary degrees to Ms. Conway; David S. Broder, the syndicated political columnist for The Washington Post; Donald Knuth, professor of computer science at Stanford University; Robert Solow, professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who won the Nobel Prize in economic science in 1987, and Reggie Williams, a Cincinnati City Councilman and former linebacker for the Cincinnati Bengals.

LENGTH: 1516 words

HEADLINE: Concerned Coaches Are Wondering, Why So Few Blacks?

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN

DATELINE: OMAHA

 BODY:
AS college baseball continues to make major strides toward more widespread popularity, the virtual invisibility of black players at the sport's college level has raised a concern about its future growth.
In this year's College World Series, which ended here Saturday with a victory by Georgia over Oklahoma State, only 6 of the 176 players were black. (The series involves 8 teams of 22 players each.) Last year, 8 of the 176 were black.
A study by the American Institutes of Research found that 7.2 percent of all Division I baseball players are black. When the predominantly black schools in Division I are removed, the figure drops to 2.6 percent. 
That number is particularly striking when compared with the percentage of blacks in Division I football, 37 percent, and basketball, 56 percent.
''The pool of talent is much smaller than coaches would like it to be,'' said Gene McArtor, the Missouri head baseball coach and chairman of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I baseball committee. ''Many of the talented black athletes are heading in directions other than baseball, and it's been a loss for the sport.
''We have to convince more kids at an early age that baseball offers as many or maybe more opportunities than the other sports they are being attracted to. That's our challenge.''
With the exception of coaches in the two predominantly black conferences, there are no black head baseball coaches at any of the 269 Division I programs that field baseball teams.
The survey seems to indicate that Division I college baseball is in a position similar to that of college football and basketball in the 1960's. But while the lack of black athletes then was a result of biased traditions and of laws in some states barring the admission of black students, the reasons for the current low number of blacks in college baseball are more complex.
''A lot of people have asked me why there aren't more blacks,'' said Skip Bertman, the head baseball coach at Louisiana State. ''In fact, one chancellor came up to me before a game and asked, 'Where are the black athletes?'
''It's not a racist thing. It's harder to get blacks into college baseball because there are fewer of them attempting to do it, compared with basketball and football.''
The reasons given for the strikingly low numbers are several: lack of youth baseball programs, particularly in poor urban areas; the steering and gravitation of these same youngsters into basketball and football, and a scarcity of full scholarships, which forces families to foot part of the bill for a college education.
But the most commonly cited reason - and one of the most compelling - is the fierce competition for high-school athletes from major league teams.
In fact, pro baseball teams legally do what many big-time college football and basketball programs have been punished for doing: They offer money and other inducements to attract choice players.
''We have something in baseball that football and basketball don't have,'' Bertman said. ''We have the pro baseball draft, and that takes many of the good high-school black kids right into the professional ranks. That's the biggest point.'' Not surprisingly, money is a strong lure.
''Because of the economic situation that many of them are in, when they get offered $20,000, they're gone,'' said Ron Polk, the head coach at Mississippi. ''We signed three black athletes in the last three years, and they ended up signing pro contracts out of high school. The ones we've gone after ended up being pretty good drafts and they ended up signing. That happens to a lot of us.'' It's not difficult to see the attraction. Darryl Strawberry received a $210,000 signing bonus from the Mets in 1980. Kiki Jones, a pitcher from Tampa, Fla., signed for $175,000 with the Los Angeles Dodgers last year.
''Personally, I've seen those blacks who are good at baseball, and they want to achieve instant success,'' said Jeff Hammonds, Stanford's all-America freshman center fielder and one of the few black players in the Pacific-10.
Hammonds, who starred at Scotch Plains-Fanwood High School in New Jersey, was a ninth-round pick of the Toronto Blue Jays and turned down a reported $250,000 bonus and signed with Stanford.
But some observers feel there may be more behind the lack of blacks in college baseball than the pull of pro baseball.
''I don't think it's a matter of blacks not wanting to go to college,'' said Don Buford, the Baltimore Orioles' director of instruction. ''I don't think they're being recruited in the numbers that whites are.'' Buford, who is black, played baseball at the University of Southern California before embarking on a 10-year major league career.
Bertman said that argument might have some merit.
''Here's what we're guilty of as white middle-class coaches,'' he said. ''I'm guilty of it, my counterparts at The Citadel and Mississippi State and Stanford are guilty of it: We don't scour the inner-city schools for the best black athletes in baseball. Why? Because we don't have to. ''There are so many kids that want to come to play college baseball who send letters and get scouts to send recommendations and whose parents can afford to accept a half-scholarship.''
Bertman said Louisiana State recently recruited a diamond-in-the-rough type of player from a Baton Rouge inner-city high school. The player is talented, but Bertman said he had to hunt for him.
Gary Ward, the Oklahoma State coach, disagrees with the premise that white coaches do not seek out black athletes. Before becoming the Oklahoma State baseball coach in 1978, Ward, who is white, coached junior-college basketball and came close to being assistant basketball coach for Eddie Sutton at Arkansas.
''I've been in the inner city, in Savannah to St. Louis, Chicago to Dallas,'' Ward said. ''Obviously, these kids have great skills. You watch those 5-8, 5-9 kids play basketball and you say, 'Gee, I'd like to have them for two or three years with a bat.'
''But in the inner-city areas in the North, where the weather is bad and there's no opportunity to play, when these 8- and 9-year-old kids go to city parks and play the hoops game, there's no baseball diamond. If there is a baseball diamond, there's not a local sponsor.
''When you get into the white affluent sections, they have the real nice city parks, the real nice uniforms, and 1,000 sponsors who give kids the chance to play from T-ball on up.''
Lyle Mouton Sr., whose son is the only black player on Louisiana State's team, attributes the situation not to a lack of black players in Little League, but to their lack of involvement at the American Legion level.
''That's where your college coaches go to recruit in the summer,'' said Mouton, who played in the Pittsburgh Pirates organization and has coached in several youth leagues in Louisiana. ''They don't go to the high schools. From all of my coaching, youth baseball, from T-ball through high school, has been dominated by black players.
''American Legion is where blacks get shelved. And if you don't play American Legion ball, slim chance you'll get to play major college baseball.''
At the same time, players like Hammonds concede that personal preference and the prestige of a given sport can play a major role in diverting black talent from college baseball. Four of the black players who participated in this year's College World Series admitted that baseball was not their first choice as a sport.
Mouton's son, Lyle Jr., played basketball for Louisiana State for two season before dropping the sport after last season to concentrate on baseball.
''I made a decision of the heart,'' he said. ''I wanted to play baseball and wasn't able to, and it hurt me to not be able to play a sport that I loved. So I had to make a life decision. I want to play this sport, and that's what I did.''
Hammonds was a running back in high school and played until suffering an injury during his senior year. He figured baseball was the most injury-free sport and focused his attentions there.
Another major factor in the low numbers is the scholarship situation. Unlike big-time college football and baseball, most baseball programs are unable to grant many full athletic scholarships. That means the average recruited athlete will need outside help to pay what the partial scholarship does not cover.
''A kid who plays baseball has got to have help from home,'' Bertman said. ''So kids go to a community college for less money and stay at home.''
For a growing number of black families, the opportunity to give a son a college education outweighs the short-term money.
Last year, Calvin Murray, an outfielder at W. T. White High School in Dallas, turned down a $300,000 bonus offered by the Cleveland Indians and accepted a scholarship to play for Texas.
When his mother, Virginia, was asked by a reporter how she could resist the lure of a six-figure bonus, she replied that she had told her son to think of the long haul.
''I tell Calvin I don't care how good he is,'' she said. ''If you're black, you need the education.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lyle Mouton Jr., the only black on Louisiana State's baseball team. (Associated Press for The New York Times)

INTERNATIONAL REPORT
 
President Bush is expected to announce that the United States will begin preparing for free-trade talks with Mexico, senior Administration officials say. American officials have long favored the principle of free trade between the two countries, but opposition in Mexico has until recent months made the issue moot. President Salinas of Mexico, however, abruptly reversed the situation this spring and called for free trade talks. [Page D1.] 
 
The United States and the Soviet Union are trying to build a new commercial relationship across the spectrum of transportation -moving goods by land, by sea, by air or even into orbit. [D1.]

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Birth of a Global Book Giant

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

 BODY:
Over the last two years, an amiable Scotsman with a tough glint in his eye has transformed one of America's oldest publishers, the sleepy house of Harper & Row, into a dynamic global conglomerate.
The work of George Craig has stirred keen enthusiasm as well as anger and skepticism, through the creation of a British-American publishing house. He has effectively buried the old house of Harper, which published Herman Melville's ''Moby Dick'' in 1851.
Last month, Mr. Craig completed the merger of Harper & Row and the British publisher William Collins, bringing the two venerable houses under the new name of HarperCollins. The new company is expected to have revenues of approximately $1.5 billion. 
 
Time of Reckoning
With the emergence of HarperCollins, the time of reckoning has come for Mr. Craig, whose aggressive -some say extravagant - purchases of books have made Harper perhaps the most talked-about publisher in America.
As chief executive of the new company, Mr. Craig must prove that HarperCollins is worth the more than $1 billion that his boss, Rupert Murdoch, spent to assemble it.
This amounts to a challenge in relatively unchartered waters. HarperCollins is committed to global publishing, both general and educational, at a time when the idea is still questioned by many people in the industry.
''The whole idea of global publishing like HarperCollins is crazy,'' said Roger Straus 3d, managing director of Farrar, Straus & Giroux. ''A book is about as personal as a deodorant. You can count on one hand the authors who can really be sold globally.''
But William Shinker, publisher of Harper's trade book division, said, ''Publishing for the world English market simply makes sense.''
HarperCollins must test its strategy at a time when its owner, Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation, has encountered difficulties. Burdened with more than $6 billion in debt and still pouring money into Sky Television, an emerging British satellite-television service, the News Corporation posted a net loss of $24 million in the last quarter and its net income fell 76 percent, to $93 million, in the nine months to March 31.
 
Cutting Debt
To cut its debt, HarperCollins sold the medical publisher J. B. Lippincott last month for $250 million. After the sale, the company had debt of $550 million.
This does not not appear to perturb Mr. Craig, who is 50 years old and the son of a Glasgow steelworker. Mr. Craig, who is on the board of the News Corporation, exudes good cheer. It is only his tendency to chain-smoke that belies the driven executive lurking beneath the bonhomie.
''Mr. Murdoch has not told me that I must avoid new acquisitions or produce a certain profit,'' he said. ''But the News Corporation as a whole is now pursuing internal growth and improved profitability. Harper would not suffer from a period of stability.''
The last few years have indeed been hectic. Mr. Murdoch's purchase of Harper & Row for $293 million in 1987 was followed by that of the religious publisher Zondervan for $56.7 million in 1988 and the textbook publisher Scott, Foresman & Company for $407 million in 1989.
Last year, the News Corporation, which had owned 40 percent of William Collins since 1981, acquired the remainder of the British publisher for $717 million.
 
Distinct Traditions
Harper and Collins began merging their operations last July. By insisting on a full merger, Mr. Craig is trying to wed two long and distinct traditions. The houses were born on different continents in 1817 and 1819 respectively.
Harper, which published Thornton Wilder and John F. Kennedy's ''Profiles in Courage,'' was the embodiment of the American establishment publisher. If there were distinguished ambassadorial memoirs to be published, Harper was the place. And Collins - which started with Bibles and moved on to publishing Agatha Christie - had an equally strong image in Britain as a house with a wide range of books and a strong commercial sense.
Mr. Craig is convinced that he has taken the right course. ''Harper was old-fashioned, a bit dull, very bureaucratic, and it suffered from a lack of direction,'' he said of the house he took over in 1987, after more than 10 years as an executive at Collins. ''What has happened since the News Corporation came in has been unbelievably good.''
 
Increased Profits
Operating profits at Harper's American business have indeed gone up, reaching $58.1 million last year, compared with $5.6 million in the company's last fiscal year before the News Corporation bought it.
Several best sellers - including ''Barbarians at the Gate'' by Bryan Burrough and John Helyar and ''The 8-Week Cholesterol Cure'' by Robert Kowalski - have improved the image of a house that seemed to many editors to be in quiet decline during much of the 1980's. A mass-market paperback division has been started with such successful titles as E. L. Doctorow's ''Billy Bathgate.''
Armed with slides featuring such words as ''Pride,'' ''Excitement'' and ''Achievement'' to portray the new Harper, Mr. Craig appears to have inspired a genuine enthusiasm, at least among many of his American employees.
Brenda Marsh, a senior vice president for sales, typified the tone of employees by saying: ''We believe we can be the best publisher. That, quite simply, is what we are trying to do.''
But Mr. Craig has clearly taken on a lot. He has spent tens of millions of dollars on books - including $9.6 million alone for the rights to Agatha Christie's works, $1 million for ''Billy Bathgate'' and another $1.5 million for books by the thriller writer Clive Barker.
Over all, some publishers believe, Mr. Craig has shifted HarperCollins toward a more commercial image. This has drawn sharp criticism from former employees and others in the industry.
''The house has gone savagely down market,'' said a former executive of Harper who now works at a rival house.
 
Global Publishing
The drive toward global publishing has also provoked the scorn of several people in the industry, including the former chairman and the former managing director of Collins.
''By trying to create the true international publishing conglomerate, all George has done is destroy two great publishing traditions,'' said Sonia Land, who quit in anger as chief executive of Collins in March.
Referring to the former logotypes of the two companies - the torch of Harper and the fountain of Collins - which were replaced last month by a new blue-and-red, water-and-fire symbol, she added, ''Somebody should tell him that fire and water do not mix.''
Ian Chapman, the former chairman of Collins who resigned last year and was once Mr. Craig's mentor, was equally skeptical. ''Of course there is resentment at Collins,'' he said. ''Under no circumstances would I have agreed to their names being merged. No editor in England can tell an editor in New York what to publish.''
Mr. Craig prefers not to comment on his falling out with his former colleagues. But Terry Kitson, who succeeded Ms. Land as chief executive of HarperCollins U.K., called her criticism ''disgraceful remarks.'' He contended that morale in Britain was high.
Behind these salvos lies the controversy over whether global publishing is a feasible idea or a panacea dreamed up by conglomerates trying to justify big investments and homogenize the erratic world of books.
Some publishers, generally from smaller houses, argue that very few authors or general-interest books can be marketed worldwide, because what succeeds in the United States may well fail in Britain.
Others, from big houses like Simon & Schuster, believe that risk can be spread, economies of scale achieved and profits increased by selling a book throughout an increasingly small world.
 
Moving Cautiously
Mr. Shinker, the publisher of HarperCollins's trade division, said the company intended to move cautiously to exploit its global reach.
Starting this fall, Grafton, an imprint of Collins, will publish and market general-interest hardcover books and paperbacks in Britain, selecting titles originally published in the United States by Harper. ''We will begin with 20 titles this fall and aim for 75 to 100 by 1991,'' he said.
There are also far-reaching plans to sell Collins's reference books and dictionaries in the United States and to market new versions of Roget's Thesaurus throughout the world.
Meanwhile, Mr. Craig said, ''The diversity of our portfolio is extremely helpful because we are not as vulnerable to the ups and downs of the glitzy trade business.''
Unlike Random House, which has also bought publishing houses in Britain in recent years, HarperCollins has extensive religious and educational publishing operations. Indeed, of its approximately $725 million in annual American revenues, about $465 million comes from school, college and religious books. And only about 40 percent of its British revenues of more than $300 million comes from general-interest publishing.
William Baker, the chief administrative officer and a 30-year veteran of the company, says he believes this mix offers a sound base for future growth.
Certainly, although Harper is publishing more commerical authors, it continues to publish the likes of Paul Johnson, Marguerite Duras and Milan Kundera.
''They have done some terrific deals,'' said Lorraine Shanley, a publishing consultant. ''George has brought out the best in people.''
The question now is how quickly can this galvanized enterprise bring in returns to justify Mr. Murdoch's bold investments and reorganization.
In a sign that financial pressure has mounted, operations in Australia and Britain are expected to be sold for $250 million. Last week, the Australian retail bookstore business, Angus & Robertson, was sold for $15.2 million.

HEADLINE: Americans Seek to Improve Transportation for Soviets

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10

 BODY:
The United States and the Soviet Union are trying to build a new commercial relationship across the spectrum of transportation - moving goods by land, by sea, by air, or even into orbit.
In recent months, there have been proposals and deals in the Soviet Union with American companies like United Parcel Service Inc., the package-delivery company, Sea-Land Service Inc., the international shipping concern, and Honeywell Inc. and Northwest Airlines, which will sell satellite-based navigation technology. The companies say they anticipate no objections from the Defense Department, which developed the American satellite.
The transportation ventures and other types of deals like the General Motors Corporation's agreement to sell car parts to the Soviets indicate Moscow's desire to become more involved in the world economy and its willingness to be open to American businesses.
Experts say international transportation presents an important opportunity for the Soviet Union to earn dollars and other hard currencies. 
But the Soviets desperately need to improve their creaking transportation network if foreign trade or the domestic economy are to have any hope of prospering.
''Their internal transportation network is breaking down,'' Marshall Goldman, associate director of the Russian Research Center at Harvard University, said last week. ''Their infrastructure is disintegrating.''
But free enterprise can only deliver so much in the changing Socialist state, as is shown by U.P.S.'s venture in Moscow and Leningrad. The company's familiar brown trucks and uniformed drivers are making their rounds in the Soviet capital, under a joint-venture partnership with Sovtransavto, a Soviet company. But laws still on the books prohibit parcels from being sent to or received by individuals. For now, the service is restricted to businesses.
The latest evidence of the burgeoning bilateral transportation relationship came last week when President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Bush met. The leaders signed accords expanding the air routes between the nations and restoring shipping activity to each other's ports for the first time in a decade.
 
Some U.S. Carriers Critical
Airlines and shipping companies in the United States expressed some dissatisfaction with the agreements, saying American objectives like provisions for currency conversion had not been fully met.
The maritime agreement came under especially harsh criticism from ship owners, who said it would be hard for them to compete with the subsidized Soviet merchant marine in carrying goods between the United States and third countries.
But Government officials defended the agreements and said it was in the American interest to make some concessions so that economic changes in the Soviet Union could be put on a more solid footing.
''I think in cases like that, we have to err in favor of the new entrant, the East bloc country that is trying to move into a new era,'' said Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner, when asked about objections to the aviation and maritime pacts.
''There are going to be some tough times before they do it, but I think they want to make it happen,'' he said, adding, ''We are going to do everything we can'' to encourage the changes.
The Transportation Department has for more than a year been accelerating the exchange of technical data between the Governments, with several missions back and forth by agencies like the Federal Railroad Administration.
 
Soviet Team in Washington
In a typical exchange between the Governments, a Soviet team was in Washington last week visiting the laboratories of the National Transportation Safety Board, which is laying plans for joint investigations of accidents that might occur as transportation trade increases.
But the big changes are happening in the transportation industries, where some grand plans are in the works. Sea-Land, for example, signed an accord in May with the new Association of Soviet Railways to improve the Trans-Siberian Railway.
Sea-Land, a unit of the CSX Corporation, has proposed other ventures, making it the first American transportation company to propose a partnership with all of the large Soviet rail, sea and air organizations.
It has concluded an agreement with Sovmortrans, a new international joint-venture company that will serve as Sea-Land's general agent in the Soviet Union for its cargo service.
Sea-Land, based in Iselin, N.J., described the agreement as the first time a foreign carrier had chosen as its agent a Soviet transportation company, organized as a profit-making enterprise under the continuing economic reforms in the Soviet Union.
The company has also been studying with Aeroflot a proposal that would expand cargo services by combining ocean and air shipments between Asia and Europe, through the Soviet Union. The idea is to use Aeroflot's extensive cargo capacity to link Eastern and Western ports by air. To make it work, Sea-Land says, extensive investments would be required in handling centers, tracking systems and marketing networks.
 
Many Obstacles Abound
Professor Goldman of the Russian Research Center, who describes himself as a pessimistic observer of the Soviet system, said achieving such aspirations faced several obstacles. First, he said, political change is occurring so fast in the Soviet Union that nobody knows exactly who is in charge. Deals struck in Moscow may be challenged at the local level, while arrangements made with independent enterprises are still subject to central veto.
Second, he said, labor unrest could pose a critical problem in the transportation industry; it has been especially acute in the railroad industry, which in the absence of a good road system is essential to tying together the Soviet economy. Finally, the fundamental obstacle of currency conversion exists, as well as the repatriation of profits, he said.
Still, the deals keep getting signed.
 
Satellite Pact Set
A few days before President Gorbachev visited Minnesota to meet with business leaders there, Honeywell and Northwest, which are both based in the state, announced a deal to use satellites to navigate aircraft.
Airliners of the future are expected to navigate across open oceans by taking precise fixes from satellites. Under the agreement with Honeywell and Northwest Airlines, an American and a Soviet satellite system will be tied together into the same network by the middle of the decade.
The companies have held test flights using the American Navstar satellite, and tests with Soviet technicians are scheduled for next year.
Some aviation agreements are straightforward sales, but even they might have been impossible until the military competition between the nations suddenly waned.
For example, the General Electric Company recently agreed to sell the Soviet Union engines for Aeroflot's newly ordered Airbus Industrie A-310 jetliners, the first such planes ever purchased by the state carrier from foreign suppliers. Because the engines have at their core a military design, export licenses must be granted, and the engines will have to be maintained outside the Soviet Union.
Meanwhile, G.E.'s competitor in the jet-engine business, the Pratt & Whitney Inc. unit of the United Technologies Corporation, said last month that it would enter the Soviet aviation market through a deal with the Soviet Government and a West German engine maker, Motoren und Turbinen Union. Pratt & Whitney said the deal could lead to the codevelopment of a new engine for use on airframes built in the Soviet Union.
 
Daring Jet Proposal
Perhaps the most startling plan put forth so far is the Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation's proposal to design a corporate jet capable of flying faster than the speed of sound, in a partnership with the Sukhoi Design Bureau in Moscow, which makes advanced jet-fighters for the Soviet military.
Gulfstream, based in Savannah, Ga., would provide marketing and avionics, while the Soviet group would build the airframe. The deal was announced several months ago.

HEADLINE: U.S. Avoids Germany's Ground Floor

BYLINE: By FERDINAND PROTZMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEST BERLIN

 BODY:
Shortly after the Berlin wall burst open in November, the International Business Machines Corporation was on the move in East Germany. Within two months, Johann Weihen, one of the company's top young executives, was assembling a unit to rebuild business in the ''other Germany,'' which had severed ties with the world's leading computer company in 1952.
Operating out of the West Berlin offices of the company's West German subsidiary, I.B.M. Deutschland G.m.b.H., Mr. Weihen and a handful of young, aggressive managers hit the ground running, traveling all over East Germany to evaluate its computer industry, assess market potential and interview prospective business partners and employees in hopes of sealing joint-venture agreements with software and hardware producers and to set up a distribution network for I.B.M. products.
''You can no longer delineate the European economic area with political or national borders,'' Mr. Weihen said. ''That opens up enormous potential. Given the European Community's plan for a single market in 1992, a European market from the Atlantic Ocean to the Urals is conceivable.'' 
 
Americans Moving Slowly
But I.B.M. is an exception among American companies. ''Where are the Americans?'' asked Kurt Kasch, a director of the Deutsche Bank Berlin A.G., who is leading the bank's drive into the East German market. ''Naturally, West German companies will take the lead. One would think Americans would at least be here on fact-finding trips. I've spent weeks in East Germany and have yet to run into any.''
Indeed, business executives from West Germany, Japan, Norway, Sweden, the Netherlands, France and Britain are rushing into East Germany to get in on the ground floor of what many say will be a second German economic miracle and into a market that could be the cornerstone for the economic reconstruction of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
But most American companies have shown either no interest or are moving extremely slowly, experts say. The few American companies entering East Germany, including I.B.M., the General Motors Corporation, the Coca-Cola Company and Levi Strauss & Company, are those with strong West German bases.
Many economists and business executives say the Bush Administration is setting the example for American companies by channeling money into Eastern European countries like Poland and Hungary rather than into East Germany, where it expects the West Germans to take the lead.
Another reason, some believe, is that American banks, already burdened with huge and nonperforming loans to third-world countries, are reluctant to finance companies' pursuits in East Germany.
Some companies are also probably waiting for clarification of important factors for doing business in East Germany, such as ownership of private property and reconstruction of the country's infrastructure.
 
'The Demand Is There'
But deals are being made and market share snapped up. Companies that wait may miss out.
''All our competitors - Hitachi, Siemens, Bull - are in East Germany,'' Mr. Weihen said. ''Every one of them is convinced that now is the time they must stake a claim.''
I.B.M. is not discouraged by the East German economy's accelerating decline. ''Short term, we don't expect big profits from East Germany,'' Mr. Weihen said. ''The demand is there. I have no doubt that East Germany will achieve a remarkable economic recovery.''
What is more, East Germany has the strongest economy in Eastern Europe and a number of other selling points, including a skilled work force.
''In software, I am constantly astonished by what they have achieved, relative to the poor hardware they have,'' Mr. Weihen said.
For I.B.M., results have come quickly. In the last several weeks, the company has signed contracts with VEB Kombinat Datenverarbeitungszentren, the state-owned arm for computer training and software research and development. The pacts authorize the Datenverarbeitungszentren to sell a wide range of I.B.M.'s products in East Germany. I.B.M. would not disclose further details of the agreements.
In mid-March, I.B.M. signed a letter of intent to establish joint ventures with VEB Kombinat Robotron, East Germany's computer builder. Negotiations are still under way. ''Robotron,'' Mr. Weihen said, ''has no products that can really compete successfully in the global market,'' But it could conceivably distribute I.B.M. products in East Germany.
On March 18, the results of East Germany's first free, democratic elections were tallied on I.B.M. computers on loan to the Government from the company.
The East German election brought in the Government of Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere, which is preparing for the merger of East and West Germany's monetary, economic and social policies on July 2.
Once that is accomplished, Mr. Weihen and his 11-man team expect to complete many of I.B.M.'s plans for joint ventures, including opening retail shops. He would not discuss details.
 
Overcoming History
But Mr. Weihen and many other European business executives worry about the perception of a united Germany as the strongman of Europe.
While 40 years of peace and democracy in West Germany have made the prospect of a unified Germany less threatening, West German Government and business leaders still look to corporate America's involvement as a way to allay fears.
They complain privately that the United States Government's diplomatic team in East Germany has been very slow to grasp the economic implications of German unity, or the democratic revolution that has swept Eastern Europe.
Robert A. Mosbacher, the United States Commerce Secretary denies that the Administration and American businesses are being overly cautious and praised Washington's representatives in West Germany. He cited the opening in March of a Foreign Commercial Service Office in West Berlin to promote American business in East Germany as an example of American interest.
''We intend to help United States business in East Germany, as we have and do in many other countries,'' he said.
''But I think you have to separate East Germany from Eastern Europe,'' the Secretary added. ''East Germany has a special predisposition toward West Germany. Although we're going in and will be working directly with East Germany and will be working with West German companies in joint ventures in East Germany, our involvement in Poland, Hungary and other Eastern European countries is on another level.''
Indeed, American investment in Eastern Europe was about $500 million in 1989, and virtually none of that was in East Germany, he said. The total United States investment in Eastern Europe is dwarfed by a single deal, worth $3 billion, between West Germany's Volkswagen A.G. and the East German auto maker VEB Ifa Kombinat Personenkraftwagen.
 
'Pretty Small Pickings'
But the Administration's actions may be discouraging Americans from entering East Germany and that could be costly, according to Martin McCauley, a private consultant and economics professor at University of London's School of Slavonic and East European Studies. He said the next two years will be decisive for companies wanting to do business in East Germany.
''If they are not in by then, they will be left with pretty small pickings,'' he said, adding that East German companies will soon be looking for financial help rather than joint ventures. But, he said, ''it will get very expensive to buy in.''
To Mr. McCauley, the economic implications are clear. ''If the Americans don't get involved now,'' he said, ''in 10 years we will see Germany completely dominating Europe economically, a Europe that will be the largest market in the world. Then the Germans will begin talking very tough indeed to the United States. And they may not be asking; they may be demanding.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: June 11, 1990

SECTION: Section D; Page 1, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 891 words

HEADLINE: Little Risk in G.M.'s Soviet Foothold

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 10

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation's $1 billion contract to supply catalytic converters and engine parts to the Soviet Union's Volga Auto Works, known as VAZ, has gained attention from economists and experts on Soviet industry mostly because the Soviets have promised to pay in hard currency, something the country painfully lacks.
Even if the Soviets are able to pay for the parts, they will have to build a car that is twice as popular as the model they now sell in Western Europe to meet the minimum order in the G.M. deal.
The agreement starts in 1992 and runs for five years. VAZ has agreed to buy enough parts, used for systems that make fuel burn efficiently with low amounts of pollution, to build 100,000 to 150,000 cars. The Soviet car, the Lada, will face growing competition from Japanese auto makers, who are gaining strength and forcing European companies to improve their products as well. 
Mary Ann Keller, an automotive analyst for Furman Selz Mager Dietz & Birney, says the Lada can make it in Western Europe, but only if it sells at a low enough price.
The potential benefits for G.M. are as uncertain as the future of perestroika, but the deal also poses relatively little risk, and it permits the giant auto maker to gain an early foothold in what one day may develop into a healthy economic environment.
''The Soviet Union announced this deal at a time when it doesn't really have the dollars,'' said Marshall Goldman, associate director of the Russian Research Center at Harvard University. ''But it doesn't start for a few years, and perhaps the economy will kick in by then.''
From a public relations perspective, G.M. may derive some immediate benefit by portraying itself as a patron of emerging capitalism in Eastern Europe.
Unofficially, G.M. executives concede that any payoff will not come quickly.
G.M. executives traveling to the VAZ operations in Togliatti had trouble communicating by telephone with their associates in Detroit. The problems may require G.M. to establish a private sattelite network that would bypass the Soviet telephone system.
 
'Pursuing New Frontier'
Speaking of G.M.'s growing investment in eastern Europe, Lou Hughes, managing director of G.M.'s Opel subsidiary said: ''Some thought the frontier spirit was dying in America, and that G.M. has its share of difficulties. It says a lot for our company, in the midst of our challenges, that we are aggressively pursuing a new frontier.''
The Ford Motor Company last year decided against a more risky venture to upgrade an auto plant in Gorky, partly because of the uncertain financial condition of the Soviet Union.
G.M. is really not risking much capital at this stage and will not have to build any plants; one G.M. executive referred to their agreement as essentially a purchase order. The Soviets, however, eventually want a joint manufacturing venture, which would cost at least several hundred million dollars. G.M.'s financial resources are not unlimited, but its pockets still are deeper than Ford's G.M. believes consumers in Poland and Romania have the greatest potential as future car buyers, and the company already is setting up dealerships in these countries. In Hungary, East Germany and Yugoslavia, G.M is setting up some joint manufacturing ventures. Mr. Hughes of G.M. said that the company was less interested in how to repatriate profits than in being a force for economic development, which will have a greater long-term effect on G.M.
 
A Different Problem
The Soviet Union, however, presents a different problem for G.M. than in Eastern Europe because its consumer economy is not as well developed. Therefore, G.M.'s approach is more cautious there. The main uncertainty is whether the Soviet Union can pay. Companies all over the world - Australian wool merchants, Japanese steelmakers and American granaries - have recently stopped shipments to the U.S.S.R. because bills have not been paid, Mr. Goldman noted.
Still, the Soviet auto industry has little choice but to press forward with new agreements. The industry is technologically backward. Indeed, G.M.'s parts will be installed in the Lada, a derivative of a 20-year-old Fiat model, so it can meet pending western European clean-air standards. Exporting large numbers of Ladas, which could generate desperately needed hard currency, is not possible without pollution controls. The Lada has received praise for utilitarian sturdiness, but few compliments for esthetics or comforts like a quiet, smooth ride.
Beyond the need to buy components, G.M. executives say Soviet automotive engineers need to learn about more sophisticated technologies, like electronic and emission controls. For example, all Russian car engines currently feature carburetors, a technology that is growing obsolete in the West; while few, if any, have on-board computers, routinely used in the most ordinary American-made vehicle.
Mr. Goldman warned that upgrading the Lada to Western European standards could create an backlash in the Soviet Union. Soviet consumers, he said, may demand a chance to buy the products for themselves.
Already, he pointed out, certain Soviet-made appliances like refrigerators are not exported as agressively as they could be, giving up some opportunities to generate hard currency in order to satisfy the Soviet consumer demand.

HEADLINE: Free-Trade Talks Seen For Mexico

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10

 BODY:
President Bush is expected to announce this week that the United States will begin preparing for free-trade talks with Mexico, senior Administration officials said over the weekend.
President Carlos Salinas de Gortari arrived here today for his third visit in less than a year for discussions with Mr. Bush and other American political and business leaders.
American officials have long favored the principle of free trade for the two countries, but opposition in Mexico has made the issue moot until recent months.
 
Abrupt Call for Pact
Mr. Salinas abruptly reversed the situation this spring and called for free-trade talks, giving pause to the Bush Administration. The Mexican President sees a free-trade agreement with the United States as an essential complement to the bold reforms he began in 1988, including privatization of banks and other state enterprises, and a crackdown on corruption. 
Mexico, which is already the United States' third-largest trading partner after Canada and Japan, would gain greater access to American markets and in turn become more attractive to investors.
Some of Mr. Bush's closest advisers have urged him to move warily with Mexico, given the immense hurdles to be overcome. Strong opposition is expected from organized labor in the United States, because of the prospect of low-priced Mexican imports that could threaten jobs. The prospect of a free-trade pact is also expected to worry members of Congress with constituencies producing textiles, footwear, base metals and other import-sensitive products.
 
Divided Administration
The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, who would have to negotiate the agreement and sell it to Congress, has been among those taking the more cautious approach. The Secretary of Commerce, Robert A. Mosbacher, and the Secretary of State, James A. Baker 3d, both Texans, want faster action.
The Administration officials said Mr. Bush was eager to respond positively to the initiatives of Mr. Salinas, who was to began his visit here with dinner at the White House. The officials also noted that any agreement would take years to negotiate and put fully into effect. The general view is that unless the Administration backs Mr. Salinas's domestic reform program, it could fail.
''Clearly, the free-trade train has left the station, and now it's a question of when it arrives at its destination,'' a senior American trade official said. ''Down the line, we are going to have a free-trade agreement with Mexico.''
 
Tied to Uruguay Talks
The formal negotiations are unlikely to begin until next year, after the conclusion of four years of world trade talks known as the Uruguay Round. Those negotiations, which Mr. Bush has declared his highest trade priority, involve 106 countries that are pursuing mutual cuts in trade and investment barriers.
The United States already has a free-trade agreement with Canada in which tariffs and investment barriers are being progressively dismantled over the next nine years. The pact with Canada provoked much concern that the country would be overwhelmed by the United States.
Even without free trade, Mexico and the United States are doing substantial business together. In 1989, two-way trade surpassed $51 billion. The United States is Mexico's primary export market and its largest supplier of imports.
 
Delay Likely in Formal Request
Several American officials said Mr. Bush and Mr. Salinas would give their political endorsement to the idea of a free-trade agreement while delaying a formal request for negotiations.
This has been the recommendation as well of the Business Roundtable, an influential group of 200 chief executives of large American companies that would be among the beneficiaries of expanded trade with Mexico.
''These negotiations should commence after completion of the Uruguay Round,'' the group said in a recently adopted position paper.
President Salinas is expected to set forth his most comprehensive views to date about free trade with the United States at a dinner meeting of the Business Roundtable on Monday.
Mr. Salinas, a 42-year-old economist who took office in December 1988, was also scheduled to have a breakfast meeting Monday morning with Secretary of State Baker.
 
Visit With Congressmen
Other items on Mr. Salinas's agenda Monday include visiting with several members of Congress, including lunch with the Senate Democratic Majority Leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, and meeting with groups of American business people.
After a breakfast Tuesday morning with Vice President Dan Quayle, Mr. Salinas will return to Mexico City before beginning a 10-day Asian trip next week.
President Salinas is expected to set forth his most comprehensive views to date about free trade with the United States at the dinner meeting of the Business Roundtable.
Under 1988 trade law, a formal request for a free-trade agreement would cause statutory notice to the House Ways and Means and Senate Finance committees, which would then have 60 legislative days (at least four months) in which to determine whether such agreement would be in the United States' interest.
 
Early Canadian Crisis
An early crisis occurred in the move toward a Canadian pact when the Senate Finance Committee on April 23, 1986, voted 10-10 on a resolution to deny negotiating authority to the Administration. Under the rules of procedure, the negotiation was permitted to go forward, but by the narrowest of margins.
Any Mexican agreement invites similar crises, which is one reason Mrs. Hills has taken the cautious line.
''I think it's very important to talk very carefully about what is intended by the trade agreement, what is the coverage, and the analysis of how it would affect sectors of this country, as well as sectors of Mexico,'' she said recently. ''I think it is better to do your analysis before you start something like that than find yourself engaged in a negotiation and then have problems.''
The two countries are already involved in trade negotiations of a much less ambitious nature. Since last October, when the two Presidents signed the Understanding Regarding Trade and Investment Facilitation Talks, the United States and Mexico have sought improvements in specific sectors of their bilateral trade.

HEADLINE: New York City Chooses Firms for Bond Offering

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Ending a fierce competition on Wall Street, New York City has named the five securities firms that will serve as senior managers for its general-obligation bond offerings over the next two years.
City officials said on Friday that Bear, Stearns & Company, the First Boston Corporation, Goldman, Sachs & Company, Merrill Lynch Capital Markets and Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. had been chosen from among 53 companies that had sought to manage the offerings.
As senior managers, the five firms will earn most of underwriting fees generated from an estimated $6 billion in general obligation bonds that are expected to be issued by the city over the next two years. 
In the course of the selection process, Mayor David N. Dinkins and Elizabeth Holtzman, the city's Comptroller, told the contestants that a firm's business connections with South Africa would be an important consideration.
In a joint news release, Mr. Dinkins and Ms. Holtzman also said efforts by firms to promote equal employment opportunities would be taken into account as well.
Based on the list of senior managers, however, it appears that economic considerations carried more weight with city officials in the decision-making process than worries about social responsibility.
The five firms selected all have various ties with South Africa. But they also have the ability to underwrite and distribute the city's securities at far lower interest rates than smaller firms with no ties to South Africa could be expected to deliver.
''Having a policy that is socially responsible has to be balanced off with the administration's responsibility to be fiscally prudent,'' said a senior city official, who asked not to be identified.
''At current rate levels, one basis point on $100 million is worth about $90,000 in present value terms,'' he said. (A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.) ''When you consider the magnitude of our program and what those savings mean, you are talking about tens of millions of dollars,'' he said. ''We have to go out and find the best people to sell our bonds. We have a fiscal responsibility to do that.''
In their news release, the Mayor and the Comptroller said the city reserved the right to replace any of the senior managers selected if they ''fail to demonstrate progress'' in curbing ties to South Africa or in promoting equal opportunity employment.
The Mayor and Ms. Holtzman also announced that Grigsby, Branford & Powell, a minority-owned securities firm, and the Artemis Capital Group, a firm owned by women were named as co-senior managers for a new equipment financing program. It is the first time that a minority-owned firm or one owned by women has been named senior managing underwriter on a city debt offering.
The names of the co-managers for the City's general obligation bond issues will be announced this week.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
More Foreign Buying Is Expected

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Some credit market analysts say that although foreign investors for the most part shunned Treasury securities in the first quarter, they have been active buyers in recent weeks and are likely to continue buying in the near term.
Most of the evidence about a recent increase in foreign buying is anecdotal. But word of any sort of increase is somewhat surprising, because interest rates in most of the world's large financial markets are extremely competitive with those in the United States.
''Right now, the American fixed-income market is extremely expensive'' relative to other markets, said Roger Portnoy, chief global strategist for Technical Data, a bond market advisory and analysis firm in London. 
''You can move from a 10-year Treasury note into a 10-year German bond and pick up about 15 basis points in the process,'' he said. ''If you moved out of two-year Treasuries into two-year German notes, you would pick up 60 basis points. The only other time you could do that was in the early 1970's.'' A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
Late last week, the Treasury's 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at a price to yield 8.45 percent. By comparison, West Germany's 7 3/4 percent bonds of 2000 were offered at a price to yield 8.63 percent.
For the most part, foreigners have been willing to forego higher yields elsewhere because the risks of investing in the United States are considered lower than in West Germany or Japan.
 
A Positive Perception
''The perception among foreign investors of the political and economic climate in the United States is positive,'' Mr. Portnoy said.
''Also, since the Federal Reserve Board moved sooner and more aggressively to deal with inflation than other central banks, there is a perception abroad that inflation is not as bad here as it is elsewhere,'' he said.
At the moment, the benefits of a more stable political climate and lower inflation risk amount to a premium of 50 to 75 basis points for Treasury securities over debt issued by other Governments, Mr. Portnoy said.
 
Further Rate Decline Seen
Mr. Portnoy said a further decline in American interest rates is likely during the next month or so.
As a result, he has been advising his firm's clients, primarily large European, Australian and Japanese pension funds and insurance companies, to increase their holdings in Treasury securities to 70 percent or more of their total portfolio.
A ''neutral'' weighting toward the Treasury market would be about 55 percent of the total, he said.
Brian J. Fabbri, chief economist at Midland Montague Economics, said, ''Around the globe, there is a fairly broad anticipation that investors who put money in dollar-denominated fixed-income securities are more likely to see interest rates decline along with economic weakness, and therefore sustain a capital gain.''
''The fear in other countries - Germany, and to a lesser extent in Japan and the United Kingdom, is that rates may rise,'' he said.
Foreign investment in Treasury securities is likely to remain healthy because the uncertainties about a united Germany will remain for some time after the East German ostmark is unified with the West German mark on July 2. As a result, Mr. Fabbri and others said, the dollar is likely to remain stronger than economic fundamentals might warrant.
Because of the dollar's strength, ''global investors may be forced to keep a bigger part of their portfolio in the United States than they otherwise might,'' Mr. Fabbri added.
 
Markets Could Be Rattled
The almost numbing stability that characterized the credit markets last week could be rattled somewhat in the next few days, as several reports on the economy and inflation are scheduled to be released.
Analysts are expected to give scrutiny to Wednesday's report on retail sales figures for May and the back-to-back reports on producer prices and consumer prices on Thursday and Friday.
By most accounts, the retail sales figures are not likely to show that consumers are providing much stimulus to the economy.
''Retail sales are flat,'' said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank.
The inflation figures will be the most closely watched, not only by the markets but by the Federal Reserve Board.
Producer prices, which have declined each month since a 1.8 percent spurt in January, probably rose by a modest two-tenths of a percentage point in May, analysts said.
And consumer prices, which galloped ahead at an annual rate of more than an 8 percent in the first quarter, also moderated in May.
Analysts at Salomon Brothers said the continued declines in retail energy and food prices probably limited the rise in consumer prices to two-tenths of a percentage point last month.
Even if the inflation figures are encouraging, few analysts anticipate that the Fed will move to ease monetary policy.
''The inflation numbers will be friendly,'' said William N. Griggs, a managing director at Griggs & Santow Inc., a financial consulting firm. ''But the only way they make sense is to combine them with what went on before. You need numbers in the 3 percent to 4 percent range to bring down the numbers we had in the first quarter.''

HEADLINE: Fed Officer Sees Dangers

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: BASEL, Switzerland, June 10

 BODY:
A member of the Federal Reserve Board warned today of the dangers posed by the weakness of the United States economy and urged a relaxation of the central bank's monetary policy by the end of the year.
There have been isolated weak spots before in the seven and a half years of American economic expansion, but now several important sectors are showing a slowdown at the same time, said Martha R. Seger, the Fed official, who is attending the annual meeting of the Bank for International Settlements in Basel. ''I personally believe that before this year is out we shall have to ease,'' she added.
But she said she did not know if a majority of the 12-member Federal Open Market Committee, which decides American monetary policy, would agree with her.
Warning of the dangers of keeping monetary policy too tight, Ms. Seger said, ''There are a lot of sleepers out there, and any mistakes could put the economy into recession.''
She added that she did not share the anxiety of some economists that an easing of policy might unsettle financial markets.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: PUBLISHING;
Caution Replaces Glamour As the Key Word in Books

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell

 BODY:
MANY book publishers would normally mount eye-catching exhibits of their fall books at the American Booksellers Association's convention. But at this year's gathering, most of the displays were unusually subdued.
Gone were the caged animals, the hot-air balloons and the preoccupation with Hollywood stars. A few celebrities were on hand, but for most publishers it was back to basics. 
The reason for the low-keyed approach, some visitors assumed, was that the convention was being held in Las Vegas, Nev., where any attempt to get attention could only pale alongside the erupting volcanos, storybook castles and tropical rain forests at the city's hotels and casinos.
That may indeed have inhibited some publishers at the event last week, but there seemed to have been something more fundamental at work, something that appears to augur well for book publishing: the understanding that smoke and mirrors, glitz and glitter are no substitutes for quality books.
Most publishers have always known this, of course. But with the rise of the blockbuster book, they either lost sight of it or chose to ignore it. Nowhere was that more apparent than at previous booksellers' conventions, where the promotions and pronouncements of huge first printings were raised to a pitch that Barnum would have envied.
This frenzy by itself was not too bad, because enthusiasm is essential to successful publishing and bookselling. What was bad was that publishers began to believe their own hyperbole and tried to persuade bookstores to believe it as well. So after paying unrealistic advances for many books, publishers leaned on booksellers to double and triple their orders.
When the books were returned, sometimes in the hundreds of thousands, the publishers had to write off not just the unearned authors' royalties but also the cost of producing and warehousing the unsold books.
At last week's convention, however, there were signs of change in the desert air. Despite what is generally regarded as one of the strongest fall book lists in years, few publishers were boasting about the size of their first printings. Instead, they were talking about ''the hand sell,'' industry jargon for selling books individually rather than like soap. And they were talking about writing quality - a departure from the recent past and a welcome recognition that books, after all, are to be read and savored.
While both the new Jean Auel and Sidney Sheldon novels are likely to have first printings of a million or more, other books will start out much more cautiously - even books by best-selling authors.
For example, in one case B. Dalton and Waldenbooks have already ordered more than 100,000 copies of a new book. Orders from the other chain stores and independent booksellers could eventually double that number. But instead of printing 350,000 to 400,000 copies, as many houses would do in similar circumstances, this house - whose executives did not want to be identified -plans to print an initial 250,000 copies to minimize the risk of heavy returns.
''I don't care how many orders we get; I'm not going to be overruled on the initial printing,'' the publisher of that house said. ''If we see a gigantic runaway, I can reprint quickly.''
One thing in the publishers' favor is that reprinting is simpler than in the past. ''Paper is widely available and there are a lot of presses with big capacity,'' said Parker Ladd, a director of the Association of American Publishers. ''It used to take as much as three months to reprint; now it can be done in a few weeks.''
Moreover, computers allow publishers to keep closer track of their book sales. ''If they find they aren't selling in Colorado, for example,'' Mr. Ladd said, ''they can move them down to stores in Florida.''
When publishers have been cautious in previous years, their caution often reflected a sluggish economy. So it would be foolish to predict that the relative absence of glitter at last week's convention represented a permanent condition. But there are reasons to think that the caution may last a bit longer than usual.
For one thing, the book chains are reducing the size of their orders. They will still place big orders for certain titles, but publishers say the chains are reluctant to fill their stores with stacks of the same titles.
''They don't get hurt as much as we do if a book doesn't blow out of the store,'' one publisher said. ''But by cluttering stores with lots of copies of books that didn't move, they have missed sales on books that will sell.''
Finally, the new-found caution reflects corporate realities.
''When publishing houses were privately owned, a big mistake was chalked up to experience,'' said the publisher of a quality house owned by a conglomerate. ''But when you're talking to absentee landlords, and they say, 'How come your revenues were up but profits were down,' they and their accountants don't want to hear about write-offs for unsold books - at least they don't want to hear about it two or three years in a row.''
So, at least for now, caution is the word.
