HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Is Europe A Common TV Market?

BYLINE: By Randall Rothenberg

 BODY:
IF Marcella Rosen is right, the ''Hallmark Hall de Celebrite'' could soon be a fixture on French television - and perhaps, in the appropriate languages, on video screens across Europe.
The worldwide media director of the Ayer advertising agency thinks advertisers will be regularly sponsoring television programs for much or all of Europe by the end of the decade.
In a speech last week to French broadcasting executives and Government regulators, as well as journalists, clients and agency executives, at Ayer's Paris office, Ms. Rosen said the proliferation of broadcast, cable and satellite television franchises in Europe would lead to advertiser-supported programming on pan-European television networks.
By asserting the inevitability of pan-European media, Ms. Rosen has inserted herself squarely in the middle of a continuing debate in the advertising industry. Some executives, like Martin Sorrell, the group chief executive of the WPP Group, have repeatedly said local differences are becoming more important to global marketers. Others, Ms. Rosen among them, believe that in Europe, political and economic integration will bring a significant degree of cultural homogenization as well. 
In her Paris talk, Ayer's media director noted that program preferences differed from country to country in Europe, with the Spanish, for example, preferring operas and novellas, while the British taste runs more to documentaries and mysteries.
But she added, ''as viewers across countries get the opportunity to sample other programming options, the viewing tastes will become more similar.''
As that happens, she said, the use of sponsorships for programs in individual countries, as well as for pan-European programs, will grow.
Under a sponsorship arrangement, a marketer pays for the development of a show and owns all of the national commercials during it. Such support, which has been common in the United States since the inception of network broadcasting, gives advertisers greater flexibility in choosing shows and audiences. It also enables them to use different advertising forms, like the long, cinematic commercials Ayer has created for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
In a telephone interview from Paris, Ms. Rosen pointed out that sponsorship has been all but nonexistent in Europe because in most countries broadcasting was so strictly controlled by national Governments that commercials were restricted to limited blocks of time - if they were allowed at all. Most television channels in Europe have been state-run.
Unable to choose the shows on which they would advertise, marketers could not pick their target audiences.
''People could always target in print, because there were many different magazines for different audiences,'' Ms. Rosen said. ''But they could not target in broadcast, for the most part. Now, with private channels, they will be able to pick programs for specific audiences and to sponsor programs.
Ayer, which has 70 offices in 41 countries, has a stake in promoting pan-European television and program sponsorship. Five months ago, the agency formed WIN Ayer, a venture with a consortium of broadcasting companies to produce and distribute original programming around the world. The project allows Ayer to develop programs on behalf of clients for worldwide broadcast.
Ms. Rosen said some European broadcasters were hesitant about program sponsorship because ''they worried that it implies cultural control.''
''We have had to tell them it doesn't work that way,'' she said. ''In the United States, you sponsor, but you don't have editorial control, because the marketplace won't let it work. All you want is a program good enough to get the audience.''
While a strong believer that European tastes will grow together, Ms. Rosen nevertheless emphasized that nationalism also will rise in importance.
''There is a trend and a countertrend,'' she said. ''You won't be able to use only pan-European media, just as you can't in the U.S. You can use national, but you also have to adjust for local, or add local. It's the same concept in Europe.''

HEADLINE: Loan Reported, Giving Trump Time to Raise Cash

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
Donald J. Trump and the banks that have backed his empire with billions in loans reached a tentative agreement yesterday that would give Mr. Trump an additional $60 million in loans and temporarily suspend some interest payments on other debt, bank officials said.
In exchange, Mr. Trump, who bankers said pressed them to lend him at least $100 million, would pledge some of his assets as collateral and is expected to give up part of his ownership in some of his major properties.
Mr. Trump is also trying to sell a stake of up to 49 percent in one of his real estate or casino assets to ease his cash problems, according to both bankers and a person close to Mr. Trump's negotiators. The developer is also trying to sell most of his smaller, high-profile assets, including planes and helicopters, they said. 
Mr. Trump and the banks, which began negotiations two weeks ago, have not determined which assets will become collateral for the $60 million loan, but people close to the talks said all the developer's properties were being reviewed. Negotiations on details of the deal continued last evening.
The agreement with the banks is intended to give Mr. Trump time to sell some assets and raise cash to pay off some of the billions of dollars of bank debt that his various companies carry.
''The premise in doing this is to give him more breathing room to sell some of his assets and come up with the cash he needs rather than have a fire sale of assets,'' said a banker involved in the negotiation.
By some estimates, his operations carry $2 billion of bank debt, which would produce interest costs of about $17 million a month at the prime rate. In addition, Mr. Trump's various gambling companies have $1 billion in high-yield ''junk bonds'' outstanding with monthly debt costs of about $15 million. Most immediately, he faces a $30 million payment this Friday on an issue of bonds used to finance his Trump's Castle casino in Atlantic City.
The banks were concerned that if Mr. Trump failed to meet this coming interest payment, it could threaten his casino licenses. Mr. Trump owns three Atlantic City casinos, the maximum allowed by New Jersey regulators, and any default on his casino bonds could force him into court and threaten his entire casino business.
 
Industry Downturns
Mr. Trump's real estate and gambling empire has been squeezed by the downturns in both those industries and the developer has been strapped for cash to meet the interest payments on his debt. Recent purchases, like the Trump Shuttle and the Plaza Hotel, have added to the strain on his finances because neither has yet produced a profit sufficient to cover its large debt-service expenses.
In the past, he has always tried to keep sole ownership of many of his main assets, including the Plaza Hotel and the three casinos.
Mr. Trump has also said that he is paying about $20 million in annual interest costs on a 72-acre parcel of vacant land in Manhattan that produces no income.
The security behind existing bank loans varies greatly. Some are secured by specific assets, and have no guarantee from Mr. Trump, while others are personal obligations of the real estate developer but not backed by any specific asset. The new loans will, in effect, be second mortgages on some assets.
 
Banks Led by Citicorp
According to one banker, Citicorp has about $300 million in loans outstanding to Mr. Trump, Bankers Trust has over $100 million and Chase Manhattan and Manufacturers Hanover each have about $100 million.
At least $40 million of the new loan will be provided by Citicorp and Bankers Trust, and $20 million will be provided by the other large banks. In addition to the New York banks, Midlantic Banks Inc. and First Fidelity Bancorp, two New Jersey banking companies, also have substantial loans outstanding to the developer.
Among the assets that Mr. Trump is considering selling are minority stakes in one or more of his main holdings - like the Plaza Hotel, Trump's Castle and the Trump Plaza. He has already announced that the Trump Shuttle, which he purchased last year, and his $30 million yacht are for sale.
''There are people who are out shopping the boat, the plane and the helicopter, amongst other of the smaller assets,'' said an executive familiar with Mr. Trump's business plans. ''There are also talks going on regarding a sale of a piece of the larger assets.''
 
Persuading Smaller Creditors
Bankers involved in yesterday's negotiations said they focused on persuading many of Mr. Trump's smaller creditors to approve the plan. Agreement for the plan must be given by all the creditors because the banks that first lent money against Trump properties must now approve the added collateral for those assets.
In addition to his cash squeeze, Mr. Trump faces several lawsuits, including a class action suit filed last week by Trump's Castle bondholders. The bondholders accused Mr. Trump of fraudulent misrepresentation of the financial condition of the Castle when the bonds were sold in 1985, violating his fiduciary duties, and hurting their investments by illegally transferring the client lists of the Castle to the Taj Mahal, the developer's newest casino.
News of the loan agreement caused the junk bonds linked to the developer's Atlantic City casino companies to rally yesterday. The Trump Castle bonds, which pay interest of 13 3/4 percent annually and mature in 1997, were being offered at about $60.50 per $100 of face value, up $2 from Friday.
The Trump Plaza bonds, which pay 12 7/8 percent, rose about $2, to about $83.50 per $100 of face value. The Trump Taj Mahal 14 percent mortgage bonds that come due in 1998 rose about $3, to about $59.50 per $100 of face value.

HEADLINE: THE SAVINGS DEBACLE: A CASE STUDY - A SPECIAL REPORT:
How One Savings Institution Came Apart

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 11

 BODY:
Carl M. Rheuban founded First Network Savings Bank in 1983, and for six years poured its Government-insured deposits into questionable real estate deals, a solar energy company and even a ''museum of magic'' in the savings and loan institution's headquarters here.
Earlier this year, First Network collapsed into insolvency amid mounting losses and civil and criminal fraud investigations. After the Government seized the failed savings and loan, regulators calculated the cost to the taxpayers of cleaning up the mess to be $100 million, or nearly 25 cents for every dollar deposited there. The $100 million represents the shortfall that the Government must pay, after all of First Network's assets have been sold, to make sure depositors suffer no loss.
Mr. Rheuban, who paid himself $11 million in dividends over six years as the owner of 97 percent of First Network, filed for personal bankruptcy last month, listing few assets and tens of millions of dollars in debts. He has not been accused of a crime, but his role in the institution is under investigation. 
The rise and fall of First Network is a case history of how one institution, like hundreds of others, rushed to take advantage of the savings industry's deregulation during the early 1980's, only to end up contributing to the most costly financial crisis since the Depression.
The First Network example also helps explain why regulators and law enforcement officials often failed to detect possible fraud and mismanagement sooner, allowing the savings crisis to grow undetected. Government officials, lawyers and other experts see a pattern in the First Network case that has become all too familiar as they sift through the wreckage of the industry.
Unlike the failure of many savings institutions in economically troubled states like Texas, the death of First Network was not primarily a result of the collapsing real estate market. Instead, First Network's troubles appeared to have stemmed from overly opti-mistic, overly aggressive or, in the view of regulators, potentially fraudulent real estate deals. The case has been referred by Federal and state regulators to the Justice Department for possible prosecution on fraud charges, and it may be years before the case is resolved, all of the money is traced and the blame can be properly apportioned.
Under Mr. Rheuban, a real estate developer with no previous experience running a savings and loan, First Network shunned home-mortgage lending, the traditional mainstay of the savings industry. Rather than establishing a large and elaborate network of branches to solicit deposits, he advertised high interest rates on deposits to attract funds from all over the country by mail, phone and computer. For most of its existence, First Network never even had a branch or tellers.
 
Small Circle of Friends
Mr. Rheuban invested First Network's federally insured deposits in complicated and risky real estate deals, often in joint ventures with a small circle of real estate developers, lawyers and other associates and friends.
George Hale, a specialist in troubled savings and loans who was brought in by regulators to run First Network, calls Mr. Rheuban ''a very bright person'' whose main expertise was in real estate and partnership law. ''He did a masterful job, if I can use that term, in structuring these deals so they went undetected for a long time during a period when savings and loans were being highly scrutinized,'' Mr. Hale said.
Citing the current criminal fraud investigation, neither Mr. Hale nor the state and Federal regulators would discuss the details of the problems they discovered at First Network. But broadly speaking, these intricate deals allowed First Network to hide some of its risks, by sidestepping Federal rules that limit how much of a savings institution's assets could be invested in real estate, according to court documents and people involved in the investigation. To date, Mr. Rheuban has not been charged with fraud.
Documents filed with a bankruptcy trustee by the Government say the regulators have evidence that First Network engaged in a variety of fraudulent loans and transactions. Among them are what regulators suspect were circular transactions in which First Network may have made or arranged loans to borrowers that were then funneled back to First Network and used to create the appearance that its financial strength was greater than it really was.
The Office of Thrift Supervision, the primary Federal regulatory agency, noted a litany of problems last month as it placed First Network into receivership including ''an excessive amount of delinquent commercial real estate loans'' and ''extensions of credit beyond the institution's legal lending limits.'' In the Beginning A Developer With Charm The demise of First Network is a stunning reversal for the 41-year-old Mr. Rheuban, whom former associates describe as young-looking for his age and charming. Mr. Rheuban declined to be interviewed.
For most the of 1980's, Mr. Rheuban lived well on his sizable income. He lived in a multimillion-dollar house in the affluent suburb of Pacific Palisades.
As his wealth grew, Mr. Rheuban became increasingly prominent in political circles. The recipients of his largesse included Senator Alan Cranston, the California Democract who also had close ties to Charles H. Keating Jr., the owner of the now-insolvent Lincoln Savings and Loan Association.
But Mr. Rheuban's donations, once eagerly sought, have now become a source of embarrassment to California politicians and his personal assets are being auctioned to pay off debts. His Pacific Palisades home, along with the adjacent property, has been put up for sale under bankruptcy court supervision for $12 million. He was recently forced to sell five of his cars and five of his motorcycles, for a total of $50,000, to pay his bills. Mr. Rheuban now spends much of his time with his lawyers, and has told creditors he plans to file suit challenging the Government's actions in seizing and starting to dismantle First Network.
Seven years ago, when he founded First Network, originally called the Deauville Savings and Loan, the savings and loan business seemed a lucrative arena for aggressive entrepreneur like Mr. Rheuban.
The savings and loan industry, once a bastion of simple, conservative home mortgage lending, was transformed during the early 1980's by the sweeping new investment freedoms granted it by Congress and state legislatures. After deregulation, the business became a magnet for a new breed of owners who saw federally insured savings deposits as an irresistible source of funds for investments in office buildings, shopping centers, residential developments, ''junk bonds,'' fast-food chains and virtually every other kind of venture imaginable.
 
No-Lose Propositions
Only half-jokingly, industry executives have taken to describe the business as ''heads I win, tails you lose,'' reflecting the fact that owners could pocket the profits when risky, complex or unorthodox investments paid off - and leave the Government and the taxpayers to pick up most of the tab when those ventures failed, were mismanaged or turned out to be fraudulent.
Mr. Rheuban was exactly the kind of entrepreneur being attracted to the business. A successful developer of mobile home parks and other projects, he was also well known in legal circles as one of the primary authors of California's limited partnership laws, a very useful specialty in the complex world of real estate financing.
At First Network, he put his deal-making skills to frequent use. Mr. Rheuban made commercial real estate loans and set up partnerships that took ownership stakes in office buildings, residential developments and a chain of ''store and lock'' personal storage warehouses. While regulators believe some of the deals through which First Network invested its funds may have been fraudulent, the institution had a large portfolio of loans and investments for real estate that was for the most part of good quality.
''The types of partnership loans and investments they were doing were far from what a traditional savings and loan would be doing,'' said William D. Davis, the deputy commissioner of the California state savings and loan department.
 
''
First Network grew rapidly, reaching $120 million in assets at the end of 1985, $205 million two years later and $517 million by the end of 1988. The strategy appeared to be highly successful. First Network reported substantial profits through its first four years, including reported net earnings of $2.9 million in 1987, one of the best performances in the nation among institutions of its size.
Even Federal regulators, who by then were already coping with an avalanche of failures, considered First Network sufficiently strong and stable at the end of 1988 to arrange for the institution to acquire Tahoe Savings, a small, insolvent savings and loan in Northern California, with more than $30 million in Government aid. In the End Transactions Seem to Unravel First Network certainly appeared to be paying off for Mr. Rheuban, who in 1987 alone voted himself more than $3 million in dividend payments. In addition to his extensive political contributions, Mr. Rheuban served on the boards of various charity organizations and, along with his wife, Deborah, was a regular on the Beverly Hills charity-social scene.
Life was also good for those working at First Network. The institution maintained a fully equipped gym on the premises for the 40 or so employees at the headquarters in the Century City section of Los Angeles, complete with two fitness trainers on the institution's payroll. The walls of the spacious offices were hung with colorful and valuable posters depicting magicians, daredevils and circus performers, reflecting the boss's passion for magic. Mr. Rheuban is an avid amateur magician.
In 1985, Mr. Rheuban spent $850,000 of First Network's money to acquire the world's foremost collection of magic-related books, artifacts and artwork, regulators said. The collection, known as the Mulholland Library of Conjuring and the Allied Arts, was housed at the headquarters. Mr. Rheuban hired Ricky Jay, one of the world's top magicians, to work as curator of the collection on First Network's payroll.
While he built up his magic collection, Mr. Rheuban was also weaving an increasingly intricate web of real estate investment partnerships and joint ventures through which First Network lent and invested much of its money. By the end of 1988, the institution had more than $65 million invested directly in the partnerships, mainly in real estate.
In addition to investing money directly into the partnerships, First Network engaged in highly complex transactions that regulators say allowed the institution to invest more funds in owning real estate than Federal rules permit. For example, people invovled in the investigation said the institution had set up a number of joint ventures, with outside investors acting as general partners and First Network being a limited partner. First Network issued letters of credit to other financial institutions, backed by some of First Network's mortgage-backed securities or other assets. With the letters of credit acting as collateral, the other financial institution would make a loan to the general partners of the joint ventures.
 
Mechanics of a Deal
The general partners would then use the loan proceeds to acquire property, perhaps undeveloped land, and transfer it to the joint ventures. The joint ventures then secured financing for the development of the properties from another set of financial institutions.
The complex transactions did not at first raise any flags with regulators. But last year, as they conducted their annual examinations of the First Network's books, Federal and state regulators found that documentation for many deals was missing or incomplete, and that Mr. Rheuban and other executives were unable or unwilling to answer questions, regulators said.
Together, the state and Federal regulators strongly recommended to Mr. Rheuban that he hire someone to shore up the company's management and resolve the record-keeping problems. The regulators specifically recommended Mr. Hale, a former accountant and real estate consultant who, since 1985, has been working with troubled savings and loans in California.
''We emphasized to Mr. Rheuban that he needed a highly qualified managing officer in there,'' Mr. Davis said. ''We made some strong suggestions to him, and the strongest was George Hale.''
Mr. Rheuban acceded to the request and hired Mr. Hale last fall as president of First Network. Mr. Hale technically reported to Mr. Rheuban, but as a practical matter he was to go in with a strong mandate from the regulators to make an independent assessment of the situation and recommend whatever actions were appropriate. At the time, even Mr. Hale said he believed that all First Network needed was a dose of management discipline.
 
'A Six-Month Turnaround'
''I thought it was going to be a six-month turnaround,'' Mr. Hale said in an interview. ''The shop was considered reasonably clean and well capitalized.''
Within a few months, however, Mr. Hale started discovering transactions and accounting practices that he said did not seem proper to him. Mr. Hale eventually became sufficiently concerned about what he was finding that he hired an outside law firm, Fine, Perzik and Singman, to study some of the transactions.
On Friday, Jan. 19, Mr. Hale received the law firm's report, which Mr. Hale said recommended that criminal referrals be made to regulators. Mr. Hale said he informed Mr. Rheuban of the report's conclusions immediately. Over that weekend, Mr. Hale and Mr. Davis said, Mr. Rheuban acted on his own to dismiss Mr. Hale and the institution's three other board members.
On Monday morning, Jan. 22, Mr. Rheuban, through his lawyer, sent a letter via fax to the California state regulators, suggesting that they move to seize First Network. Regulators are not certain what Mr. Rheuban hoped to accomplish by inviting seizure, but they accommodated him almost immediately. The state savings and loan department took control of the institution that same afternoon, immediately removing Mr. Rheuban as chairman and reinstating Mr. Hale to run the company under government supervision. Federal officials formally took possession of First Network last month. The Aftermath The Accountants Tally the Damage After examining First Network's loans and investments, regulators decided recently added $76 million to the institution's reserves to cover potential losses on loans and investments. The loss provisions, combined with a large operating loss, led to a net loss for the year of $110.9 million, according to preliminary figures compiled for regulators by an outside accounting firm. The auditors recorded a loss on the partnership investments of $21.7 million and a provision for losses on letters of credit, issued by First Network as part of the partnership deals, of $13.4 million.
Regulators and Federal prosecutors are investigating a number of the partnerships, seeking to determine why some of the partnerships do not have title to the property they were purportedly developing among other irregularities. The Government is also trying to force Mr. Rheuban to return $4 million in dividends he paid himself early last year, court documents say.
For now, First Network continues to operate under Government ownership, with all deposits insured up to $100,000, the national ceiling. Officials of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the new Federal agency formed to sell the assets of failed savings institutions, are compiling lists of First Network's office buildings and residential developments, even the solar energy company and an asparagus farm, which will be sold.
The magic collection may prove to be more of a problem. Mr. Rheuban seems certain to claim at least a portion of it as his personal property, and the collection could be tied up in litigation for years. If there is any good news, Mr. Hale says, it is that the magic collection is likely to have been a good investment, worth more now than Mr. Rheuban and First Network paid for it.

TICKER: SBFL (NASDAQ) (93%); 

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%); 

STATE: CALIFORNIA, USA (92%); 

CITY: LOS ANGELES, CA, USA (92%); 

COMPANY: SAVINGS BANK OF FINGER LAKES (93%);

HEADLINE: U.S. AND MEXICANS CAUTIOUSLY BACK FREE-TRADE IDEA

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
The United States and Mexico agreed in principle today to move toward negotiating a ''comprehensive free-trade agreement'' but, in an acknowledgment that substantial economic and political hurdles remained, the two nations stopped short of announcing the start of formal talks.
Officials of both nations said any agreement to dismantle barriers to the free flow of goods, money and labor was likely to face significant opposition in the United States.
Labor, business, political and immigration groups fear a huge influx of Mexican labor and of wages in Mexico that are only a fraction of the American level. With those concerns in mind, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, who is in Washington on a three-day visit, immediately began lobbying here on behalf of the move. 
 
Calls Were Resisted by Mexico
Until this spring, when Mr. Salinas decided that quicker integration of the two economies was the only way to compete with emerging trading blocs in Europe and East Asia, Mexico had resisted a decade of calls by Republican administrations in the United States for a single market ''from the Yukon to the Yucatan.'' Having made the commitment, however, he now finds Washington hesitant about the timing and extent of an agreement.
In a joint statement issued this morning, President Bush and President Salinas said such an accord would be ''a powerful engine for economic development, creating new jobs and opening new markets'' on both sides of the border. But a separate American statement also noted that while ''the announcement endorses the concept'' of a free-trade pact, it ''does not initiate negotiations toward that goal.''
Officials of both countries said that preliminary ''consultations and prepatory work,'' with Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, representing Washington and the Minister of Commerce and Industrial Development, Jaime Serra Puche, representing Mexico City, were likely to continue until Mr. Bush and Mr. Salinas meet again in Mexico in December.
 
No Timetable Offered
The joint statement said the two Governments hoped eventually to eliminate not only tariff barriers but also ''import quotas, licenses and technical barriers'' and would seek ''means to improve and expand the flow of goods, services and investment between the United States and Mexico,'' but offered no timetable for an agreement.
Mr. Salinas said during a meeting with American reporters here that he hoped a free-trade agreement could be concluded in less than three years. Ms. Hills said that this timetable was possible ''if we do a very good job on consultations'' but added that she would ''rather have the vote be unanimous'' in Congress than rush the process and risk rejection. ''We want this to be a success when we embark on it,'' she said.
Trade between the two countries last year amounted to more than $50 billion. Mexico ranks as the third-largest trading partner of the United States and the United States is the largest market for Mexican goods.
 
'Biggest Market in World'
''The Europe of 1992 will be the biggest market in the world,'' Mr. Salinas said. ''But if we can reach a free-trade agreement, North America could be the biggest market in the world.''
Reservations about a free-trade agreement have been expressed by industries in both countries that fear rival companies across the border would have a competitive advantage. But the strongest condemnation of any accord has come from the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, which last month called on Mr. Bush to reject negotiations on the grounds that ''a free-trade agreement will only encourage greater capital outflows from the United States and bring about a further increase in imports from Mexico, further harming the United States industrial base.''
The industries most likely to be affected are textile companies and steel producers.
 
Formal Request Required
Under a 1988 trade law, any country wishing a free-trade agreement with the United States must make a formal request to that effect, which then is submitted to the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee. Those two panels then have 60 legislative days in which to determine whether such an agreement is in the interests of the United States and authorize the President to proceed.
''Now that we have the approval of our Senate to negotiate, I think the real problems in getting an agreement through are going to come on the American side,'' said one Mexican official likely to be involved in the talks. ''We are going to have to deal not just with Congress, but the labor unions and industries that think they are going to be hurt, as well as anti-immigration groups that don't want to open up the flow of labor.''
Aware of the long political battle that lies ahead, Mr. Salinias met this morning with members of the ''border caucus,'' a group of 23 members of the House of Representatives from districts on or near the United States-Mexican border, and later lunched with the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maine, and several other senators. Tonight he also addressed the Business Roundtable, an influential group of corporate leaders, to lay out the Mexican position.
 
Less Immigration Seen
''We want to export goods, not labor,'' Mr. Salinas said earlier to reporters. ''To us, free trade means more job creation and less immigration to the United States.''
Failure to conclude a free-trade agreement would have a negative impact on the Mexican economy, Mr. Salinas argued, and the export of Mexican labor ''will actually increase.'' If the United States were to withhold free-trade benefits from an Asian country, he said, ''they will not swim across the ocean to come to the United States, while Mexicans will merely walk across the border to look for jobs in the United States. Therefore I consider it to the benefit of both countries to increase the flow of goods in order to avoid increasing the flow of manpower.''
Addressing the business group, Mr. Salinas also rejected the argument that his country would benefit from a free-trade agreement at the expense of the American wage-earner. ''The strengthening of the Mexican market would mean additional opportunities for American exporters,'' he said, adding that an increase of $10 billion in American exports to Mexico during the last two years had already ''created thousands of new jobs.''
An adviser to Mr. Salinas said that the preliminary discussions between Mr. Serra and Ms. Hills were likely to focus on ''the reach of the agreement.''
 
Exclusion for Oil
''Obviously,'' he added, ''from our point of view the key question is what types of services and investment should be included, while from the American side the labor factor is the most sensitive matter.'' Mr. Salinas said that ''certainly oil'' would also have to be excluded from the talks.
In theory, a free-trade agreement between the United States and Mexico, combined with a similar accord between the United States and Canada that is already in place, could pave the way for formation of a North American common market. Mr. Salinas, however, made it clear today that he favored a more limited linkage among the three countries.
''We merely want free trade, not a common market'' he said. ''That would mean a common parliament, a common currency and even a common army.''

HEADLINE: Kampala Journal;
The Land Amin Seized Now Preoccupies Uganda

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KAMPALA, Uganda

 BODY:
For sale or repossession: $1 billion worth of commercial buildings, tea and coffee plantations, residences.
Location: war-battered African country, now rebuilding; World Bank favorite. Contact: scandal-ridden Government agency.
On the face of it, the impoverished Ugandan Government, broke because of a sharp drop in coffee prices and the cost of trying to repair its economy, should be able to make a fortune from nearly 7,000 properties seized from Asian owners 18 years ago by Idi Amin. Indeed, the best buildings in the capital, Kampala, stand dilapidated and encrusted in dirt from war and neglect, awaiting either their old owners or new ones. 
But despite urging from the World Bank and the United States, both enthusiastic backers of President Yoweri Museveni, the Government's action to divest itself of the confiscated properties is proving extremely slow.
The properties include virtually all of downtown Kampala, as well as potentially high-grade farms and tea plantations. All told, according to a Washington concern, the Privatization Center, which valued the properties on the basis of potential revenue, the real estate is worth $1 billion. Pride or Prosperity? At stake in the Government's move to turn the property back to private hands, say Western donors and many senior Ugandan officials, is the recovery of this East African country. Without the rehabilitation of this property, these officials say, the engine of the economy will never get started.
Yet for many Ugandans, there is something much deeper at stake: the reappearance of the dominant Asian trading class that ran the economy before the 1972 expulsion.
About 80,000 Asians were expelled by General Amin because of what he called ''economic imperialism.'' Most of them were Indians, and they dominated the trading and economic life of Uganda, causing enormous resentment among the Africans not only because of their wealth but also because they were thought to have taken on the air of superiority.
Since the expulsions, all the property owned by the Asians have been put in the hands of the Departed Asian Property Custodian Board, a Government body with no money to keep up buildings since fallen into disrepair, without water or working sewage systems.
Many have been rented at low rates to political favorites. The Ugandan press has almost daily revelations about corruption at the board. Amid increasing scandal, the head of the board was recently forced out.
 
Attracting Capitalists
Ugandans in decision-making positions say they know that they have two choices. The first is to encourage the Asians to return and bring with them the capital and entrepreneurial skills the country lacks. About 100 Asian families are thought to want to return because they can see the money-making potential.
The second choice for the Ugandans is to continue the current situation of making it extremely difficult, through red tape and bribes, for the Asians to come back. This would mean much slower economic growth but would insure that African Ugandans hold the upper hand, albeit in a tumbledown economy.
Many Ugandans are said to look nervously toward neighboring Kenya, where they know about 70 percent of the economy is dominated by Asian families.
Mr. Museveni's position on the confiscated properties is not clear.
''At first, Museveni was taking the position the all the properties should be distributed among all sectors of society and not to foreigners,'' said a Western official urging speedy divestiture. ''Where he is today, I don't know.''
Asian Ugandans who have come back from Britain, Canada or Australia also detect ambivalence from Mr. Museveni. Mumtaz Kassam, now a British-trained lawyer, was a 16-year-old schoolgirl when her Ugandan passport was torn up by Amin immigration officials in 1972. She has been working for the last few years to reclaim 45 properties that belonged to her parents and uncles.
 
Effect on 'His People'
''I think Museveni is very sincere and has good intentions,'' said Miss Kassam, who met the President at a session of the Uganda Women Lawyers Association. ''But he also has reservations about the Asians, because a lot of his people will be hurt.''
For example, said Miss Kassam, who now practices law in London, the Third Deputy Prime Minister, Abubakar Mayanja, had been given the right to work a dairy farm that belonged to one of her uncles at the time of the expulsion.
About 30,000 of the Asians living in Uganda chose to take Ugandan passports instead of British passports at the time of independence from Britain in 1962, only to be expelled 10 years later. As one of those who chose to be Ugandan, Miss Kassam feels that she and her parents and uncles - also Ugandan passport holders at the time - should be able to regain their properties.
After nine years of trying to complete the task, first started by her uncle, Miss Kassam recently won back the family sock factory. She drove to the industrial area to look over the plant. It had been idle since 1972, but the machines, decrepit and partly broken, remained. An engineer was on his way from India.
''Uganda is currently importing all its socks,'' she said. ''We want to start making them here - starting with the army.'' She would like to remain in Uganda herself.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mumtaz Kassam, now a British-trained lawyer, was a 16-year-old schoolgirl when her Ugandan passport was ripped up during Idi Amin's expulsion of Asians in the 1970's. She has been working for the last several years to reclaim 45 properties in Uganda that belonged to her parents and uncles. She talked with the security guard at her uncle's sock factory in Kampala the day she took possession of it. (Raymond Bonner for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Thailand Defense Minister Quits Just Before Premier Flies to U.S.

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 11

 BODY:
Hours before the Thai Prime Minister left for a long-planned visit to Washington, his Government was thrown into crisis today by the resignation of his Deputy Prime Minister and Defense Minister.
The aide, Chavalit Yongchaiyudh, retired only 10 weeks ago as army Chief of Staff and acting supreme commander, and his decision then to join Chatichai Choonhavan's faltering coalition Government was regarded as a boon for Mr. Chatichai, the first elected Prime Minister in 12 years.
Mr. Chavalit's resignation today, however, prompted concern about a military coup, as the army staged rallies in his support in various parts of the country. The Thai stock market fell 42 points, losing 4 percent of its value. 
Mr. Chavalit, as supreme commander, had sharply accused Thai politicians of being corrupt and called Thai political parties ''trading companies.'' But it is widely assumed that he wants to be the next prime minister, and he needed a leg up in politics. Mr. Chatichai, in what appeared to be a clever move, put Mr. Chavalit in charge of the Counter-Corruption Commission.
 
Chavalit and Wife Accused
But a junior minister in the Government, stung by charges of corruption, made thinly veiled charges that Mr. Chavalit and his wife, Khunying Phankrua, were themselves corrupt, comparing her to ''a moving jewelry box.''
A flamboyant figure, she then called the junior minister, Chalerm Yoobamrung, ''a moron,'' and wondered whether his wife had no love for jewelry. Mr. Chavalit's former colleagues in the military, which retains crucial influence in Thai political and economic life, leaped to his defense with emotional warnings to politicians to hold their tongues and stop insulting the army and its sons.
The Supreme Commander, Gen. Sunthorn Kongsompong, said: ''Human patience is limited. We've been trying to be patient to help maintain the country's peace and order. But if the infringement becomes more serious, then some lessons have to be taught.''
Mr. Chavalit did not show up at a Cabinet meeting this morning, but instead delivered a resignation letter to Mr. Chatichai, in which he said, ''Present conditions do not allow me to carry on serving my country in the spirit I had intended.''
The timing of the letter, just before Mr. Chatichai's weeklong trip to the United States, seemed intended to put pressure on the Prime Minister to dismiss Mr. Chalerm, perhaps even to drop his small party from the coalition.
 
Meeting With the King
Given that Mr. Chavalit represents no political party, his departure does not threaten the governing coalition, unless it results in a coup attempt. Apparently in an effort to forestall that possibility, Mr. Chatichai went this afternoon to the nearby resort of Hua Hin, where King Bhumibol Adulyadej has a summer palace. The King has calmed down the military before.
Mr. Chavalit's successor as army Chief of Staff, Gen. Suchinda Kraprayoon, returned to Bangkok from a trip to Singapore and Brunei and met with Mr. Chavalit and Mr. Chatichai.
According to a deputy Government spokesman, Likhit Hongladarom, ''Suchinda reassured Chatichai he could travel in peace,'' and said Mr. Chavalit is ''a very good soldier'' who would not do anything ''drastic.''

HEADLINE: Election Victor in Peru Plans Drug Appeal to U.S.

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, June 11

 BODY:
Marking a change in Peru's anti-drug policy, President-elect Alberto Fujimori said today that he planned to visit the United States this month to argue for development aid to wean Peruvian coca leaf growers from the illicit crop.
Peru is the world's largest supplier of coca leaf, the raw material for cocaine. The United States, the world's largest consumer of cocaine, has long supported crop eradication programs here. 
''The fight against drug trafficking should not be seen only in its repressive dimension,'' Mr. Fujimori said in an interview. The 51-year-old agricultural engineer advocated foreign aid for crop substitution.
On Sunday, Mr. Fujimori, a political unknown three months ago, defeated Mario Vargas Llosa, the writer, by as much as 20 percentage points, exit interviews with voters indicate. Although no official returns have been made public, Mr. Vargas Llosa has conceded.
Today, Mr. Fujimori, who is to be inaugurated on July 28, his birthday, outlined a centrist blueprint for governing Peru through the first half of the 1990's.
The President-elect, the son of Japanese immigrants, said he had no illusions about the task facing him.
''It's a difficult post, probably the most difficult post in Latin America because the situation we face is almost catastrophic,'' he said. ''In addition to the problems of terrorism, illiteracy, poverty and hunger, you add the natural disasters,'' he said, citing a drought that he said affected 40 percent of agricultural production and an earthquake in the Amazon region of Peru last month that killed 137 people.
Mr. Fujimori will head a nation of 22 million people with only $150 million of reserves in the central bank. Half the country is under military rule because of the Shining Path insurgency, and a yawning gap between Government spending and receipts is causing prices to jump by 1 percent a day.
Coca cultivation, however, contributes an estimated $1 billion a year to the Peruvian economy.
To promote crop substitution, Mr. Fujimori said he would offer growers free market prices for farm products, better roads to take produce to the cities, and schools and health clinics to raise living standards. He proposed that cocaine-consuming countries contribute to a development fund.
After visiting the United States and Canada later this month, he plans to visit Europe.
''Rebuilding roads is nothing for the United States compared to the $120 billion paid for the illegal drug,'' Mr. Fujimori said, estimating the cost of cocaine to American society. American officials here say they have not discovered a crop that can be grown in Peru's remote interior that can compete in price with coca leaves. Almost all the anti-drug efforts here focused on coca bush eradication.
''A repression program is also necessary,'' Mr. Fujimori said today. ''Obviously if you adopt repressive actions, you discourage cultivation.''
He was noncommittal about another unresolved aspect of Peruvian-American relations - a $35 million American military arms and training package intended to help Peru's Government wrest control of the coca-growing areas from the Shining Path. The President-elect said he did not know the details of the plan, but added, ''I don't accept participation in military operations of foreign military forces.''

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
Poll Finds Americans Give Soviets Priority Over the Chinese on Trade

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. KAGAY

 BODY:
The American public approves of the way President Bush is handling foreign policy by nearly 3 to 1, but the public disagrees with the Bush Administration's priorities on trade with China and the Soviet Union, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
Sixty-two percent of the 1,084 adults interviewed last Tuesday through Friday approved of the way Mr. Bush was handling foreign policy, a rise of five percentage points since a Times/CBS News Poll taken in May, just before the President's summit meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union.
 
Soviets Over Chinese
But when asked, ''When it comes to international trade, should the United States give more favorable trade privileges to the Soviet Union, or to China?'' the public split 49 percent for the Soviet Union and 16 percent for China.
This is in disagreement with the priorities of the Bush Administration, which set no conditions on continuing favorable trade status to China but has tied more favorable trade status for the Soviet Union to a liberalization of Soviet emigration policy. 
The latest poll reflected the impact of the summit meeting, which ended two days before interviewing for the poll began.
Mr. Gorbachev reached his highest standing with the American public since the Times/CBS News Poll began measuring this factor in 1987. For the first time a majority of 51 percent said they had a favorable opinion of the Soviet leader, up six percentage points since the pre-summit poll in May. Nine percent held an unfavorable opinion. How Essential Is Gorbachev? At the same time, there was a drop in the proportion of the public seeing Mr. Gorbachev himself as essential to American interests. Fifty-five percent said it was ''very important to the interests of the United States that Mikhail Gorbachev, and not someone else, remains in power in the Soviet Union,'' a drop of five percentage points since the pre-summit poll in May.
The nationwide telephone poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Other findings related to the summit included these:
* 81 percent said the summit meeting had contributed to world peace, including 24 percent saying it contributed ''a lot.''
* 57 percent said the United States and the Soviet Union had gained similar advantage from the summit talks, while 8 percent said the United States had gained more and 23 percent said the Soviet Union had gained more.
* 41 percent said the cold war was over, an increase of seven percentage points from April, but a majority of 52 percent disagreed.
* 26 percent said the summit meeting had been intended mainly to reach agreement on important matters, while 54 percent said the it had been ''intended mainly to help the political interests of President Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev.''
President Bush's rating on his handling of the American economy stood at 43 percent approval, a drop of four percentage points since April and six pecentage points since January.
Mr. Bush's overall approval rating for his handling of his job as President remained unchanged at 69 percent approval, the same level as in May.
 
How the Poll Was Taken
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted last Tuesday through Friday with 1,084 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen to insure that each region was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, telephone numbers were formed by random digits, permitting access to unlisted as well as listed numbers. The numbers were screened to limit calls to residences.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of residential telephone lines and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
BULGARIAN VOTING STUNS OPPOSITION

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SOFIA, Bulgaria, June 11

 BODY:
Stunned by the Bulgarian Socialist Party's decisive victory in Sunday's parliamentary elections, leaders of the main opposition group told a rally today that they would keep up their fight against the former Communists, refusing all offers to form a coalition government.
''We will enter the National Assembly as an opposition that will confront the Communist Party with its crimes, and insist that it take responsibility for everything it has done under its rule,'' vowed Zhelyu Zhelev, head of the Union of Democratic Forces, before a crowd of about 50,000 people who gathered to protest the election results.
Official results on the elections to the 400-seat Grand National Assembly were not complete today. But preliminary results show the Socialists ahead with about 48 percent and the Union of Democratic Forces with 34 percent. 
Many Bulgarians are still absorbing the news that after 45 years of Communist rule, almost one in two voters gave the Communists' successor, the Socialist Party, a mandate to lead the country again.
Although Bulgarian Communists have shed their old name and eased their grip on economic and political life, their victory still set a precedent -it was the first time that a ruling Marxist party has competed in multiparty national elections and won since the collapse of Communist rule began in Eastern Europe last year.
 
Socialist Leader Urges Calm
In a television appearance tonight, Andrei Lukanov, the Socialist Prime Minister and an architect of the party's changes, appealed for calm. He called the election ''the first step toward the creation of a democratic society.''
At a news conference, representatives from several international observer teams declared that the elections had been free and fair, although a separate, unofficial group of monitors, led by Americans, maintained that ''fear is still a factor.''
The opposition accused the Socialist Party of resorting to fraud and intimidation to win the elections, but its leadership stopped short of calls to invalidate the vote. A second round of voting will be held on June 17 in districts where no candidate won more than 50 percent.
Tens of thousands of disappointed opposition supporters paraded peacefully for several hours through the capital tonight, without any interference from the police, who in some cases moved to the sidewalk to let the chanting, flag-waving protesters pass by.
A breakdown by Bulgaria's 28 electoral districts, based on a tally drawn from 1,300 selected precincts, showed the Socialists winning in all but three districts.
 
Ethnic Turks Give a Pledge
Sofia, the capital, was captured by the Union of Democratic Forces, while the Turkish Rights Movement won in Razgrad and Kirdzhali, two regions where ethnic Turks make up a majority. The Turks' leader, Ahmed Dogan, pledged cooperation with the Union of Democratic Forces in the second round.
Projections for the 200 Assembly seats apportioned by proportional representation show the Socialists with 100 seats, compared the the Union's 67 and the Turkish Rights Movement's 17. The Bulgarian Agrarian Party has so far captured only 16.
Results from the 200 single-member districts were still not available.
The Assembly, which will sit for 18 months, has the responsibility of rewriting the Bulgarian Constitution. But the new Government first must tackle the worsening economic situation, in particular a $10.3 billion debt and a severe cutback in factory orders from the Soviet Union.
To deal with these problems, the Socialist Party has said it will seek a broad-based coalition. But the rejection by the Union of Democratic Forces, a group made up of 16 parties and movements, means the Socialists' narrow majority will be put under considerable pressure.
The victory by the former Communists in Bulgaria, the last country in Eastern Europe to hold free elections, was in part a reflection of people's reluctance to embrace change, some people here said.
 
Living Standards Improved
Members of the Socialist Party said the vote was also an indication of the people's loyalty to a Government that since World War II has increased the standard of living and kept the peace, although with an iron hand.
But many people who were out demonstrating in the streets of Sofia said the vote showed the continued hold that local Communist authorities still have on the population, particularly in the countryside.
''People think the Communists are omniscient,'' said Filip Dmitrov, deputy chairman of the Bulgarian Green Party. ''That is how they are intimidated.''
At back-to-back news conferences, two groups of observers differed over the fairness of the Bulgarian elections.
Although repeatedly given second-hand accounts of intimidation, Geoffrey Tordoff, a member of the House of Lords and head of the British team, said he could find no corroboration of a single instance of political pressure.
But a team of 60 observers from 23 countries led by the National Democratic and Republican Institutes in Washington, D.C., reported finding evidence of the legacy of dictatorship -''psychological and sociological'' pressures ''not visible to the naked eye.''
''One could smell it,'' said Tibor Vidos, director of the Alliance of Free Democrats, a major Hungarian party, who came here as an observer. ''People coming from Eastern Europe have a nose, and we can identify how people behave.''
The official United States delegation did not issue a statement in Sofia. A spokesman said it will be delivered first to the White House.
Reports of intimidation by local Communist authorities, who continue to have considerable control over jobs, housing and other necessities, had surfaced before the elections in interviews to opposition figures, journalists and human rights monitors.
Today, speaking to the protesters, Mr. Zhelev said such behavior should have been expected. ''It would have been strange and naive to expect any other way of proceeding on the part of a party that came to power by fraud and violence and kept power for 45 years by fraud and violence,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Apathy and Disaffection on the Rise Among California Voters

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 11

 BODY:
California voters may have made national waves by nominating Dianne Feinstein to run for governor and passing a ballot proposition to raise taxes, but Ethan J. Henderson had nothing to do with it.
To Mr. Henderson, a 22-year-old college student from the San Francisco suburb of Richmond, voting is a waste. ''I look at my parents voting,'' he said. ''The candidates they vote for make promises and promises and promises and nothing ever changes.'' 
California may often set the national pace in politics, but it has also become a national leader in political disengagement. Living far from the seat of power in Washington, Californians seem more than ever to be turning away from government as a means of solving problems.
In the week since the California primary, political analysts have been poring over the election turnout statistics, which were even lower than forecast. Nearly three-quarters of eligible adults did not vote last Tuesday, a new low, despite a hotly contested Democratic primary for governor and several controversial ballot measures.
 
'Totally Useless'
In interviews conducted in Northern and Southern California since the election, nonvoters offered a variety of reasons, from sheer apathy to anger over the government's perceived ineffectiveness. ''I find voting totally useless,'' said William H. Sanhueza, a 38-year-old physical education teacher from the Los Angeles suburb of Highland Park who has not voted since 1980. ''The big wheels are going to manipulate the system anyway.''
Whatever the reasons, the result is a widening gulf between voters and non-voters. White, educated and affluent Californians have long tended to vote at higher rates than others, but this distinction is dividing the state into two political tiers. Even as the state's population grows more diverse and the percentage of minorities rises, political power is becoming more concentrated in the hands of older whites.
Although black, Hispanic and Asian people make up more than 40 percent of the population and more than 30 percent of adult citizens, they typically now make up only 15 percent of voters, said Mervin D. Field, director of the independent California Poll. Likewise, while whites over age 60 represent 21 percent of the adult population, they are nearly 30 percent of voters.
 
'Trend of Disengagement'
Voting participation has been declining in California since a high of 67 percent of adult citizens turned out in 1938 for the general election, even though barriers to registration and absentee voting have been lowered in recent years. The June gubernatorial primary drew 44.8 percent of adult citizens in 1966, 28.5 percent in 1986 and only 26.6 percent last Tuesday, according to still unofficial figures from the secretary of state. ''Unquestionably, there has been a gradual trend of disengagement, disconnectedness, withdrawal on the part of the public,'' Mr. Field said.
Some voices of the disengaged in shopping malls last weekend:
Maria G. Reyes, 18, a student and clothing salesclerk from Pinole: ''I don't know anything about politics. I was going to vote, but then I thought about it and thought I didn't know anything about it. If you don't understand it and you vote, then you're going to mess things up. I don't watch news. I don't read. It's full of problems; it's one more headache.''
Edward J. Laroche, 20, a software salesman in Glendale: ''It's hard to vote for something you don't believe in. They give you certain choices, but what if you don't like any of the choices? I hate to say it, but I felt like my vote didn't really matter. I didn't know much about the candidates or the propositions. But to tell you the truth, I probably wouldn't have voted anyway.''
Danny Marmolejo, 28, a hair stylist from Sherman Oaks: ''I didn't see this as an important election. It's just the primary. I always vote in Presidential elections, and I will vote for governor because those are important elections.''
 
Losing Confidence
Some older people said they used to vote regularly but have lost confidence in the political system. ''I just got fed up,'' said Lee G. Silva, 68, a retired man from San Pablo. ''We passed Proposition 103, and then they're fooling around with it,'' he added, referring to the measure passed in 1988 to roll back car insurance rates, which has stalled in litigation and political wrangling.
And there were immigrants who feel remote from the American political process even though they are citizens, like Yong Wilt, a 35-year-old woman who emigrated from Korea 10 years ago. ''I have an English problem,'' Mrs. Wilt said. ''Whatever they say, I don't understand anyway. Sometimes my husband explains to me.'' She said she turns to religion for political help. ''I pray for things to change,'' she said.
Others resented the seeming uniformity of views among the main candidates. Ms. Feinstein, the former mayor of San Francisco, and her main opponent, Attorney General John K. Van de Kamp, as well as the Republican nominee, Senator Pete Wilson, all favored a woman's right to choose on abortion. ''I would have thought about voting if one had been pro-life,'' said Joyce Davis, a 45-year-old post office counter clerk from Altadena.
And to Wayman G. Henry, a 36-year-old custodian in Richmond, who said he was a cocaine addict for several years, the government has failed to deal with drugs. ''I made it out by the grace of God,'' he said. ''No politicians did anything. It seems like such a big game. They promise you the world and then don't do anything. I just listen now.'' Sign of Contentment? Some politicians and political scientists find nothing alarming about the non-voting trend, asserting that it is a sign of contentment. George Deukmejian, the Republican Governor who chose not to run again, told the Sacramento Bee just before the primary that people are not motivated to vote unless they are suffering economically.
''If the younger voter and the person who's not as interested as other aren't going to the polls, I don't know what else can be done to encourage them to participate,'' he was quoted as saying.
Others disagree. Mr. Field, in a recent speech at the University of California, Los Angeles, said: ''The more that non-voters become different than voters in color, in class, in attitudes toward life, we create and build threatening pressures which could easily explode and alter for the worse the future course of our precious democracy.''

HEADLINE: Let the Wealthy Pay Their Fair Share of Taxes;
Not Just Capital Gains

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''New Taxes Without Fear'' (editorial, May 27) attempts to propagate the myth that inflation affects the taxation of capital gains more than it affects shorter-term income. This is not true and can be seen in the following examples:
The usual argument for indexing capital gains goes like this. If inflation is 5 percent a year and an investment of $10,000 yields a return of 5 percent a year, then there will be no real gain from this investment. After 20 years the investment will be worth $26,532.98. If it is sold at this point, an investor in the 28 percent tax bracket will pay $4,629.23 in taxes and will be left with $21,903.75. This represents a real loss of 17.4 percent. 
The example that is never given shows that inflation hurts income that is taxable yearly even more! If an investment is placed in an interest-bearing account that yields 5 percent a year, and if inflation is also 5 percent, then there will be no real gain from this investment. However, taxes will be collected every year.
The first year's income of $500 will be reduced by the $140 that must be paid in taxes. After one year the investment will be worth $10,360. After 20 years the investment will be worth $20,285.94. This is less than the $21,903.75 that the long-term investor would have and represents a real loss of 23.5 percent due to taxes alone.
Because the investor in the second example must pay her taxes as she goes along, she loses more to inflation than the investor in the first example. If we index income to inflation, we must keep in mind that in addition to capital gains, income that is taxed yearly must be protected. It would be unfair to have indexing only for capital gains, an investment vehicle much more readily available to the richer than the poorer.
 
LEE NEWBERG
 Berkeley, Calif., May 27, 1990

HEADLINE: 'I'm Convinced That Gorbachev Wants A Free-Market Democracy'

BYLINE: By Ronald Reagan; Ronald Reagan, the former President of the United States, plans to visit Berlin, Poland and the Soviet Union in the fall.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Three years ago today I stood in front of the Berlin Wall and urged Mikhail Gorbachev to tear it down. This was not a spur-of-the-moment idea. Rather, it reflected my belief that both my relationship with Mr. Gorbachev and the effects of his policy of glasnost at home had reached a point where I could publicly call for this act of East-West reconciliation.
Although the wall did not come down then, most of the elements for its demise were in place by 1987. Its destruction, beginning last December, has now become a symbol for the tide of democracy that has covered what had been the Soviet bloc. 
Glasnost had let the free speech genie out of the bottle in the Soviet Union; Mr. Gorbachev's call for perestroika, or reform, held the promise of better times for his citizens. Democracy's stirrings were getting stronger in Poland and beginning to be felt in other parts of the Soviet bloc. West Germany's decision in 1983 to deploy cruise missiles and our decision to begin work on the Strategic Defense Initiative had signaled to the Soviet military that the West had not only the resources but also the political will to make any Kremlin effort at military superiority a fruitless one.
Today, the political map of Europe has changed utterly. The two Germanys will soon be unified, first with a common currency, then with an increasingly unified economy and, not far in the future, political unification through an all-Germany election. Little more than half a year has passed since the people of East Germany took to the streets of Berlin, Leipzig and other cities to demand their freedom. At first, the Communist leaders sought to mollify them with minor concessions. But the people wanted real freedom and they went back to the streets again and again until they got it.
Already, the market system is beginning to bring its positive lessons to East Germany. West German companies are providing needed capital and technology to joint ventures in the East. Volunteerism, or efforts by private citizens, is an important factor also in the coming together of the two Germanys.
Democracy and the market system are moving ahead full-speed in Poland where the Government, backed by a popular mandate, is shifting the economy ''cold turkey'' to free enterprise. The Polish people have gone into this with their eyes open, knowing they will have to make initial sacrifices to reap greater rewards down the road.
Hungary and Czechoslovakia are close behind. While Romania's democracy seems more fragile than the rest, there is no question that its people cherish freedom.
Mr. Gorbachev was probably the immediate catalyst for the bursting forth of democracy throughout the former Soviet empire. A realist, he knew that the old ways did not work and that the old-generation of hard-line leaders in the satellite countries needed to be replaced. In allowing this to happen (indeed, encouraging it), he expected to replace the Honneckers and Ceaucescus with Gorbachevites. But, just as glasnost could not be confined to free speech about minor bureaucratic inefficiencies, so the dropping of support for satellite dictators unleashed a process that Mr. Gorbachev could not control.
There is an air of unpredictability about the future of Central and Eastern Europe that makes everyone somewhat uneasy.
This is especially true as we look at recent events in the Soviet Union.
The other day over coffee in San Francisco, I saw Mikhail Gorbachev. He was every bit as warm, earnest and optimistic about his country's future potential as I remembered him from our previous meetings.
Yet, back home he faces an array of problems that would daunt a less vigorous man: a surge of nationalism (and in the case of the Baltic republics, which were incorporated into the Soviet Union against their will, a determination to be independent); a drumbeat of criticism over the lack of consumer goods; complaints about the lack of hard currency with which to make needed purchases of machinery and equipment; and, not least, a challenge to his leadership from Boris Yeltsin.
I am convinced that Mr. Gorbachev is sincerely determined to convert the Soviet Union to a free market democracy. In a country so large and complex, the transition from centralized control will inevitably involve some delays, errors and false starts. We are limited in the things we can do to help this process.
Basically, it must come from Mr. Gorbachev's leadership and the will of his people. We certainly can and should provide encouragement to the Soviet people as they go through it. But we can do more than cheer them on.
Let us assume the cold war is over, although that, in itself, does not mean we can afford to dismantle our defenses. Even though we see ourselves as the victors, we must not humiliate the other side. The Soviets still have raw memories of the millions of lives lost at Nazi hands in World War II. But one thing we and our Western allies must convince them of is that a newly united Germany's membership in NATO is Moscow's best bet for a Europe that is both stable and secure.
There are many products and much know-how the Soviet Union would like from us. We should use the American impulse for generosity with some caution.
The concept of ''linkage'' can play a role here. For example, we might provide the Soviet Union with some things they want from us in exchange for their agreement to stop propping up their few remaining dictator clients. In due course, forces for democracy will do the rest in those countries.
Like the chips of the Berlin Wall that are being sold everywhere these days, democracy seems to be sweeping the world. When we look closely, however, we see that its work is far from done.
