HEADLINE: New York Port Loses Top Spot To Los Angeles

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
New York has been eclipsed by Los Angeles as the nation's pre-eminent port, the result of surging trade with the Far East and changing shipping trends in this country.
The growth of maritime trade along the West Coast, which has been building since the 1970's, has been so strong that last year four of the nation's top five ports in dollar volume were on the Pacific.
New York still ranked second in the value of cargo it handled. But in the 1980's it has grown far more slowly than a half dozen other ports on both coasts. Some experts are worried that more and more of the nation's cargo will bypass New York's docks and terminals, costing the region an opportunity for economic growth. 
 
Port Not Keeping Pace
Still, despite a common belief that business in New York's port has been dropping, the port handled $49 billion in goods in 1989, $1.5 billion more than in 1988. But that was $6 billion less than Los Angeles and only $7 billion more than Long Beach, Calif.
In 1988 New York handled more than $2 billion worth of cargo more than Los Angeles. And in 1981 New York handled $11 billion more than Los Angeles and Long Beach combined.
''Our tonnage has remained relatively stable,'' said Anthony J. Tozzoli, president of the New York Shipping Association, the trade group that negotiates and administers labor contracts with dockworkers. ''However, you've had a global growth in cargo, and we have not shared in that growth.''
Economists and shipping executives say the New York port, which stretches from Brooklyn to Staten Island to Elizabeth and Newark, missed out on much of the Asian trade because of commercial, as well as geographic, reasons.
Many businesses around the nation have tightened inventories, and this has made faster delivery of goods - called ''just in time'' service - critical in determining how cargo is shipped. It is now common for cars, computers, television sets and other consumer goods to be shipped from Asia to West Coast ports, then loaded onto trains, sometimes in double stacks of aluminum containers, and sent to cities across the country, even in the East.
Many companies find this method of shipping, sometimes known as ''landbridge,'' cheaper, quicker and more dependable, and much cargo that would have moved in ships through the Panana Canal to eastern ports is now being sent across the country on trains instead.
As it competes for more of the world's cargo, New York is hindered by higher handling fees and, especially on the New York City side of the port, by traffic that delays trucks heading to and from the waterfront.
''The hassle factor in the New York metropolitan area is more intensive than in other ports in less populated areas,'' said Peter R. Moe, vice president of marketing and logistics for Sea-Land Service Inc., a large container-ship line.
 
Rise of Air Shipping
In a telling indication of the changes in the shipping industry and the regional economy, the value of international cargo moving in and out of the region by air exceeded that shipped through the waterfront by $7.5 billion in 1988 and $11 billion in 1989.
New York is still a vast market for goods, and imports have long dominated shipping activity here. Imports of general cargo, the more valuable goods, rose from 6.98 millon long tons in 1980 to 9.29 million long tons in 1989. (A long ton equals 2,240 pounds.) But as manufacturing declined -New York City alone lost 150,000 factory jobs in the last decade - exports have been hurt. They dropped from 4.25 million long tons in 1980 to 3.96 million in 1989.
In what some regard as an unfortunate commentary, the port's leading export is waste paper; 1.19 million long tons were shipped from New York in 1989, four times more than plastic materials, the runner-up. The paper goes out in containers that, because of the trade imbalance, might otherwise be empty.
 
'Sleepy Ports' Awaken
Such statistics, along with the markedly higher growth rates of other ports - not only Los Angeles and Long Beach, but also such smaller East Coast rivals as Boston, Baltimore and Norfolk - suggest that New York is shifting from a port that once served much of the nation's needs to one increasingly focused on its own.
''In earlier decades, if you wanted to ship foreign, New York was the name that came to mind, particularly on the East Coast,'' said Rexford B. Sherman, director of research at the American Association of Port Authorities in Alexandria, Va. ''Now, if you're in the South, it goes through Charleston or Savanah. The sleepy little southern ports aren't so sleepy anymore.''
Although the number of New York dockworkers has shrunk to 4,200 from more than 30,000 in the 1950's, a result of the rise of container ships, the port's impact ripples through the region. Maritime trade generates $14 billion in economic activity annually, according to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, and it affects such major regional industries as wholesale trade, transportation and banking.
''The whole distribution system of the Northeast is hinged around the Port of New York,'' said Mitchell L. Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University, who has studied the region's economy and its waterfront. ''We cannot afford to be a declining port.''
 
Containers Bring Change
New York was in the shipping forefront in the 1960's, when the use of containers ushered in what might have been the biggest change in the industry since sails gave way to steam engines. Hemp slings are gone now. Huge cranes hoist the 40-foot aluminum boxes off the ships.
New terminals were built on Staten Island and in New Jersey, and the finger piers that ring Manhattan were variously reincarnated as bus depots, Sanitation Department garages, parking lots and places for sunbathing. One of the relatively few Manattan piers still used for a maritime purpose, besides those that handle cruise ships, is home to a prison barge.
In exchange for allowing the port to automate, the International Longshoremen's Association won a guarantee of an annual income - now $34,200 - for its members, no matter how many days they work. The shipping industry says this provision, along with the rising cost of medical and other benefits, has pushed up the assessments charged on cargo in New York.
The labor agreement negotiated last year included an early-retirement program that further reduced the size of the work force, although the shipping association says there are still about 400 more dockworkers than are needed. Still, the organization cut assessments by $1, to $4.85 a ton, plus $65 for each container. If cargo originates from or is destined for points 260 miles or more inland, the assessment drops to $1.85 a ton, with no container charge. The Port Authority also has an incentive program.
 
Cheaper Labor in West
It is difficult to compare costs with those in other ports, because they are often calculated differently. But the consensus is that New York is a more expensive place to do business, sometimes significantly so.
Robert D. Dockendorff, director of research for the Pacific Maritime Association, said the cost of dockworker benefits on the West Coast was ''much, much, much cheaper,'' because the increase in cargo there had offset the labor-saving impact of automation.
Although the growth of shipping has been striking along the West Coast, especially at Los Angeles and Long Beach, Mr. Dockendorff played down the economic impact regionally, saying that much of the cargo was simply unloaded there from ships and then loaded onto trains for other parts of the country.
The surge of shipping has also had its price. ''Damage to bridges, highways - that's a problem,'' Mr. Dockendorff said of the increased truck traffic. ''On the other hand, more of the ports on the West Coast are starting to locate rail facilities right on the docks.''
 
Hopes for Expansion
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey plans to spend several hundred million dollars during the 1990's modernizing and upgrading its terminals, too.
The agency has its eye, of course, on increasing trade with the European Community. It also hopes to attract more ships westward from Southeast Asia through the Suez Canal, and perhaps increase business with Latin America.
''We will try to be better prepared, if we should be so fortunate to experience'' an increase in trade, said Kate J. Ascher, an assistant director of the authority's Port Department.
Professor Moss credits Stephen Berger, who last week said he would be leaving as the Port Authority's executive director after five years, with bringing in new managers, but adds, ''He's competing against global economic forces.''
''We did not recognize how much cargo could come in from the West Coast by rail,'' Professor Moss continued. ''We lost our national distribution pre-eminence. Unless we do something to get the cargo that comes in from Europe, it will bypass New York.''

HEADLINE: Jobless Rate in Connecticut, At 5.6%, Tops U.S. Average

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, June 11

 BODY:
Connecticut's unemployment rate rose to 5.6 percent in April, from 5 percent in March, exceeding the national average for the first time since May 1977.
A year ago Connecticut had one of the lowest unemployment rates in the nation, at 3.3 percent. The national seasonally adjusted jobless rate was 5.4 percent in April. 
Economists said the new figure confirmed a sharp slowdown in the state's once-booming economy. But several said the greater significance was in the pattern of joblessness rather than the number of jobless workers.
The number of people employed in construction, one of the most depressed areas, rose by 6.8 percent, to 69,500 jobs from 65,100 in March. That increase was countered by declines in manufacturing, which employed 800 fewer workers, and by growth that was slower than expected across a spectrum of businesses.
 
'This Is Not Texas'
''The ultimate good news is that Connecticut's economy is not so dependent on any one sector - this is not Texas,'' said Richard H. Mattoon, an economist for the Connecticut Business and Industry Association. ''The bad news is that it's a broad-based decline.''
Figures from the State Labor Department show that the total number of people employed in non-agricultural jobs rose slightly, to 1.671 million from 1.668 million in March and 1.669 million in April 1989.
The number of people listed as actively seeking work also declined, to 91,600 in April from 93,000 in March.
The higher jobless rate, the experts said, arose because the traditional spring increase in the number of jobs did not materialize with anywhere near the usual vigor.
 
Possibility of Revision
''One month does not a recession make,'' a professor of economics at Fairfield University, Edward J. Deak, said. ''But this is certainly different from what the state was experiencing in 1987 and 1988.''
Deputy Labor Commissioner Lawrence S. Fox said preliminary figures for last month showed a decline in the number of people receiving unemployment benefits. He speculated that the jump in April might have been a ''fluky'' result that could be revised as additional information arrives.
New York had a 4.9 percent unemployment rate in April and 5.1 percent last month. The New Jersey rate in April was 4.9 percent, falling to 4.8 in May.

HEADLINE: Daily News Announces More Cutbacks in Jobs

BYLINE: By DAVID E. PITT

 BODY:
With labor tensions rising, The Daily News announced yesterday that it was laying off almost a quarter of its 57 electricians.
It was the third wave of job cuts at the financially ailing paper in three weeks, and a management spokesman, John Sloan, said layoffs of other unionized workers were under study.
''We are looking at our production and distribution departments, where we have been mandatorily overstaffed for years,'' Mr. Sloan said. 
The laid-off electricians, all members of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, do maintenance work in company buildings in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Kearny, N.J., with an average pay of $21.25 an hour, he said.
Mr. Sloan attributed the layoffs of 14 electricians to the need for savings amid ''New York's continuing poor economic conditions.''
 
'An Enviable Heritage'
''This newspaper is a world-class franchise with an enviable heritage, and its management has the responsibility to return it to the best possible financial condition,'' Mr. Sloan said.
But union officials characterized the cuts, which are permitted under the terms of contracts that expired March 30, as part of a continuing management campaign to provoke a strike by one or more of the tabloid's 10 unions.
Beginning late last month, the paper eliminated 21 of its 75 photoengravers, who help make printing plates, and 17 of its 49 machinists, who keep the presses in working order.
The News, vowing to eliminate what it has characterized as financially ruinous overstaffing, featherbedding and labor abuses, has been engaged in increasingly fractious contract talks with its unions since late January.
On Friday, Don Singleton, a negotiator for the Newspaper Guild, representing 750 advertising and newsroom employees at The News, walked out of a session after denouncing management for ''foot dragging.''
 
Contrast in Strategies
Labor leaders have accused The News and its parent company, the Tribune Company of Chicago, of seeking to provoke a strike in an effort to break the unions as part of a plan either to close the paper or to make it more attractive to a buyer.
In recent months, leaders of the paper's 2,414 unionized workers have sought to convince the rank and file that the best strategy is to avoid a strike in the hope of winning eventual legal judgments against the paper for unfair labor practices.
Mr. Sloan, saying eliminating the 14 electricians' jobs would save The News $570,000 a year in wages, said those laid off would receive up to six weeks of severance pay and three-month extensions of their medical insurance.
Union officials have charged that the savings are minimal when compared to what they assert is the $4 million a month that the paper is spending on strike preparations.
The company, which has said it will continue publishing in the event of a strike, has declined to say how much it is spending. But it has accepted job applications from more than 13,000 people willing to work as replacement workers, hired a Nashville law firm to conduct negotiations, trained hundreds of management employees to operate presses, and established an alternative newsroom in North Bergen, N.J.

HEADLINE: Boeing Gets Big Order For 747's

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
The Boeing Company, which has seen soaring demand from the world's airlines for its planes, announced today that Korean Air Lines had agreed to buy 23 of the aircraft maker's long-range 747-400 wide-body jets in a deal worth nearly $5 billion.
The order is the third for Boeing in recent weeks from Asian carriers. It recently announced sales to China's Civil Aviation Administration and to Japan Air Lines totaling more than $5 billion.
Boeing said the Korean airline had placed 12 firm orders for the planes and reconfirmed options for 11 more aircraft. It said a reconfirmation, though it could be canceled, was considered a firmer commitment than an option. 
 
Shares Jump in Heavy Trading
The planes are expected to cost $200 million each. The airline had previously ordered nine 747-400's.
Boeing's shares jumped $3 today, to $58.50, on the New York Stock Exchange, where it was the most active issue, with more than 1.8 million shares traded. The Seattle-based company announced a 3-for-2 stock split over the weekend.
Industry analysts said orders from Asian airlines for Boeing planes were likely to grow as the 747 continued to dominate long-haul routes out of Asia.
The four-engine, 393-seat Boeing plane has a range of more than 8,000 miles, enabling it to link Seoul with London or New York nonstop.
Spurred by rapid economic growth throughout the region, Pacific Rim air traffic is outpacing world growth, and Boeing's 747-400 will be the long-distance plane of choice throughout this decade, analysts said.
''The Boeing 747-400 is the biggest, fastest airliner flying, and it has the longest range,'' said Thomas Lloyd-Butler, a Montgomery Securities analyst.
He said its capacity and range made it ideal for handling nonstop intercontinental flights needed by the booming Pacific Rim economy. ''That market's going to keep expanding,'' he said.
''It's a very hot market right now, with a 15 to 20 percent annual growth rate,'' said Paul Nisbet, a Prudential-Bache analyst. ''It should average 9 to 10 percent throughout the rest of the decade.''
 
Airbus Not Considered
Other analysts said they expected new aircraft orders from other Asian carriers, including All Nippon Airways, Cathay Pacific and Korea's Asiana.
Korean Air Lines' senior executive vice president, Y. H. Cho, said the purchase would bring to 48 the number of 747's the carrier had committed itself to buy since its first purchase in 1970.
''The advanced technology built into this new airliner makes it ideal for the Pacific routes over which we operate,'' Mr. Cho said, adding that there was no question of buying Airbus Industrie planes because the European consortium does not make any similar long-range planes.
Boeing's chairman, Frank Shrontz, said the first delivery of the planes would be in 1994, reflecting Boeing's production backlog. But he said the company was slowly increasing its production capacity on all models.
Boeing said at its annual stockholders meeting on April 30 that its commercial airline backlog was worth $77.5 billion.
 
No Decision on Engine
Mr. Shrontz, noting that 1989 was a record year for the plane maker, said this year would not be as good. But he added, ''I didn't think we could keep up that rate.''
Korean Air Lines officials said that no decision had been made on which engines would power the planes but that talks were being held with United Technologies' Pratt & Whitney unit, the General Electric Company and Rolls-Royce Aeroengines. Pratt & Whitney engines power other Korean Air Lines Boeing 747's.
The new deal was announced at the end of a two-week visit to the United States by a delegation of South Korean businessmen to buy American goods as a way to help reduce Korea's trade surplus with America. Last year, Korea had a $6.3 billion trade surplus with the United States.

HEADLINE: Dow Rallies in 30.19 Rise On Light Day

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
Led by Boeing and I.B.M., stock prices rebounded sharply yesterday in light trading, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining 30.19 points - recovering much of the ground it gave up last week.
Traders said the faltering rally revived as bargain hunters sought blue chips, which had fallen off last week in four straight days of selling. Technology, oil and retailing issues were also stronger.
The Dow, which lost 38.59 points last week, finished the day at 2,892.57. Advancing issues totaled 918 as 563 declined. 
 
Broader Index Gains
The broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks also rose, by 2.92, to 361.63.
Only 119.6 million shares changed hands yesterday, the lightest volume since April 19, and down from 142.6 million on Friday.
Program buying driven by computers buoyed yesterday's recovery. Birinyi Associates, a Wall Street research firm, recorded five buying programs, during which the market rose by 19.3 points, and a selling program that accounted for a 3.71-point drop.
The Seattle-based Boeing, which split, 3 for 2, effective with yesterday's trading, led the most-active list, rising by 3, to 58 1/2, on a volume of 2.3 million shares. Investors reacted favorably to news of a large order of its 747-400 jumbo jets from Korean Air Lines. The carrier plans to buy 23 747-400's worth nearly $5 billion. Two other Asian carriers have ordered the jets, and the trend of orders from the Pacific Rim is expected to continue, the analysts said.
I.B.M., which has been a sporadic market leader, finished up by 1 1/8, at 119 7/8. It was the fifth-most-active issue on the Big Board, with more than a million shares changing hands.
Many other technology issues were strong. Compaq rose by 1 1/8, to 120 1/4, and Texas Instruments gained 1, to 40 3/8. In over-the-counter trading, Microsoft rose by 1 3/8, to 74 7/8; Sun Microsystems by 1, to 31 5/8, and Intel also by 1, to 47 1/2.
 
Occidental Up to $27
Among oil issues, ARCO was strong, rising by 2, to 116 7/8. Occidental Petroleum, the Big Board's second-most-active stock, rose by 3/8, to 27, on a volume of 1.5 million shares. Chevron added 1 1/8, to 70 5/8, while Exxon picked up 7/8, to 47 7/8.
Other strong blue chips were Procter & Gamble, which rose by 1, to 81, General Motors, which was up by 5/8, to 49 1/8, and Merck, which gained 3/4, to 80 3/4.
''Obviously, this market doesn't want to go down,'' said Monte Gordon, the research director for the Dreyfus Corporation. ''With a cascade of economic news coming out at the end of the week, you would think the market would be stately, concerned and relatively careful.''
Among the reports scheduled to be released this week are the Producer Price Index on Thursday and the Consumer Price Index and data on industrial production, both on Friday.
Many money managers still have cash they can commit to the market, Mr. Gordon said, and that has cushioned the decline. ''This really has been a shallow, short-lived, well-constrained correction,'' he said.
But any surprises in the economic statistics, he added, could rock the market's recent optimism.
Retail stocks, which fell because of weak sales last month, showed some strength. The Gap, hit hard lately, recovered 1 7/8 to close at 58. Some of the analysts said that despite the company's May performance, it had a bright outlook.
A stock that did not benefit from the rally in technology issues was Microcom, a maker of data-communications equipment based in Norwood, Mass., which fell by 8 1/2 on the Nasdaq, to 9 3/4. The stock was the second-most-active issue there, with more than 1.7 million shares changing hands, and its 46.6 percent drop made it the Nasdaq's largest in percentage terms.
Microcom said on Friday that it expected a loss for its first fiscal quarter ending on June 30. The analysts also slashed the company's earnings estimates for the fiscal year.
In other gauges, the American Stock Exchange's market-value index gained 1.15, to 362.32, while the Nasdaq composite index rose by 1.92, to 462.79.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Soviet TV To Get U.S. Money Show

BYLINE: By JEREMY GERARD

 BODY:
During an installment of the television show ''Adam Smith's Money World'' last November, Donald M. Kendall, the president of Pepsico, speculated that perestroika and glasnost would translate into great opportunities for American business. He advised the business community to take advantage of those opportunities before Japan and Western Europe also got into the act.
One person well aware of the tremendous changes taking place and already acting on them was the show's host, whose real name is George J. W. Goodman. When ''Adam Smith's Money World'' begins its seventh season on public television in the fall, the weekly program focusing on connections between business and the larger world will also be shown in prime time on Soviet television. 
''Money World,'' which will be dubbed in Russian, will be the first American business program broadcast on Soviet television, where American shows of any sort are a rarity.
Mr. Goodman and his Soviet colleagues conceded yesterday that much of the information presented on ''Adam Smith's Money World'' would be beyond the comprehension of the typical Soviet viewer, who is generally unschooled in the ways of Western finance. But you have to start somewhere, they said. The show typically deals with one topic, like the savings and loan crisis or inflation, and looks at the larger impact of those situations.
''We anticipate that the vast majority of the population may have a very difficult time with much of the vocabulary and concepts,'' said Marek L. Bezzubov, the president of Soventure Group Inc., the American half of a joint venture that acquired the broadcast rights from the American producers for Co Star, a Soviet joint venture company that produces and distributes films.
''It is literally a must for them to start getting acquainted with the business world, and eagerness usually translates into trying to understand,'' he said.
The half-hour show will be presented on the Soviet Central Television Network sometime between 7 P.M. and 9 P.M., Mr. Bezzubov said. Its competition in that time slot may include news programs, cartoons, sports events and blocks of commercials. In type of programing, it will compete with ''600 Seconds,'' a late-night news magazine that sounds suspiciously like one-sixth of a popular American counterpart.
Soviet Central TV operates two television channels in Moscow. Two others, presenting similar programing, are Leningrad Program and Moscow Program. There is also a fifth, an instructional channel.
 
Talks Began Last Year
Mr. Goodman said talks with Co Star began last year when he was planning an hourlong special on perestroika and glasnost for the Public Broadcasting System. Because of preliminary work on the special, he said, ''Money World'' was familiar to executives at Soviet Central TV.
Under the agreement, Co Star will get the broadcast rights to 52 weekly installments of ''Adam Smith's Money World,'' which is produced by Alvin H. Perlmutter Inc. and WNET, the public television station in New York. Co Star will also sell 90 seconds of advertising to American companies doing business in the Soviet Union, like the General Motors corporation and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
In return, the American producers will get technical support for the PBS special on perestroika and glasnost, as well as for segments of the weekly program. No money is being exchanged in the deal between Co Star and ''Money World,'' Mr. Bezzubov said.
 
'A Fabulous Turn of Events'
''It's just a fabulous turn of events.'' Mr. Goodman said yesterday in an interview at his midtown office, ''Adam Smith has come to theland of Karl Marx. I think there's enormous confusion because the signals aren't clear there as they go to a market economy.''
''Money World'' is underwritten by Metropolitan Life Insurance and Unisys, he said, but he hopes that ''some alert, forward-thinking foundation would put up the money so that we can do a prologue for each show about why we're doing it, a primer to let Russian audiences watch and then tell us what they think of it.''
Mr. Goodman said that the program's title presented some problems in the translation. ''We changed the word 'money' to 'finance,' '' he said, ''because they said 'money' had a dark financial tone.'' But given the changes taking place in the Soviet economy, Mr. Goodman added, that is likely to change as well.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 14, 1990, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Tuesday about the coming introduction of ''Adam Smith's Money World'' on Soviet television misidentified the organization for which the program is preparing an hourlong special on perestroika and glasnost. It is the Public Broadcasting Service.

HEADLINE: Lower Cigarette Sales Linked to Tax Rise

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
A new study suggests that raising taxes on cigarettes helps to reduce smoking, lending momentum to a movement in Congress to raise Federal levies on tobacco as a way to curb use and to ease the Federal deficit.
Researchers for the National Bureau of Economic Research, a private research group, studied cigarette taxes and their effect on sales between 1955 and 1985. They concluded that although smokers behaved as though they were addicted, their smoking could be reduced with higher prices.
Michael Grossman, an economics professor at the City University of New York and one of three authors of the paper, said ''there were studies that even heroin addiction was not unresponsive to price.'' He cited a 1977 paper in The Journal of Urban Economics that found that a 50 percent rise in heroin prices resulted in a 13 percent decline in consumption. 
In the case of cigarettes, whose addictive qualities have been strongly debated by scientists, Mr. Grossman and his colleagues, Gary S. Becker and Kevin M. Murphy, both economists at the University of Chicago, said they found a similar phenomenon when they studied the imposition of excise taxes in all 50 states. They adjusted the data for such factors as income and demographic trends.
The researchers said that after a permanent 10 percent rise in cigarette prices, adjusted for inflation, consumption was reduced 4 percent in the first year and 7.5 percent spread over five years. Temporary price rises for only one year were found to reduce consumption less, they said.
They also tested for the impact of ''stressful events'' like divorce and unemployment, on tobacco use and for whether a person's religion had any effect.
Rising unemployment did not seem to increase smoking, they found, but smokers' level of tobacco use did seem to rise with divorce. As for religion, states with many Mormons, who have a prohibition against smoking, showed less tobacco use; states with many Roman Catholics showed more, but the researchers did not explain the connection. $18 Billion Gain Seen In 1989, retail sales of cigarettes totaled more than $39 billion, according to the Tobacco Institute, a trade group. Of that total, $4.3 billion represented Federal excise taxes, $5.1 billion state taxes, and $200 million municipal taxes.
Texas has the highest state excise tax, at 41 cents a pack; North Carolina, a big tobacco-industry state, has the lowest at 2 cents a pack, according to the institute.
Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, and other Congressmen have advocated doubling Federal excise taxes to 32 cents a pack. The Congressional Budget Office has estimated that would add $18 billion to Federal revenue over the next five years.
Currently, the average retail price of cigarettes in the United States exceeds $1.60 a pack.
Walker Merryman, a spokesman for the Tobacco Institute, disputed the National Bureau of Research paper's characterization of smoking as addictive. He cited Federal statistics that more than 40 million people have quit smoking, 95 percent of whom have done so without help. ''These figures and common sense contradict any claim that cigarette smoking is addictive,'' he said.
John R. Nelson, a spokesman for Philip Morris USA, the domestic unit of the world's largest tobacco company, said that doubling the excise tax was regressive. ''Sure, higher taxes will reduce some consumption,'' he said, ''but it's more likely to just mean that more poor people will pay more taxes.''
The National Bureau of Research study does not cover the period after 1985 when the tobacco industry, partly in response to high excise taxes, introduced discount cigarettes on a wide scale. Many customers of such brands are the poor and working class.
 
Growth in Discount Brands
These so-called price value cigarettes had a 14.8 percent market share in 1989, up from 11.1 percent the year earlier, according to John C. Maxwell, Jr., a tobacco analyst with Wheat First Securities in Richmond.

HEADLINE: Talking Business; with Breeden of the S.E.C.;
Risks of Market Fragmentation

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
Richard C. Breeden, the 40-year-old head of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has a knack for making waves. In his short tenure, the Bush Administration appointee has taken a hard line toward people suspected of violating securities laws, has made overtures toward helping Eastern Europe develop stock exchanges and has made it clear he wants to eliminate creaky regulations that may inhibit United States companies in global competition.
One of his most controversial moves has been an effort to regulate some of the financial futures now under the jurisdiction of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. And he is strongly backing a measure introduced by Representative Edward J. Markey, a Massachusetts Democrat, that would empower the S.E.C. to suspend some program trading and close the exchanges in an emergency. Mr. Breeden was in New York recently and discussed several issues. 
Q. Where do things stand legislatively on regulations for Wall Street?
A. The most important is the Administration's new legislation, which has three objectives. The measure would put the S.E.C. in charge of overseeing margins on stock index futures, would eliminate the ''exclusivity clause'' that has inhibited Wall Street's ability to develop new hybrid products, and would transfer the jurisdiction for regulating stock index futures from the commodity commission to the S.E.C. This is a significant step in dealing with instability in the current system.
Q. Is passage assured?
A. There's a vigorous campaign under way by the futures industry to block it. But the odds are very high that this step will be taken. The United States is the only nation that maintains this market fragmentation - and the risk and costs it entails. I don't think we're willing to see leadership in both the futures and securities markets move overseas.
Q. The Chicago markets see the bill as an effort by the traditional New York markets to assert their dominion. How do you respond?
A. That's absolutely groundless. The Secretary of the Treasury, the chairman of the Federal Reserve and the chairman of the S.E.C. are urging reform. We've all watched severe risk in the stock and futures markets not once, but twice, in 1987 and 1989. Last Oct. 13, 50 million Americans lost $160 billion of value in their pension and retirement accounts in 90 minutes. The element that introduced the greatest amount of risk was that we went into that day, just as we did in 1987, with 97.8 percent leverage in the stock index futures market. And then, in the midst of the crisis, those exchanges were trying to dramatically raise margins, which sucked out liquidity and created further selling pressure.
Q. Had you been the S.E.C. chairman in October 1987, what would you have done?
A. We wouldn't have entered that day with margins of 2.2 percent on stock index futures. If you had a minimum margin of 15 percent, you then would have the flexibility to cut margins to 10 percent when the market was under stress to inject liquidity. Under the Markey bill, the futures exchanges would have the authority to recommend margins. But if they proposed going from 14 percent to 2.2 percent, we would have the authority to say ''that's too low.'' We'd expect to see margins set in line with those in the options market.
Q. Isn't computer index arbitrage almost always destablizing to markets?
A. I would not make a blanket statement. Index arbitrage is a symptom of an underlying problem and that problem is the vast differences in leverage rules that apply to the same products. If you have $100,000 you can buy $200,000 worth of S.&P. 500 stocks or $4.4 million worth of them through the index futures market, and the index futures market will react more forcefully to economic stimuli.
Q. What sort of sentence should Michael Milken get?
A. A substantial period of incarceration would be appropriate.
Q. Should we have a clearer definition of insider trading.
A. The basic prohibition against insider trading as elaborated by the Supreme Court and other courts is reasonably clear and probably more clear than if we had a long, tortuous statutory definition.
Q. Will the savings and loan crisis lead to securities fraud prosecutions?
A. It may. It is a matter of public record that several institutions that were customers of Mr. Milken have failed and involved losses to the taxpayers of several billion dollars.

HEADLINE: U.S. Exporters Wary Of Technology Accord

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Despite a lengthy briefing yesterday at the Commerce Department, representatives of American exporters of manufactured goods remain reluctant to assess the potential effect of last Thursday's agreement between the United States and other large industrial nations to relax cold war trade restrictions.
They want to see the final regulations for the agreement, which are due to be published on July 1. ''The devil is in the details when it comes to export administration,'' said Howard Lewis 3d, who oversees international affairs for the National Association of Manufacturers, the Washington-based industry group.
 
Soviets to Get Access
The agreement, reached at a meeting in Paris of the 17 nations that belong to the technology-transfer watchdog organization known as Cocom, will eliminate the need to seek export licenses for 30 types of equipment of limited strategic value, like electric furnaces and vacuum pumps. It will also grant the Soviet Union and Eastern European nations access to much more sophisticated computers, telecommunications equipment and machine tools. 
Hungary, Poland and Czechoslovakia were singled out for preferential treatment, which they will receive as soon as they pass rules preventing re-export of sensitive equipment, or information about it, to the Soviet Union and other former allies.
The final critical provision of the accord calls for a complete re-examination by the end of the year of all export controls to construct a new, and presumably more limited, list of items that will be subject to review by the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Exports Controls.
 
New Opportunities Seen
In theory, the changes should open new trade opportunities for a wide range of manufacturers. The reforms should be especially advantageous for those in businesses where the United States has technological leadership, including computers, telecommunications, medical equipment and pollution control, said Dennis E. Kloske, the Commerce Department's Under Secretary for Export Administration.
But business representatives who attended the briefing said yesterday that they were concerned about details that had not yet been settled. For instance, the pact says that export restrictions will be dropped on computers that calculate at speeds slower that 275 megabits a second and that Cocom members will be able to use their discretion in allowing exports of computers that operate at speeds up to 550 megabits.
The Commerce Department said in the briefing that the rules would mean decontrol of almost all personal computers, such as the PS/2 by the International Business Machines Corporation, Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh and the Compaq Computer Corporation's Deskpro 386.
Minicomputers that would be decontrolled include the Digital Equipment Corporation's PDP 11 machines and several I.B.M models. More powerful Digital and I.B.M. machines, as well as the Control Data Corporation's Cyber 180-850 model, would fall into the discretionary approval category.
Special consideration could be sought for large mainframes that might be used to process seismic data or in scientific research.
But processing speed is only one of about 20 specifications covered by Cocom restrictions. The rules limit the speeds at which disk drives operate or that computers can network with other machines, for example.
''Until we see all the parameters, we can't be certain,'' said Charles Hough, the director of trade administration in Washington for Honeywell Inc., a Minneapolis-based computer maker. ''It looks very promising for our process controls, but we don't expect a lot of relaxation in aviation controls.''
Business representatives said the July 1 target for putting the new rules into effect seemed optimistic, given that they would have to be drafted by the Commerce Department and then reviewed by the Office of Management and Budget. Some said they feared that European and Japanese competitors would gain an advantage if the United States' version of the new rules was delayed.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Top Executive Retires At Citizens Utilities

 BODY:
In a long-planned move, Ishier Jacobson, president and chief executive of the Citizens Utilities Company, yesterday announced his retirement after more than 35 years with the company. Daryl A. Ferguson, senior vice president for operations and engineering, will replace him as president and chief operating officer, but the chief executive position remains vacant.
Citizens, a diversified public utility based in Stamford, Conn., has more than 475,000 customers in over 500 communities in 12 states, mostly in the West. Three weeks ago, it began Services Inc., a natural gas transmission and distribution company with revenues exceeding $150 million. 
James W. Swenson, chairman of Louisiana General, said he was ''thrilled'' with the planned merger and said the acquisition would be Mr. Jacobson's ''crowning jewel.'' Mr. Swenson added, ''This was his legacy.''
The company is highly regarded by market analysts, but some anticipate a change in attitude with the departure of Mr. Jacobson. ''The company is very successful but has a policy of not telling you anything,'' said Edward J. Tirello Jr. of Shearson Lehman Hutton, who has been following the concern for 15 years.
The company not only covers a broad geographic sweep from Hawaii to Vermont, but also handles a great variety of utilities, including water, electric and gas services as well as telecommunications.
Mr. Jacobson, who will be 68 later this month and whose retirement takes effect June 30, helped cultivate Citizens' diversification strategy, and the company has had 45 consecutive years of record earnings. Mr. Jacobson has been with the company since 1954, and has been president since 1970.
The next president, Mr. Ferguson, 51, was recruited by Mr. Jacobson for his extensive telecommunications experience. He holds a doctorate in business from George Washington University and a bachelor of science degree in economics and business from Augustana College.
Both Mr. Ferguson and Mr. Jacobson were in Arizona on company business yesterday and could not be reached for comment.
The company's board has left both the chief executive and chairman posts open. Richard L. Rosenthal retired as chairman in June 1989.

HEADLINE: Chip Indicator Resumes Climb

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, June 11

 BODY:
United States orders for computer chips reached a high last month as the semiconductor industry's leading indicator resumed its climb. 
 
The Semiconductor Industry
Association, based in San Jose, Calif., today reported a book-to-bill ratio of 1.14 for the three-month period that ended in May, up from 1.09 in April and down slightly from a revised figure of 1.15 in March.
The ratio compares orders with shipments and is considered a leading indicator of the industry's performance. A ratio of 1.14 indicates that for every $100 in product shipped, $114 was ordered, indicating that demand is rising.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Security Prices Are Stable

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were essentially unchanged yesterday after moderate losses earlier in the day were erased toward the close. The declines after the opening in New York followed earlier weakness in the Tokyo and London markets for Treasury debt issues.
But with most of credit market participants expecting interest rates to decline, the Treasury debt market benefited from the near absence of short sellers. The bond market optimists expect to be rewarded by the flow of economic reports due out later this week. 
Dealers said that even those who expect the latest data to, at best, produce mixed signals did not care to challenge the bulls by selling Treasury paper short.
Meanwhile, the average discount rates at the Treasury regular weekly auction of bills increased modestly. The average rate on 90-day bills rose to 7.73 percent from 7.69 percent; the average rate on the six-month bills increased to 7.64 percent from 7.62 percent.
''The selling we witnessed at the opening resulted from a somewhat odd set of factors that developed overnight in Tokyo not any shift in market sentiment, as was seen by the recovery later in the day,'' said Philip Braverman, chief economist at the DKB Securities Corporation, an arm of the Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank of Tokyo.''
Mr. Braverman, who is bullish on the bond market, said the selling began in Japan after the ruling Liberal Democratic Party there lost an election. The lost seat was not important to the ruling party. But it was a surprise, not to mention an embarrassment to the pollsters, and this caused fair-size losses in the Tokyo stock and bond markets.
''Japanese portfolio managers try to avoid hurting their own markets even when they want to unload holdings,'' Mr. Braverman continued. ''It so happened that many Japanese investment managers had built up large profits in dollars and dollar-denominated assets. So rather than sell into their own declining market, the portfolio managers moved to offset losses in their stock and bond markets by selling dollars and dollar assets such as our Treasury paper.''
The resultant weakness in dollar assets carried over to the London market and when the New York market opened, some Japanese houses were still winding up their sales of Treasury paper and dollars.
After the selling ended, prices recovered and late in the session the Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 8.75 percent issue maturing in 2020, was off 3/32, at 103 10/32, as the yield edged up to 8.44 percent, from 8.43 percent late Friday. The long notes, the 8 7/8's of the year 2000, dipped 1/32, to 102 23/32, with the yield unchanged at 8.46.
Among other representative Treasury issues traded in the secondary market, the 8.5's of 1992 were unchanged at 100 10/32, as was the yield at 8.32 perent; the 8.5's of 1995 lost 1/ 32, at 100 9/32, but the yield was unchanged at 8.41 percent.
The Federal Reserve, meanwhile, intervened again in the money market to add reserves to the banking system with another set of three-day systemwide repurchase agreements. Fed watchers said the operation was aimed at providing the banking system with sufficient liquidity through the end of the two-week bank maintainence, or accounting, period, which ends tomorrow.
In any case, the key Federal funds rate that banks charge each other for temporary loans, traded all day at 8.25 percent, which the credit market holds has been the Fed's target since last December. Any move by the Fed to lower (or raise) interest rates would immediately be reflected in the funds rate.
What has been less evident, but nevertheless important, factor in the domestic Treasury debt market is the turmoil in the Canadian credit markets. The crisis there over the possible secession of the province of Quebec has indirectly bolstered the market in United States Treasury paper.
Francis A. Scotland, managing editor of the Montreal-based International Bank Credit Analyst, said that ''there has been some flow of capital southward recently because of the uncertainty over the Quebec issue.'' He added, ''This uncertainty has, if anything, grown worse, as the June 23 deadline for resolving the issue nears.''
There was some euphoria in the domestic ''junk bond'' market after the Trump Organization obtained new financing from its bankers. Trump's high-yielding bonds posted moderate gains.
Following are the results of the Treasury's regular weekly auction of three and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Lower in Light Day As Reports Are Awaited

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was lower yesterday against most primary currencies except the Japanese yen. Trading was slow.
''It's been very quiet today, all day long,'' said Lorenzo Troni, the vice president for foreign exchange at Paine Webber International Ltd. in New York. ''I think everyone is waiting for some economic data.'' 
Later this week, the Government is to release reports on retail sales, producer prices and consumer prices. The market is anticipating lower inflation and lower retail sales that could prompt the Federal Reserve to push down interest rates, leading to a weaker dollar, Mr. Troni said.
Against the Japanese currency, the dollar climbed in New York trading to 154.77 yen, from 153.49 late Friday. Earlier, in Tokyo, the dollar rose by 1.45 yen to close at 154.10 yen. In London, it was quoted at 154.45 yen.
One trader, Linda McLaughlin of Chemical Bank, attributed the dollar's strength against the yen to money from individual investors in Japan who have just received semiannual bonuses. The workers are apparently looking to invest in United States markets, she said.
In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.6858, up from $1.6843 late Friday. The pound traded at $1.6860 late yesterday in New York, more expensive than $1.6840 late Friday.
The dollar also fell against the West German currency, closing at 1.6927 marks, down from 1.6975 marks late Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late Friday, included: 1.4430 Swiss francs, down from 1.4495; 5.6965 French francs, down from 5.7145; 1.1710 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1743, and 1,243.25 Italian lire, down from 1,248.00. Gold prices finished mixed. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery rose by 70 cents, to $356.40 an ounce. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid of $355.10 an ounce, up by 10 cents from late Friday.
In London, the metal was quoted at a bid of $354.45 an ounce yesterday, down from $354.50 an ounce late Friday. In Zurich, the bid price was $355, up from $354 late Friday.
In Hong Kong, gold fell by $1.28 to close at a bid of $355.75 an ounce.
Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.01 an ounce, down from Friday's $5.02. On the Comex, silver for current delivery rose 0.5 cent an ounce to close at $5.012 an ounce.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Bright Future Seen for Product Managers

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
A REFUGEE from the New York retailing scene, Mary Jane Schmuhl happily works in Andover, Mass., for a leading national retailer, and she lives in Boston, which means reverse commuting from the city to the small town. She also travels the world.
Her business card reads: ''Mast Industries Inc., Product manager -Limited Sweaters.''
Mast Industries is the ''sourcing'' and production arm that sells about $1 billion worth of apparel yearly to its parent, the Limited Inc., the largest apparel chain in the nation, with 78 stores operating under its name. On the side, the Limited also owns affiliates like Henri Bendel, the higher-priced New York apparel store; Lane Bryant, a chain that caters to large women, and Abercrombie & Fitch, a sports clothing and gift specialty store. 
Last week, Miss Schmuhl, who is 26 years old, described her job, emphasizing the word ''sourcing.''
''Sourcing within Mast Industries entails working with producers within various countries overseas and searching out production areas for a specific product,'' she said. ''My category is sweaters.''
She enjoys the diversity of the job. ''It is like running my own business,'' she commented. ''I also do yarn research, which means I often travel to Europe. I love to travel.''
Later this year she plans to make a business trip to Florence, Italy, for a trade show and to Milan, where her company has an office. ''My mother is coming along,'' she said, explaining that she has accumulated a large amount of frequent flier benefits.
''I have one customer,'' she stressed. That customer is the Limited, and more specifically its 25-year-old sweater buyer, Lisa Kamalsky, at the Limited's Columbus, Ohio, headquarters, to which Miss Schmuhl travels often.
''I consult with the buyer on what types of sweaters and what colors she wants for the various stores,'' she said. Then Miss Schmuhl works out the production details, which means that she sometimes travels to textile manufacturing centers such as South Korea, Thailand and Hong Kong.
The job involves plenty of competition, too, because outside vendors try to sell their sweater versions to the Limited's buyer. Much depends on Miss Schmuhl's ability to give the best prices, best delivery and the best fashion, including quality. It becomes a business decision on the part of the buyer as to how many thousands of sweaters to order and where to buy them, Miss Schmuhl explained.
Central buying is not new by any means for large retailers but the Limited officials believe they have carried it ahead further than most others. ''The situation changes daily,'' Mark G. Oswald, Mast's vice president of human resources, said last week. ''But last year Mast sold about $1 billion worth of apparel to our parent, the Limited, or about 40 percent of what the Limited bought.'' Outside competition ''keeps us on our toes,'' he added.
Miss Schmuhl thinks that her interest in design, along with a college major in marketing, has helped her career. ''My hunger or passion for design makes my use of it work for the business,'' she said. ''A lot of my design ideas were not welcome at first, but I think the trend of the market will require more designing. I think it is aiding the buyer.''
A 1986 graduate of Bowling Green University in Ohio, she obviously has moved ahead quickly in retailing, since her first job ($15,500 yearly) with Liz Claiborne Inc., where she specialized in sweaters. She stayed there for about six months until she found a somewhat higher-paying job with Ralph Lauren Women's Wear Inc. as a product manager for sweaters, specifically product manager for ''active label sweaters,'' meaning tennis and ski sweaters.
''I was not content at the time with the opportunities and my position was menial, and I wanted a change in my personal life,'' she said. Through networking she learned about possible openings at Mast and was interviewed. A year ago she landed the job with Mast in a salary range ''of $40,000 and over,'' according to Mr. Oswald.
In the hierarchy of Mast there are also about a dozen senior product managers, who earn $60,000 and over, and ''about 40 product managers like me,'' Miss Schmuhl said. Their specialities might be accessories or various types of apparel.
There are also about 30 assistant product managers in training, usually young people right out of college who earn in the ''late $20,000's,'' according to Mr. Oswald.
Looking ahead, Mr. Oswald pointed out that the outlook for doing business in Europe was good, and he pointed to the labor shortage in Hong Kong. ''There is only 1 percent unemployment there,'' he said.
By the late 1990's, when the Chinese are scheduled to finally take over in Hong Kong, he thinks European manufacturers will be in a strong position to compete with Far Eastern ones. Hong Kong might dwindle as a manufacturing center because of the labor problem, he suggested, but that meant there would be more of a focus on Europe, possibly Eastern Europe, for product managers like Miss Schmuhl.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 13, 1990, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
The Careers column in Business Day yesterday about product managers misstated the number of stores operated by the Limited Stores division of the Limited Inc., the nation's largest apparel chain. It is 780, not 78.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
GORBACHEV YIELDS ON ALLIANCE ROLES IN A NEW GERMANY

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 12

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today removed one of the main conditions that his country had imposed on German unification. He agreed for the first time that West German troops could remain in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization without a corresponding role for the East Germans in the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact.
His offer, made during a report to the Soviet Parliament on his talks with President Bush in Washington, falls short of Western demands that a united Germany be allowed to remain in NATO without conditions.
Mr. Gorbachev proposed that East Germany retain a vaguely defined ''associate membership'' in the Warsaw Pact, and that a united Germany ''honor all obligations'' inherited from the two Germanys. 
 
Formula for Germany in NATO
But Mr. Gorbachev's remarks clearly showed that he was striving to find a formula that would allow a united Germany to join NATO, and to prepare his Parliament and public opinion for such an eventuality. [In Washington, Bush Administration officials assessing Mr. Gorbachev's statement said they were growing increasingly convinced that the Soviet leader was slowly reconciling himself to the idea that a united Germany would be in NATO, provided that Moscow's economic, political and security concerns are met. Page A18.] Before Mr. Gorbachev spoke today, Soviet officials had previously suggested various approaches intended to prevent German unification from tipping the military balance in NATO's favor. They had proposed a neutral Germany, joint membership for Germany in both alliances, and the dismantling of the alliances, all ideas rejected by the West.
 
Dual but Not Equal Roles
Today the Soviet leader renewed his call for a broad, general security structure to supplant the two alliances, but he conceded that the rival blocs would continue to exist ''for longer than might be imagined.''
He again called for ''dual membership'' for Germany in the competing alliances, but this time it was clear that he was not insisting on an equal membership. The West German Army, or Bundeswehr, would belong to NATO, he said, while the East Germany Army would answer only to the unified German government, not to either alliance.
''United Germany could declare that for this transition period, it would honor all obligations it inherits from the Federal Republic of Germany and from the German Democratic Republic,'' Mr. Gorbachev said. ''For this period, the Bundeswehr would, as before, be subordinate to NATO, and the East German troops would be subordinate to the Government of the new Germany.''
 
Troops to Remain in Germany
That proposal would evidently leave a united Germany free to use East Germany's Army any way it saw fit - including, as some West Germans have proposed, abolishing it.
The Soviet leader said he had proposed to President Bush that during that period, Soviet troops would remain stationed in East Germany, a condition the West has already accepted, and Moscow would agree to the continued presence of American troops in Europe.
''I told the President that I think that the American presence in Europe, since it fulfills a certain role in maintaining stability, is an element of the strategic situation, and does represent a problem for us,'' Mr. Gorbachev told his Parliament.
Mr. Gorbachev's carefully worded statement on the intricacies of the German question was so murky in places that many diplomats spent the day puzzling over it before recognizing the new elements.
 
Narrowing of Differences
Western diplomats here said Mr. Gorbachev's comments reflected a rapid narrowing of the conceptual differences between East and West on the future of Germany, although the negotiations on concrete proposals remain excruciatingly complicated.
''He is no longer insisting that united Germany can under no circumstances be a member of NATO, something he had said two months ago was absolutely excluded,'' said one European diplomat.
But the two sides remain mired in the complexities of such questions as the numbers of troops, the command structure, compensation of the Soviets for possible loss of East German trade, and the creation of new political organizations that would give the Soviets some say in European affairs.
''Given the circumstances, it would be unreasonable to expect him to show more of his cards now,'' the diplomat said. ''He is still waiting to see some concrete proposals from us at the NATO summit,'' a meeting of the Western leaders scheduled for July, the diplomat said.
 
Threat of Hard-Line Assertions
Mr. Gorbachev's main concern is that German reunification not add to the threat - or the fear among his countrymen - of a decisive shift in the military balance, with NATO strengthened by the gain of a united Germany, while the Eastern alliance disintegrates.
If Mr. Gorbachev is not careful, his supporters say, hard-liners in the Government and military might use the loss of Germany to undermine the Soviet leader by asserting that his foreign policy is selling out Soviet security.
In the Communist Party Daily Rabochaya Tribuna today, Oleg Baklanov, the Communist Party official responsible for the military industry, warned that the Soviet Union was rushing into a position of disadvantage in Europe.
''In short, we are leaving and NATO is staying behind and, as far as I can judge, growing stronger every day,'' Mr. Baklanov said, in an interview reflecting the hard-line pressures on Mr. Gorbachev. ''I think we should stop and look around for a moment to understand the disposition of forces in Europe, and it is not tending toward parity.''
In a gesture apparently toward the hard-liners, Mr. Gorbachev today tersely rejected a written suggestion from one member of Parliament that Communist Party political cells in the military be abolished to make the army more independent of party control. ''No, I don't think so,'' he said. Mr. Gorbachev today also dismissed speculation that Moscow would welcome a united Germany that would be, like France, linked politically to NATO but not formally integrated into its military structure.
During the summit meeting in Washington, President Bush renewed the American insistence that Germany should remain in NATO, but offered a package of nine measures with a goal of alleviating Soviet security fears.
They included a promise not to extend NATO troops to East German territory, maintenance of 300,000 to 400,000 Soviet troops in East Germany at West German expense, revamping the NATO force structure to make it less threatening to Moscow, future discussions on limiting the German Army, and ways to institutionalize the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which would give the Soviets a voice in general European security affairs.
Mr. Gorbachev today welcomed those proposals as a show of good faith and said that if NATO continued to remake itself into a more purely political alliance, the unification of Germany may be accomplished without bitterness.

HEADLINE: The Home's Link To School Success;
A New Road to Learning: Teaching the Whole Child

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN

 BODY:
For more than 20 years in this city of scholars and elms, schoolchildren and their parents have been studying a basic axiom: students in troubled schools learn better when families and educators work together.
In the process, these children of troubled schools and their parents, most of them poor and black, are discovering that schools need not be rigid institutions concerned only with academic performance, but can also be places that tend to a child's psychological and social growth. And when those two sides of a child's life are entwined, the child feels better about himself and learns more.
This is the essence of a program developed by Dr. James P. Comer, a Yale University psychiatrist, and carried out in New Haven. The results have been higher attendance, fewer behavior problems and improved academic performance. School systems around the country are eager to replicate it, and the Rockefeller Foundation has committed $15 million to that end. 
The process turns on a seemingly simple insight: that a child's home life affects his performance in school, and that if schools pay attention to all the influences on a child, most problems can be solved before they get out of control. The Comer process, as it is called, encourages a flexible, almost custom-tailored approach to each child.
Take the case of Ramon Cato. Ramon, a chubby, bright-eyed boy with a chipped front tooth, has known extreme family stress. For much of the last two years, Ramon has lived with his mother, described by relatives as a drug abuser, and her boyfriend, in one room in a condemned house known as a haven for drug users. He struggled in school and behaved badly, when he was there. He missed 57 of 180 days in the term that ended a year ago.
Educators at Grant Elementary School did not throw up their hands and write him off. When they could not get his mother involved, they found a great-uncle who cared. Now the uncle is a regular visitor to Ramon's classroom, and the boy is living with a foster family, doing well in school. He will graduate from fourth grade with his classmates Friday.
Not every child has problems as severe as Ramon's. But whatever the pressures on a family may be, a school using the Comer (pronounced COMB-er) process will be alert to discovering those problems and helping solve them, supporters say.
This common-sense melding of home life, school life and social service aid is what attracted the Rockefeller Foundation's attention and led it earlier this year to make a five-year, $15 million commitment to replicate the methods of Dr. Comer, the coolly charismatic father of the approach.
The Comer process has already been adopted by more than 100 schools in nine districts in eight states. In the last three years, the New Haven school system has expanded it to include all 42 schools in the 18,000-pupil system.
''There's a difference one can see almost right away once his principles are applied,'' said Priscilla Hilliard of Howard University in Washington, D.C., who heads a partnership between the college and that city's public schools to carry out the program.
For low-income students in troubled inner cities, and especially for black and Hispanic students, whose achievement-test scores badly trail the national average, Dr. Comer's program offers one of the greatest hopes, many educators say. In an economy increasingly incapable of absorbing unskilled workers, undereducation may sentence much of a generation to join an underclass marked by joblessness and the pathologies of the forgotten.
 
The Process
Relationships Based on Sharing
The Comer process, which Dr. Comer himself calls the School Development Program, emphasizes building relationships based on sharing that bring school administrators, staff, teachers and parents together regularly - in many cases daily.
The approach concentrates on the emotional, social, and psychological needs. His clearly-structured programs establish three goals: to induce parents to participate in the school's life; to force school administration, teachers, and other staff to share authority in managing the school; and to bring guidance counselors, mental health professionals and teachers into a team that meets regularly to combat behavior problems.
Parents, for example, are encouraged to become classroom assistants, tutors or aides. Some are encouraged, as are some teachers, to join their school's governance committee, which meets bi-weekly and includes the principal. The mental health and guidance professionals are part of the process of school management.
According to Dr. Comer, most administrators and teachers are not trained to recognize that a student's academic and behavioral lapses may be linked to the cultural and social gap between home and school.
''Some of these children come from families that cannot give them often the elementary things they need, like how to say 'Good morning,' 'Thank you,' 'Sit still' and all kinds of stuff,'' said the 55-year-old psychiatrist. ''On the other hand, you have staff that often doesn't understand that that is the problem.''
The children, Dr. Comer said, ''are in foreign terrority.''
When parents and educators work together in schools, social and psychological needs of students are not only better identified, but can be addressed to make students feel they are a welcome part of the school, say supporters of the Comer program. Their confidence is restored, and they are taught some of the things their families were unable to teach them.
 
The Bridges
Parent to School, School to Child
Interest in Dr. Comer's methods has never been more keen. Recently, the National Committee on Children, created by Congress and the President to be an advocacy group for children, visited New Haven to study Dr. Comer's program. And President Bush, while preparing last year for his meeting with the nation's governors on education, turned to Dr. Comer for advice.
For low-income students in troubled inner cities, and especially for black and Hispanic students, Dr. Comer's program may offer one of the greatest hopes, educators say.
''Dr. Comer's work builds bridges,'' said Hugh B. Price, a Rockefeller Foundation vice president. ''One is built from the parent to the school, and one out from the school to the children.''
For the next five years the foundation plans to spend $3 million a year to help schools implement the Comer process and train teachers in its tenets.
 
Effect on Educators
''Any educator who is exposed to his way of thinking emerges from that enlightened and empowered,'' Mr. Price said. ''We spent a good amount of time surveying all the possibilities and became struck by the fact that Dr. Comer's work was the most powerful we encountered. People who listen to him emerge saying, in effect, 'I knew it all along; he affirms my own best instincts.' ''
Unlike programs for economically disadvantaged children that limit their reforms to early childhood education, Dr. Comer's approach is a comprehensive, system-wide strategy for all ages.
Results of the Comer process have been especially impressive in reaching students considered ''at risk,'' Mr. Price said. In a study of some schools in Benton Harbor, Mich., that used Dr. Comer's approach, researchers found significant improvement in student performance and behavior. Suspensions in schools using the Comer approach dropped 8 percent - while rising 34 percent in the district as a whole. Similarly, students in the Comer schools excelled in reading and mathematics. In reading, the average gain in the Comer schools equaled that of the district as a whole at the second-grade level. But at the fifth and sixth grade levels the Comer schools, on the average, surpassed district-wide averages.
 
The Family
How Involvement Nurtures Esteem
Because Dr. Comer's program tries to reduce the sense of alienation some students and their parents feel for school, parents often welcome it as readily as do children.
Debra Kelly, who has three children, ages 6 to 9, in the New Haven system, said she is so pleased by what she has seen that she became active in her childrens' school and is now president of the Parent-Teachers Organization.
''In the last two years, I've done a lot of volunteer work here,'' said Ms. Kelly, who is 30. ''Now I promote it. It helps children and makes them feel more comfortable.''
Jacqueline Lecraft is 23 and childless. But she troops into her 5-year-old godson's kindergarten class almost every day.
A college student studying early childhood education, Ms. Lecraft said she got involved because her godson's parents could not get as much time off as she could.
''I want him to get a good start,'' she said. ''My mother was involved in my school, and it made a lot of difference. I want to do the same thing.''
 
Praise by Superintendent
Educators as well as parents say evidence abounds that Dr. Comer's methods work. ''We now have outstanding parent involvement, and youngsters are really focused on self-esteem and self-respect, and teachers are intimately involved in teaching,'' said John Dow Jr., New Haven's public school superintendent.
Jeffie Frazier, principal of the city's Helene Grant Elementary School, in an economically depressed black section of the city, explained: ''We have boys and girls who come into school who basically do not feel good about themselves. Our main job is to get them to feel good about themselves.''
That's what happened to Ramon Cato.
 
Living Proof
A Child Saved From Himself
Last year, Ramon lived on the edges of three worlds after his grandmother and grandfather, who were taking care of him, died within months of each other. Back with his mother and her boyfriend, he lived in a single room where soiled sheets served as window panes and the furniture consisted of a mattress and several milk crates. Often he roamed the streets at night. In the mornings, filthy and frustrated, he sometimes went to school.
''He was lost,'' said Ms. Frazier. She and her staff made contact with Ramon's great-uncle, Theodore F. Hogan Jr., an executive with the Southern New England Telephone Company.
Mr. Hogan said he grew particularly concerned after teachers at Ramon's school talked to him about the boy's absences and behavior.
''That really bothered me,'' he said, ''because I knew he was really smart, smart as a whip.'' With help from Ramon's teachers and principal at Grant Elementary, Mr. Hogan said, he was able to convince the city's Department of Children and Child Services that Ramon needed better care, and get him placed with a foster family.
''I do like my uncle tells me, act like nothing ever happened,'' Ramon said of his ordeal.
 
Another Success Story
Not all success stories are as dramatic, or as personal, as Ramon's.
About a year ago, Ms. Frazier, working with parents and teachers, decided to institute a school-uniform policy. Some parents had complained that some students appeared too concerned about the style of their expensive clothes and sneakers. And students whose families were unable to afford the clothes felt inadequate. A joint parent-teacher-principal management team - one of the components of the Comer process - decided on simple uniforms of Girl Scout-green and white and gray. Students and parents point to them as a source of pride and distinction. Even Ms. Frazier wears a variation of the green uniform to her office every day.
 
The Critics
The Sternest Tests May Lie Ahead
There are some, albeit only a few, detractors of the Comer program.
A professor of social work at a prestigious Southern university said Dr. Comer's program raises nearly as many questions as it answers. ''A crucial question is whether Comer's model can be replicated in any school district,'' said the professor, who asked not to be identified. ''Are there some school systems that are simply too large, such as New York City's?'' The professor also wondered if Dr. Comer's program can cope with fragmenting families, whose members may be unable to participate in school life because of poverty.
Dr. Comer maintains that with careful application his program can be adapted to the needs of any school system, although neither he nor his Rockefeller Foundation supporters are yet prepared to tackle New York.
And Dr. Comer agrees with his critics to a degree in acknowledging that the social deterioration in many major cities will force educators and parents to work even harder.
''We are beginning to see the first of our crack babies in our schools,'' Dr. Comer said, adding that their behavioral problems will present his program with special challenges.
Nonetheless, he said he is not shaken in his long-held belief that child development should be the centerpiece of education. For many black and Hispanic children, whose parents, Dr. Comer says, have had a ''traumatic social history,'' education must do more than teach the basics.
''Those families under stress are least able to give children the kinds of experiences they need to go to school and succeed,'' Dr. Comer said.
 
A Pupil's Two Worlds
At Katherine Brennan School, one of the New Haven elementary schools where Dr. Comer introduced his approach early on, there is a climate of calm and caring. The sight of parents in the school is almost as commonplace as that of teachers. Halls are quiet and clean. Bulletin boards celebrate black history and achievement in brightly-colored posters and hand-cut construction paper.
Outside, the school's double steel doors stand shut to a poverty-ravished neighborhood of public housing projects, graffiti-scarred streets and the ever-festering menace of drugs.
Brooke Rogers knows about the contrast. Recently, the fourth-graer said school represents her ''inside world,'' one quite apart from the ''outside world where people don't have anything in their heads but drugs and hurting people.''
With that, she pushed away from the table, stood up, thrust out her chin and said: ''I'm going to grow up and be somebody.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: A parent-child education program developed by Dr. James P. Comer has been in use in New Haven for more than 20 years. Jacqueline Lecraft studied with her godson, Jeffrey Gilmore, at Grant Elementary School. (John J. P. Coleman for The New York Times) (pg. B7)
