HEADLINE: Strategic Interests Tie U.S. to Liberia

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12

 BODY:
United States strategic interests tie Washington to the Liberian crisis, even as American officials privately voice criticism of the nation's embattled President and the leader of rebel forces moving on the capital.
Liberia grants the United States landing and refueling rights for military aircraft and ships on 24-hour notice, the only nation in sub-Saharan Africa that accords Washington such rights. The United States also controls a navigational station that emits low-frequency signals that guide ships and aircraft in the Atlantic. 
The installation in Liberia, one of eight in the world, serves as a backup guidance system for the American nuclear submarine fleet.
Washington also operates two communications relay stations outside Monrovia, the capital, that handle virtually all diplomatic and intelligence messages in sub-Saharan Africa and transmit Voice of America radio programming to most of the continent.
''They are important installations,'' said Herman J. Cohen, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs. ''It would be difficult and very expensive to move them to another country.''
Asked if the 2,000 marines stationed in four ships off the coast of Liberia might be landed to defend the installations, he responded, ''I wouldn't want to reject any options.''
The installations have so far been untouched by the six-month civil war fought by the army of President Samuel K. Doe and the guerrillas of Charles Taylor.
While neither side has threatened to harm the installations, Mr. Cohen has said he was concerned that they could be damaged in crossfire.
Critics of Washington's long financial support for the Monrovia Government have asserted that the United States overemphasizes the importance of the installations in Liberia.
''I'm not sure there is any facility there that can't be replaced somewhere else,'' said Representative Ted Weiss, a Manhattan Democrat. ''When you are willing to overlook any kind of misdeed, from the most brutal to the most larcenous, to protect strategic assets, then those assets are not going to be very secure anyway.''
 
The Firestone Factor
Liberia has been close to the United States ever since it was founded in 1822 by freed American slaves. Its capital is named after James Monroe. Its 1847 Constitution was written at Harvard Law School. The descendents of the American settlers ruled over poorer tribal peoples for more than 150 years. The American dollar is the Liberian currency.
These ties fostered a special strategic relationship between the United States and Liberia. The United States Navy has long used the deep-water port of Monrovia when sailing in West African waters.
After World War I, when American strategic thinkers wanted secure supplies of rubber, Washington promoted the interests of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company in Liberia. Firestone won concessions of land at bargain prices, and developed the largest rubber plantation in the world.
''All the evidence suggests that a desire to maintain these installations and privileges has been a major factor in determining U.S. relations with Liberia's successive governments,'' said Gordon C. Thomasson, an anthropologist at Marlboro College in Vermont and president of the Liberian Studies Association.
Washington voiced criticism of the execution of members of the Tolbert Government by Doe forces, but provided Liberia with $500 million worth of military and economic aid between 1980 and 1985.

HEADLINE: Poorer Countries Are Hit Hardest By Spread of AIDS, U.N. Reports

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12

 BODY:
The AIDS pandemic is spreading rapidly through the world and is switching from a disease of the industrial world to a disease of the developing nations, says Dr. Michael Merson, director of the United Nations' Global Program on AIDS. In an interview on Monday, Dr. Merson said that five years ago about half the world's known human immunodeficiency virus infections were in the developed countries, most in the United States. New estimates show that two-thirds of the HIV infections, which are known to cause AIDS, are in the less-developed countries, and that in 10 years three-quarters of all infections will occur in the developing countries. 
Dr. Merson, who succeeded Dr. Jonathan Mann earlier this year as director of the World Health Organization's Global Program on AIDS, said current estimates say there are now about 700,000 cases of AIDS, and six to eight million infections worldwide.
 
'Immense' Impact Seen
Among the consequences of the shifting burden of the disease, he said, is that for the first time in decades childhood mortality has stopped declining and will now begin to rise in some nations.
In addition, Dr. Merson said, ''the economic and social impact of a disease that kills people in their most productive years will be immense.''
''The selective impact on young and middle-aged adults, who include business and government workers as well as members of social, economic and political elites, could lead to economic and even political destabilization in some developing countries,'' he said.
Dr. Merson said that the pandemic would not level off for decades, and that it is likely that at least 15 to 20 million people will be infected in 10 years. As the spread of the disease is beginning to slow in the United States and other developing countries, it is just beginning to rise geometrically in other nations, including some in Asia, where the first wave of infection has passed through intravenous drug users and is now spreading rapidly among urban prostitutes.
 
Stark Figures
In India, less than 1 percent of prostitutes tested were infected in 1987. Now, up to 20 percent are infected in Bombay and other large cities.
In Thailand, less than 1 percent of intravenous drug users tested were infected in 1987; now, 50 percent are infected. Among urban prostitutes, the number has gone from less than one percent to 40 percent in some places. In those same three years, estimates say, the number of infected people in the nation has gone from a few hundred to more than 50,000.
In the early years of the epidemic in the United States and Europe, most cases were among homosexual men. Today, 60 percent of the infections worldwide are believed to have been spread by heterosexual acts. That proportion is expected to increase to 80 percent in the next 10 years.
Dr. Merson said it is not known how the disease will spread in Asia because it is unknown how much sexual activity, either heterosexual or homosexual, there is in the Asian nations that are now seeing an increase in the disease rates.
At the same time the disease is set to explode in Asia and elsewhere, Dr. Merson said, the Global Program on AIDS, a division of the World Health Organization at the United Nations, expects a $40 million shortfall in its budget for next year. The United States has cut back its contribution to the program from $25 million in fiscal 1989 to $21 million for 1990, and President Bush's request for $19 million in 1991.

HEADLINE: U.S. Urged to End Opposition to Ozone Aid

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12

 BODY:
The head of the United Nations Environment Program strongly urged the United States today to reconsider its decision to oppose new financial aid to third-world countries to help them phase out chemicals that are destroying the earth's ozone layer.
The official, Mustafa K. Tolba of Egypt, executive director of the program, said that if the industrialized countries failed to provide the economic and technical help required by the third-world nations, the ''global bargain'' to protect the earth's environment would fall apart.
He said he was optimistic that the United States would change its position before a meeting in London this week called to strengthen an existing international treaty to protect ozone in the atmosphere from being destroyed by chlorofluorocarbons and other industrial chemicals.
But at a Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing today, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d reiterated that the Administration preferred to use ''existing resources'' to help the third-world countries adhere to the ozone treaty. 
Opposition to providing additional money to help the third-world countries phase out the offending chemicals originated with Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, and John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, Administration officials said.
While the American contribution would only be about $20 million, the White House officials reportedly feared that providing such additional funds would open the door to broad demands by those countries for assistance in solving their environmental problems.
The Bush Administration wants such aid to be provided from existing funds from the World Bank or other international lending institutions. The Administration also opposes the creation of a new fund at the World Bank for environmental programs.
Legislation has been introduced in Congress that would require the Government to contribute funds to help the poorer countries protect the ozone layer.
In a speech at the National Press Club today, Dr. Tolba called for a ban on the chemicals destroying the ozone layer when the nations gather in London this month. Under a protocol signed in Montreal in September 1987, those who agreed to the treaty committed themselves to a 50 percent reduction in the production and use of the chemicals by the end of the century.
Since then, new scientific information has shown that the destruction of the ozone layer is proceeding even more rapidly than previously recognized. A thinning ozone layer permits more ultraviolet radiation from the sun to penetrate to the earth's surface, causing skin cancer and cataracts in humans and harming crops and wildlife.
Dr. Tolba also said today that he expected the international community to adopt a treaty ''with teeth'' to address the global-warming problem when it gathers at a conference in Brazil two years from now.
Carbon dioxide, chlorofluorocarbons and other industrial and agricultural gases are accumulating in the atmosphere and, by trapping radiation from the sun, will cause the earth to warm substantially in the next century through a process called the greenhouse effect, many scientists believe. Despite some lingering skepticism about the scientific issues surrounding the greenhouse effect, Dr. Tolba said, ''we are moving toward a truly global consensus on the need for action and action now.''
Although the Bush Administration has been stressing the need for more information about the scientific and economic implications of a global-warming treaty, ''the United States, I am sure, will not block unanimity'' but will meet ''its responsibilities toward its own people and the world at large,'' he said.
At the luncheon, which was sponsored by the World Resources Institute, the United Nations official also emphasized the need for a treaty through which the nations could cooperate to preserve the world's biological diversity.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
U.S. Thinks Gorbachev Might Give In on NATO

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12

 BODY:
Bush Administration officials are growing increasingly convinced that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union is slowly reconciling himself to the idea that a united Germany will be in NATO, provided Moscow's economic, political and security concerns are met, Administration officials said today.
The officials said they were encouraged by the fact that Mr. Gorbachev was, in effect, dropping his demand for German forces to be equally divided between the Eastern and Western alliances in his latest compromise proposal, made today. They said he was gradually moving toward Washington's position with his plan, which calls for the West German Army to be part of NATO and for the East German Army to be under strictly German control.
 
Evolution and Negotiation
While expressing optimism about Mr. Gorbachev's views in light of the new plan, the officials said they thought that the overall change would be an evolutionary process and that there will be protracted negotiations about the terms as Mr. Gorbachev prepares the Soviet public for NATO membership for a united Germany. 
''You are very clearly seeing an evolution in Soviet views,'' a senior Administration official said. ''It wasn't all that many months ago when any form of German unification according to the Soviets would have had to be premised on neutrality, which had been their position since 1952. They now know and recognize that neutrality won't work. They are willing to concede in principle unified German membership in NATO. But they are trying to grapple with how you tie that to other arrangements.''
Another top official said: ''Gorbachev is clearly conditioning his environment by showing that he is ready to consider alternatives for Germany other than the ones he has presented up to now. It won't happen overnight but you can see that he is embarked on a process.''
Reacting to initial reports of Mr. Gorbachev's latest proposal, President Bush told reporters, ''Our position is well known to him, which is that a unified Germany should be in NATO with no conditions.''
The President said he expected Moscow to float more ideas and said, ''We'll listen and we'll discuss them without rancor.''
 
Addressing Security Concerns
Mr. Gorbachev said that if NATO leaders revamped their own military doctrines at the NATO summit meeting in London on July 5 and 6, ''then within this framework a new solution could be found for insuring security for a united Germany.'' That statement was viewed as a signal that the Soviet leader has been influenced by a nine-point program offered by Washington to ease Soviet security concerns about a united Germany in NATO.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, testifying before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today, said: ''All of our Western European allies see the advantage of a unified Germany as a member of the NATO alliance, and so do at least three members of the Warsaw Pact. And the Soviet Union recognizes, and it has stated that they recognize, the important role that United States forces can play as a stabilizing factor in Europe.''
At the NATO summit meeting, Mr. Baker said, ''there will be debate among the heads of state of the NATO countries with respect to NATO's military strategy and doctrine.'' Among the basic NATO strategies that Mr. Baker hinted would be up for reconsideration was the longtime doctrine of the first use of nuclear weapons.
This doctrine, which has been central to NATO military planning, says that if a conventional Soviet attack on Western Europe cannot be halted at the German border, American short-range nuclear weapons could be used to disperse it. To back up the doctrine, NATO keeps short-range nuclear weapons in Germany, which is why the Germans, along with the Soviet Union, are among the leading advocates of abandoning first use of nuclear weapons.
 
Bush Position Hardening
The Bush Administration's public position on Germany and NATO has been hardening a bit lately, not softening. In the final communique at last week's meeting of NATO foreign ministers in Turnberry, Scotland, the United States refined one of the nine points in the program it has offered to Moscow on NATO membership for a united Germany.
Initially, American officials said, no NATO troops would be extended to the territory of what is now East Germany. But in the NATO final communique, and again during testimony before Congress today, Mr. Baker said that the American position was for not extending NATO forces into what is now East German territory ''for a transition period.''
American officials said that after that unspecified period, Germany and NATO could extend their forces over the entire area of German sovereignty. While conceding that this had not been their public position, Administration officials said that this was always how they had formulated their stand when speaking with the Soviet Union in private.

HEADLINE: Study Finds Gains for Babies of Low Birth Weight

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA

 BODY:
The first large-scale study of a development program for babies who weighed less than normal at birth showed that it achieved striking success in raising their scores on intelligence tests and improving their social functioning.
Low-birth-weight babies, those five and a half pounds or less, are known to be at greater risk of developmental, medical and behavioral problems than are babies whoses weights are normal at birth.
But the researchers who conducted the study are reporting today in The Journal of the American Medical Association that the children who participated in the development program from birth were found at the age of 3 to have I.Q. scores that averaged up to 13 points higher than those of children who did not participate.
Although smaller studies have indicated that child development programs could help low-birth-weight babies to function better intellectually, experts said the new research was the first large, carefully controlled study on the subject carried out at multiple sites. Many of the children were from poor families living in inner cities. 
 
Similar Results Cited
Dr. Donna Bryant of the Frank Porter Graham Child Development Center at the University of North Carolina said previous studies led by Dr. Craig Ramey of the center, who was a consultant in the study being reported today, showed similar results for children from poor, uneducated families born at normal weights. One study showed a rise of 16 points in I.Q. by the age of 3, she said.
Dr. Duane F. Alexander, director of the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development in Bethesda, Md., said the latest study was ''extremely important,'' and added: ''What science has provided here is an indication that kids who are at risk of delayed development from low birth weight and economic deprivation can be helped. The gains were substantial. These were not little differences -they were major improvements.''
In the four-year, $33 million study, 985 premature babies who weighed five and a half pounds or less at birth were divided into two groups.
One group received the special intervention. The parents were counseled in groups that met every two weeks. The researchers visited the babies' homes each week, providing health and development information to the parents and a program of games and activities to improve the child's cognitive, language and social skills.
When the children were a year old they were put in an educational day care program, with one teacher for every three children from 12 to 23 months old and one teacher for every four children from 24 to 36 months old.
The second group of babies served as a comparison group and was not offered special help.
 
Substantially Higher Scores
By the time the children were 3 years old, those who had received special help had substanially higher scores on intelligence tests and better social functioning. The I.Q.'s of the heavier babies in the intervention program -those who weighed from 4.4 to 5.5 pounds at birth - were 13.2 points higher than those of comparable size in the control group. And the I.Q.'s of the lighter babies, who weighed less than 4.4 pounds at birth, were 6.6 points higher than those of comparable babies in the control group.
The babies in the control group as a whole were nearly three times more likley to be mentally retarded, the researchers found.
Nearly 7 percent of all babies born in the United States, or about 260,000 babies a year, are classified as low birth weight. More than half are born to poor women who had inadequate nutrition and prenatal care, said Dr. Sumner Yaffe, director of the Center for Research for Mothers and Children at the child health institute.
Dr. Julius Richmond, who was Surgeon General from 1977 to 1981 and is now the John D. MacArthur Professor emeritus of health policy at Harvard, said, ''The fact that the results seem to be so favorable has significance not only for the children and their families, but also in terms of policy.''
 
Programs Could Start at Birth
He said that recent legislation provides Federal funds for states to start programs for children at risk of learning disabilities and that the programs, at the states' discretion, could start at birth.
Dr. Alexander said the new study, directed by Dr. Ruth T. Gross of Stanford University and sponsored by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation in Princeton, N.J., ''is the first one done with a very large population, in a very carefully controlled, prospective way and at multiple sites with very careful follow-up.''
Dr. Gross said she and the other researchers who conducted the study were ''surprised and ecstatic'' when they saw the results. ''It's exciting,'' she said. ''It tells us that improving the environment can go a long way'' toward helping children of low birth weight.
Dr. Ruby Hern, a vice president at the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, who conceived the study, said the work was ''carried out in some of the most difficult circumstances we have in this country,'' and added, ''To me, the very encouraging thing is that by intervening early and frequently we were able to make substantial differences in the children.''
 
Some Questions Remain
The study was done at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York and in centers in seven other cities: Boston, Dallas, Little Rock, Ark., Miami, New Haven, Philadelphia and Seattle.
Dr. Yaffee, the director of the child health institute's research center, said some questions about the study still remained. ''It is important to learn how long these differences will be sustained,'' he said.
The Robert Wood Johnson Foundation is continuing to follow the children, who are now about 5 1/2 years old, but it will not be known for years if the intervention program will translate into greater academic success and fewer social problems for the children.
If the effect is sustained, Dr. Yaffee said, it could make a big difference in the childrens' lives. ''Twelve I.Q. points makes a big difference when it comes to what you are capable of achieveing later in life,'' he said.
Dr. Hern said the study spent $9,000 per child per year just for the child development center services. ''Obviously, our costs were more than it would cost to deliver these services,'' she said.
Dr. Marc Bornstein, who is head of family and child research at the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, said, ''We were schooled in the 1980's that there are certain problems that you can't throw money at to solve.'' But he added, ''This is an example of a problem that if we throw money at it in a certain way, we can make healthier children and, presumably, in the long run, have better citizens and a better society.''

HEADLINE: In Texas, a Look at a Deal Bringing Profit and Peril

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, June 12

 BODY:
The sight of an oil tanker ablaze provoked little surprise along the Texas coast, where many people have struck a bargain with industries that can bring both wealth and danger. But after watching the ship burn for four days, some officials and politicians say they are beginning to wonder whether the bargain should be re-evaluated.
As salvage crews struggled again today to contain the fires aboard the Norwegian tanker Mega Borg almost 60 miles from Galveston Island, several voices were asserting that lack of attention to environmental concerns had unnecessarily increased the dangers posed by such a tanker accident.
Since the oil spill from the Exxon Valdez off Alaska last year, the Texas Land Commissioner, Garry Mauro, has been warning that Texas is unprepared to respond to a major tanker accident. But he complains that he has drawn little attention from fellow elected officials and news organizations. 
 
'Public Has Been Lulled'
''The public has been lulled into a feeling of safety,'' he said today, ''because we have so many small spills every year that do not do major damage and because we've lived with so much oil for so long without ever facing the ultimate catastrophe.''
Since Saturday, when the first explosion occurred aboard the Mega Borg, the prospect of just such a catastrophe has been driven home by the image of fire belching from a ship loaded with 38 million gallons of crude oil.
''Everyone around here knows that there are disasters waiting to happen, but everyone has figured, 'It's not going to happen to me,' '' said Doug Matthews, city manager of Galveston, about 50 miles southeast of Houston.
''This event is a clear sign that we were wrong,'' he said. ''Now it happened in a big way that threatens the whole coast, and we've all been held hostage for four days so far while that ship sits there burning, and we have no control over what is happening out on the Gulf.''
Like Mr. Matthews, most critics have focused on the delay in firefighting efforts while equipment was brought from the Netherlands. Complaints also have been aimed at the rapidly growing and unregulated practice outside Gulf ports in which big tankers like the Mega Borg transfer all or part of their cargoes to smaller vessels that can navigate shallow ports.
 
A General Ambivalence
But interviews with people in business, public officials and others in this region reveal the deep ambivalence of those who want both a healthy environment and a healthy oil industry.
''It will be devastating if that crude gets into the bays, just devastating - a nightmare when you think of all the fine sea life that is threatened.'' said J. Link Smith, an avid fisherman and president of the Bay Oil Company, a family owned concern that distributes petroleum products.
Yet moments later, he argued: ''Every time something like this happens, you hear the same protests, but who is willing to do without all the things we get from oil, whether it is our plastic milk jugs or gasoline?''
Paradox seems to permeate the very landscape of the Texas coast, where sand castles sometimes share vistas with refinery towers.
Galveston Bay, which is far less polluted than it was 20 years ago, is at the heart of a vast estuary system that is a fertile home for a wealth of wildlife, including speckled trout, shrimp, oysters and waterfowl. But many of the people who spend their weekends enjoying the bay and its fruits work during the week at the harbors and the refineries and chemical and other industrial plants that line the shore.
 
Beachgoers and Barges
Along the coast beachgoers on barrier islands face a horizon dotted with offshore oil rigs, and barges laden with petroleum products press down channels dug out of salt marshes that host endangered species like the whooping crane. Despite earlier leaks and accidents, there has been no real pressure to make hard choices about this complex cohabitation.
''We've created a contradiction, a Catch-22, here, and I know we have to live with it, as much as I hate it when things like this tanker accident happen,'' said Mr. Smith. ''No one is guilty of anything, but the times are catching up with everyone.''
Jim Blackburn, chairman of the Galveston Bay Foundation, one of the leading environmental groups in the Houston area, said, ''I think the public has low expectations on the environment because so many people make their livings from oil and petrochemicals, but even though we are way behind the rest of the country, attitudes are changing.''
Even if the Mega Borg is salvaged with no further loss of oil, the massive environmental peril it has represented for four days is likely to contribute to that change, Mr. Blackburn said.
The tanker fire was only one of several recent incidents that have highlighted the environmental dangers. Just the day before the blast aboard the Mega Borg, there were three major industrial accidents in the Houston area that either caused injuries or forced the evacuations of residential areas, or both. But, before such events can change minds, they must overcome a long legacy.
 
A World Apart
As in so many other respects, Texas has considered itself a world apart in environmental matters. Both boom times and busts offered rationales for accommodations at the local level in favor of economic development.
''When big oil was paying 30 cents of every tax dollar, no one was going to go to the barricades when it did something unacceptable, and I believe a preponderance of Texans will still come down on the side of the buck rather than the environment, although clearly the standards are changing,'' said T.R. Fehrenbach, chairman of the Texas Historical Commission.
Oil exploration and extraction do not play the roles they did before the oil price cuts of the 1980's, but the economic recovery of the Houston area over the past two years has been aided by rapid growth in the petrochemicals industry, which has brought new environmental risks. Up and down the Gulf Coast, state and local governments have aggressively courted petrochemical companies with tax incentives and assurances that environmental permits would be expedited -all in hopes of seeing new plants and new jobs in their communities.
But no matter what the economic promise, new pollution threats are no longer accepted automatically and universally.
In Port Lavaca, abut 80 miles down the coast from Galveston, a small environmental group has successfully demanded that the expansion of a plastics plant be subjected to rigorous study before necessary permits are granted. A major project to deepen and expand the Houston Ship Channel faces a potential delay of four years because the Galveston Bay Foundation and other groups have successfully pressured Federal agencies to examine the environmental consequences.
 
'Change Is Coming'
''The change is coming from the bottom up,'' said Frances Farenthold, a prominent Democratic politician in the 1970's. ''It is the people working in hazardous plants or living near them that are raising a ruckus. Meanwhile you hardly hear about the environment in Austin or in political campaigns.''
The slowly changing attitudes are evident even among those in industries once guilty of environmental sins.
Jim Calaway, an independent oil man, said, ''I've been in the oil industry 35 years, and the change in environmental consciousness has been from utter blackness to light.''
He noted that after large capital investments in new wells, production is frequently delayed for months while environmental permits are processed. ''Even ten years ago,'' he said, ''we'd be pumping as much as we could as soon as we could and not thinking about the toxins we were dumping in the air or water, but now we know we can't do that and most important I believe we in the oil industry understand why we can't.''

HEADLINE: The Editorial Notebook;
It's a Wired, Wired World

BYLINE: By LEON V. SIGAL

 BODY:
Expatriate Iranians exported revolutionary ideas from Paris by videocassette. East Germans imported ideas from West Germany by television. Last year Chinese students used telephones, fax machines and laptop computers to organize their protest in Tiananmen Square and tell a watching world about it. 
Electronic communication is breaking down walls between countries and transforming those countries internally. Globally, cross-border telephone traffic increased sixfold in the 1980's. And the details of who's talking to whom, and how much, tell a lot about the pace of economic and social change.
Gregory Staple and Mark Mullins, consultants to the International Institute of Communications in London, have devised a statistic to gauge traffic flows - MiTTs, or minutes of telecommunication traffic. MiTTs measure voice, facsimile and data transmissions on public circuits.
Americans spend the most time reaching out to touch someone abroad, 5.3 billion MiTTs in 1988. But that's because there are lots of Americans with lots of phone lines. A better indicator of growing globalism is MiTTs per 1,000 people. Hong Kong leads with 56,296, one-third of them to China. The next most outward-reaching country is Singapore, followed by Canada, the Netherlands and West Germany. By this measure the U.S. ranks ninth, with 21,839 MiTTs per 1,000 people.
A fifth of that time was spent on outgoing calls to Canada and a tenth each to Britain and Mexico. Then come West Germany at 7 percent and Japan at about 4 percent. The next six, each between 2 and 3 percent, include some surprises: France, Italy, South Korea, the Dominican Republic, Colombia and the Philippines. That's a lot of business in the last three countries.
Such communication flows create a virtual map of economic interdependence. Nearly three-fourths of South Korea's time telephoning abroad and half of Taiwan's goes just to the U.S. and Japan. Singapore's calls, and business abroad, are less concentrated. Singaporeans spend the same portion of time, 13 percent each, calling Indonesia, Hong Kong, Japan and the U.S.
Europeans mostly phone each other, except for the British, who spend more than a fifth of their time ringing up the U.S. One of every four Japanese minutes of foreign calls comes to the United States, almost twice as many as go to South Korea.
In an era of global economic competition, a communication link is an axis of influence. That may be why West Germany is bidding to install phones in Eastern Europe. And that's why it's shortsighted for the U.S. and British Governments to block the installation by American and British companies of a fiber-optic cable across the Soviet Union.
The Soviet people, notwithstanding perestroika, are less connected with each another and less wired into the outside world than are the Chinese. Entrepreneurs from South Korea or Japan could soon fix that, allowing Soviet markets and democracy to function better.
As economies turn from manufacturing to services, measuring by MiTTs may also prove a useful way to track economic growth. So if geopoliticians and economists want to stay on the ball, they'll have to use their MiTTs.LEON V. SIGAL

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: What Economic Decline? What Exported Jobs?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
That 9 out of 10 Americans are disturbed by developments such as economic decline and ''exported'' jobs, as discussed by the poll taker Louis Harris in ''Bush Isn't a Shoo-In for '92'' (Op-Ed, May 23), is no surprise. However, if government policies are to be based on these polls, it is important to know if those feelings are based on facts. In the case of America's economic ''decline,'' they are not. From 1981 to 1989, the United States enjoyed a real economic growth rate of 3 percent a year, lower than Japan's 4.1 percent, but higher that Britain's 2 percent, France's 1.9 percent and West Germany's 1.3 percent.
As for the jobs that have been allegedly exported abroad, it is difficult to see where they have ended up. Job creation in the United States has consistently outpaced that of Japan and Europe. American workers remain the world's most productive, and our standard of living is second to none.
Quite contrary to Mr. Harris's assertion, a Democratic strategy of exploiting fears of economic ''decline'' would play into the President's hands. Mr. Bush may not be a shoo-in, but a Democratic campaign based upon inaccurate economic perceptions will definitely improve his chances.
 
THOMAS J. TIMMONS
Research Associate, Asian Studies
Center, Heritage Foundation
 Washington, May 24, 1990

HEADLINE: In Public Schools, Class Will Tell

BYLINE: By Hodding Carter; Hodding Carter is president of Mainstreet TV Productions, which makes documentaries for public television.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
There is a consensus that public school education is either poised on the precipice or already dashed upon the rocks below. We are regularly barraged with admonitions, advice and policy proposals to remedy the situation. Depending on whom you trust, you may believe that what is required is more tax money, the same or less money spent differently, vouchers, more individual choice, more direct intervention by the private sector or a combination thereof.
It is a rich stew of agitated concern, bubbling furiously in the mass media and scholarly journals, but it is missing the one ingredient that the schools need most: the children of the influential. 
Until America's most affluent and best educated people offer their own children in large numbers to the public school mix, progress will come grudgingly if at all.
To the degree that class and income determine whether you are a public school or private school patron, the public schools will fall disastrously short of their potential, with all that means for wasted lives and diminished prospects for the nation's future.
The flight from the public schools is no respecter of ideology. Harvard professors no less than New Orleans bankers and New York editors long ago decided their children's future was too important to be entrusted to public schools.
Liberals on Capitol Hill rarely make common cause with conservatives. But they are often as one when it comes to the selection of schools for their children, and those schools frequently aren't public. And yet virtually all of them engage in endless public discourse on the tragedy of the public schools and the desperate need to save them. However, the disparity between the leadership class's rhetorical commitment to improving public education and the reality of its wholesale desertion of the public schools is the message that matters.
It is considered patronizing in some quarters to suggest that high-quality education can take place only in schools integrated by race and at least partially by income as well. And many people flatly reject the idea that they should risk their children's future for the sake of what they regard as nebulous social theories and generalized concerns about civic health. The fear of violence is widespread; the reality is far less widespread, but nonetheless real.
To which the answers are, first, the profile of the total school population matters in every way that counts. If white leadership has its kids in the public school system, that system automatically has political clout. It is clout that translates into attention and money, far more of both than a system without such participation can expect or will receive. It may not be fair, but it is nevertheless a fact of political life.
School systems whose patrons are drawn disproportionately from the powerless are themselves relatively powerless to improve. Resources will flow wherever the powerful send their children to school. So will innovation.
Why should the powerful care? Because the public schools are the place where most people receive their education. If they do as bad a job over the next 25 years as they have over the past 25, all of us can kiss America's current position in the world goodbye, along with economic prosperity. We're no longer a giant among pygmies. Our allies and friends now include ferocious competitors, all of whom are building their economic machines on firm foundations of well-educated and trained workers.
Second, protecting our children is an altogether human and logical impulse, but in this instance it is self-defeating. They are the ones who will inherit the society that a failed public school system is certain to produce.
There is no point in pretending that there will be no costs involved, or that public school education can easily be upgraded to match a Phillips Exeter Academy. Nevertheless, affluent families have the intellectual and financial resources to insure that learning takes place outside the classroom as well as in - if they are as willing to give time as they are to give lip service to their children's well-being. And their families, banding together, can help see to it that the schools measure up.
Moreover, the sheltering of upper income children in private schools not only accelerates the deterioration of public education, it hides its consequences from precisely those people who could do something about it.
As for violence, there is only one answer, not only for schools but for society. It is a problem that requires the wholehearted, cooperative effort of everyone. It will only grow worse as the affluent increasingly live like so many noblemen of the Middle Ages, segregated from the rabble in enclaves moated by elaborate security systems and safely removed from the poor's reach.
Violence within the schools cannot be overcome by its primary victims, the children of the nation's least powerful families. It could be controlled if those with the means to call society's institutions to account would stay involved long enough to make the calls.
Earnest lectures, learned articles and philanthropic largesse are no substitute for basic commitment. When it comes to the schools, a paraphrase of an old church saying is particularly pertinent: where your kids are, there is your heart.
When the white leadership abandoned the schools following total integration in my old home town in Mississippi, it hurt the schools and weakened the community. What happened there is little different from the effect of similar desertions in New York City and a thousand other American towns and cities. It seems likely to continue to occur.
Until the nation's leaders admit that what they do with their children matters more than what they say, America's public schools cannot and will not be turned around. If they are not turned around, the continued success of our great national experiment will be in grave doubt.

HEADLINE: Democracy on Hold

BYLINE: By Edward J. Markey; Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, is chairman of the House telecommunications and finance subcommittee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
If the Bush Administration has its way, the people of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union will hear the sounds of democracy with one ear.
At a meeting in Paris last week, the Administration convinced U.S. allies to accept the bulk of its proposals to restrict high-tech exports to the former East bloc. The agreement is being touted as a major breakthrough in liberalizing high-tech export controls. Yet in the field of telecommunications, all it does is afford the new democracies in Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary about the same access to technologies that we allow the old dictatorship in China. 
The Soviet Union, along with Bulgaria and Romania, would be held to an even lower level of technology. Already, a $500 million proposal by a U.S. telecommunications firm to install a fiber optic line to connect the Soviet Union, Europe and Asia - for civilian long-distance phone service and business data communications -is imperiled.
We Americans know about the power of communication. It is an article of faith among us that free and open communications is the best guarantee of democracy. The old Stalinist regimes that once ruled throughout the East bloc paid homage to that faith: they systematically denied their people access to modern telecommunications.
Yet the Bush Administration's shortsighted policy refuses to acknowledge the fundamental opportunity for democracy in tearing down the Sonic Wall that now divides Europe. The practical result of this policy will be that Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union will only be able to communicate with the world in the technological equivalent of whispers.
It is the U.S. intelligence community that represents the key stumbling block. Its representatives argue that eavesdropping on civilian communications systems in these countries will become more difficult if we grant them access to more modern, and more secure, telecommunications technologies. They are correct: it will.
While the interests of the intelligence community should not be dismissed lightly, we must remember that they exist to serve, not dictate, America's broader national interests. In Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, our overarching interest must be to actively encourage the transition to pluralistic, democratic societies with market-oriented economies.
Do we want to deny emerging democracies access to these technologies simply because it makes it harder for us to listen in on a civilian telephone line? The Soviets already maintain a separate, dedicated telecommunications system for sensitive Government communication; civilian telecommunications equipment is largely resistant to diversion for military uses.
We want to encourage democracy. If these nations are to succeed in making their transition to freedom and free markets, their antiquated civilian telecommunications systems - some consisting of rotary phone equipment dating back to the 1930's - must be upgraded. While the U.S. has about 90 phone lines per 100 people, and Western Europe has about 60, Eastern Europe averages only nine phones for every 100 people. Even today, a Polish citizen must wait 13 years to get a telephone in his home.
Telecommunications tools are a vital part of the infrastructure of a free, open and economically viable society. We should be encouraging Eastern European and Soviet citizens to shout democracy from the technological rooftops rather than eavesdropping on their every whisper.
Instead of the Bush Administration's half-hearted policy, we should enact the legislation adopted by the House of Representatives last week. Among other things, the bill would:
* Decontrol exports of less sophisticated civilian telecommunications products and technology. This would give Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union access to items already available to China.
* Allow the Western nations and Japan, at their discretion, to decide which sophisticated civilian telecommunications equipment and technology to export to Eastern Europe.
* Encourage continued progress toward reform in the Soviet Union by allowing exports of sophisticated equipment on the basis of national discretion. However, the lifting of more restrictive controls on technology transfer would be contingent on further democratization.
With these policies in place, America can take pride in laying the technical foundations of democracy in the modern world. We will have provided a precious gift to the people of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union: the power of communication.

HEADLINE: Wagner's Schools Legacy: Varied Grades and a Major Impact

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
Robert F. Wagner Jr. will be ending his four-year presidency of the Board of Education at the end of the month, leaving behind a school system that he altered in important ways through both his artfulness as a politician and his scholarly grasp of the system's fundamental flaws.
His critics accuse him of seizing too much of the day-to-day operations from the chancellors, of snatching power for the central board from the community boards, of failing to follow through on his own criticisms. Some say that his personality, introspective to the point of diffidence, could not passionately project his own vision to the public.
But those who praise him say he is probably the best board president in two decades, and they fear that there is no one on the horizon who will match him when an almost entirely new board takes over on July 1. Mr. Wagner has not been reappointed to the board by Mayor David N. Dinkins.
After a series of board presidents whose roots were largely in politics, Mr. Wagner, though the scion of an illustrious political family, brought with him an intellectual's vision of how the system should be changed and a shrewd ability to work with governmental bodies and news organizations, his admirers say. 
Mr. Wagner's legacy includes the widely-praised Project Giant Step program for 4-year-olds, smaller classes for elementary schools, clinics that provide birth control advice to teen-agers, more attractive salaries for teachers, a more stringent custodians' contract, and a construction authority freed from some of its notorious red tape with a $4.3 billion plan for building new schools.
It was Mr. Wagner, supporters say, who created the search committees that brought leaders with national reputations - first Richard R. Green and then Joseph A. Fernandez - to New York City as Chancellors. And it was Mr. Wagner, in an advantageous climate created by a series of school scandals, who helped spur the State Legislature - many of whose members he knew personally - to keep politicians and school employees off school boards and to restrict tenure for principals.
After the revenue drought that followed the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's, when moldering textbooks were not replaced and classrooms went unpainted, Mr. Wagner was able to extract perhaps $350 million a year more from the city and state beyond inflationary increases. The size of classes in the early grades fell from 28 to 25 pupils and, at many impoverished schools, 22.
''He started building back a system that for a decade had been left to rot,'' said Sandra Feldman, president of the United Federation of Teachers. ''It's still in a fragile state, but he started a momentum toward a viable school system.''
In assessing Mr. Wagner's tenure, the most elusive question is, What did it ultimately mean for the academic proficiency of the schoolchildren? Mr. Wagner says that dropout levels declined sharply, from 43 to 29 percent, and that reading levels gradually improved. But the methods of calculating both measures underwent revisions that officials acknowledge make comparisons difficult.
In a two-hour interview in his Brooklyn office, the 46-year-old Mr. Wagner, who first joined the board in January 1986, said he was proud that New York had become ''a major focus of school reform in the country.'' But he lamented that he was not able to reform special education - the program for handicapped and emotionally disturbed youngsters - so that it was not ''an educational ghetto'' from which many students ''never escape.''
 
'We Have No Choice'
''The school system has to do what it's never done before: provide an education for 100 percent of all kids,'' he said, noting that 85 percent of new jobs require at least a high school diploma. ''Maybe we're asking the schools to do too much, but as a city and as a society, we have no choice.''
The issue of Mr. Wagner's accomplishments was raised publicly two weeks ago by James F. Gill, head of the Joint Commission on Integrity in the Public Schools. He called the Board of Education ''a sleepy-eyed lumbering brontosaurus primarily interested in grazing,'' and singled out Mr. Wagner for what he said was a failure to respond to the commission's findings. There was a bitter irony to the attack because it was Mr. Wagner who created the commission.
Mr. Gill, a man whose temper is not always reined in, has indicated to mutual friends like former Mayor Edward I. Koch that he was goaded by a television reporter and did not intend to attack Mr. Wagner personally. Nevertheless, he said in a recent interview that Mr. Wagner and the board did not promptly overhaul an ineffective inspector general's office and did not replace what he said was an incompetent chief investigator at the Board of Examiners, the agency that licenses teachers.
Mr. Wagner's supporters reject this criticism as simplistic, and ultimately unfair to the overall Wagner record.
 
'Sometimes a Plotter'
''Bob is a very complicated man,'' said Stanley S. Litow, the deputy chancellor for operations. ''He's not a conventional spokesperson. If he were, he would probably be mayor. He's a writer and thinker and sometimes a plotter. But his expertise on the issues is absolutely unparalleled, and he succeeds to the extent that solving problems requires a sense of history, politics and the city's problems all at once.''
Detractors say Mr. Wagner, who worked almost full time as the $20,000-a-year president, undermined both Mr. Green and his predecessor, Nathan Quinones, even limiting their ability to hire their own staff. Even Ms. Feldman, who is generally complimentary, said Mr. Wagner ''was basically running the system as president and there was not a strong leadership role to be played by the chancellor, and that was not healthy for the system.''
Mr. Wagner rejects the picture of him as a meddler and argued that it was under his leadership that the board ''ceded'' the day-to-day business to the chancellor, ''despite what Jim Gill has said.''
Mr. Wagner, the son of a former mayor and the grandson of a United States Senator, brought to the board presidency long friendships with political figures - he regularly has dinner with Mr. Koch - and the mystique of a man who had almost been chancellor himself. The State Education Commissioner overturned his 1983 appointment as chancellor, citing a lack of credentials.
 
Koch Praises Board's Unity
Mr. Koch said Mr. Wagner, a graduate of both Harvard and Princeton's Woodrow Wilson School, was able to create a board with a unified philosophy, no mean feat, he said, considering that the board's seven members are chosen by five borough presidents and a mayor. ''The board has no philosophy, can't have a philosophy because you don't have a single appointing authority,'' Mr. Koch said. ''But what was substituted there was Bob Wagner's basic philosophy.''
Mr. Wagner, admirers say, was able to bring onto the board people like Edward L. Sadowsky and Richard I. Beattie, who had a citywide, rather than a provincial, borough perspective. They add he was able to advise the board how to approach legislators and prepare for editorial board meetings.
Early in his term, Mr. Wagner visited a bilingual class inside a boy's bathroom, its urinals still intact. Determined to relieve overcrowding, he put together the concept of a school construction authority. To cut construction time, the authority would be able to leapfrog many of the reviews needed for site approval and hire a single supervising contractor rather than four separate ones, as other agencies must do under the Wicks Law.
 
Press and Patronage Concerns
Politically, Mr. Wagner helped create a consensus for change, appointing a blue-ribbon study commission, gaining union support, then using his influence with state legislators to obtain passage of the bill creating the authority.
One of Mr. Wagner's severest critics is Dennis Coleman, a Bronx school board member who is president of the New York City School Boards Association. He says Mr. Wagner was ''successful in getting into the boardrooms of the major newspapers'' to create favorable editorials that then generated favorable stories and was able to squeeze money out of City Hall by giving jobs to ''high-level bureaucrats.''
Jeanne Frankl, the executive director of the Public Education Association, criticizes Mr. Wagner for not being a ''galvanizing leader.'' Mr. Wagner, she said, failed to involve parents and community organizations sufficiently.
''Although I think he feels very passionately about children, he hasn't made others share his passion,'' she said. ''He's too much of an academic. His ideas about what needs to be done tend to be theoretical rather than immediate and concrete.''
As to the future, Mr. Wagner is holding his plans close to the vest. He says he wants to continue teaching classes on urban affairs at Columbia and New York Universities and is exploring a book about schools. Friends occasionally urge him to run for the United States Senate. But Mr. Wagner, whose last race was a losing one for Manhattan borough president, is not sure he has a campaigner's personality.
''I'd love to be in the U.S. Senate,'' he said. ''But I'm not sure I'd love to be in a race for U.S. Senate.''

HEADLINE: Selling Authorities To Private Industry Is Backed by Rinfret

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 12

 BODY:
The Republican candidate for governor, Pierre A. Rinfret, said today that he favored selling several state agencies to private industry.
Mr. Rinfret, an economist, said he thought that private owners would run the agencies more efficiently. ''I think you can think about selling anything where the government is totally inefficient and incompetent,'' he said at a news conference here today.
Among the public agencies that Mr. Rinfret said he would like to sell to the highest bidder are the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates Kennedy, La Guardia and Newark Airports, and the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, which owns and maintains New York City's major bridges and tunnels. He also suggested selling several New York City subway lines.
''Sell them - they're worth a lot of money,'' he said.
In his remarks, Mr. Rinfret did not address the potential legal problems of such a huge sale of public assets. Nor was it clear whether Federal law would permit such a sale. Recently, Albany County tried to become the first municipality in the country to sell its airport to a group of private investors but was rebuffed by the Federal Aviation Administration.
 
'Going to Be a Battle'
Mr. Rinfret acknowledged that his plan was likely to face enormous political opposition. ''It's going to be a battle,'' he said, ''because all the people there don't want to be privatized. It may become efficient.''
Today's news conference came during Mr. Rinfret's first visit to the state capital since he accepted the Republican nomination two weeks ago. He was offered the nomination after at least 19 other potential candidates turned it down.

HEADLINE: Provost From Michigan Named to Head M.I.T.

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, June 12

 BODY:
Charles M. Vest, the provost of the University of Michigan and a former dean of engineering there, has been selected to be the new president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, school officials announced today.
Dr. Vest's selection, by the executive committee of M.I.T.'s governing board, ends an unusually difficult search process that began a year ago when Paul E. Gray announced that he would step down as president at the end of this month.
Two men initially considered the leading candidates, John Deutch, M.I.T.'s provost, and David Baltimore, a Nobel prize-winning biologist, both took themselves out of the running. In February, another distinguished biologist at M.I.T., Phillip A. Sharp, accepted the presidential nomination, but then stunned the school a week later by changing his mind and saying he preferred to remain a professor. 
Dr. Deutch, a chemist, withdrew his name after opposition surfaced from some professors and students critical of his ties to the military and to private business. He is now considering leaving M.I.T. for a new professorship at Harvard University, officials of both institutions said today. That switch would be a coup for Harvard, whose division of applied sciences has lagged well behind M.I.T., its neighbor down the Charles River.
Dr. Baltimore has accepted the presidency of Rockefeller University.
 
'The Right Choice'
The selection of Dr. Vest, 48 years old, still requires the approval of the full 65-member M.I.T. governing board, which is expected to meet in a special session in Cambridge next Monday, school officials said today.
A spokesman for the University of Michigan said Dr. Vest would have no comment until his confirmation. Dr. Vest has been provost and vice president for academic affairs there for 18 months. He was dean of engineering from 1986 to 1989, and was credited with helping develop a new $100 million industrial technology institute.
''M.I.T. made the right choice,'' said James J. Duderstadt, the president of the University of Michigan. He described Dr. Vest as a man of ''extraordinary vision and depth'' who is also ''very persuasive, with that rare ability to get people to do things by believing they want to do them.''
Dr. Duderstadt predicted that as president of M.I.T. Dr. Vest would emerge as a ''national spokesman for science and industry.'' He noted that Dr. Vest had developed close relations with leaders in both the automobile and aerospace industries.
Dr. Vest is one of a number of university presidents to come from the University of Michigan in the past few years. Harold Shapiro, who became president of Princeton University in 1988, had been president and before that provost at Michigan, and Linda Wilson was picked as president of Radcliffe College last year after being a vice president at Michigan.
 
'He Filled the Template'
Robert Solow, a Nobel laureate in economics and head of the M.I.T. faculty committee that helped pick a new president, said Dr. Vest was chosen because ''he filled the template of what an M.I.T. president should look like.''
Dr. Solow noted that Dr. Vest was both an engineer by training, which fits one of M.I.T.'s traditional strengths, and an experienced administrator. Michigan has 35,000 students, while M.I.T. has 10,000.
''I thought he was a reflective and thoughtful person with very broad academic sympathies, not just for engineering but for the humanities, social sciences and hard sciences,'' Dr. Solow said.
Dr. Vest has no previous connection with M.I.T., having received a bachelor's degree in mechanical engineering from West Virginia University and master's and Ph.D. degrees in mechanical engineering from the University of Michigan. Of M.I.T.'s 14 presidents, only three have had M.I.T. degrees, and six had no previous ties to the university either as students or as faculty members.
Dr. Vest is a specialist in three-dimensional imaging and image reconstruction, and has written a standard textbook, ''Holographic Interferometry.''
His experience with the manufacturing sector was also a factor in his selection, said Dr. Solow, because M.I.T. has taken an increasing interest in examining reasons for the decline in competitiveness of American industry.

HEADLINE: Home Economics Lives On

 BODY:
To The Living Section:
Marian Burros's point in her Eating Well column of May 9 [''Good health habits can reduce risks of hazards in food''] is timely and certainly important. However, Ms. Burros is erroneous in her comment about home-economics classes, which she claims ''appear to have gone to the way of automobile fins.'' 
Home-economics classes - which do indeed teach, among other vital information, rules of hygiene - are mandated in New York State at the junior high school level. They are alive and well in many high schools throughout the state, especially in New York City and on Long Island. In fact, students are able to major in home economics at the high school level and graduate not only with a Regents sequence and a diploma, but an immediately marketable skill.
Home economics offers not only the traditional foods-and-nutrition and clothing-and-textiles courses, but also majors in human development and family studies and in housing and environment. It is sad that a discipline as vital, timely and necessary as home economics is not recognized for the valuable function it can play in the overall education of the young person and thus is considered extinct by people who should know better.
 
MARILYN F. CHIARAMONTE
District Supervisor of Home Economics
Baldwin (L.I.) Public Schools

HEADLINE: THE PURPOSEFUL COOK;
When the Weather Gets Hot, The Hot Decide to Make

BYLINE: By JACQUES PEPIN

 BODY:
THE question often arises by midafternoon at our house: ''What are we cooking for dinner?'' Sometimes my wife, Gloria, decides; sometimes I do. But when neither of us feels like eating much, and this happens often in hot weather, we usually end up with pasta. It is quick, easy, economical and always welcome.
Although we like pasta with fish and shellfish as well as meat, more often than not we eat it with herbs or vegetables. A refreshing all-vegetable menu is ideal hot-weather fare. Fresh vegetables and fruit are at their best, available in all markets and reasonably priced now.
If prepared in the winter, spaghetti with pesto would be quite costly, since it requires a lot of fresh basil and parsley. But in summer basil and parsley are free, if you have a garden of your own, and inexpensive to buy if you don't. I use a pound of spaghetti for six servings here, enough for a first course. To serve this as a main course, double the amount. 
This is also the time of year when zucchini is regularly featured at our table. One day we might have a salad of zucchini, another day fried zucchini sticks, sauteed zucchini with garlic, ratatouille with tomatoes, eggplant and zucchini, or the zucchini boats with herb stuffing that are part of the accompanying menu.
Stuffed zucchini can be served cold or hot. When cold, sharpen the flavor by garnishing it with additional oil or a little vinaigrette and fresh herbs just before serving; fresh basil, tarragon, parsley or chives are good choices in summer.
Zucchini boats can also be stuffed with a meat mixture. Leftover cooked meat or cold cuts can be chopped and added to the vegetable stuffing to extend it and make it heartier.
The melon dessert is excellent when ripe, juicy, fragrant melon is used. I used a large, heavy, yellowish (rather than green) cantaloupe with a pleasantly fruity smell. You can substitute honeydew or muskmelon for the cantaloupe. The most important requirement is ripeness; if you cannot find a ripe melon, use fresh, ripe peaches or plums instead. It is best to prepare this dessert ahead and let the fruit macerate in the sauce for a few hours in the refrigerator.
With this summer menu, I suggest a cold, flavorful white wine like a riesling from Alsace or a California sauvignon blanc.
 
The Season's Bounty in Three Dishes
 
Zucchini Boats With Herb Stuffing
Preparation time: 45 minutes
Cooking time: 1 hour 15 minutes
 
6 zucchini of equal size, about 3 pounds
2 tablespoons virgin olive oil, plus 2 to 3 tablespoons for garnish
1 1/2 cups coarsely chopped onions
1 tablespoon chopped garlic
 1/2 cup minced scallions
5 cups 1-inch cubes leftover bread
1 cup milk
 1/2 cup chopped herbs (chives, parsley or basil or a mixture of these) plus extra for garnish
 1/2 cup grated Parmesan cheese
 1/8 to 1/4 teaspoon cayenne pepper
2 eggs
1 teaspoon salt
 1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper
Red-wine venegar for garnish (optional).
1.Wash zucchini, trim ends and cut in half lengthwise. Using a metal measuring tablespoon with sharp edges, hollow out the inside of the zucchini; remove most of the seeds and a little of the flesh so that the remaining hollows have a shell about 1/4-inch thick. There should be about 4 cups of flesh and seeds. Chop coarsely into 1/2-inch pieces and set aside.
2.Heat 2 tablespoons oil in a skillet. When hot, add onions and saute for 4 to 5 minutes over medium-to-high heat. Add garlic, scallions and reserved zucchini flesh and saute for 10 to 15 seconds. Then cover and cook for 5 minutes over medium-to-high heat, until mixture is soft. Set aside.
3.Preheat oven to 375 degrees.
4.Add bread to milk and mix until most of the milk has been absorbed by the bread. Crush mixture to create a paste and add to it the chopped herbs, Parmesan cheese, cayenne, eggs, 1/2 teaspoon of the salt and pepper. Mix well and add reserved zucchini mixture.
5.Arrange zucchini boats in a large roasting pan and sprinkle with remaining 1/2 teaspoon of salt. Mound equal portions of stuffing into the boats and place in oven. Cook for 30 to 35 minutes, then place under a hot broiler for 4 to 5 minutes to brown stuffing on top.
6.Serve hot, sprinkled with remaining 2 to 3 tablespoons olive oil, or serve at room temperature, sprinkled with olive oil and additional herbs. If you prefer a more pungent taste, sprinkle a little vinegar on top before serving.
Yield: 6 servings.
 
Spaghetti With Pesto
 
Preparation time: 12 to 15 minutes
Cooking time: 10 minutes
 
3 to 4 quarts water
 
For the pesto:
 
 1/4 cup grated Parmesan cheese
 1/4 cup walnuts or pecans
5 cloves garlic, peeled
1 small jalapeno pepper, cut in half and seeded (optional)
1 cup parsley leaves (tightly packed)
2 cups basil leaves (moderately well packed)
 1/2 cup virgin olive oil
 
For the pasta:
 
1 pound thin spaghetti (No. 4)
1 1/2 teaspoons salt
Freshly ground black pepper to taste
Hot pepper flakes (optional)
Grated Parmesan cheese, for garnish.
1.Bring water to a boil in a pot. Meanwhile, to make the pesto, place Parmesan cheese, nuts, garlic and jalapeno pepper, if desired, in bowl of a food processor and process for about 30 seconds. Add parsley, basil and oil, and pulse a few times to mix the greens into the oil. Process for about 30 seconds, until the mixture is finely pureed. Yield should be about a cup. Set aside.
2.Add spaghetti and 1 teaspoon of the salt to the boiling water a few minutes before serving. Return to a boil and boil over high heat for 8 to 9 minutes until slightly al dente or as preferred. Using a measuring cup, remove a cup of the cooking liquid.
3.In a large bowl, mix reserved cooking liquid with pesto mixture. Drain pasta and add it to the sauce with the remaining salt and black pepper. Toss and serve immediately with hot pepper flakes, if desired, and grated Parmesan cheese.
Yield: 6 servings.
 
Melon With Orange and Rum
 
Preparation time: 10 minutes plus time for refrigeration
 
1 large ripe cantaloupe, honeydew or muskmelon (about 3 pounds)
 1/4 cup honey
 1/2 cup orange juice
3 tablespoons dark rum.
1.Cut melon in half and remove seeds. Cut each half into 4 wedges. Remove flesh from skin and cut each flesh slice into 5 pieces. There should be about 4 cups of melon pieces, each about 1 1/2 inches square.
2.In a bowl, combine honey, orange juice and rum. Add melon pieces and toss well to mix thoroughly. Cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate until serving time.
Yield: 6 servings.
 
 
Summer Refreshment
 
Spaghetti With Pesto
Zucchini Boats With Herb Stuffing
Melon With Orange And Rum
 
 
Special Tip
WHEN making a pasta dish, many cooks wait until they have finished preparing the sauce before putting water on to boil for the pasta, even though it usually takes longer to bring the water to a boil than it does to make the sauce. Remember to put the pot of water on to boil when you begin making the sauce.
You can double or triple the pesto recipe here. It will keep for up to a week in the refrigerator and is very good over grilled fish or meat, as a delicious and healthful flavoring (instead of butter or sour cream) for baked potatoes, or as a topping for other pastas.
Be sure to cover the pesto with a piece of plastic wrap that touches the surface of the pesto. This will prevent it from discoloring excessively; there will still be some darkening on top, but this can be stirred into the pesto before serving.

HEADLINE: Book Notes

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell

 BODY:

A Doubleday Closing
An important chapter in New York bookselling history will end at 6 P.M. Saturday when the Doubleday Book Shop at 673 Fifth Avenue, at 53d Street, closes for good after 22 years in that location.
Doubleday's flagship store, at 724 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, remains open, continuing a tradition of at least one Doubleday book store on Fifth Avenue dating to April 1916. There are also Doubleday stores at Citicorp Center, at East 53d Street, the South Street Seaport and at 777 Third Avenue, at 49th Street.
But the store that will close was special. ''It was strong in books on the performing arts and architecture, and we did a spectacular business in fiction and mysteries,'' Gary P. DelVecchio, the president of Doubleday Book Shops, said. ''It was the store with most of our account customers, and it attracted more New Yorkers and out-of-towners than our other stores.'' 
Until a few years ago, its record department carried a large collection of show tunes and jazz albums, but declining sales forced that department to close.
''The combination of the fall-off in traffic, the increased rent and the fact that the store needed to be modernized made it impractical to keep it open,'' Mr. DelVecchio said. In fact, Doubleday Book Shops - now owned by the B.D.B. Corporation, which also owns Barnes & Noble and B. Dalton - planned to close the store two years ago, when its 20-year lease expired. It even put signs in the window to that effect, but at the last minute the lease was extended the lease for two years. This time, however, the closing is irrevocable.
 
Eastern Europe Pays
It is only a footnote to the East European story, but Hungary and Czechoslovakia have recently begun to pay royalties on at least some foreign literary properties, including those of John Steinbeck.
''It just started last month,'' Elaine Steinbeck, the author's widow, said this week. ''From Hungary I'm getting royalties for book sales and for the stage production 'Of Mice and Men,' and from Czechoslovakia I'm getting book royalties.''
What is important about the royalty payments, Mrs. Steinbeck said, is that ''they're a good sign of improving economic conditions in those countries.''
The Steinbeck estate - the author died in 1968 - used to receive royalties from Poland, Mrs. Steinbeck said, but those stopped several years ago. The Soviet Union never paid royalties despite the immense popularity of ''The Grapes of Wrath'' and other Steinbeck novels. ''They said their contracts with John were signed before they joined the international copyright convention,'' Mrs. Steinbeck said. But there have been recent inquiries from the Soviet Union about producing the stage version of ''The Grapes of Wrath.'' That adaptation won a Tony Award this month as the best play, and the novel, published more than 50 years ago, has been translated into 40 languages and still sells throughout the world.
Speaking about ''Of Mice and Men,'' Mrs. Steinbeck said: ''The sun never sets on that play. It plays somewhere in the world all the time.'' The best version she has seen was in Paris in 1975. ''I didn't think they had a clue about California or ranching,'' Mrs. Steinbeck said, ''but they played those characters exactly as John wrote them.''
 
Return of Thurber
In September, Donald I. Fine Inc. will reissue two books by James Thurber, ''The Thirteen Clocks'' and ''The Wonderful O,'' books originally published in 1950 and 1957.
''Part of the deal with the Thurber estate,'' David Gibbons, the associate editor, said, ''was that we had to do facsimiles, and any changes had to be approved by the estate and the original illustrator.''
Even after all those years, the illustrator, Marc Simont, still had the original art except for the cover of ''Clocks,'' and he did a new illustration for that. The Thurber estate approved, and the the Book-of-the-Month Club bought 5,000 copies of both titles.
 
Medical Ethics
Do terminally ill patients have a right to kill themselves? The debate is finding its way into books.
''Convictions,'' a posthumous collection of essays by Sidney Hook, to be published by Prometheus Books on June 29, includes an essay advocating legalizing voluntary euthanasia. And euthanasia and many other ethical questions are addressed in ''Ethics at the Bedside,'' edited by Charles M. Culver, a Dartmouth College book scheduled for publication in October. The essays are written by doctors, philosophers, theologians and a legal expert, all medical ethics consultants.

MARKETS
 
A panel created to restore investor confidence after last October's stock plunge recommended that the Government require most financial markets to close for as much as a full day at times of great volatility. But the panel recommended only minor curbs on computerized program trading. [Page A1.] 
 
Stocks soared in the last hour, with the Dow adding 40.85, to 2,933.42, just shy of its record high of 2,935.19. [D10.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities dipped slightly in lifeless trading, as credit market participants marked time. [D17.]
 
The dollar ended mixed as the soaring British pound attracted the most attention. [D16.] Gasoline futures soared, erasing the steep losses from the three previous trading sessions. [D16.]

The ''one share one vote'' requirement was thrown out by a Federal appeals court. The three-judge panel said the S.E.C., which imposed the rule in 1988, had exceeded its authority and improperly extended its reach into corporate affairs. [D1.]
