HEADLINE: Chrysler-Renault Project Is Ended

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 12

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation, which has lost several top executives in recent weeks, suffered another big disappointment today as an international joint venture with Renault, the French auto maker, fell apart.
Chrysler and Renault announced that they had jointly decided not to cooperate on a $500 million project to build a mini-Jeep to compete with the Suzuki Motor Company's Sidekick and Samurai and the General Motors Corporation's Geo Tracker. The vehicle would have been sold in Europe and the United States.
The two companies had considered assembling the vehicle in the United States and Europe and sharing the cost equally. Although no manufacturing site had been chosen in the United States, the partners announced in February, a year after the preliminary pact was signed, that they would build the vehicles at a vacant Renault plant in Valladolid, Spain, about 100 miles north of Madrid. 
Chrysler declined to elaborate on the reasons for the termination except to say that both sides believed it ''is no longer economically attractive.'' Chrysler said a distribution agreement under which Renault sells Jeep vehicles in Europe would not be affected.
A spokeswoman for Renault confirmed that a study by the two companies had concluded that an alliance was ''not feasible.''
It was not clear whether Renault's increasing involvement with Volvo A.B., the Swedish auto maker, affected the decision to drop the mini-Jeep project. Since the agreement with Chrysler was made, Renault and Volvo have agreed to a large-scale joint venture to build trucks in Europe.
Chrysler said it plans to continue with the project, code-named JJ for ''junior Jeep,'' and ''is reviewing various implementation alternatives,'' including a different partner. Chrysler has been negotiating with union and city officials in Toledo, Ohio, where it operates an assembly plant for full-size Jeeps, to build mini-Jeeps.
Chrysler and Renault had originally talked of starting production of the mini-Jeeps in 1992.
For Chrysler, pressing on alone with the project would be likely to raise the company's capital costs significantly at a time when the No. 3 auto maker's financial resources are already stretched. The company's sales have been soft and its market share in the United States has declined in the last year.
The company has also been jolted by a series of executive changes. Two weeks ago, Gerald Greenwald, vice chairman and heir apparent to Lee A. Iacocca, the company chairman, announced his resignation. The departure of Mr. Greenwald, who left to run UAL Inc., the parent of United Airlines, followed the defection of a vice president in charge of international business and the resignation of Chrysler's treasurer.
And on Monday, Bennett E. Bidwell, the chairman of Chrysler's automotive subsidiary, confirmed that he would retire at the end of the year for health reasons.
After Mr. Greenwald's announcement, Mr. Iacocca told Chrysler's board that he would stay on as chairman indefinitely and would begin working on a succession plan. His current management contract expires at the end of 1991.
Like its competitors, Chrysler has tried in the last two years to build a presence in Europe to balance its heavy reliance on the United States auto market. The Ford Motor Company and G.M. have recently had trouble making a profit in their United States operations, but have managed to balance those results with strong earnings in Europe.
Chrysler sold off its European operations more than a decade ago to raise cash. But it has an agreement with Steyr-Daimler-Puch A.G. to build mini-vans in Graz, Austria, beginning in 1991.
When Chrysler first announced the venture with Renault, Mr. Iacocca projected eventual sales of 100,000 mini-Jeeps a year in the United States and 50,000 in Europe.
''It's a wild car,'' Mr. Iacocca had said when the joint venture was first announced. ''It's a youth-oriented vehicle that will have appeal in many countries. Russian kids will like this, too.''
At the time, Mr. Iacocca had said the vehicle would be assembled using an innovative manufacturing technique, but he had declined to elaborate. Today, a spokesman said Chrysler is aiming to have its suppliers assemble parts into large subassemblies, which Chrysler workers would put together to create a whole vehicle. This modular-assembly process would require far fewer workers, perhaps as few as 300, compared with a few thousand in a conventional assembly plant, a spokesman said.
But so far, the sales of competitive vehicles suggest that the entire mini-Jeep market might not be as big as Chrysler had projected. ''Chrysler's goal of selling 100,000 was way too ambitious,'' said Christopher Cedergren of J. D. Power & Associates, a market research firm. ''The mini sport utility market is pretty dead right now.
''Most of the vehicles - the Suzuki Samurai, Geo Tracker and Suzuki Sidekick - are not suitable as a primary means of transportation. Even young people are reluctant to buy them for their primary car, because they're not very comfortable for long periods of time.''
Two years ago, the Suzuki Samurai was branded as unsafe by Consumer Reports magazine, a contention that Suzuki denied, and sales of the Samurai fell sharply. Since then, Suzuki and G.M. have teamed to build similar vehicles, the Sidekick and Tracker, that the companies say are inherently more stable than the Samurai because of their dimensions.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Unusual View On Interest Rates

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:
THE good news, say Robert J. Barro of Harvard University and Xavier Sala i Martin of Yale University, is that high interest rates are not bad for the economy. The even better news, say the two economists, is that the size of the Federal deficit doesn't matter.
Two surprising conclusions. According to conventional wisdom, high rates limit growth, slow investment, put a brake on economic activity and can lead to a recession. Today's high rates have already led to protests by home builders, who have seen sales fall, and to rumors of a rift between the Bush Administration and the Federal Reserve over interest-rate policy. 
The conventional wisdom also says that when the Federal Government borrows to finance the deficit or bail out savings and loan institutions, it competes for scarce capital in the domestic markets and drives rates up.
But if Professors Barro and Sala i Martin are right, the conventional wisdom is wrong.
Professors Barro and Sala i Martin have constructed an ingenious model that uses economic and financial data from the 10 major industrialized countries going back as far as 1952. The model simulates the effect of business activity on interest rates, adjusted for inflation, through a series of elaborate equations. The two economists constructed a world index of interest rates for the 10 countries they studied. With their model, they say they can forecast future real interest rates, which are defined as nominal rates less inflation.
The first conclusion from their continuing research, presented as a working paper, is that ''high real rates of interest reflect increased rather than diminished business opportunities,'' Professor Barro said. The conventional wisdom is that high rates slow business activity by making it more expensive to invest.
Their second finding is that American rates are strongly influenced by business conditions in the other countries surveyed and not just by domestic factors like the savings rate and Government borrowing. Interest rates in the United States seem especially sensitive to what is going on in the world's stock markets.
As the two scholars see things, the chain of logic runs as follows: good business conditions lead to higher stock market prices as investors looking for profit opportunities eagerly bid up stocks. And those higher prices suck in money from the rest of the economy. Interest rates go up as the demand for funds increases.
And the process goes on beyond national borders. Opportunities in one country influence rates in the next. ''Rising stock markets abroad mean rising interest rates in the United States,'' Professor Barro said. ''We were quite excited when we found this out.'' The two economists forecast an average interest rate of 5.5 percent, adjusted for inflation, in most of the industrialized world this year, falling to 4.7 percent by mid-decade as growth slows.
While Professors Barro and Sala i Martin generally see rising rates as a vigorous competition for investment funds and thus a sign of health, they concede that at some point high interest rates can choke off investment and lead to a recession. But that happens, Professor Barro said, ''when interest rates go up as a result of tight monetary policy.'' During the 1982 recession, for example, rates climbed ''because the Fed kept money tight.''
The two professors put little faith in low interest rates as a spur to growth. They say this should be clear from looking at recent events. In the 1970's, interest rates were very low because they were reflective of sluggish economic activity, a low stock market and little investment opportunity, they say. When rates picked up, later in the decade, it was because business activity also picked up.
What these findings mean for policy makers is that it would be a mistake to conclude that rising rates are bad for growth.
''Today's average real interest rate for the 10 countries we studied is the highest we have seen since the 1920's,'' Professor Barro said. But these high rates have been accompanied by a ''significant rise in investment in the 10 countries we studied, to levels not seen since the late 1960's. That's very bullish for growth.''
The model has been criticized because it is still only a preliminary effort and because it ''overstates how much economists really know about what moves interest rates,'' said Robert E. Lucas Jr., a professor of economics at the University of Chicago. ''Everyone knows that sometimes the stock and bond markets move in the same direction and that there appears to be a link,'' he said. ''But sometimes they don't.'' Professor Barro concedes that his efforts are still preliminary, but contends that the model has advanced economists' understanding of what moves rates. ''I'm going out on a limb, but I think we have found predictors of future rates,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Foreign Investors Held $2 Trillion in U.S. in '89

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12

 BODY:
Foreign investment in the United States rose to a record total of $2 trillion in 1989, up 12 percent from $1.786 trillion in 1988, according to preliminary statistics released today by the Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis.
About a third of the $214.6 billion increase, or $72 billion, was in direct investments. These include foreign spending on factories, real estate, corporate takeovers and ownership of 10 percent or more of an American company. 
The remaining two-thirds of the increase in foreign holdings came from so-called portfolio investments, which include purchases of American corporate securities and Government bonds. Foreign investment now plays a very large role in financing the huge Federal budget deficit.
 
Fourfold Increase
Since 1980, foreign investment in the United States has increased fourfold, the report noted.
''Until the budget and trade deficits are brought under control, the U.S. will continue to rely on foreign capital,'' said Elliot L. Richardson, chairman of the Association for International Investment, which represents foreign investors.
Brad Larschan, a spokesman for the group, warned that today's report could ''exacerbate concern about foreign investment in the Congress and with the public generally.''
Three bills pending in Congress, including one proposed by the Bush Administration, would increase Government surveillance of foreign investments.
A recent report by the General Accounting Office has raised questions about the effect of foreign investment on national security. ''The basic question, as many have posed it, is whether the U.S. defense industrial base is being gradually 'hollowed out' as foreign investment takes place,'' the report said.
Supporters of foreign investment say that it provides the money needed to finance the deficit and support the stock market and that it provides jobs, management skills and technology. They say the ability of the United States to attract foreign investment reflects its strength in the global economy and improves Americans' understanding of foreign cultures.
Critics contend that the United States has become overly dependent on foreign capital, which could lead to an erosion of political and economic independence as decisions affecting Americans are increasingly made abroad. In addition, they say some foreign investors buy American companies to acquire their technology and damage their competitors.
Pat Choate, a vice president of the military contractor TRW Inc. and a leading critic of foreign investment, said the report showed that ''bit by bit we're surrendering control of our economy.''
While foreign direct investment increased by 22 percent in 1989, according to an analysis of the Commerce Department data by the Association for International Investment, American investments abroad increased by 9.7 percent, or $31.7 billion, raising its value to $358.6 billion.
 
British Remain in the Lead
The British continued to be the largest direct investors in America, with the Japanese remaining in second place. They were followed by the Dutch, Canadians, West Germans and French.
British investment increased by $20.2 billion, or nearly 20 percent, for a total of $122.1 billion, accounting for 30.5 percent of all direct foreign investment in the United States, according to the analysis of the Commerce Department data by Mr. Richardson's organization.
Japanese investment increased by $17.3 billion, or 32.4 percent, for a total of $70.6 billion, or 17.6 percent of all foreign direct investment.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
ITT Reducing Its Stake in Alcatel

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The ITT Corporation said yesterday that it would sell 7 percent of Alcatel N.V. for $640 million.
The sale to France's Compagnie Generale d'Electricite will reduce ITT's ownership in Alcatel, a French telecommunications equipment manufacturer, to 30 percent. That is the level ITT sought to own in the 1986 negotiations on forming the joint venture with Compagnie Generale d'Electricite. To assure completion of the deal, which created the world's biggest maker of telecommunications equipment, ITT had agreed to take a 37 percent stake.
ITT said it would report an after-tax gain of about $139 million on the transaction, which is expected to close on June 14. The gain will be included in ITT's second-quarter earnings, the company said.
Shares of ITT rose $3.25 yesterday, to $60.625, on the New York Stock Exchange, ITT said proceeds would be used to buy additional shares of its common stock under the company's stock repurchase program, which began in 1987.
Rand V. Araskog, ITT's chairman and chief executive and also chairman of Alcatel's supervisory board, said ITT's investment in Alcatel has grown since the venture began.
''Our Alcatel shares have more than doubled in value in three years and our board of directors is pleased not only with this outstanding appreciation of our investment, but also with the positive working relationship developed between ITT and C.G.E.,'' he said.
Alcatel's growth has been spurred by economic development within the European Community and Eastern Europe. The creation of a single European marketplace in 1992 is expected to increase demand for Alcatel equipment.
ITT, based in New York, is primarily involved in the telecommunications field.

HEADLINE: Current Account Deficit Is Lowest in Six Years

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12

 BODY:
The deficit in the broadest measure of United States trade shrank to $22.94 billion from January through March, the lowest quarterly imbalance in six years, the Commerce Department reported today.
The current account trade deficit narrowed by 14 percent in the first three months of the year, compared with a $26.69 billion deficit in the final three months of 1989.
The improvement was credited to a record level of sales of American products overseas, which helped to reduce the merchandise trade deficit. 
Domestic earnings on overseas investments and payments by foreigners for services like travel and tourism also played a part in reducing the current account imbalance.
 
Smallest Since 1984 Quarter
The first-quarter deficit was the smallest quarterly trade gap since a $20.5 billion deficit in the first quarter of 1984.
The current account, also known as the balance of payments, is the most closely watched trade statistic because it measures trade not only in merchandise but also in services and investments.
Even with the first-quarter improvement, the United States is beginning the new decade in a far different position than it began the 1980's. Ten years ago, the United States was the largest creditor nation. It ran surpluses in its current account as the earnings on overseas investments were enough to offset perennial deficits in merchandise trade.
But as Americans handed over billions of dollars to foreigners in payments for imported cars and television sets, the investment cushion eroded. It disappeared altogether in 1985, when the United States became a net debtor for the first time in 71 years.
 
Loss of Control Seen
That means foreigners now own more in United States assets than Americans own overseas, a development that has led some to say that the country is losing control over its economic destiny.
Today's report indicates that the nation's debtor position has now risen to around $670 billion, although the Government's official account of the gap between American holdings and foreign investments will not be made until later this month.

HEADLINE: Japanese Trade Surplus Down

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 12

 BODY:
Japan's trade surplus declined slightly in May, the 12th month in the last 13 during which the surplus narrowed from a year earlier, the Finance Ministry reported today.
The May surplus of $3.13 billion compared with $3.76 billion in May 1989. Exports fell nine-tenths of 1 percent from a year earlier, to $21.52 billion, while imports grew by 2.4 percent, to $18.38 billion.
Economists said a slowing in the rate of declines in exports indicated that the yen's recent weakness might cause a renewed buildup in the surplus.
They added that slower growth in the domestic economy might be depressing imports. A cheaper yen makes Japanese goods more competitive in price overseas.
''I'm confident that possibly as early as July we could see a widening in Japan's trade surplus,'' said Jesper Koll of S. G. Warburg Securities.
 
In trade with the United
States, Japan's surplus shrank to $2.44 billion in May from $2.76 billion a year earlier.
Japanese companies exported $6.82 billion worth of goods to the United States in May, down 4.5 percent from a year earlier.
Imports from the United States fell by two-tenths of 1 percent, to $4.38 billion.
 
Japan's surplus with the
European Community shrank to $1.2 billion, from $1.63 billion in May 1989.

HEADLINE: Japan Criticized on Trade Progress

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12

 BODY:
The Senate Finance Committee's ranking specialists in trade policy expressed concern today that Japan was not living up to promises to open its economy and warned that Congress ''may have no choice'' but to respond with retaliatory legislation.
They were reacting to reports that progress had stopped in negotiations on the Structural Impediments Initiative with Japan, which calls for more public investment, stiffer anti-monopoly enforcement, streamlined retail distribution and other measures to make the Japanese economy more receptive to imports.
The Senators said in a letter to Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, that Congress was ''very concerned about the state of the U.S.-Japan trade relationship.''
 
Signed by Leaders
The letter was signed by the Democratic chairman of the Finance Committee's Subcommittee on Trade, Max Baucus of Montana, and by the ranking Republicans on both the full committee and trade subcommittee, Bob Packwood of Oregon and John C. Danforth of Missouri. 
The Finance Committee's chairman, Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, issued a separate statement accusing the Japanese of ''stonewalling'' and warning Japan that he and other members of his committee ''will insist that more be done.''
Such harsh statements by members of Congress on trade matters are not unusual, given their sensitivity to the complaints of their business constituents. In recent years, Congress has taken the lead in forging trade policy toward Japan and other countries.
In response to today's comments, the economic minister at Japan's Embassy here, Hiroshi Hirabayashi, insisted that his Government ''is making utmost efforts to put flesh on the bones'' of the sought-after changes under the structural initiative.
''We would hope that Congress, instead of constantly speaking of retaliation and threats of retaliation, would move in more constructive ways for the betterment of the U.S.-Japan relationship,'' he said.
 
Effect on the Deficit
The hope of Congress and Administration officials is that opening Japan to more imports from the United States would help shrink what last year was a $49 billion American trade deficit with Japan, though some experts doubt that the changes would affect the deficit significantly, at least not immediately.
The two Governments produced an interim report last April 5 that seemed to resolve most of the basic issues. But now American negotiators say the talks are not going well.
''The Japanese want the clock to stop after the interim report,'' said a senior American trade official who asked not to be identified. ''Our meetings have come up snake eyes.''
He stressed, however, that the talks had not broken down and that both sides were still scheduled to meet in Tokyo on June 25 to try to conclude a report. But he acknowledged that if the final report did not broaden Japanese commitments and establish specific monitoring mechanisms, it could be a ''big political problem'' for the Bush Administration.
 
A July Deadline
The final report, outlining specifics on government spending, antitrust enforcement and other issues, is supposed to be completed by the time President Bush next sees Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu at the Houston economic summit meeting of seven industrial nations next July 9.
It was on the basis of the broad promises of the interim report, as well as a series of specific market-opening agreements involving supercomputers, satellites and other products, that President Bush on April 27 dropped Japan from a list of countries that could become subject to reprisal tariffs because of unfair trade practices. At that time, many lawmakers said it was premature to ease the pressure on Japan before the final report had been completed.
In their letter, the Senators said that although Japan had repeatedly agreed to work to eliminate its current account surplus, some Japanese Government officials were now arguing that the Japanese surpluses could be sustained indefinitely at very high levels.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Next Challenge for Solar Power: Cheaper Cells

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FREDERICK, Md.

 BODY:
Scientists have been continually improving photovoltaic cells by raising the amount of electricity they produce from a given amount of sunlight. Now, industry experts say, progress in the technology of manufacturing is at least as important as gains in the lab in the struggle to make the cells more competitive in cost with conventional ways of making electricity.
Much of the production, which has a lot in common with the manufacture of computer chips, still takes place in rooms that are not automated and look more like workshops than factories. Costs are high, because the materials must often be applied in many steps, and the components can be contaminated by a fingerprint. 
Automation can solve these problems and reduce costs, but it is difficult to justify for a product with a market that is limited, at least at today's prices. But growing sales volume is encouraging progress. Primarily by using industrial robots, the Solarex Corporation's factory here turns out cells with one-third the manpower of three years ago. Another Solarex plant is automating the complicated task of producing ''thin film'' cells that use less costly materials in small amounts.
 
Studying Ease of Fabrication
Other manufacturers are considering the ease of manufacturing when developing designs for cells. Some are expanding production, and in the process are discovering efficiencies that cut the cost per unit.
Photovoltaic cells use the energy in sunlight to shake loose electrons from atoms of silicon or other materials. The electron, with a negative charge, and the atom that gave it up, with a positive charge, migrate to separate terminals, creating an electric current. The technology, which was born in 1954 and got its first big boost from the space program, has found growing applications in everything from wristwatches and hand-held calculators to remote microwave communications relays and navigation buoys.
But photovoltaic power is still far too expensive to compete with coal or even oil for making electric power in the amounts useful to utilities. Electricity from solar power still costs more than 25 cents a kilowatt-hour; residential customers in the United States pay an average of about 10 cents.
Costs have fallen, however, because the efficiency of the cells - the ratio of the energy deposited as sunlight to the electricity produced -has risen to 28 percent from 6 percent for the first silicon crystal cells. Thin-film cells, a more recent development made by applying to glass small amounts of materials that convert light to electricity, have achieved efficiencies of 15.6 percent in the lab and are competing successfully with crystalline cells because they are cheaper to produce.
In fact, it is production cost, rather than wattage per square foot, that is developing as the key variable, industry officials say.
''You're seeing the focus going from the lab, on being science-driven, to being one where, if we're going to succeed, we're going to be good at manufacturing,'' said John Corsi, the president of Solarex, a subsidiary of the Amoco Corporation of Chicago and the largest American-owned photovoltaic producer.
Indeed, the Bush Administration has proposed a $43 million budget for solar research next year, up from $35.5 million this year and the first increase in eight years. Nearly all of the increase would go into studying the technical roadblocks to multiplying the scale of production, said Scott Sklar, executive director of the Solar Energy Industries Association, in Washington.
''You could probably lower the cost of photovoltaic modules a lot more easily in dealing with the manufacturing approach than in worrying about the efficiencies of the modules,'' Mr. Sklar said.
But Kenneth B. Zweibel, the manager of polycrystalline thin film research at the Solar Energy Research Institute, a Government-supported laboratory near Denver, pointed out that makers do not even agree on the ingredients for the product whose fabrication they are trying to improve. In addition to silicon, in crystals or in an amorphous, non-crystalline state, companies are aggressively researching materials including copper indium diselenide, gallium arsenide and cadmium telluride. All function by having light energy shake loose electrons, but they differ in efficiency and longevity.
The choice of materials can be influenced by problems in manufacturing, said Scott P. Albright, vice president of Photon Energy Inc., a young company in El Paso. Photon is working to bring to market its first cell, made of cadmium telluride. Nearly all of the steps involved are performed at atmospheric pressure, so capital costs are only one-tenth those of amorphous silicon, the dominant thin-film cell, which requires that some steps be conducted in a vacuum, Mr. Albright said.
The cost of fabrication is also the key factor at the Solarex factory here, according to officials. Much work has been done, and continues, on the recipe for making silicon blocks from which the polycrystalline cells are made. But another problem is turning the blocks into wafers.
 
Large Amount of Waste
The old method is to use a saw to slice wafers, one by one, that are 12 mils, or 12-thousandths of an inch, thick. Thinner wafers would work as well, but the saw cannot cut them. Worse, using a saw turns half of the block into a sawdust-like waste.
The company has recently begun to use as a saw a thin steel wire wrapped scores of times around a block, to slice the whole brick simultaneously. It makes wafers that are only 7 to 8 mils thick, with 20 to 25 percent less waste.
The silicon accounts for only 8.5 percent of the cost of the finished cell, but making the technology competitive with oil will mean increasing the efficiency of every step, company officials say.
At another plant, in Newtown, Pa., the company is pursuing another strategy: thin-film cells. Here, materials cost is not really an issue; half the cost is in the ordinary window glass on which the cell is built. But engineers are putting finishing touches on an automated production line that would turn out cells with a capacity of one megawatt a year, with four workers a shift, and have begun assembling parts for a line that would turn out 10 megawatts a year with the same number of workers.
The next step, said Dr. David E. Carlson, a thin-film pioneer who is in charge of the project, is a 100-megawatt line, which would cost only triple the model one-tenth as large. That development might require putting the plant adjacent to a glass factory, to achieve economies of scale.
Even the large plant would be of modest size by the standards of the utility industry; a single large coal plant produces 600 megawatts, and a nuclear reactor may produce 1,100. But the scale is huge by the standards of the photovoltaic industry, for which total worldwide production last year was only about 40 megawatts.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Pound Rises Sharply As the Dollar Ends Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended mixed yesterday as the soaring British pound attracted the most attention, reaching a four-month high against the American currency in European trading.
Gold prices fell after rising overseas.
Currency dealers said dollar trading was slow and in a narrow range in advance of several economic reports scheduled for release later this week. 
The market is hoping that the Government reports on May retail sales, April merchandise trade and May consumer and producer prices, among others, will shed more light on the direction of the United States economy, traders said.
Most of the market's interest yesterday was focused on a rush to buy sterling.
The pound rose against other currencies and reached a four-month high against the dollar in Europe on reports that Britain plans full membership in the European Monetary System within a year.
The Financial Times reported yesterday that Treasury officials expect Britain's underlying annual inflation rate to be low enough toward the end of the year to include the pound in the monetary system.
Sterling traded at $1.7020 in London, up from $1.6858 late Monday, and at $1.7035 in New York, up from $1.6860.
Against the Japanese currency, the dollar slipped in New York to 154.55 yen, from 154.77 late Monday. Earlier in Tokyo, where the global trading day begins, the dollar rose 0.30 yen to a closing 154.40 yen. It was quoted at 154.44 yen in London.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's quotes, included: 1.6965 West German marks, up from 1.6927; 1.4382 Swiss francs, down from 1.4430; 5.7090 French francs, up from 5.6965; 1,245 Italian lire, up from 1,243.25, and 1.17255 Canadian dollars, up from 1.17095.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $355.70 an ounce, down 70 cents from late Monday. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid for gold at $354.70 an ounce, off 40 cents.
Silver prices strengthened. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.018 a troy ounce, up from $5.012 Monday. Silver rose in London to $5.06 an ounce from $5.01.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
New Sports Complex for Cleveland

BYLINE: By Jennifer Stoffel

DATELINE: CLEVELAND

 BODY:
THIS city is moving ahead with an ambitious plan to have its new baseball stadium and basketball arena ready for the 1994 season, after voters approved an excise tax to help finance the downtown sports complex.
To be constructed on a 28-acre site a few blocks from Public Square, Cleveland's center, the new Gateway complex is expected to encourage downtown redevelopment and extend the urban center south to the main highway exits, an area long considered urban fringe.
The complex is expected to draw an additional two million people downtown each year and increase the city's attractiveness as a convention center. 
''Back in 1980, we identified the area as the most visible gateway to the city and we asked if this is so important, why does it look so bad?'' said Hunter Morrison, Cleveland's planning director. ''It sets a bad impression of the city.''
The Gateway project will have a $128 million open-air stadium for the Cleveland Indians. The 45,000-seat baseball stadium will be expandable to 72,000 seats for football games. The project will also have a $75 million 20,000-seat indoor arena for the Cleveland Cavaliers basketball team. It will be used for hockey games as well.
As part of a long-term effort to redevelop the southern edge of downtown, an additional $35 million will be spent to acquire property surrounding the complex. Preliminary proposals for the site include office, retail and hotel development.
The development and operation of the project will be managed by the Gateway Corporation, a nonprofit company.
The push for a new stadium, which began in the mid-1980's, has been readily embraced by business executives interested in creating a more profitable city center. But it has been more difficult to sell the project to the public. A 1984 referendum to raise property taxes to help finance a plan for a domed stadium was defeated by a 2-to-1 margin.
On May 8, however, voters in Cleveland and the rest of Cuyahoga County approved by a narrow margin a new excise tax on cigarettes and alcohol that is expected to raise $150 million over the next 15 years. Additional money for the sports complex will be raised from the sales of luxury seating.
Local investors have also promised up to $20 million through a development partnership backed by Cleveland Tommorrow, a business group. The Gateway Corporation has until the end of the year to have the financing in place in order to meet a Federal deadline for tax-exempt bonds.
For its part, the State of Ohio gave its support with a $4 million loan granted in 1985 to help buy the land. The site was assembled over two years by the Greater Cleveland Domed Stadium Corporation, which has since gone out of business. Demolition of selected buildings began in 1987; much of the site is currently used for parking lots.
While owners of the Indians and the Cavaliers have both agreed to negotiate 20-year leases with the Gateway Corporation, no terms have yet been reached. And the long-term fate of the 59-year-old lakefront Municipal Stadium, current home of the Cleveland Indians and Browns, is still uncertain.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
MOSCOW LOOSENS ECONOMIC SANCTION AGAINST LITHUANIA

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 13

 BODY:
The Soviet Government eased one of its economic sanctions against Lithuania today as an encouragement for negotiations to begin over the rebellious republic's attempt to thrive independent of Moscow.
The Kremlin move, announced at a meeting with Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene of Lithuania, amounted to a relatively modest increase in fuel for a single fertilizer factory in the republic.
But it was important as a gesture of the Gorbachev Government's eagerness to back down from the three-month sovereignty crisis and negotiate a solution. [In Washington, the United States hailed Moscow's reported decision to ease its economic sanctions against Lithuania, and President Bush called President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's talks with Baltic leaders a ''significant change'' that could help end the Baltic crisis. Page A18.] Restoring Some Faith Mrs. Prunskiene held exploratory talks with a Soviet delegation led by Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, who announced the slight easing in the fuel embargo. Later she said, ''This meeting allowed us to have more faith in one another. It is very obvious they do want negotiations to begin.'' 
She emphasized, however, that the Lithuanian Government would have to settle the basic question of whether it might suspend or ease some of its independence measures, a conciliatory step the Kremlin wants as a condition for ending the sanctions and starting full-scale negotiations on the future relations between the republic and the central Government.
 
Pledge to Double Supply
Mr. Ryzhkov promised to double the limited amount of natural gas that is being piped to the Lithuanian fertilizer factory at Jonava, Lithuanian officials said. The increase of 3.5 million cubic meters of gas would raise the plant to 30 percent of capacity, a spokeswoman for the Lithuanian Government said, and would put about 1,600 plant employees back to work.
Mr. Ryzhkov said he had told Mrs. Prunskiene that ''great opportunities'' will open if they accept the idea of ''freezing'' the independence resolutions ''not to annul them'' but to get negotiations under way.
''There has been progress,'' he said. ''We have made our step, now it's up to them to make theirs.''
In Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital, President Vytautas Landsbergis also reacted with optimism, telling Lithuania's Parliament that his conversation in Moscow on Tuesday with Mr. Gorbachev had been ''concrete, constructive and, I should say, even friendly.''
''This can be regarded as a good sign showing an obvious desire to solve the problem, not to make us yield to the one who is stronger but to find a way out acceptable to both sides,'' he said, adding that the Soviet Government seemed interested in ending the economic sanctions ''as soon as possible'' by the two sides taking ''simultaneous steps'' toward each other.
 
Moving Toward a Solution
The mood about the sovereignty crisis has shifted in recent days, with President Gorbachev laying out new terms to invite negotiations and Lithuanian officials offering indications, in turn, that they expected an end soon to the economic sanctions and progress toward some sort of compromise.
But this was not the outcome of the one-hour-forty-five-minute meeting at the Kremlin. Mrs. Prunskiene said the next step would be to present Mr. Gorbachev's latest proposals to the Lithuanian Council of Ministers on Saturday, and eventually take them up in the republic's parliament and craft counter proposals for the Kremlin.
Rita Dapkus, a Lithuanian spokeswoman, quoted the Prime Minister as saying after the meeting that ''now we are pretty clear on the position the Soviet Government takes, which makes it much easier for us to know where we go from here.''
Most recently Mr. Gorbachev has talked of a new Soviet federation that would treat all Soviet republics as ''sovereign states'' with considerable control over their own affairs. He has seemed amenable to Lithuania's latest offer to place a moratorium during a period of negotiations on all actions taken since its declaration of independence, made March 11.
 
One Concrete Promise
In initially trying to contain the sovereignty movement that is sweeping through the Soviet republics, Mr. Gorbachev reacted to Lithuania's declaration of independence by imposing economic sanctions including a tough but not complete fuel blockade and embargoes on a few other commodities, resulting in closings at many factories in the republic of 3.4 million people and widespread hardships like gas shortages.
In the talks today, the Lithuanian Prime Minister had brought up the possibility of easing the embargo on crude oil supplies to the republic, her office said after the meeting. But Prime Minister Ryzhkov replied that subject was much larger and no decision could be made as yet, and instead promised to increase the gas supply to the fertilizer plant.
''That's the only concrete thing he promised,'' Mrs. Prunskiene said after the meeting, according to her office.
Her office could not immediately confirm reports in the Soviet press that she had enthusiastically declared after the meeting that the supply embargo would be eased for several other Lithuanian enterprises.
Interfax, a quasi-independent Soviet press agency, quoted the Lithuanian Prime Minister as saying of the Soviet Government after the meeting: ''We do not doubt that it is ready to lift the economic blockade. This was said very concretely, so we have the opportunity to act and open contacts with the Government.''
Her office said one ''model'' of the future outlined in the Soviet proposals was that of taking part with ''special status'' in a new future Soviet federation. Her office said she thought this model could not immediately be discussed because the republic would need to know more about the future look of the Soviet Union, particularly in consideration of the republic's determination to set up trade and travel contacts with the West.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: June 14, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 17, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 656 words

HEADLINE: BONN WELCOMES NEW SOVIET SHIFT

BYLINE: By FERDINAND PROTZMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, June 13

 BODY:
West German officials today welcomed as ''fundamentally positive'' President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's latest remarks on Germany, describing them as a softening of the Soviet position on a unified Germany's status but again rejecting the suggestion of dual alliance membership.
Mr. Gorbachev, speaking to the Soviet Parliament on Tuesday in Moscow, said that after German unification West German troops could remain in NATO without a corresponding role for the East Germans in the Warsaw Pact, and suggested that East Germany retain a vaguely defined ''associate membership'' in the Warsaw Pact while it honors all obligations inherited from the two Germanys.
While officials reiterated Bonn's continuing opposition to membership in both organizations, a West German Government official said: ''Mr. Gorbachev's suggestion is not really new, but coming at this time it confirms that the Soviet position remains open and flexible, that we have not heard the last word. While they have shifted their stance a bit over the past few months, it is fundamentally positive that Mr. Gorbachev now views German membership in NATO as possible.'' 
 
New Germany, New Alliances
Still to be worked out, he added, are the conditions of German membership in NATO. ''That will be the focus of the upcoming two-plus-four talks,'' he said, referring to negotiations on German reunification involving East and West Germany, and the four World War II victors: Britain, France, the Soviet Union and the United States.
The Soviet Union and the Western allies are currently at loggerheads over Germany's military affiliation after unification. West Germany is a member of the United States-dominated NATO alliance, while East Germany belongs to the Warsaw Pact and has about 420,000 Soviet troops stationed on its soil.
West Germany, the United States and other major NATO countries want a united Germany to remain in NATO, while the Soviet Union opposes exclusive NATO membership and is seeking the creation of a new ''security order'' in Europe.
 
Preliminary Talks
The ''two-plus-four'' Foreign Ministers are scheduled to meet in East Berlin on June 22. In preparation for that gathering, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany and his Soviet counterpart, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, held talks on reunification on Monday in Brest, in Soviet Byelorussia. The two men will meet again next week.
Mr. Gorbachev's suggestion of German membership in both alliances was immediately rejected by Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany and other Western leaders.
''This is a proposal we do not consider realistic,'' Mr. Kohl said. ''I find that proposal unacceptable because it completely misunderstands the purpose and foundations of NATO.'' President Bush also reiterated that a united Germany must belong to the alliance without conditions.
 
Shifting Soviet Position
A NATO spokesman also dismissed the Soviet proposal for membership in both organizations, saying: ''Among other problems, the ideas of associate membership of a united Germany in both alliances, or of dual membership, do not seem promising to pursue. A united Germany must have the right, recognized in the Helsinki Final Act, to choose to be a party to a treaty of alliance, without the establishment of constraints on its sovereignty.''
Many Western analysts believe the shifting Soviet stance on the question of alliance membership for a unified Germany is primarily meant to extract the best possible terms for the Soviet Union as it relinquishes control over East Germany and Eastern Europe.
Economic assistance from West Germany appears to be one of the main Soviet objectives. The Soviet Union would like assurances that a united Germany will fulfill the long-term contracts that it has signed over the years with East Germany. In addition, it is believed to be pushing for a dramatic increase in West German financial, scientific and technological aid.

LENGTH: 705 words

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
Bush Sees 'Significant Change' in Baltic Standoff

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 13

 BODY:
The United States today hailed Moscow's reported decision to ease its economic sanctions against Lithuania, and President Bush called President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's talks with Baltic leaders a ''significant change'' that could help end the Baltic crisis.
Mr. Bush and other White House officials have avoided commenting on developments in Moscow's test of wills with Lithuania over the Lithuanian declaration of independence. But after two weeks of pressure from Congress on Mr. Bush's decision to sign a new trade agreement with Mr. Gorbachev despite the continued stalemate over Lithuanian independence, the White House welcomed the latest developments in Moscow with a markedly upbeat assessment.
Mr. Bush took a few minutes at the start of a news conference with regional news organizations to read a statement in which he seemed to allude to the political pressures of the Lithuanian stalemate. 
Referring to Mr. Gorbachev's meeting on Tuesday with President Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania, President Anatolijs Gorbunovs of Latvia and President Arnold Ruutel of Estonia, Mr. Bush said, ''I was very, very pleased to see this occur in the wake of what I think was a successful summit meeting.''
 
Push to Upgrade Trade Status
He said: ''We applaud Mr. Gorbachev's meeting with the Baltic Presidents. For some time, we've urged a peaceful resolution of this confrontation, one that will result in dialogue, negotiation if you will, and lifting of this economic blockade against Lithuania. And so I hope that what we saw yesterday is a first step in a dialogue that will lead to the self-determination that we strongly support.''
Mr. Bush spoke before the White House learned of today's reported decision by the Soviet Union to ease slightly its economic sanctions against Lithuania. He refused to answer questions about the report during a subsequent photo session in the Oval Office.
Marlin Fitzwater, the President's spokesman, said: ''We welcome this announcement. Together with the beginning of the dialogue yesterday, these are positive steps.''
But Administration officials were more reserved in private, saying there were conflicting reports about how far Moscow was willing to go to ease its economic sanctions. ''We are not yet willing to say this is the end of the crisis,'' an official said.
Congressional response to the news from Moscow was mixed. Senator George J. Mitchell, the Majority Leader, who has been critical of Mr. Bush's signing of the trade agreement, said he was heartened by news reports from Moscow.
 
'This Smacks of Propaganda'
Senator Max S. Baucus, the Montana Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Finance subcommittee on international trade, which will be the first stop in the Senate for the new trade agreement, said, ''Today's dramatic events make it clear that it is time'' to grant favorable trade treatment to the Soviet Union.
''The President showed great vision in signing a trade agreement with the Soviet Union a few weeks ago,'' he said. ''Now it is time to make good on the commitments in that agreement.''
But Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican who has been one of the most vociferous Congressional critics of Mr. Bush's Lithuania policy, disputed the reports from the Soviet Union.
He said he had been ''pleased and delighted'' at first by news that Moscow would ease its economic blockade of Lithuania. But he said he spoke by telephone with Mr. Landsbergis late in the afternoon and was told that such an agreement ''had not been solidified.''
He said, ''This smacks of propaganda when what we need now is not propaganda from the Soviets, but action.''
 
Pact and Soviet Emigration Law
Administration officials said they hoped movement in the Lithuania stalemate would ease Congressional opposition to the trade agreement, which Mr. Bush said he would not submit until the Soviet Union enacts a new emigration law that is a precondition for broadening trade ties. But they said they had received no assurances from Mr. Gorbachev during his visit to Washington that a breakthrough was imminent.
Indeed, the official said the talks with the Baltic leaders came a little sooner than some American analysts had anticipated.

HEADLINE: Senate Passes Measure to Protect Alaskan Forest

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 13

 BODY:
Seeking to strike a compromise between environmentalists and the timber industry, the Senate overwhelmingly approved legislation today to prohibit logging on 673,000 acres of pristine Alaskan land in the Tongass National Forest.
The bill would also discourage logging in other areas of the forest by modifying contracts with local pulp mills that had allowed them to buy trees at well below market price.
But the Senate measure, approved 99 to 0, did not leave either environmentalists or Alaskan timber industry executives happy. Both sides will be looking anxiously to see what version emerges when lawmakers meet in conference to work out differences between the Senate bill and a House-approved measure that calls for much stronger action to protect the Tongass..
The House bill, approved last year, designated 1.8 million acres of the forest as a wilderness area where no roads or any commercial development, including logging, could be established. The measure would also cancel long-term logging contracts in the Tongass and subject future timber sales to competitive bidding. 
 
Effort to Save Jobs
The Senate bill was devised as a compromise aimed at preserving jobs. It bars logging from a much smaller area, 673,000 acres, and would allow some limited commercial activity like mining.
The Tongass, the largest national forest in the United States, is the last major expanse of temperate rain forest in North America. Protection of the forest, which occupies an area the size of West Virginia, has been a major priority of environmentalists. They argue that it is inconsistent for the United States to criticize Brazil for the destruction of its rain forest while allowing overharvesting of trees from the Tongass.
''We are no longer embarrassed,'' said Senator Tim Wirth, a Colorado Democrat who was a major proponent of the Senate bill. ''Last year I was in Brazil and met with President Jose Sarney, and the first thing he said was, What about the Tongass?''
But the debate did not turn on purely environmental issues. There were also concerns about the loss of jobs in Alaskan cities like Sitka and Ketchikan, whose economies are heavily dependent on logging, and some Alaskan legislators resented what they see as the dictates of outsiders.
''Alaska is an area that's remote and easy to attack,'' said Senator Ted Stevens, Republican of Alaska. ''Any time someone wants to prove they're an environmentalist, they go to Alaska and get another area declared a wilderness.''
Both environmentalists and timber industry officials expressed concern today about what would emerge from the House-Senate conference.
 
Not Jumping for Joy
''To put it bluntly, we're not exactly jumping up and down with joy,'' said Rollo Pool, manager of public relations of the Alaska Pulp Corporation, one of the two mills operating in the region. ''We're not excited with the Senate version and even less excited with the House version. If we had our choice we would have preferred no bill. But, looking at the political realities, that is not a real choice. We have to wait and see if the conference will leave us enough scraps to live on.''
Environmentalists, who strongly supported the House bill, were critical of the Senate version. Bart Koehler, executive director of the Southeast Alaska Conservation Council, said, ''The Senate bill doesn't protect enough lands, doesn't designate them as wilderness, doesn't include as tough a buffer zone provision as the House passed bill, and doesn't terminate the long-term contracts.''
Representative George Miller, a California Democrat who is a chief proponent of the House bill, expressed confidence that most issues could be resolved in conference, but he added, ''It's clear there are going to be difficult decisions.''
The dispute over the Tongass underlines the continuing debate over the extent to which pristine lands should be used for commercial benefit or left in their natural state. It also focuses attention on the policies of the Forest Service, which critics contend has emphasized logging interests in the national forests at the expense of other uses like commercial fishing and tourism.
At the heart of the dispute is the Tongass itself, which at 16.7 million acres occupies about 85 percent of southeastern Alaska. In 1980 Congress designated 5.4 million acres of the forest as wilderness. The Tongass, which has stands of Sitka spruce that are more than 800 years old, provides a home for more than 400 species of wildlife, fish and shellfish, including the world's highest concentration of bald eagles and grizzly bears.
 
Guarantee of a Profit
The provision of the Senate bill involving the pulp mills would revise an arrangement made in the 1940's and 1950's, when the Forest Service granted 50-year contracts to two companies that promised to build pulp mills in southeastern Alaska. In exchange for building the mills, the companies were guaranteed long-term supplies of timber from the Tongass. To promote economic activity in the area, whose remote location has often made logging only marginally profitable, the Forest Service maintained pricing policies for timber in the forest that guaranteed the two companies a profit.
One company, Alaska Pulp, which is owned by a consortium of Japanese companies, pays the Federal Government as little as $1.48 per thousand board feet for the right to cut trees in the Tongass. Species of trees native to the Tongass now fetch more than $200 per thousand board feet on the open market. About 50 percent of the trees harvested in the forest are turned into pulp, much of it exported to Japan for use in clothing products, including disposable diapers.
The Senate bill directs the Forest Service to negotiate timber sales to the two pulp mills taking into account prevailing market conditions.

HEADLINE: The Washington Mayoral Race: After Barry Who?

 BODY:
These six people have said they intend to run for mayor of Washington.
 
David A. Clarke: District of Columbia Council Chairman, Democrat.
Bachelor's degree from George Washington University in 1965, law degree from Howard University in 1969. Mr. Clarke became a Council member in 1975 and has been chairman since 1983. He has been an aide to the Senate Committee on Nutrition and Human Needs in 1969 and was counsel and director of Washington bureau of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference in 1971 and 1972. Mr. Clarke is the only white candidate in the race so far. 
 
Maurice Turner: Retired District of Columbia Chief of Police, Republican
From 1981 to July 1989, Mr. Turner was Chief of Police of the Metropolitan Police Department. Mr. Turner attended the F.B.I. National Academy. He became a police officer in 1957, a sergeant in 1965 and lieutenant and the officer in charge of recruiting in 1969. After retiring in 1989, Mr. Turner announced that he was joining the Republican Party and so far is its only candidate. He has little political experience. His candidacy has been endorsed by the White House.
 
Walter E. Fauntroy: Nonvoting delegate to the House of Representatives since 1971, Democrat
Doctorate from Yale Divinity School and B.S. in history from Virginia Union. Mr. Fauntroy has been a pastor at New Bethel Baptist Church since 1959. Before that he was director of the Washington bureau, Southern Christian Leadership Conference, and vice chairman of the District of Columbia City Council from 1967 through 1969. His campaign got off to a ragged start; opponents are questioning his effectiveness on Capitol Hill.
 
Sharon Pratt Dixon; Lawyer, Democrat
Law degree from Howard University. Ms. Dixon is in private practice specializing in the rights of children and families. She taught at the Antioch School of Law and was appointed as vice chairwoman of the District of Columbia Law Revision Committee. In 1976 Ms. Dixon joined the staff of the general counsel's office at a utility company, where she became the vice president in 1983.
 
John Ray: Council member, Democrat
Bachelor's degree from George Washington University, law degree from George Washington University. Mr. Ray has been assistant counsel and counsel to the Senate Antitrust and Monopoloy Subcommittee under the late Senator Philip Hart and Senator Edward M. Kennedy. He was elected as an at-large member of the City Council in 1979 and re-elected in 1980, 1984 and 1988. Mr. Ray, considered a top contender, has been especiallly successful in raising money and winning endorsements among politically powerful black minister.
 
Charlene Drew Jarvis: Council member, Democrat.
Bachelor's degree from Oberlin College, master's from Howard Univeristy, doctorate in neuropsychology from the University of Maryland. Ms. Jarvis was elected to the Council in 1979 and re-elected in 1980, 1984 and 1988. She is chairwoman of the Council's Committee on Housing and Economic Development. Polls indicate Ms. Jarvis has little chance of winning.

HEADLINE: Tough Test in Peru

 BODY:
In just 10 weeks, Alberto Fujimori has rocketed from obscurity to Peru's presidency. The speed of his ascent shows. Though confronted with staggering problems, he has yet to produce a serious program. His inauguration is due next month; there's no time for delay. Other Latin countries and the United States have a stake in his success. Unfortunately, they can't offer much direct help. 
The principal U.S. connection is coca leaf, of which Peru is the world's largest producer. The Bush Administration proposes a military program to support Peruvian eradication and interdiction efforts. Mr. Fujimori argues that the U.S. could more usefully help by supporting economic programs to promote crop substitution.
His preference makes sense as drug policy and addresses Peru's economic plight. Inflation now runs at more than 2,000 percent. Less than one Peruvian in five is fully employed. But there is no realistic chance that the U.S. or Japan, Mr. Fujimori's ancestral homeland, can bankroll a painless recovery. Mr. Fujimori won by promising less-harsh economic adjustment measures than his rival, Mario Vargas Llosa. He still has to offer persuasive details. Yet he risks alienating his political base if he cannot produce.
That base includes the urban and rural poor, small-business owners, Protestant evangelicals and others outside the traditional elite. Peruvian democracy owes its survival to these groups' resistance to the Maoist message of Shining Path.
Shining Path terror and army counterinsurgency drives have cost 17,000 lives in the last decade. Mr. Fujimori says the answer is social reform. Probably so, but his predecessor, Alan Garcia, said the same thing five years ago to no visible effect.
Washington can serve American interests by helping Mr. Fujimori finance a reasonable coca crop substitution program. It can also provide military and police training, if wanted, and steady political support. Mr. Fujimori could yet succeed where his recent predecessors have failed. But he will need to be bold and tough; effective help from without requires effective leadership from within.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Migrant Labor: The McShuttle To the Suburbs

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Ramona Hardy, a 17-year-old Bronx high school student, needs more money to help support her young son.
Perry Morgan Jr., a 30-year-old unemployed messenger, hopes to earn tuition for a cooking school.
Zeke Minaya, 18, works as a bank data processor during the day and wants a night job to supplement his college scholarship. Charles Chestnut, 16, is saving up for a car. The four Bronx residents were among 27 people waiting at 2 P.M. Tuesday in the smoking section of a McDonald's restaurant on White Plains Road near Allerton Avenue to fill out peach-colored job applications served up by a McDonald's manager, Jean Paul Baptiste. 
Nearly seven hours later, Mr. Baptiste had interviewed 131 applicants who had been lured by advertisements that promised immediate hiring for all shifts and by the prospect, unstated, of premium pay.
They also promised free round-trip transportation - less a perquisite than a requirement for most people who answered the advertisements because the restaurant Mr. Baptiste manages is not the one on White Plains Road in the northeast Bronx, but another, also owned by the Trefz Corporation, about 25 miles away on the Connecticut Turnpike in Darien.
Connecticut traditionally has imported migrant labor for its apple orchards and dwindling tobacco fields. Increasingly, though, service businesses in the region around New York City are confronting a labor shortage by aggressively recruiting in the city, where unemployment is about double the 3 percent or so in Stamford, Conn., Middlesex County, N.J., and Poughkeepsie, N.Y.
And some of those businesses provide or subsidize round-trip transportation.
 
Those Fairfield
County McDonald's owned by Trefz have been described as the chain's only restaurants that routinely import employees by bus. But other companies offer their own version of the McShuttle.
The Andover Nursing Home in Sussex County, N.J., brings workers by van from Port Jervis in Orange County, N.Y., about 25 miles away. The Trump Taj Mahal hotel and casino in Atlantic City recruited employees from Washington, Gary, Ind., and Camden, N.J. (as well as Europe and Puerto Rico), relocated many of them and subsidizes commuting costs for those workers who come by train from Cherry Hill, N.J.
In many places, the problem of a dwindling labor pool, particularly among young people, is compounded not only by the lack of affordable housing nearby but also by inadequate public transportation.
''The biggest job increases in the region in recent years,'' said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, ''have been in less developed areas like Putnam and Sussex Counties.''
Labor shortages have abated in some suburbs because service industries are growing more slowly and the jobless rate is rising in response to the Northeast's sluggish economy.
''McDonald's was paying $6, $7, even $8 an hour,'' said C. Richard Ficks, a spokesman for Connecticut's Labor Department. ''Now they're back to $4.50 to $5'' - apparently still more than in the Bronx. Officials of McDonald's and Trefz politely declined to give wage differentials, but a call to two of their restaurants found that the same entry-level evening job that pays $4 an hour in the Bronx pays $4.75 an hour in Connecticut.
In Connecticut, the unemployment rate climbed to 5.6 percent in April from 3.3 percent a year ago. Declining tax revenues, meanwhile, crimped seasonal jobs at pools and playgrounds operated by local governments.
Rather than being buffeted by periodic fluctuations in the quantity and quality of younger potential employees, a number of companies, McDonald's among them, have wooed retirees. Abraham & Straus, the Brooklyn-based retailer, which until two years ago bused workers from the city to Long Island and New Jersey branches, now emphasizes full-time, more highly educated and better-trained ''sales specialists'' to whom it pays commissions.
Nonetheless, the gap between the resident labor force and the number of jobs is growing in many suburban counties. This year alone, the Regional Plan Association figures there will be 56,000 more jobs than resident employees in Westchester, 87,500 in Fairfield and 111,000 in Bergen.
This may be good news for would-be workers in the Bronx, like Ms. Hardy, Mr. Morgan, Mr. Minaya and Mr. Chestnut. That they answered the advertisement Tuesday reflects a statistical trend: besides those using private transportation services like the McShuttle, the average number of Metro-North commuters bound for the suburbs from the Bronx during the morning rush has tripled to 1,500 since 1982.

HEADLINE: Cocaine Prices Rise; Police Role Is Cited

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

 BODY:
For the first time in almost 10 years, the wholesale price of cocaine is rising sharply in New York and other American cities, suggesting that extensive law-enforcement efforts in this country and Latin America may finally be reducing the availability of the drug, Federal officials and independent drug experts say.
In New York and Los Angeles, wholesale cocaine prices have jumped by more than 40 percent since December.
At the same time, heavily diluted cocaine has been turning up in many cities, further suggesting diminished supplies, the officials say.
But they caution that price rises have not been consistent across the nation and that they have been noted only in the last three to six months.
 
No Declaration of Victory
''We don't have enough of a pattern yet to make an overall conclusive statement,'' the acting head of the Drug Enforcement Administration, Terrence M. Burke, said in a telephone interview from Washington. 
''But,'' he said, ''there's enough smoke out there to cause us to realize that something is happening. We haven't seen signs like these up till now. We're not quite sure, but it's our hope and belief that there's a good possibility that this has been because of law-enforcement action.''
Analysts in the office of national drug policy headed by William J. Bennett are reaching the same conclusions. ''We're not in a position to declare victory,'' said Stanley E. Morris, a deputy to Mr. Bennett, ''but we're seeing movement in the right direction.''
 
Tentative Conclusions
Some skeptical Federal drug officials say they suspect that the South American smuggling organizations may be holding back on sales to drive up profits or may be using the news of drug seizures and other police operations to justify price increases while continuing to maintain high supply levels. Still others say aggressive law enforcement may be increasing smuggling costs, which are being passed on to consumers.
But Dr. Mark A. R. Kleiman, an expert on drug policy at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University and a frequent critic of Washington, said his tentative conclusion was that police and military operations appeared to be ''now taking hold.''
''That would be the hopeful interpretation,'' he said. ''Less hopeful would be that this is some kind of a temporary glitch. If this keeps up for another six months, you'll have to say something is working.''
 
Fewer Patients
The developments in the cocaine market come as some social scientists say they are seeing the first tentative signs that the hard-core use of cocaine - mainly crack - may be declining in the inner cities, following a trend noted earlier among high school students and middle-class families.
One indicator is a report from the National Institute on Drug Abuse in Washington describing a sharp drop in patients being treated in emergency rooms across the country for reactions to cocaine in the last quarter of 1989. In Washington, the presence of cocaine in people being arrested has been declining for several months. Elsewhere in the country it appears to have reached a plateau.
''We could be on the verge of turning the corner,'' Dr. Kleiman said. He added that he believed that having seen the devastating effects of cocaine and crack for several years, many young people in the inner cities are deciding not to try the drugs. #40 Percent Rise Wholesale drug prices are established through negotiations between principal distributors who operate in the major cities and generally deal in quantities of at least several kilograms of 2.2 pounds each. The larger the purchase, the better the price.
In New York in the last few days, Drug Enforcement Administration officials say, undercover agents several times have been offered cocaine at $32,000 to $36,000 per kilo, compared with a high of $25,000 per kilo in December. In Los Angeles, the wholesale price is as high as $23,000 per kilo in contrast to $16,000 at the turn of the year.
In Baltimore, the cost of a kilo of cocaine rose from a high of $17,000 in September to $22,000 in December and has now climbed to $24,000. In Chicago, a kilogram is selling for as much as $32,000, up more than 20 percent from $26,000 at the turn of the year.
Prices for individual customers on the streets in New York, Baltimore and Los Angeles have not increased, the city police and Federal agents say. But Federal officials say they are seeing indications in those and other cities that dealers are effectively raising their street prices by diluting their products.
When cocaine is diluted, often with lactose, the effects of the drug are diminished, with the predictable result, experts say, that addicts buy more to reach familiar highs.
 
Less Purity
In Los Angeles, a Drug Enforcement Administration spokesman, Ralph Lochridge, said the agency has been seizing crack lately that consists of only 35 to 55 percent cocaine compared with 80 to 100 percent in recent years.
The Drug Enforcement Administration agent in charge in Baltimore, Jack Taylor, said the purity of cocaine being sold on the streets in his area had fallen to 15 to 30 percent. from 30 to 50 percent in September. In New York, a spokesman for the Federal drug agency, Mark Hannan, said agents had recovered some kilo packages consisting of 50 to 60 percent cocaine down from the standard in recent years of 88 to 93 percent.
The wholesale price of cocaine reached a high in the United States of $65,000 a kilo in 1981 and had been falling steadily as coca crops and processing expanded in South America, outpacing the demand of a burgeoning North American market. United States officials in Colombia, the main refining and exporting country, estimate that production there has peaked at 600 metric tons a year.
United States officials in Colombia say that Government raids may be curtailing processing in Colombia but that new refineries are being started in Peru and Bolivia, where most of the coca, the raw material for cocaine, is grown, as well as in the jungles of Brazil. This contributes to skepticism that the flow of cocaine to the United States is diminishing.
 
Fluctuation in Miami
Federal officials and other drug experts have been closely following cocaine prices since late last summer when Colombia declared war on drug traffickers and President Bush announced an intensified anti-drug campaign.
Prices in Miami, one of the principal hubs for importing, jumped several thousand dollars in September, a month after Colombian police and soldiers went into action, but fell back within a few weeks.
Since then, Federal drug officials in the United States and Latin America have searched in vain for evidence to justify the Bush Administration's strategy of devoting 70 percent of its anti-drug money to law enforcement. The Federal Government is putting $9.5 billion into the fight against drugs this year.
The wholesale price in Miami has risen nearly 20 percent since December to as much as $23,000 per kilo. In Houston and San Antonio, the wholesale cost of a kilo reached a high of $14,000 by the turn of the year, or nearly 20 percent more than in the fall. James O. Hawkins, the chief of intelligence in Houston for the Drug Enforcement Administration, said he expected prices now being tabulated to show an additional 10 percent increase by the end of June.
Information on smugglers and dealers is sketchy, and drug officials in different cities and even within the same office sometimes come to different conclusions in their analyses.
 
Possible Price Manipulation
As sea and air patrols and electronic surveillance have increased in the Caribbean and along the Florida coast, much of the cocaine smuggling has shifted to routes through Central America and ultimately across the Mexican border. Because more people have become involved, smuggling costs have increased, some Federal officials say. Michael Garland, the chief of intelligence for the Drug Enforcement Administration in Washington, says he believes that these factors, coupled with anti-drug operations in Colombia, is responsible for the price rises.
In the Houston office of the Drug Enforcement Administration, which oversees most of Texas's long border with Mexico, Mr. Hawkins said that cocaine was still readily available and that he believed traffickers were manipulating prices.
''It's there for the purchase,'' he said. ''All you've got to do is come up with the money. They can make available whatever amounts you want.''
Some Federal agents and police department officials say they suspect price manipulation is contributing to the higher prices in New York.
 
Effects on Supply
Peter Reuter, an economist and drug expert in Washington for the Rand Corporation, and other Federal agents said they believed this might be possible for short periods. But, Mr. Reuter said, ''Lots of other people can get into this business from other places and if cocaine is arriving here, they can offer it at lower prices.''
Though the Colombian drug rings are sometimes referred to as cartels, they have not in the past fixed prices but have functioned as cooperatives of processers, financiers, shippers and enforcers for distribution in widely varying sales arrangements.
James S. Milford, the deputy chief of the Drug Enforcement Administration's New York office, said he is convinced that less cocaine is reaching the city.
''Traditional major traffickers in this area don't have large amounts available for wholesale distribution,'' he said. ''We're seeing traditional buyers of 5 and 10 kilos having to look elsewhere.''
At Drug Enforcement Administration headquarters in Washington, Mr. Burke said that in conversations with chiefs of police across the country and through telephone wiretaps in several cities he had found that ''people are talking about having trouble putting together packages and there's a great deal of discussion about the purity of the stuff.''
''I think the point is,'' he said, ''that there is less cocaine available to individual entrepreneurs.''
