HEADLINE: Excerpts From Durenberger's Senate Testimony

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 13

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from testimony today by Senator Dave Durenberger, Republican of Minnesota, before the Senate Ethics Committee, on the second day of hearings into his financial activities, as supplied by the Federal News Service, a transcription company:
This investigation and this hearing focuses on only a few years of the 55 years of my life. While it may appear proper to talk about those years as if we could somehow cleanly separate them and study them, there is much living that has affected those years. And very briefly, let me give you some context.
I was born on the campus of the monastery of St. John's Abbey and University in Collegeville, a second-generation Minnesotan. My father, the college athletic director for 42 years; my mom, a superwoman, a mother, teacher and a volunteer. I graduated from grade school, a two-roomer; high school, and college at St. John's. St. John's is a Benedictine community, and the Benedictine motto is ''Work and pray.'' And I must say I learned those lessons well, as you'll see during the course of this matter. 
I spent time in the Army. I graduated from the University of Minnesota Law School in 1959, and I joined a firm in South St. Paul. In 1962, I married Judy McGlumphy. Our sons were born in 1963, 1964, 1965 and 1967. We discovered that Judy had breast cancer at the birth of our youngest son, Danny, who happens to be with me here today. She died three and a half years later at the age of 31.
At that time, I was serving as Gov. Harold Evander's chief of staff. Shortly after Judy's death, I became H. B. Fuller Company's legal and community affairs counsel, and I became active in the leadership of literally dozens of community organizations.
 
Struggles With Family
Despite appearances, I was overwhelmed by the sadness and the daunting challenge of raising four small sons under the age of 8. Within a year of Judy's death, I met and married Penny Tuohy. She was a Vietnam War widow of a U.S. Marine captain. Steve Tuohy was killed in the Tet offensive, and Penny undertook to help raise these four boys. While she had her own cross to bear, she added five more - of ours. With a mother lost to Charlie, David, Mike, and Danny, a husband lost to Penny and a wife lost to me, sadness made bonding difficult in our family.
Some of that sadness was acknowledged, but a lot of it was never dealt with. My grief counseling was to throw myself into my work and yes, gentlemen, that was a serious mistake but one I didn't know how to acknowledge.
I was elected to the U.S. Senate in 1978 and again, I threw myself into my work, and, as you know, that's not hard to do around here. Over the past 12 years, I have been extremely proud of representing the people of Minnesota handling their constituent issues; helping develop legislation on national health policy, intergovernmental relations, national security, tax reform, civil rights and economic equity, the environment and, most recently, as you know so well, the work on the Clean Air Act, the Pepper Commission, and the Americans with Disabilities Act, among just a few -among many other areas.
Yes, there have been many ups and downs in my personal life. But I thank God for the friends; staff, past and present; and the constituents who have supported me. And I thank God especially for my family because they have remained the keys in my daily life even after everything I've put them through.
 
Passion of Public Service
Yes, there have been good times and tough times in my career. But I want to tell you that one thing remains constant, I believe deeply in public service. It's been my vocation, it's been my passion and, sometimes, my refuge. And whatever public service has cost me, including the opportunity for personal wealth, or, for that matter, even financial security, it's been worthwhile. There are many things in my life I would change if I could start over. The opportunity to serve my community, whether on a park commission or in the United States Senate, is not something I've ever regretted.
Hopefully, some sense of my past will now help inform the future. Yesterday's presentation painted a very different portrait of me and my situation. And I would say to the members of the committee that you can only accept Mr. Bennett's characterization if you ignore four clear and undisputed historical facts.
My personal history includes three decades of public service requiring substantial responsibility and integrity. . . .
Secondly, I have a strong background in ethics in government. I was the vice chair of the Minnesota Ethical Practices Board and its predecessor, the Minnesota Ethics Commission. I was executive director of the Minnesota Constitutional Study Commission and the Minnesota Supreme Court Advisory Committee on Professional Standards for Judges.
Third, none of the people involved with me in these matters can be described as anything but upstanding. They are well-respected members of their communities. They're not fast-buck or special interest operators.
To me, reprehensible is an appropriate word to characterize the suggestion that these people would participate in the kind of scheme outlined by the Special Counsel.
And fourth, all of these matters were done in the open and disclosed. There has been no obfuscation or cover-up. And I must say, somebody called yesterday who were watching my facial expressions or something like that when Bob Bennett got to the point of the Piranha Press chewing up the prey or whatever it was. I guess I got one of those facial expressions that said I was arrogant or something like that.
But I must say, every time somebody brings up this notion of Piranha Press I just have to say: Would anybody in their right mind believe that anybody was going to cook up a scheme to evade U.S. Senate rules by going out and creating a company called Piranha Press? No, Mr. Bennett's characterization flies in the face of these well-known facts, and I would urge you to take into account these facts as you weigh his conclusions.
 
Political Realities
Now I want to turn to several comments which reflect in a more personal way on the facts my counsel has given to you. And first let me talk about what has come to be known as the condo deal. Those Americans who argue for a citizen legislature can look to me, for better or worse, to see some of the realities that face someone who comes into public office relatively late in life. I was a grass-roots activist, and what I knew about the mechanics of the Senate came when I was told how much I could spend for my staff, given the keys to my office, and my unabridged dictionary, and told good luck.
While I don't presume on this occasion and in this forum to offer myself as an expert or a guide to my colleagues on the committee or in the Senate on the subject of political ethics, there are a few personal thoughts that I need to share.
It is with a great deal of sadness that I approach this proceeding and review my own actions which have provoked them. The Senate is an institution I love. I've come to love it. . . . To the extent my actions, my inactions, my failure to perceive the consequences of my actions, have in any way reflected poorly on the Senate as an institution, or been uncomfortable or distressful to you as a person, I must say, I am sincerely sorry. I have tried to uphold and to strengthen this institution. . . .
I've been careful not to abuse my rights, or my privileges, as a Senator, with respect to allowing the Senate to work its will and get its business done, and I think you've observed that. . . .
 
Proud of Work in Senate
I believe I've made a significant contribution to the work product of this institution. I've taken my institutional responsibility very seriously to protect the Senate's structure, and ease its operation. And that sense of the value of the institutional responsibility, makes my sense of sadness over this situation all the more acute.
As I've said, I was raised in a small town. I think when college was out it wasn't more than about 200 people. The first 21 years of my life were in this closely knit educational community. Other people's perceptions of what you did weren't much of a factor in that kind of an environment, since we were all known on a first-hand basis.
But those kinds of personal relationships can't exist in the larger public arena. People must, of necessity, rely on other's views and impressions. And that's when perception becomes a real factor. Appearances, I have learned, are much more than a tool of public relations, in this business. They have ethical consequences far greater than we usually attribute to them.
As Professor Thompson of Harvard testified to the House of Representatives, and I'll quote him, Public officials have a ethical obligation to do all they can to make sure that citizens do not have any reasonable basis for believing that they or their colleagues are violating their own ethics rules.
There is an ethical obligation to protect the appearances of propriety almost as great as to produce its reality, end quote.
What I have learned is simply that a clear conscience or a legal opinion does not make you ethically bulletproof - a tough lesson to learn - a good lesson, but it's tough to learn it the way I have. The difficulty for rules-driven ethics is that it is difficult to write or to enforce a rule governing appearances. It becomes quite difficult when ethics, like beauty, is in the eye of the beholder.
 
Accountable for Mistakes
But let there be no misunderstanding of what I am saying. There's no excuse for my actions to be found in changing public perceptions or in the way other members conduct themselves. I am fully responsible, and I am accountable for the mistakes that I have made. I am simply pointing out from my own experience that the broader challenge of political ethics which we in this body will have to address in campaign finance reform, limitations on honoraria, our associations with nonprofit organizations, the proactive work that the Vice Chairman referred to earlier of ethics, rules, disbursing, to inform and advise those and a host of other issues.
Publc attitudes about political ethics have changed, and we have to change with them or be swept aside.
In conclusion, members of the committee and the Senate and especially the people of Minnesota, I want to express again my regret and my sadness for the circumstances that have brought us to this point. I acted throughout in good faith. I sought out competent legal and official advice. I worked too hard on your public agenda to attend to my private one. Since my service to you began, I have never sold your vote or bartered your influence to enrich myself.
But I recognize that real damage has been done, by what has been perceived as my desire to push the limits and take advantage of the Senate. And for that, I am deeply sorry.

HEADLINE: Beatrice Coleman, Philanthropist, 74; Headed Maidenform

 BODY:
Beatrice Coleman, chairwoman of Maidenform Inc., a manufacturer of lingerie, died on Tuesday at her home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.
Mrs. Coleman, who was 74 years old, died of cancer, a spokesman for the company said. 
Mrs. Coleman became president and chairwoman of the 67-year-old company in 1968, succeeding her late husband, Dr. Joseph A. Coleman.
The daughter of Ida and William Rosenthal, who founded Maidenform, Mrs. Coleman joined the company in 1938, after graduating from Barnard College. She worked in various areas of the company's operations before settling on product development as her field of expertise.
President Jimmy Carter appointed her to the National Commission for Unemployment Compensation.
At her death, she was chairwoman of the Ida and William Rosenthal Foundation, a private philanthropy.
Mrs. Coleman was active in community affairs, including serving as a trustee of Barnard College; a director of the National Women's Law Center; a trustee of the Pension Fund of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union; chairwoman of the Jamaican-American Chamber of Commerce, and a director of the Tri-State United Way.
She is survived by two daughters, Catherine C. Brawer of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Elizabeth Coleman of Atlanta, and four grandchildren.

LENGTH: 1378 words

HEADLINE: Can Small Be Cheap and Also Beautiful?

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN

DATELINE: MONTREAL

 BODY:
IT is the architectural equivalent of the Japanese compact car, without options like power steering or a tape deck. But two professors at McGill University are betting that many young prospective homeowners would willingly trade closets and other amenities for a home of their own that is efficient and affordable.
The ''Grow Home'' - two stories, 14 feet wide, 1,000 square feet -is an experimental house recently built by the Affordable Homes Program of the McGill School of Architecture. In Montreal the two-bedroom, one-bathroom town house cost $36,000 for materials and labor, in United States dollars. The estimated selling price in Montreal would be $62,000. In the United States, the selling price would vary, depending on local land and construction costs.
''We felt there was a gap between architects, housing and the needs of the public,'' said Avi Friedman, who is co-director of the graduate program with Witold Rybczynski, the author of ''Home: A Short History of an Idea'' and ''The Most Beautiful House in the World.'' 
''The whole issue of affordability isn't talked about enough,'' Mr. Rybczynski said. ''No one knows how to manipulate interest rates and land costs. So as architects we thought it was worth taking a look at the product again.''
As a model, Mr. Rybczynski and Mr. Friedman looked to the row house, a staple of cities like Montreal, London and Philadelphia. Row houses allow relatively high densities but also have some advantages of single-family houses, chiefly a private front door and a private rear garden. Grow Homes could be assembled in rows, pairs, terraces or courts.
Perhaps the biggest issues raised by the house are lot zoning and house size. Since the housing boom of the 1950's, the size of North American houses has been on a steady incline. The Levittown houses of the late 1940's, for example, offered buyers 800 square feet without a basement. Now, according to the National Association of Home Builders, the median size of a new American home is 1,850 square feet.
But family sizes have decreased. In 1949 4.2 people lived in the average single-family home; today the figure is 2.3 people, said James McKeller, the director of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Center for Real Estate Development in Cambridge, Mass. The result, Mr. McKeller said, is ''twice as much house for half as many people.''
Michael Carliner, an economist for the home builders' association, said house sizes became larger partly because buyers' incomes were rising and partly because members of the baby boom have moved from being first-time homeowners and in trading up can afford more.
In addition, he said, many places effectively encourage bigger houses with zoning that establishes minimum building lots of one-eighth to one-fifth of an acre (about 5,500 to 8,700 square feet).
The 1,500-square-foot lot that might comfortably accommodate a Grow Home would not be legal in many areas. ''There has been a history of exclusionary zoning and growth control,'' said Karl Case, a professor of economics at Wellesley College. ''Though decreased lot zoning is the ticket to affordability, many municipal zoning laws would not permit it.''
A small-is-cheap-and-beautiful ethic (''space costs money,'' Mr. Rybczynski said) was a major impetus behind the creation of the Grow Home, which has been attracting a steady stream of visitors since it was opened last week. The house will remain on campus and open to visitors through June 30.
''It takes a certain amount of sophistication to appreciate smallness,'' Mr. Rybczynski said. In central Philadelphia, he noted, historic town houses as narrow as 12 feet are considered charming and highly desirable. The no-frills design of the Grow Home - which might be compared to knockdown furniture or generic grocery brands - was formed in part by a consumer survey conducted with The Montreal Gazette.
Although Europeans are accustomed to buying unfinished houses and buying additional components later, it is not a North American tradition. ''We were very surprised by how many people said they would be willing to do work on the house themselves in exchange for lower costs,'' Mr. Rybczynski said.
The idea, as with a Japanese car, Mr. Friedman said, was to combine ''small size with a high degree of finish and workmanship.'' Construction, land and marketing costs are all lower for a smaller house.
Homeowners could add on options - a basement with a garage, for example, or a second bathroom - as they go. The architects envision four models: the Windsor now standing at McGill; the Straight-Back, without a pergola, a lattice-covered back porch, or front balcony, which would sell for $56,000 in Montreal; the Ottomane, with an unfinished basement, $67,000, and the La-Z-Boy, the top of the line, with an unfinished basement and a garage, $76,000.
The Windsor has a blue stucco facade and classic architectural details, and comes with a second-floor balcony in front and a small pergola in back. Rather than shrink every room, ''we really tried to make judgments,'' Mr. Rybczynski said. Built-in closets, which are extremely labor-intensive, were not included; it is assumed that the homeowner will buy storage units seperately and place them where they want them. But the house has an expensive steel front door, because ''we felt the front door was important,'' Mr. Rybczynski said.
In their design, which they developed with a research associate, Susan Ross, the architects tried to keep contemporary living in mind.
There is no entry foyer; the front door opens into the kitchen. The kitchen is bright, spacious and designed to be the heart of the house and the principal dining area. The sitting room is a snug 14 by 10 feet. The downstairs bathroom is large enough to hold a washer and dryer.
The interior is meant to be flexible. ''Houses, especially the noise level and the placement of furniture, change with life changes,'' Mr. Friedman said. The upstairs is an unpartitioned loftlike space. A wall can be installed at extra cost. At McGill, the second floor was set up as a master bedroom and child's nursery, with a Venetian blind between them. A number of visitors walking through the house suggested that this space looked perfectly wonderful for two people - without any children.
Though small, the house does not feel claustrophobic, in part because of the abundance of windows divided by wooden mullions and the two sets of French doors to the pergola and balcony. Where inexpensive materials are used, it is assumed that they can be replaced with better materials later. ''Creative use of vinyl can be as attractive as marble,'' Mr. Friedman said. ''Creativity and energy are a resource, like money.''
The Affordable Homes Program was begun last year as a graduate program for architects and designers, the only advanced degree in affordable housing from a North American school of architecture. Its students are studying economical kitchen designs, housing for households headed by single women and other issues. The program is financed by the Canadian Government, the Quebec Government and private benefactors. The house was financed by Dow Chemical Canada Inc., with furnishings fromIKEA Canada Ltd. The builder was Modulex Inc. of Quebec City.
Reactions from visitors seemed generally favorable. For every person who said, ''I wouldn't dream of living in it; it's too small,'' there was another who marveled at the amount of space. Although he had not seen the house, I. Donald Terner, president of the Bridge Housing Corporation, a nonprofit housing company in San Francisco, cautioned that provision for automobiles could significantly drive up the cost.
Mr. Rybczynski and Mr. Friedman said that even with differences in land costs the ''Grow Home'' could be built for significantly less than a typical home. But ''expectations are the hardest things to change,'' Mr. Rybczynski admitted.
''What is a home?,'' Mr. Friedman asked. ''It's a cozy kitchen, a place to hang a baby's picture and a place to watch the evening news.''
The architects seemed determined to turn smallness into a virtue.
''Upper-story-loft dinner parties could be an attraction,'' Mr. Friedman said.
''Even Roseanne eats in the kitchen,'' Mr. Rybczynski said.

LENGTH: 1015 words

HEADLINE: Japanese Say Their Country Has Sold Its Soul

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, June 13

 BODY:
Japan's postwar mistake has been selling its soul to the West along with its cars and computers, several Japanese novelists and critics told an international literary conference here this week.
''With prosperity, the economic miracle, has come cultural and spiritual degeneration,'' said Masao Miyoshi, a critic and professor of literature at the University of California at San Diego, who moderated a panel of Japanese writers on Monday. ''Japan has surrendered to Western cultural hegemony. We are represented in industry but not in cultural matters.'' 
The same point was made more informally by the novelist Kenzaburo Oe, a perennial candidate for the Nobel Prize. ''You know why Honda is great,'' Mr. Oe told his American dinner companions at a gathering that opened the conference. ''But we don't care about Honda. We care that our cultural life is unknown to you.''
 
A Shift in Focus
The panel discussion, one of a dozen here this week at the War Memorial and Performing Arts Center, was part of the Wheatland Foundation's fourth annual conference on world literature, which until this year has been dominated by Central European and Soviet writers. But in this most Asian of American cities, the conference organizers shifted the focus and, for the first time, invited novelists, poets, playwrights and essayists from Japan, South Korea, China and Southeast Asia.
The Chinese panel, scheduled for Thursday, is expected to be the most provacative because of last year's massacre in Tiananmen Square. Most of the participating Chinese writers, all living in exile, are members of the younger generation, but they were joined here by Liu Binyan, the eminent journalist who has twice been expelled from the Communist Party.
The Japanese panel was considered the most distinguished assemblage of the week, with several of the country's foremost writers. Among them were Mr. Oe, whose books include ''A Personal Matter'' and ''Teach Us to Outgrow Our Madness,''and Yuko Tsushima, daughter of the prominent novelist Osamu Dazai, who committed suicide shortly after World War II. Ms. Tsushima's novels include ''Child of Fortune'' and ''The Shooting Gallery.''
 
Prize for Translation
Mr. Oe's work is distinguished by twists of syntax and sentence structure more common in English and the European languages than in Japanese, said Van C. Gessel, a professor of Japanese literature at the University of California at Berkeley, who attended the conference. Ms. Tsushima's novels, he said, are full of the mundane details of domestic life and grapple with the struggles of a divorced mother in a country that is harsh on nonconforming women. Later in the week, Ms. Tsushima's translator, Geraldine Harcourt, will be awarded the Wheatland Foundation's translation prize, which has previously gone to Arpad Goncz, the new interim President of Hungary.
The Wheatland Foundation was established in 1984 by Ann Getty, the philanthropist who is married to the heir to the Getty oil fortune, and Lord Weidenfeld, the British publisher. Together, Mrs. Getty and Lord Weidenfeld bought Grove Press in 1985, subsequently losing millions of dollars. They put the publishing house on the market and found out last month that it was virtually unsalable because of its liabilities. Mrs. Getty lives here in San Francisco in a lemon yellow stucco mansion with sweeping views of the bay and is the hostess at the city's grandest dinner parties.
 
The Getty Touch
Mrs. Getty's touch was evident at the conference, held in the Green Room of the War Memorial and Performing Arts Center, a high ceilinged chamber that opens onto a stone loggia overlooking City Hall. It was here, in brilliant spring sunshine, that conference participants nibbled chocolate-dipped strawberries during the breaks between panel discussions.
The discussions, more often than not, left participants yawning, whispering among themselves like school children or trying to sneak a look at the baseball box scores without rustling the newspaper. But occasionally sparks flew, as they did when Mr. Oe made it clear that he did not think much of Yukio Mishima, Japan's most famous postwar novelist, who committed hara-kiri after a failed attempt to take over a military base.
Mr. Oe argued that Mishima shaped his life to ''live up to the image of Japan created by Europeans.'' Mishima's decision to die in the ''traditional way,'' Mr. Oe said, was the final proof of his ''perverted relationship with the image of Japan'' and ''a great betrayal of his fellow Asians.''
This incensed Pierre Mertens of Belgium, a novelist and lawyer who writes frequently about war crimes and totalitarianism. ''Mishima is accepted in other countries as a great writer,'' Mr. Mertens sputtered into his microphone, calming himself with a sip of cool water. ''I don't think the Japanese have a right to decide he's not a great writer. And once we've thrown the suicides out of literature, what happens to Primo Levi? We'll be getting into cultural genocide before too long.''
 
Two Confessions
While Mr. Oe lamented that Japanese writers are too obeisant to the West, rather than ''turning our eyes to the Asian literature,'' his life and career follow the same pattern. He was 10 when the war ended and vividly recalls the truck full of American soldiers who rolled into his village with chocolate bars and chewing gum, copies of ''The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn'' and ''Black Beauty'' and volumes of Walt Whitman and William Butler Yeats.
''This was the beginning of my literary life,'' Mr. Oe said, dipping his head apologetically. He went on to study French literature at Tokyo University and write a thesis about Sartre.
Ms. Tsushima, too, offered a contrite explanation for a lifetime spent reading Western literature in translation rather than indigenous Japanese works. ''Women seemed so free and liberated in the foreign literature,'' she said. ''There were very few books written by Japanese women and to read them made me feel I was going back to the olden days. That aspect within me has changed recently.''

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Down 0.7% Last Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 13

 BODY:
In a surprisingly weak performance, American shoppers cut retail spending by seven-tenths of 1 percent in May, the third straight monthly decline, the Commerce Department said today.
It was the first time since September, October and November 1981, during the nation's most recent recession, that retail sales for apparel, autos, furniture and other items have fallen for such an extended period.
The report sent bond yields falling to their lowest levels since mid-February as market participants said the report further evidenced a weakening in the economy. [Page D17.] The news prompted some analysts to wonder whether the economy would continue to move ahead, however languidly, without some move to ease monetary policy by the Federal Reserve. 
 
'A Grim Number Indeed'
''This was a grim number indeed,'' said Donald H. Straszheim, chief economist at Merrill Lynch, suggesting it was now ''very possible'' that the Fed would cut interest rates even before the next scheduled meeting of its policy-making Federal Open Market Committee on July 2.
Other analysts, noting that much of the country suffered from poor shopping weather last month and that retail sales figures are quite erratic in any event, were somewhat less concerned.
Richard B. Berner of Salomon Brothers said that while the latest figures ''paint a picture of sluggish consumer spending'' they probably overstated the severity of the decline in retail sales.
He observed that exceptionally warm weather early in the year may have ''stolen'' sales from the spring and predicted that the May figures would be revised upward substantially, as they were in May 1989.
The data are adjusted for seasonal, holiday and trading-day differences, but major aberrations in the weather can swamp the adjustment factors.
 
Many Taken Aback
Even those who see no imminent danger of recession, like Edward Guay of the Cigna Corporation, were nonetheless taken aback by the scope of the declines in sales last month, with only apparel stores managing to post an advance, perhaps because of volume-enhancing price cuts.
''I don't think it's enough weakness for the Federal Reserve to ease, but it's certainly going to cause some argument'' at the next Federal Open Market Committee meeting, Mr. Guay said. He suggested the Fed would defer easing until more data on the domestic economy are in and until there is some evidence that German economic unification will not touch off a bout of inflation there that could cause a rise in German interest rates. April Drop Revised Today's report also showed that retail sales declined more in April than initially reported - nine-tenths of 1 percent instead of six-tenths of 1 percent - and that, unlike other recent months, May's poor sales could not be attributed to a paucity of car sales. Auto sales in May fell six-tenths of 1 percent compared with a drop of 1.6 percent in April.
Last month, retail sales excluding the automotive sector slumped eight-tenths of 1 percent, slightly more than for total retail sales. In April, non-auto sales fell seven-tenths of 1 percent.
But in the first 10 days of June auto sales have headed downward. In a separate report released today, Detroit's Big Three auto producers said that sales of North American-made cars and trucks tumbled 14.9 percent.
 
Food Sales Down 1%
The Commerce Department's report showed that outlets selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes posted a 4.2 percent drop last month after a 3.2 percent drop in April. Home furnishings and equipment fell 1.1 percent and food fell 1 percent.
Stores selling general merchandise suffered a 1 percent decline, gasoline service stations had a 1.6 percent decline, while drug and proprietary stores and eating and drinking places showed sales lower by 1.3 percent and five-tenths of 1 percent, respectively.
Peter A. Radford, chief economist for the National Westminster Bancorp in New York said the fact that the declines were so widespread was ''the thing that disturbs me the most.'' He said, however, that while economic growth had decelerated markedly in the last few months, the Federal Reserve would probably wait until at least mid-July before relaxing the monetary reins.
 
Growth Estimate Cut
In a market letter dated Monday, Merrill Lynch disclosed that it had cut its estimate of 1990 growth in gross national product to 1.8 percent from the 2.1 percent it had predicted earlier, and Mr. Straszheim of Merrill said today that even the new figure might well prove too optimistic.
The Commerce Department's report showed that retail sales last month were $146.84 billion, which, while down from the previous month, were 1.5 percent above the $144.71 billion posted for May 1989.
With retail inflation running at about 4 percent, this implied that volume last month was about 2.5 percent below levels a year earlier.
Sales of durable goods fell 1.1 percent last month, while nondurable sales fell five-tenths of 1 percent, the department reported.
Without any adjustment, sales last month were $152.94 billion, up from $144.85 in April and from $150.26 billion in May 1989.

HEADLINE: U.S. Likely to Forgo Sanctions Against India

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 13

 BODY:
Although India has refused to negotiate removal of trade barriers with the United States, the Bush Administration has ruled out sanctions against New Delhi lest broader trade liberalization talks be undermined, American trade officials said today.
Under the decision, expected to be announced on Thursday by the trade representative, Carla A. Hills, the Administration would wait until the multilateral talks among 106 nations, known as the Uruguay Round, conclude at the end of this year before determining what action, if any, to take on India.
India is the only country remaining on the ''hit list'' of those selected for reprisal under 1988 trade legislation. The Journal of Commerce reported today that it was virtually certain that the Administration would decide not to impose sanctions. 
Japan and Brazil worked their way off the retaliation list with a series of market-opening measures adopted after negotiations with the United States earlier this year.
 
A Steadfast Refusal
But India has steadfastly refused to negotiate under a unilateral threat of sanctions. ''As a sovereign independent country, we cannot be subject to another sovereign independent country's laws,'' said Shrimati Prem Singh, minister of commerce at the Indian Embassy here.
The Administration faces a June 16 statutory deadline in deciding what to do about India, which was accused of maintaining unfair trade barriers by excluding foreign insurance companies and by imposing onerous conditions on foreign investment.
Mrs. Hills broadly hinted at the decision she is likely to take during a breakfast meeting with reporters today in which she outlined her options.
 
A Variety of Options
She said she could retaliate immediately, take no action at all or ''defer and say we're negotiating on issues of services and investment in the Uruguay Round, and that therefore I will determine what action to take when those negotiations close.''
The United States is now preparing for major international meetings it hopes will give a greater political thrust to the ambitious multilateral trade talks begun in Uruguay four years ago. The hope is not only to cut tariff and nontariff barriers, but also to reduce subsidies that distort trade in agriculture, set rules of good conduct for trade in financial, construction, tourism and other services and widen protection against piracy of books, movies, brand-name jeans and other intellectual property.
The global talks have been foundering in disputes over agricultural protection and other matters. For the new political push, Washington is looking to the July 9 economic summit meeting of seven industrial nations in Houston and a meeting of developed and developing country members of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade the last week of July in Geneva.
 
Sanctions' Explosive Potential
Sanctions against India, the world's biggest democracy, at a time when the United States is seeking international consensus on what President Bush calls his highest trade priority would outrage not only India but also other developing countries and could tilt the balance against further progress in the round, American and international officials say.
They also note that while New Delhi has refused to sit down with American negotiators, it has quietly taken a series of liberalization steps that American officials say point it in the right direction.
The coalition Government of Prime Minister V. P. Singh has just revalidated a $1 billion investment by Pepsico Inc. in India. Pepsico officials had urged the Bush Administration not to impose sanctions, arguing that approval of their project would help create a better climate for resolving the outstanding trade issues.

HEADLINE: U.S. Concern Over Japan's Surplus

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 13

 BODY:
The Bush Administration today interjected itself publicly into a domestic policy debate in Japan that Washington contends is slowing bilateral trade talks.
In the first comments by an American official on the issue, Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, said the United States was concerned that Tokyo is now thinking of maintaining trade surpluses at about 2 percent of total economic output. She said the concern had already been related to the Japanese Government. 
''It's one thing to come upon a surplus because of currency swings and the like,'' she said at a breakfast meeting with reporters. ''It is quite another thing to have a policy to maintain a 2 percent surplus. It's that which creates dislocation in the trading system.''
 
The Argument's Implications
This new argument between Washington and Tokyo has broad implications for the ''structural impediments initiative,'' in which the two Governments are trying to revamp their economies to reduce the American trade deficit with Japan, which last year stood at $49 billion.
Should Japan set limits on surplus reduction, the initiative, which seeks to increase competitiveness in Japan so that imports will respond to market forces, could be undermined.
Indeed, Mrs. Hills suggested as much when she noted the trouble American negotiators are having in concluding a final report on the initiative in time for next month's economic summit meeting in Houston.
An interim report committing Japan to a series of measures making it easier for foreigners to invest and do business in Japan was agreed on by the two Governments on April 5.
''These negotiations are difficult and very slow,'' she said today. ''I am not pleased with the progress, but I am not giving up.''
Earlier this month Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto welcomed a report from a Japanese Government advisory panel saying that Japan's surpluses were needed to meet rising demand for world savings to pay for reconstruction of Eastern Europe, unification of Germany and demands of the third world. Agreement from the I.M.F. The International Monetary Fund made a similar argument in its recently published International Economic Outlook.
''The possibility of a rise in world demand for saving associated with recent and prospective developments in Germany and Eastern Europe suggests that it might not be desirable for Japan to eliminate its external surplus over the next few years, especially through actions that would reduce national saving,'' the I.M.F. said.
Japan's overall current account surpluses, which include trade and services accounts with all nations, have declined dramatically, to 2 percent of gross output from around 4 percent to 5 percent.
In the structural initiative, American officials say, Japan is resisting American demands for a big increase in public spending, precisely because of fears of the impact on trade accounts.
Washington is asking for a sharp jump from the current 6.7 percent of gross national product to 10 percent.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
New Mexico Utility Picks Leader

 BODY:
Ashton B. Collins Jr., an expert in electrical services, will take over next week as chairman of the Public Service Company of New Mexico, a large electric and natural gas utility in Albuquerque. He will replace Jerry D. Geist, who is retiring after spending 30 years at the helm.
The succession also includes John T. Ackerman, currently president and chief operating officer of the concern's gas division, who will become president and chief operating officer of the parent company, two posts also held by Mr. Geist. 
Mr. Collins, 58 years old, said the three positions had been split to enable ''another set of shoulders to bear the burden'' of responsibilities. Mr. Ackerman will handle day-to-day operations while Mr. Collins will concentrate more on the overall direction of the concern. He will also remain president of his own company, Reddy Communications, which provides information services to utilities.
Mr. Geist, 56, said Mr. Collin's ''experience and sensitivity to electric utility issues'' will enable him to maintain the company's image as a strong service utility.
Mr. Collins complimented Mr. Geist on the company's ability to balance economic development and environmental concerns. ''He did an extraordinary job positioning the state for a strong future and enabling New Mexico to be the only state to qualify for the most stringent Federal clean-air standards,'' he said.
In the 1970's the company shied away from the polluting coal-burning plants and worked with environmental groups to create a strict set of air and water standards. They now have a diversified set of energy outlets, including nuclear and solar energy.
The greatest challenges Mr. Collins said he would face would be instilling more confidence into shareholders after the company shed all of its non-utility operations over the last two years. ''It will take some time,'' he said. ''We are not paying dividends and have not had a rate increase since 1984.''
After graduating from Cornell University with an economics degree, Mr. Collins worked for his father's company, Reddy Kilowatt, and took over as president more than 20 years ago, changing its name to Reddy Communications. He joined the New Mexico utility in 1979 as a director.
Mr. Ackerman, 46, has a bachelor's degree in electrical engineering from the University of New Mexico and a master's degree in utility management from New Mexico State University. He has held a variety of utility-related jobs since then. ''He's strong in management and human relations. He's also a journeyman who can get an operation running smoothly,'' Mr. Geist said.
Mr. Collins, in the meantime, said he does not mind ''wearing two hats'' by heading both Reddy and the Public Service Company of New Mexico. ''Come back in six months and I'll tell you how it feels,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Early June Vehicle Sales Down 12.6%

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 13

 BODY:
Sales of domestically produced cars and light trucks declined 12.6 percent in early June, puncturing hopes by manufacturers that a surge in late May signaled an end to the auto industry's eight-month slump.
The decline comes despite fairly broad and aggressive cash rebates and other financing incentives, including rebates offered by several Japanese manufacturers.
''Sales continue to be sluggish in a saturated market,'' said David Healy, an auto industry analyst for Barclays Bank in New York. ''Some people hailed the upturn in late May sales as a recovery, but it ain't.'' 
Mr. Healy said the strong showing in late May was primarily becaue of a pattern by Japanese manufacturers with plants in the United States, and particularly the Toyota Motor Corporation, to report the bulk of their sales in the last third of the month.
 
Car Sales Down 14.7%
The 10 companies that make cars and trucks in the United States reported total car sales of 152,630, a decline of 14.7 percent from moderately strong sales a year ago. Cars sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.4 million, well below the 7.3 million rate in late May, and behind the rate of 7.2 million for the corresponding period a year ago. The sales rate for the last 60 days was 6.6 million.
There were eight selling days in the period this year, compared with nine days a year ago. Percentage changes are based on daily selling rates.
Sales of domestic light trucks and mini-vans fell 8.8 percent, to 92,140, accounting for slightly more than one-third of vehicle sales.
The Big Three reported a 14.9 percent decline in combined sales of cars and trucks, ranging from a 12.4 percent drop posted by the Ford Motor Company in early June, to the General Motors Corporation's decline of 16.7 percent. The Japanese producers all reported sales gains, led by the Honda Motor Company, whose car sales increased 30.8 percent.
 
Personal Debt Seen as Factor
Edward A. Sullivan, an analyst with the WEFA Group Inc. in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., attributed the continuing sluggish market for autos to the rising personal debt of American consumers.
''Consumers are so overloaded with debt that a slowdown in the economy, particularly in the Northeast, has caused a lot of people to re-evaluate their purchases,'' he said.
In a move that underscores the declining borrowing power of some car buyers, Ford's financing division told dealers two weeks ago that it would offer lower loan fees for customers it considers creditworthy, and higher fees for those with irregular credit histories.
''We've recognized some of the economic realities of the business,'' said Randy Kniebes, manager of marketing and business development at the Ford Motor Credit Company. ''Consumers who have better credit histories and are better able to repay can get lower rates, and consumers that have had difficulty paying in the past may pay a higher rate.''
The General Motors Acceptance Corporation adopted a similar financing program in March 1989. The Chrysler Corporation's financing unit makes no differentiation in loan fees offered to customers.
Car sales at G.M. fell 19.2 percent, to 71,810, while sales of G.M. light trucks were down 11.3 percent, to 36,906.
Ford reported the largest decline in car sales, down 20.2 percent, to 43,628. Sales of Ford's light trucks rose five-tenths of 1 percent, however, to 33,184, largely on the strength of the popular new Explorer sport utility vehicle.
 
Chrysler Car Sales Off
Chrysler's car sales declined 10.3 percent, to 20,659, a better showing than Chrysler has mustered for several weeks. But sales of Chrysler light trucks, including the important mini-vans, fell 19.1 percent, to 19,866. Analysts attributed the drop in Chrysler's light-truck sales to an end to the rebates Chrysler had offered on its mini-vans.
Honda's car sales increased 30.8 percent, to 9,054.
Toyota reported a gain of 35 percent in sales of its cars, to 3,842. The Mazda Motor Company's car sales rose 22.8 percent, to 728, while the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation posted an increase of 59 percent in sales of its cars, to 1,180.
The Nissan Motor Company's car sales rose 30.5 percent, to 1,517, and sales of light trucks rose 1.1 percent, to 1,922.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Mostly Weaker As Pound Keeps Surging

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended weaker yesterday against most major currencies after a mixed performance overseas, while the soaring British pound continued to take center stage.
Currency dealers said the dollar's decline was largely the result of technical factors, with traders selling the dollar to buy the West German mark and Swiss franc. 
But they said the dollar was also depressed by the report of an unexpected decline of seven-tenths of 1 percent in May retail sales, which suggested economic growth was continuing to slow. Dealers said the report caused concern among currency traders that the Federal Reserve might lower interest rates, making the dollar less attractive to investors relative to other currencies.
Three more indicators to be reported this week may also affect the dollar: producer prices come out today and consumer prices and trade figures tomorrow.
The British pound continued to show strength because of high British interest rates and a growing expectation that Britain will join the European Monetary System later this year.
The pound rose to a nearly four-month high against the dollar, dealers said. It traded at $1.7070 in London, up from $1.7020 Tuesday, and at $1.7115 in New York, up from $1.7035.
In other trading, the dollar fell against the West German mark, to 1.6865 marks from 1.6965. It managed a slight gain, however, against the yen, rising to 154.75 yen in New York trading, up from 154.55 yen late Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.4240 Swiss francs, down from 1.4382; 5.6720 French francs, down from 5.7090; 1,238.00 Italian lire, down from 1,245.00, and 1.17195 Canadian dollars, down from 1.17255.

HEADLINE: White House Tutors Kremlin In How a Presidency Works

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
On his visit to Camp David this month, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev dropped German unification and Soviet political reform for a moment to quiz President Bush about the logistics of being President. How does paper flow in his office? Who decides who gets into the Oval Office? How does his staff handle Congress?
Enjoying his newfound rapport with Mr. Gorbachev, Mr. Bush responded enthusiastically, officials said, and agreed to one of the more unusual accommodations to grow out of the new superpower comity: At Mr. Gorbachev's request, John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, was detailed to tutor the Kremlin on the running of a presidency.
For two days this week, Mr. Sununu played host to an aide to Mr. Gorbachev, Mikhail S. Shkabardnya, arranging an in-depth tour of the White House's administrative operations and those of four Cabinet agencies. 
 
Moscow Trip Planned
And the White House announced today that Mr. Sununu had agreed to take the project a step further by traveling to Moscow for a firsthand look at Mr. Gorbachev's own presidential operation and to offer more advice. Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said no date had been set for that trip.
The project is remarkable both on a personal level and as a symbol of the emerging relationship between the White House and the Kremlin. No one seemed more surprised than Mr. Sununu, a staunch conservative, at the idea of shepherding a delegation of Kremlin efficiency experts through the White House, officials said.
''Even if you look at how quickly and how far we've come, it's amazing that the lines of communications are improved to a degree that we can now do such things,'' said Sig Rogich, Mr. Bush's director of events and initiatives, who also met with the Soviet officials.
 
A Schedule for Gorbachev
Mr. Sununu's class on executive staffing follows a visit late last year by Soviet legislators who went to Congress for tips on running their fledgling Parliament. The Soviet Embassy made tentative inquiries about a similar visit to the White House after the Soviet Parliament elected Mr. Gorbachev to the new post of President on March 14.
The plan for Mr. Sununu's seminar was not made final until June 2, when Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev met at Camp David. ''They began talking about the Presidency and organization and scheduling,'' an official said.
Mr. Bush showed Mr. Gorbachev his minute-by-minute schedule, the official said, and Mr. Gorbachev asked if he could study the document. ''Keep it,'' Mr. Bush replied, handing it to the Soviet leader.
''Gorbachev then said that he would like to have someone talk to Sununu about how the Presidency works as an institution,'' an aide to Mr. Sununu recalled.
''Our resident Sovietologists were impressed with how quickly they followed up,'' the aide said. He said the White House heard from Moscow on June 5, the day after Mr. Gorbachev went home, and Mr. Shkabardnya arrived on Monday.
 
'Process, Process, Process'
Mr. Shkabardnya, a Gorbachev aide previously unknown to the White House, came with five other Soviet officials. ''He's an engineer, like Sununu, so Sununu liked him,'' the aide said. ''There was no ideology, no policy, no philosophy. It was all process, process, process.''
Touring the White House, the visitors ''went from mailroom to switchboard,'' the aide said. ''But of course they didn't go to the situation room,'' the top-secret command center in the White House basement, he said.
Other than Mr. Sununu, the visitors did not meet with policy makers. Instead, their tutors were the White House officials, silent and unseen from the public perspective, who run the nuts-and-bolts operations.
James Cicconi, the staff secretary, and Joseph Hagin, the scheduling and appointments director, gave a crash course in organizing a President's day. ''They asked a lot about our system of prioritization and how things are ultimately put on the President's schedule,'' an aide said.
 
Paper Flow Studied
Ede Holiday, the Cabinet secretary, talked about how to deal with the Government departments and agencies, officials said. ''They were very interested in paper flow, what gets to the President's desk, how it is checked for quality and content,'' an aide to Mr. Sununu said.
The Soviet officials were briefed on the structure of the Cabinet councils on domestic policy and economic policy, the aide said. Using specific examples, they were shown how policy documents move through the bureaucracy to the President's desk, he said.
The Soviet visitors seemed especially interested in learning how often the President talks with his Cabinet secretaries and how the White House communicates with the agencies, officials said.
Dmitri K. Simes, a Soviet specialist with the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, noted that Mr. Gorbachev is grappling with the transformation of a Government run by the Communist Party into the more Western model of legislative and executive branches.
''I think that in terms of the mechanics of government and helping them to remove the power from the party apparatus and give it to the presidency, which is in everyone's interest, it is entirely constructive for Sununu to be doing this,'' he said.
But he said it was important for the White House to handle the situation with delicacy, given Moscow's political uncertainties. ''You want to make absolutely certain that reasonable people would not think that you are taking sides,'' he said.

HEADLINE: HIGH COURT RULES HOSPITALS CAN SUE ON MEDICAID RATES

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
In a decision likely to fuel the growing debate over how to pay for medical care for poor people, the Supreme Court ruled today that hospitals and nursing homes can sue states for higher Medicaid reimbursement rates.
The Court ruled that hospitals can go to Federal court to enforce their legal right to ''reasonable and adequate'' reimbursement for the cost of treating patients covered by the Medicaid program.
The 5-to-4 decision is likely to further strain the troubled program and put new financial pressures on state governments at a time when many are trying to control Medicaid costs, which they share with the Federal Government. [Page A15.] Less Than Adequate Care Many hospitals and nursing homes around the country say inadequate reimbursement rates have led them to transfer costs to patients with private insurance and, in some cases, to provide less than adequate care for poor people. 
Hospital administrators in Virginia who are part of an association that initiated today's case said the shortfall in Medicaid reimbursements had not forced them to turn away any indigent patients, but had in some cases hampered a hospital's ability to deliver the best possible medical treatment.
The Court upheld a ruling by a Federal appeals court in Richmond, permitting a lawsuit by a group of hospitals that contend that the state's Medicaid reimbursement rates are causing them to lose $1 million a week collectively. The state appealed to the Supreme Court, arguing that Congress had not intended to permit Medicaid providers to bring such lawsuits.
 
Case Has Yet to Go to Trial
The case, brought in 1986 by the 106-member Virginia Hospital Association, has not yet gone to trial. But similar cases have been pursued successfully by Medicaid providers in other states. Every Federal appeals court that has addressed the question has permitted the lawsuits.
Under the Constitution, states cannot be found liable for retroactive damages, so any judgments in favor of Medicaid providers must be prospective only. Nonetheless, the result of a successful lawsuit can be to force the states and the Federal Government, which finances at least half of each state's Medicaid program, to spend substantially more than they are now.
The case before the Court today concerned not the broad policy debate but a precise question of law: what Congress meant in 1980 when it amended the Medicaid law to give states more flexibility in setting reimbursement rates.
 
A More General Standard
Under the legislation establishing the Medicaid program in 1965, states were required to reimburse the reasonable costs of services that hospitals actually provided. But the Boren Amendment in 1980 allowed the states to adopt a more general standard, not tied to any hospital's actual costs. Under the amendment, the rates only had to be ''reasonable and adequate to meet the costs which must be incurred by efficiently and economically operated facilities.''
Virginia and most other states adopted plans that provided prospective payments, rather than actual reimbursement, based on what various procedures and treatments should cost. In its lawsuit the Virginia Hospital Association contended that the rates its members were receiving were not ''reasonable and adequate'' as required by the law.
The Federal District Court in Richmond and the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit agreed that the 1980 amendment gave Medicaid providers an ''enforceable right'' to a reasonable and adequate reimbursement rate.
The Supreme Court agreed today in an opinion written by Justice William J. Brennan Jr. ''We decline to adopt an interpretation of the Boren Amendment that would render it a dead letter,'' Justice Brennan said, adding, ''The only plausible interpretation of the amendment is that by requiring a state to find that its rates are reasonable and adequate, the statute imposes the concomitant obligation to adopt reasonable and adequate rates.''
 
Chief Justice in Dissent
Justice Brennan's opinion, Wilder v. Virginia Hospital Assoc., No. 88-2043, was joined by Justices Byron R. White, Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun and John Paul Stevens.
In a dissenting opinion, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist said the text of the Medicaid law ''does not clearly confer any substantive rights on Medicaid services providers.'' He said providers would perhaps be able to bring suits challenging the administrative procedure by which a state set its rates, but not to challenge the result of that procedure.
The Chief Justice said, ''To support its decision, the Court looks beyond the unambiguous terms of the statute and relies on policy considerations purportedly derived from legislative history and superseded versions of the statute.''
Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy joined the dissent.
As reflected in the tone of the dissenting opinion, the debate on the Court was only partly over the Medicaid law and had at least as much to do with the more general question of how to decide whether there is a private right to bring a lawsuit to enforce a generally worded Federal law that does not explicitly grant such a right. The Court has been debating this question for many years.

LENGTH: 1140 words

HEADLINE: After Barry, Uncertainty;
Mayor's Move Brings Painful Era to Close

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
A painful era in this Federal city's relationship to Congress and the country comes to an end with Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s decision not to run for re-election, but it is far from clear whether what follows will be a political rebirth for the troubled city or just a refocusing of complaints by its legion of critics.
The District of Columbia's political establishment voiced relief the morning after Mr. Barry's announcement, the long-awaited denouement of the political drama created when the Mayor was arrested by Federal agents last January for smoking crack under the eye of an F.B.I. camera at a downtown hotel.
After that arrest, all the city's problems - the murders, the dropouts, the infant mortality, the drug use -seemed suddenly to be embodied in this one man who 12 years ago brought whites and blacks together to elect him Mayor but then slowly lost this widespread support until only a core of firm backers was left by the time of his announcement Wednesday evening.
 
Strains With Congress
Compounding the bleak problems, symbolized by the Barry era, were the worsening political strains between local leaders and Congress, exemplified most recently by efforts from Congress to dictate to Washington about how it should spend its police budget. 
''The city was being distracted from really focusing on those problems that affect it,'' Joslyn Williams, the district's Democratic Party leader, said of Mr. Barry's legal and political troubles. ''Our relationship with Congress was at a standstill. Our enemies were using this as an excuse to really whip the city, and our friends were being put on the defensive. Now I think that excuse and impediment has been removed.''
But Mr. Barry's departure will not solve the city's underlying problems. Being mayor of any big city is a tough job. Being mayor of Washington is even more complicated. There are all the problems of poverty and crime and taxes that many American cities struggle with, and then there is the special relationship that only Washington has to Capitol Hill and the nation.
Mr. Barry had surely strained that relationship, to the point where the district was ''shunned'' by members of Congress, Democrat and Republican, who viewed the Washington government as mismanaged and corrupt, said a senior Congressional staff aide. Many have noted that Washington has one of the highest ratios of employees to residents of any city in the country, with about one employee for every 12 residents.
 
'Honeymoon' Is Expected
A new mayor will no doubt get a ''honeymoon'' with Congress, said Representative Stan Parris, a Republican from northern Virginia who is one of Washington's chief critics on Capitol Hill. To the extent that problems of mismanagement or corruption were directly the result of Mr. Barry's presence, his departure may indeed help ease the strains with Congress.
But there was considerable belief here today, in Congress and among the city's political figures, that critics of Washington had used Mr. Barry's problems as ''an excuse,'' as Mr. Williams phrased it, and that they would find new ground to criticize the district after Mr. Barry is gone.
The city, by the Constitution, is a ward of Congress. Congress has all the power to tax and spend, and the Mayor and his government are delegated these powers by Congress. It is a relationship no other mayor in the country has to deal with.
Members freguently use the city's appropriations bill as a place to fight about national issues, knowing that they can brag about it back at home without paying any political price with voters here.
This year Congress barred the district from spending money - even money it raised itself - on abortions for poor women. Some lawmakers are also hoping to reinstate the death penalty here for certain crimes.
 
Statehood Drive Stressed
The Rev Jesse Jackson said today that many members of Congress have used Mr. Barry's presence in office ''as a reason for not voting for statehood,'' which Mr. Jackson is pushing. Yet no one interviewed today thought the city was any closer to statehood than it was before Mr. Barry announced he was leaving.
Mr. Jackson said statehood was his principal interest now, as he reaffirmed that he has no plans to seek the Mayor's job. Mr. Jackson had re-emerged in recent days as the chief voice in favor of a plea bargain deal that would avoid a trial that could further damage the image of both Washington and its black political leadership.
If no deal is struck, the trial will most certainly be under way while Nelson Mandela, the South African black leader, is visiting Washington.
Mr. Barry's departure will at least give new leaders a chance to improve the city's situation. Six candidates are vying for Mr. Barry's job, and now that the Mayor has stepped off center stage, they will get a better chance to be heard.
Mr. Williams, the Democratic Party leader, said it would be several weeks before the shape of the September Democratic primary becomes clear. Mr. Barry may yet try to help either John Ray or Charlene Drew Jarvis, both members of City Council. Sharon Pratt Dixon, an officer of the local power utility, has impressed insiders with her campaigning, but has yet to make much of an impact on voters.
 
Racial Outlook Unclear
The one white candidate in the field, David A. Clarke, chairman of the City Council, has already demonstrated his ability to win black votes. But the effects of the racial strains caused by Mr. Barry's case are not yet clear.
In the days before his announcement, Mr. Barry and his allies had blamed the white prosecutors for his plight, helping to fuel an image of racial polarization here. Lost was the irony that a man first elected Mayor because he had the strongest biracial appeal was reduced in his last days of power to holding an angry and disaffected base with charges of racism.
In truth, the city's race relations are not so much polarized as separate. The city has no white working class to speak of anymore and thus does not have the stress so visible in New York, say, or Chicago, where whites fear economic competition from blacks, said Mark Plotkin, who became active in Washington politics at the same time Mr. Barry did and is now a political commentator for a local radio station, WAMU.
The one obvious political effect of Mr. Barry's decision was the blow it dealt to the Republican Party's effort to make inroads here. The party has recruited a former police chief, Maurice Turner, to run for Mayor. Against Mr. Barry, with all his legal troubles, Mr. Turner would have provided a powerful law-and-order candidacy. But none of the now likely candidates are saddled with such problems. So unless Mr. Clarke wins the nomination and a racially divided election follows, the Republican plan seems unlikely to go anywhere.

HEADLINE: Oil Cleanup Plan Aims At Protecting Refuges

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GALVESTON, Tex., June 14

 BODY:
The Coast Guard said today that the blaze aboard the stricken Norwegian tanker Mega Borg had resisted firefighting efforts, and state officials announced a strategy for coping with oil that is expected to begin washing ashore this weekend.
The plan, unveiled six days after the ship began leaking crude oil into the Gulf of Mexico, gives first priority to such sensitive areas as marshes and estuaries but offers virtually no protection to the broad, sandy beaches that are the summer playground for residents of Houston, the nation's fourth-largest city.
Buck Wynne, chairman of the Texas Water Commission, said that although he was sensitive to the economic concerns of beach communities, ''it is a whole lot easier to make people whole for their economic losses than it is to undo environmental damage.''
The Coast Guard statement and the cleanup plan announced today represent a new level of official concern about the potential of serious damage from the spill. Contrasted with earlier statements that the fire was under control and that the amount of oil likely to reach the shore was negligible, they suggest that the spill is becoming considerably more menacing. 
 
'No Way They Can Compensate'
Coast Guard officials said this afternoon that the oil, now just 20 miles off shore, seemed likely to hit this weekend on the west part of Galveston Island, an area that has prime beaches and is near a series of marshes and estuaries. In economically depressed Galveston, the state's plans were received grimly.
''There is no way they can compensate everyone who makes a living off the beach in one way or another,'' said Doug Matthews, city manager of Galveston. ''This is a city of 65,000 people, and tourism represents about one-third of our economy, more than $300 million a year. There is no way they can make up the losses if we get oil on the beaches.''
Oil spill specialists said there is no practical way to prevent oil from reaching the beaches. Booms cannot be strung in the water in front of beaches to keep oil off the sand, because the surf will disrupt them, said Jim O'Brien, owner of O'Brien Oil Pollution Services Inc., the New Orleans-based company that is overseeing the cleanup efforts. Instead, he said, debris will be cleared from beaches likely to be hit so that the sand can then be more easily cleaned.
But spill specialists said that booms and other measures can be used to limit the amount of oil reaching the marshes and estuaries, which are almost impossible to clean up once they are oiled.
 
Prime Breeding Ground
Tony Amos, an oceanographer at the University of Texas Marine Science Institute, said: ''At this time of year, the bays and marshes are the prime breeding ground for many species of birds such as egrets, spoonbills, herons, pelicans, as well as large numbers of gulls and terns. Oil pollution in that environment would have a devastating impact.''
Salvage crews have been struggling to extinguish the fires on the tanker since the ship was hit by an explosion of unknown origin around 11:30 P.M. last Friday. Fires were still burning in the pump and engine rooms, Capt. Thomas Greene, commander of the Coast Guard marine safety office here, said today.
 
As Fires Burn, Oil Leaks
The Coast Guard announced Tuesday that the fires were under control, but efforts on Wednesday to extinguish it with foam had to be suspended when the flames flared anew. Coast Guard officials said today that they still consider the fires to be under control, adding that the flames are much less intense than before.
A spokesman for K/S Mega Borg II, the Norwegian company that owns the ship, said this afternoon that the salvage and pollution control efforts so far had cost the firm $2 million.
Oil continues to pour out of the ship. Captain Greene said that from 12,000 to 48,000 gallons of oil are now in the water, heading northwest slowly in a patchy slick roughly 30 miles long and up to 10 miles wide. He said the main part of the slick is about 30 miles from shore, half the distance from the ship to the shore, and thin streamers of oil with the consistency of mousse extend another 10 miles toward shore.
Sharon Christopherson, scientific advisor to the Coast Guard station here, said this morning that the oil could reach shore as early as Friday, although it is more likely to arrive over the weekend. When it does hit land, she said, it will be in the form of gooey tar balls that can stick together to form large globs.
 
Bacteria Test Today
Meanwhile, Garry Mauro, the Texas Land Commissioner, announced today that the state would apply naturally occurring bacteria on a part of the slick to determine whether the bacteria can help break up an oil slick at sea. The bacteria, contained in a corn starch powder, has been used in cleanups on land but not at sea.
 
Best Beaches Likely Target
A spokesman for K/S Mega Borg II, the Norwegian company that owns the ship, said this afternoon that the salvage and pollution control efforts so far had cost the firm $2 million.
The beaches likely to be hit by the oil are on barrier islands that stretch along the coast. Between the island are passes that lead to the intercoastal marshes and estuaries.
Captain Greene said this afternoon that although winds and currents are highly variable it seemed most likely that the oil would come ashore this weekend on the West End of Galveston Island. The most attractive beaches on the island are on the West End, and hundreds of weekend and vacation homes have been built behind the dunes there. Off the western tip of the island is San Luis Pass, which leads to a large network of marshes and estuaries.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Protectors Of Industry Hard Up For Battles

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
For all the talk of the ris= ing tide of American protectionism, one of the few precise markers available, the caseload of the International Trade Commission, seems to show that the storm surge has passed.
Under trade laws that go back a century, the six commissioners of the I.T.C. adjudicate trade disputes between domestic industries that want higher tariffs put on foreign imports and foreign suppliers who want unimpeded access to American markets.
The agency's 1990 budget, $40 million, is twice what it was a decade ago. But, try as it may, the agency won't be able to spend all the money that Congress appropriated for it this year, said Anne E. Brunsdale, the commission's chairwoman. 
This year, the commissioners will have before them only a third the number of petitions they received in 1982 from domestic industries alleging instances of unfair competition from imports being subsidized by foreign governments or sold below cost, said Ms. Brunsdale. (A finding by the commission that a domestic industry has been ''materially'' injured is a green light to the Commerce Department to order higher duties on the import.) Because it exists to serve home state or hometown interests, the agency is a favorite of Capitol Hill. And many of its friends there are puzzled by the declining caseload.
''You might say this reflects the law of unintended results, since we've been trying for years to make it easier for industries to go to the I.T.C.,'' mused Representative Sam Gibbons, a Florida Democrat who is chairman of the House trade subcommittee.
Has the agency been done in by its own efficiency, having so successfully laid the ground for protection that there is not much new demand? Or are there other factors at work? The answers, most analysts say, are yes and yes.
In a study for the Institute for International Economics, a policy group here, Gary C. Hufbauer, professor of international finance at Georgetown University, found that by the end of the Reagan Administration, about 22 percent of the $500 billion a year the United States spends on imports was already covered by some form of protection. The figure for 1980 was 12 percent. The 10-point difference, he says, is costing consumers $80 billion a year.
Most bigger industries have been taken care of. Imports of steel, autos, machine tools, textiles, apparel, semiconductors, softwood lumber and myriad other products are subject to quotas, high tariffs, or so-called voluntary restraint agreements in which exporters, like Japanese car makers, impose restrictions on themselves to avoid more drastic curbs.
Another factor is that since the economy has been enjoying unbroken growth since the 1981-82 recession, domestic industry is having an increasingly hard time demonstrating injury. The clearest demonstration, after all, is to show a deteriorating profit and loss statement and a weak balance sheet. And in these fairly good times, many companies, even those with import competition, show rising profits and strong balance sheets.
Still another influence is the dollar. Exchange rates have changed since the dollar reached its highs in 1985. With American currency more competitive around the world, American exports are setting records.
But any look at the trade commissiion is a look at only part of the trade story. The commission deals with imports to the United States. And today, Congress and the White House are concentrating on barriers to American exports abroad. Under the so-called Super 301 Section of the 1988 trade law, President Bush has threatened to curb imports from Japan, South Korea, the European Community and other countries that exclude American exports.
So far, the big stick seems to be working. The United States recently signed agreements with Japan opening up markets in telecommunications, supercomputers, satellites and wood products. Countries acting to avoid American import sanctions include South Korea, which has opened its beef markets, and Taiwan, which is cracking down on counterfeiters of American jeans and other products.
Where does this leave the I.T.C.? ''The complainers will be back again - just give us a recession,'' said C. Michael Aho, a foreign trade specialist at the Council on Foreign Relations. ''Trade policy is loser-driven.''
