HEADLINE: Ruling Likely to Increase Strains on Medicaid

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
The nation's already troubled health care program for the poor is likely to face new financial strains because of the Supreme Court's decision today holding that hospitals and nursing homes have a judicially enforceable right to ''reasonable and adequate'' payment under Medicaid.
Medicaid, the primary source of health care for 24 million low-income people, is under siege in many states, with local officials trying to hold down costs even as the Federal Government requires more services.
At the same time, hospitals and nursing homes complain bitterly that they have been underpaid by Medicaid programs in many states, so that patients sometimes receive inadequate care.
 
A Flood of Lawsuits Forecast
By giving hospitals and nursing homes the right to sue for increased Medicaid payments, the court ruling may compound the problems. Poor people may benefit if hospitals and nursing homes succeed in getting more money for care provided under Medicaid. But increased payments could worsen the fiscal problems of many state governments. Over all, states pay 43 percent of Medicaid costs, but the proportion varies from state. 
Today's decision opens the way to dozens of lawsuits affecting millions of dollars in Federal and state funds.
''If states continue to underfund Medicaid, there definitely will be more lawsuits brought by health care providers,'' said Fredric J. Entin, senior vice president and general counsel of the American Hospital Association, which represents 5,500 hospitals.
The High Court decision does not guarantee that hospitals and nursing homes will prevail in such litigation, but it emphatically affirms their right to sue. Health care executives, state officials and lawyers predicted that, as a result, states would be much more careful, and somewhat more generous, in setting Medicaid rates for hospitals and nursing homes.
Many health economists say that hospitals have tried to offset their financial losses on Medicaid patients by increasing charges for more affluent patients, who have private health insurance or use their own money to pay hospital bills. If today's decision leads eventually to a change in that practice, it could indirectly benefit middle-income families. But such families might have to pay higher Federal or state taxes to help finance Medicaid.
Eugene Tillman, a Washington lawyer who specializes in health care issues, said that hospitals and nursing homes had an obvious, direct financial interest in assuring adequate Medicaid payment, because ''they are businesses and need to survive.''
At the same time, he said, ''if these cases result in rational state decision-making and more adequate funds to carry out Federal mandates, the ultimate beneficiaries will be the Medicaid recipients.''
Mr. Tillman helped write a legal brief filed with the Supreme Court on behalf of the American Health Care Association, which represents nursing homes, and the American Hospital Association.
 
What Medicaid Costs
Medicaid rates are set by the states, which share the costs with the Federal Government and the states. The program cost $61.3 billion in the last fiscal year. Washington paid $34.6 billion, while states spent $26.7 billion. Total program costs have increased an average of 10 percent a year over the last five years.
Medicaid accounts for 10 percent of the gross revenues of hospitals and 43 percent of the total receipts of nursing homes.
The Supreme Court decision comes just 15 weeks before the effective date of a major 1987 law, under which nursing homes will be required to meet strict new Federal standards for safety, sanitation, nursing staff and social services.
California and some other states say they do not have the money to increase Medicaid rates to cover the costs that nursing homes will incur if they comply. Today's decision gives the nursing homes a potent tool to squeeze more money out of the Medicaid program.
Carter G. Phillips, a lawyer who advised the American Health Care Association, said states would now have to re-examine the techniques used to set Medicaid rates.
Benna Ruth Solomon, chief counsel of the State and Local Legal Center, which represents the interests of the nation's governors, said: ''We are very disappointed by today's decision. It could eventually cost states a lot of money.'' She said it was impossible to estimate the cost because no one had measured the gap between Medicaid rates and the amount that would be deemed ''reasonable and adequate.''

HEADLINE: Marion Barry's Good Years, and Bad

 BODY:
The announcement by Marion Barry that he will not seek a fourth term as Mayor of Washington D.C. comes as a relief to a city beset by drugs and by the strong suspicion that Mr. Barry himself may be a drug abuser. Now both the Mayor and the nation's capital can get on with recovery.
Mr. Barry's remarkable career makes his ignominious demise even sadder. The son of Mississippi sharecroppers, he jumped into the civil rights movement in the early 1960's and was the first national chairman of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee. He became active in Washington politics and took office as Mayor in 1979. 
Though hampered by laws that give Washington only limited control over its municipal affairs, Mr. Barry generated economic development projects and tended to neglected social ills. He was a source of particular pride for poor blacks and a symbol of growing black political power.
But the shining accomplishments were clouded. Several subordinates were charged with corruption and fraud. Rumors circulated of drug use by Mr. Barry. In 1988, the growth of drugs and drug-related violence made Washington the murder capital of the nation. Other problems mounted, like prison overcrowding, homelessness and a budget that is $90 million out of balance.
In January the Mayor allegedly smoked crack cocaine with a friend at a downtown Washington hotel. The encounter was videotaped in a joint sting operation of the F.B.I. and the District's police department. It formed the basis of drug possession and perjury charges that will be heard in Mr. Barry's Federal trial, which began this week. Whether or not he negotiates a plea bargain, his troubles made it impossible for him to deal with those of his city.
In his announcement, Mr. Barry declared that ''a time for healing'' had arrived. His departure from center stage allows that process to begin.
